number of helpful: 39 of 50 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 19, 2014
												Edit: The expansion is out. I don't like it. All the problems of the base game havent been fixed and therefore cannot recommend. It also managed to be released with bugs and worse balance thant the base game.Edit: Even after 2 patchs the game is still shallow. Patches are very slow to come, some easily fixable issues aren't fixed and the patches have brought their lot of bugs and poorly thought changes.Not recommended.I have played around 80 hours of this game and after playing multiple times on max difficulty (Apollo), I can safely say that I would not recommend the game in its current state. I've finally managed to break my personal record with a turn 145 standard speed victory with Harmony due to the massive amount of oversights the game has.Right now a ton of features are imbalanced or broken which is very problematic in a strategy game. Let's list them here:-Trade routes are either too numerous, too strong or both. The ability to spam cities just to increase trade route that will imediately pay for themselves is fundamentaly broken. Their strength belittle a lot of other mechanics making them the only real strategic purpose.-The mechanic supposed to slow expansion doesn't work and is ineffective (health). The panalities for expanding are laughable in comparison to the benefits. The system to get health is anyway badly designed as this is a global ressource mostly acquired through local bonuses... this makes it very hard to get positive without investing virtues. But at the same time it's very easy to stay positive since you can spam local health until you reach each city threshold.-The main strategy due to those two previous points is to just spam cities and trade routes. But trade route interface is horrible making the only relevant strategy a hassle to play.-The UI is worse that the previous game. For no reason. The scales are wrong, colors are terrible and the iconic way of representing buildings units and technologies is lazy. It's very hard to know at a glance what an icon represents. It's a shame considering the wonderful art design of Civ 5.-The terrain tiles are very hard to distinguish at a glance from one another, especially in fungal maps. You can activate Tile Yields or play with a mod to help for this though.-The 3 affinities were presented as 3 very different objectives but they are basically all a form of a science victory. Just get the required techs, build the wonder, wait and win. Exit, culture victory, diplomatic victory. Now you have Domination, 3 science victories and Contact is basically a luck victory if you find the right artifacts....-The game is incredulously easy to beat even on the hardest difficulty. The AI is pathetic, not agressive enough and still awful at fighting wars.-The spy system that was advertised as deeper than civ5 is weak. It takes way too long to use the additional options from spies unless you use an exploit. And even it's not very interesting.-Favors, advertised as a way to manipulate AI ended up falling flat. It's only purpose is to exploit the AI to get many loans of gold.-A quest system is in the game but some quests are bugged and many decisions in them are just stupid bonuses that never feel like a choice due to the terrible balance of the options.-No civilization leaders, lack of soul. No leader introductions with voiceovers, barely any context.There are some stuff I like:-Combat animations and unit models-Outpost mechanics-Artifacts-The tech tree and virtue treeBut that is it. And sadly the rest make it an unworthy challenge for any strategy fan.It's really with astonishing wonder that they got so much stuff wrong after 5 years of civ5. A game that was heavily copied to get this one.If you have never played Civilization 5, please buy Civilization 5 Complete instead of Civ:BE. It's a way more interesting product. It has some issues but you will find a lot more appealing than this one. If youre a fan of Civ5 but are a little bored this may entertain you for 50hours or so but be warned.This review was made with v1.0 Maybe some patches will fix some of my issues... maybe.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
												Not recommended for anyone who still remembers and loves Alpha Centauri. This game simply lacks the charm of extraterrestrial exploration. It's not easy to pinpoint what, exactly, is wrong with it: maybe it's the lack of AC's narrative elements that popped up after each significant achievement of your faction. Maybe it's because we have nations again instead of factions. Or perhaps it's because the aliens are not menacing at all - once you've researched some basic upgrades, you can steamroll over anything but sea giants, and those are pretty passive. So BE basically boils to good old faction vs. faction warfare.Plus, compared to AC, this game is very simplistic. Domestic policies with special bonuses and drawbacks? Not anymore! Because all players love Civ5 culture advancements that are strictly positive and boil down to "+5% to military unit strength", right? Of course, option to design your own units is also gone, as well as psi-combat. Everything is as simplified as possible.And the most baffling design decision of all involves affinities: they are not mutually exclusive! So you can be a human purist who aspires to become a half-alien hybrid while modding himself with cybernetic augmentations to high heavens. And of course, descriptions (for example, in diplomacy screens) never acknowledge how ridiculous this monstrosity is. Nice work, Firaxis.

												I had high hopes for this game and was really looking forward to seeing what next Civilization would bring us.  While some parts of the game were great and loved a few of the new mechanics the game is incomplete.  This feels similiar to what they did with Civilization V; releasing a game but leaving out some many of the mechanics that would make the game complete.  Simply put Beyond Earth is only 1/2 (or maybe 1/3) of the game it was meant to be.  What I worry is that Sid Meier's is going to put out DLC to fill out the game.  I have played better Civ V mods that did a better job of incorperating and making  changes to the base game.   It would be better to just wait for all of their DLCs to come out and then wait to the whole package goes on sale for 75% off.  Don't give Sid Meier any more money for an unfinished product.

content:
Posted: November 12, 2014
												Experience the spiritual successor to Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri, which despite 15 years of technological advancement decides to remove pretty much most of the features that made the 1999 original so amazing, and hopes we'll shut our eyes to it because this game has GRAAAPHIIICS. Speaking of graphics, experience the sequel to Sid Meier's Civilization V, which despite 4 years more technolocially advanced than it's predecessor has very few noticeable graphical improvements to it's predecessor and a completely dumbed down UI. It also throws away pretty much most of the good features of Civ 5 making this completely new game more bland than the vanilla Civ 5. In short, this is is an incomplete game, which has barely enough balanced features to make it playable, and "expansion packs" or DLC will likely be released soon to "complete it" even though it was discovered that some of the missing features are within the games code, simply locked for now (until maybe a DLC will unlock it). I had high hopes of this game and rode the hype train and was ultimately disappointed. Do yourself a favor and stay away and stay away or get Civ 5 (or any previous Civ), which is pretty much the same game but much better.

Posted: November 13, 2014
												The game is timid in every way.  The design is so hide-bound in appealing to everyone that it feels like it has pitiful appeal to anyone.The science is weak, the extremities of the various affinities is even weaker and each feels completely without any character whatsoever.  They're visually less interesting than Civ V leaders and lacking the depth and personality of Alpha Centauri leaders.The lack of wonder or end-game cinematics is disappointing, the aliens are largely reskins of models that the player can get with no interesting mechanics whatsoever.  They're boring and less intimidating than early barbarians in standard Civ games and offer far less alien intensity than Alpha Centauri.This game is poor when viewed as a sequel to Civ V AND when viewed as an inheritor to Alpha Centauri.  A fail on both counts is impressive.The quests are a moderately interesting idea but still provide almost no sense of ownership.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												The Good:  You have not bought this game yet and can make an informed decision. The Bad:  While this game does have a few very minor improvements over Civ 5, it is also missing a lot of things from Civ 5.  For example, the virtue system is a bit better than the Civ 5 civic choices, but instead of city states, you get stations which are only good for trading with.   The enemy AIs have no personality.  This is NOT a remake of Alpha Centari, not by a long strech.  At best this is nothing more than a mod for Civ 5.  The AI is just as dumb and the diplomatic AI makes no sense whatsoever.  You might as well not even have diplomacy.  The Ugly:  If there was an Alpha Centari mod for Civ 5, it would be a better game in almost every other way.  If you like games like Civilization and do not own Civ 5, then buy it with all the DLC for less money than this game with no DLC.  You will get a much better game.  I sure hope they fix this game and make it good, but as it stands in its current state (I am not talking about bugs, but game design), its garbage.  CIv 5 is a better game in every way.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												"Beyond Earth" is not at all a bad game. I enjoyed my time with it so far, and I believe it's a solid addition to the 4x genre.Yet, it has drawn a lot of criticism from gamers. I think the main "problem" of Beyond Earth is that it carries the legacy of not only one, but _two_ immensely popular games (Alpha Centauri, and Civ 5), and it cannot really pull ahead of either of those.BE borrows most of its mechanics directly from Civ 5. They just got renamed - "happiness" became "health", "gold" became "energy", etc. Most mechanics of the Civ 5 expansions were not included in BE, which is a problem for many Civ 5 players, who tend to think that the expansions were what made Civ 5 enjoyable. BE does try to add some new things: The tech web allows very flexible research strategies. The victory conditions are new ideas, fit the setting, and are mechanically solid. The "orbital layer" adds tactical depth (but seems underused). So the innovation _is_ there, but only in some details, so veteran Civ 5 players will still get the feeling that they "lost" the Civ 5 expansion content and are basically playing an elaborate mod of the Civ 5 base game.BE borrows most of its _setting_ from its spiritual predecessor, Alpha Centauri. It can't use the exact same setting due to legal issues, but the parallels are obvious. Unfortunately, the setting is BE's weakest point. Where Alpha Centauri featured interesting characters, an overarching story of the planet's exploration, and a clash of ideologies that permeated every fiber of the game (down to leaders providing voiceovers with ideologically colored, well written comments about researched technologies), BE feels surprisingly bland in that regard. It feels as if the devs didn't even try to flesh out the setting, but just took some civs from Civ 5 and reskinned the leaders. Coincidentally, there is currently another 4x game on the market (Endless Legend) which has its strengths exactly in the lore and atmosphere aspects, which makes BE's shortcomings in that regard all the more obvious.Unfortunately, BE also fails to correct that one major flaw of "Alpha Centauri" - the weak AI. The game sticks to the "one unit per tile" paradigm from Civ5, and the AI still can't handle it. The AI is incapable of positioning its forces efficiently, it doesn't read the terrain well, and it still cannot plan ahead simple movements. I've seen units being sent into certain death because the pathfinding insisted to send them through miasma tiles when other options were available. I've seen the same unit going back and forth a dozen times when I simply opened or blocked a passage. I've seen AI units sitting uselessly on the same spot for ages. I've seen the AI sacrificing a dozen planes to my interceptors instead of using the "sweep" mission just once. I've seen an AI from another continent first sending a colonist to mine, then settling there without sending any units, and then (after I conquered the outpost) asking for peace and offering me one third of their empire: a full-fledged city on their continent, that I hadn't even discovered yet, so I posed no threat to that AI whatsoever.That said, if you strip away the legacy of Civ 5 and Alpha Centauri, then BE is quite a decent game. It still has complex gameplay (just don't focus on what was "lost" compared to the other games), it still has an interesting setting (just don't focus on how SMAC's setting was much more enticing), it does bring interesting new things to the table. It _is_ very enjoyable as a 4x game, the mechanics are solid, and it's not as bug-ridden as new 4x games tend to be.Since the game itself seems decent, BE's "not being able to escape its legacy" issue would probably not be much of a problem _if_ the game were priced accordingly, at perhaps 30€. With an initial price tag of 50€, though, I think people started focusing on what BE is not, instead of appreciating what it is. Coincidentally, it's on sale for 30€ now, and I believe that it's worth that. It would probably have received a much warmer welcome if it had been offered for that price from the start.

												Civ 5 is pretty much my favorite game,beyond earth is another story.Here are just a few rants I come up with:1)The whole landscape looks freaking gloomy and ugly;2) tons of bugs,we all saw the explorer-jogging-forever glitch in those preview builds,they say they are going to fix it,well,NO THEY DIDN'T.While all the bugs they did not fix in civ 5,obviously still exists;3)Extremely imbalanced gameplay,Apollo(highest difficulty) is a cakewalk,no improvements on AI whatsoever;but the most game breaking of all are the internal trade routes,way too powerful;4)Where are the demographics screen?!!City list?!And global politics screen doesn't even tell you which factions are at war with each other?!If you want to reskin the entire Civ 5,at very least keep all those good stuff,do we have to buy some"Info pack DLC" in the future?Not surprised if they do release it.5)I understand there will be more factions coming in DLC's,but 8 factions only?!That's just pathetic.6)Each city can have up to 3 trade routes,each trade route must be manually reassigned every 20 turns,so if you have more than 30 cities in the late game and want to find the best trade route among a long list of cities...enjoy!(unlike in civ 5,there is no "sort by highest gold" option)7)Almost forgot to mention,they did not even make a single scenario;Overall,this game is,as everyone said,a reskin of civ 5,but feels extremely rushed and missing so much stuff,just like civ 5 back upon release,I do have faith in Firaxis coming up with great DLCs,but at this state I cannot say this game worth the price.

number of helpful: 178 of 288 people (62%) found this review helpful32 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												I remember a news feature on a guy who has been playing a game of Civilization 2 for the past ten years. The world had been reduced to three factions, each in perpetual war and every single turn over a hundred nuclear devices would be produced and detonated. The game was a total stalemate and the planet had been reduced to an uninahibtable ball of dirt.Beyond Earth proposes the outcome of the end of the world. Beyond Earth picks up right where the science victory (or the nuclear holocaust) has left the planet. The world has suffered a horrible man-made calamity and now the people flee to the stars in order to find a new home. You take control of a sponsored faction. Make planetfall on a planet with an above average sustainability and you begin to colonise. Beyond Earth essentially is just Civ 5 with a very elaborate reskin, but there is more to it than that. The standard Civ games retell the journey of mankind through the ages. Beyond earth explored the unknown; the final frontier, and with it come some new considerations. For instance, your faction will need to make decisions regarding the local wildlife, refugees from less fotunate factions and most importantly: the local wildlife. Unlike earth, where the occasional barbarian would kidnap your workers, the planet pays host to a remarable menagerie of extra terrestial horrors. From the small wolf beetle to the awe inspiring siege worms; your military's first task will be to control the monsters, before you seek to undo your fellow humans. Because you're in the future now you'll no longer be inventing things like the wheel or dynamite. We're taking gene splicing and nano technology here. The tech tree has been refurbished into the tech web. Your choice for military R&D might eventually lead you away from sustainability or prosperity or vice versa. You can choose your own technological agenda. Eventually, you'll have to decide how the human race will proceed. The game introduces an affinity system. You can pursue Purity, Supremacy or Harmony. Each affinity brings its own boons. As purist, you'll maintain humanity the Warhammer way; by shunning any and all foreign and alien influences to your technology or biology. It paves the way for incredible weapons and amazingly polarised world views. Supremacists fuse their bodies and minds with machines. The result is an efficient human race that seeks to remove any and all inefficiencies. Even if that means getting rid of biological components all together. Harmonists seek to use the new world and its bounties to their adavantage and eventually evolve to be at home in the hostile world. Each affinity comes with its own special victory. The purists claim the new world as their own, while the supremasists travel to earth to upgrade the people there. The harmonists transcend humanity as collective hivemind with the planet itself. Each victory requires a vastly different approach to resource and tech management, as well the application of your forces. The supremacists need to sacrifice their troops to subjugate the population on earth, while harmonists will want to keep their assets close to defend their cities before transcendence is achieved. Naturally, you can still just destroy all your enemies like back in the olden days with military might. Or you can go for a more peaceful solution and attempt to make first contact. The new world is open to any and all options. The whole newness is what makes this game so different then. It still works the same; turn based, resources, explore, dumb AI who can't value a deal. However, everything is new and looks differently. It is really hard to come to terms with unknown and in the first few games you play you'll be wondering if you're doing it right. In fact, even after a few turns you're wondering why the AI has such a great health record and why your cities are dying from disease and malnourishment. The game also lost a tick in its pace. Somehow it feels slower. Between the many new technologies, you won't notice much of a change until you reach a certain level of affinity. It makes your actions seem useless and it kind of ruins the game as it slips into its fourth quarter. The late game units are a blast to use when you can, simply because of their insane proportions, but it takes too long to get them, and you won't have much time to use them. All in all, Beyond Earth is very familliar, but at the same time so outlandish and new that you'll feel like you're exploring new worlds. It's a nice change of pace when you're fed up with racing to build pyramids and stonehenge. The aliens allow for a more active use of your military than in regular Civ and that is a nice step up. However, the crash in pace might turn some people away. If you like Civ and sci fi, then this is certainly for you.

content:
Posted: October 18, 2016
Have you tried Civ5? You haven't? Try and then come back!Firstly, To those who haven't played Civilization V I recommend to go back and play that instead, and then come back here. When you've had enough of Civ5 then comes time for this expansion standalone game called Beyond Earth. Still it's a really nice expansion of the basic game, pretty enjoyable, so why all that negativity? Maybe the reason is that Beyond Earth still feels more like Mode or DLC for Civ5 not overcharged standalone that it is. Nevertheless if we put this fact aside and focus on the gameplay and other aspects of the game, Beyond Erth together with its major expansion Rising Tide still can be an amazing piece which can offer dozens of hours of fun. Pros✪ Virtues and personal traits - Cultural and political development as in previous titles is nice, simple and gently improves the gameplay.✪ Victories - New possibilities of how to win enhanced with more than just "build and win" (some of them)✪ Affinities - You can choose, depending on your gamestyle, which path you will go down. Purity, supremacy or harmony. Progress is made through technologies you research, quests you complete and decisions you make during the game.  ✪ Unit upgrades - Unit improves and changes their appearance depending on affinities you chose. ✪ Quests and decisions Neutral✪ TechTree - it's nice loooking on some different "exotic" kind of techtree (techWeb here) than we are accustomed to. Nevertheless it feels like most of the tech is useless when you get some first esencials. In later stages of the game I clicked on anything just to have some research progress though not needing any. Cons✪ AI is immensely stupid and not balanced. Increasing difficulty feels only like AI has many factors favouring his civilization, but the same playstyle. If you attack even the strongest AI early in the game, it can be extremely weakened and won't be able to compete with you afterwards.✪ No scenery, No campaign, just skirmish.✪ There is not much of a difference between civilizations you choose to play as. The only differences are colour on the map, leader appearence and one minor almost not recognizable benefit.✪ There are no leaderboards, no history and no record on anything when you finish the game. I just want to know info about what every player focused on and what every competing civilization did the whole game. 6.5 /10 The game is fun and enjoyable overall, but I do not feel like it has much progress next to the previous titles. I recommend only those who played properly Civ5 and are looking for something familiar.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												Beyond Earth is not a huge departure from its predecessor, Civilization V. Now that we've got that out of the way, I think your impression of this game might depend largely on your expectations. If you're expecting something revolutionary and different then you might want to wait for this one to go on sale so it's comparably priced to a DLC or an expansion and continue to patiently wait for Civilization VI, which Beyond Earth is not.  If you want a solid 4x game with great graphics, a gorgeous color palette, beautiful map terrain and cool resources, immersive music, an interesting premise, and chock full of sci-fi references, then you'll probably enjoy this. I can't stop playing it, I just want to test out all the new victory types and see what all the units look like after upgrades attached to each of game's the three affinities. Even though much of the game -- from the UI to the AI -- feels familiar, there's enough that's fresh that you have to pay attention to the details. And I keep finding myself pleasantly surprised by the new stuff I discover. And sometimes I find myself familiarly irritated by some of the things that have plagued most incarnations of Civilization games, like repetitive AI that offers insanely lopsided trade "deals" and then launches an attack a turn after telling you how awesome you are.I really like the addition of quests to the game, even though sometimes it's difficult or even impossible to complete some of the tasks (also wow fragile explorers). Once you accept that though, the tasks you can do become a nice little addition to the game and a way to earn extra bonuses while you're playing.On the down side, the end-game tends to drag a bit, and some of the victory conditions have "false summits" in which you think you are almost there but then find out that you have to have to jump through hoops for another 50 turns in order to actually win.I wish there were some more statistical and information options for those of us who like to really delve deeply in our strategy games and think things through completely before committing to a path. I also wish there were more incentives to cooperate with the other colonies, like science and economic boosts for signing cooperation agreements. I'd have liked more emphasis on science, perhaps via the ability to enter into research agreements through diplomacy or the ability to trade techs like in earlier Civ games.Overall, I'd say that the fact that I played the game for over 40 hours in less than a week speaks to its value, at least in my eyes. It's not perfect, but it's a lot of fun and it definitely has that "one more turn" factor that makes it a solid addition to the Civ family.

number of helpful: 115 of 182 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												 It is evident, after spending 18.7 hours with the game, that Civ Beyond Earth was shoved out the door way too early. Don't really understand why, when Civ fanbase is the most patient fanbase I know.  The most egregious example, is the lack of support of HDTV's, or the now infamous "120 Hz resolution problems", a problem that doesn't and didn't exist for ANY other Firaxis product. My review in just one sentence : The game had a lot of potential and it is evident that developpers had ambitious goals with the title, but when playing the final product, one can't help but feel as if large parts of the game  got hacked out or never finished. I'll elaborate on that : For example, there are a lot of technologies and it is fun to explore them, but some technologies only offer one building and an affinity boost and nothing else. It feels  as if a part of the team did their job and the other didn't. Also, speaking of technologies, the "Tech web" or technology tree is non-intuitive and is nearly impossible to spot out wonders (unless you look closely at the cost of the building). As other reviewers have pointed out, there is a severe lack of polish (again, this adds to the feeling that BE was rushed) with very few voice over work, lackluster wonders, boring Diplomacy interface and lackluster victory screens.  Also, it seems that some mechanics were rushed (the favor and intrigue mechanic) and didn't reach their full or intended potential. The "favor" mechanic for example, is basically a new currency when trading with an AI. It should help you force trades that would otherwise be impossible or very expensive, but in the end, a favor point basically amounts to about 50 energy. That's it.  I hope future patches or expansion packs will help Beyond Earth reach its full potential, but everyone that has pre-ordered the game, like me, are left dissapointed and most of all frustrated that this game wasn't given more attention/money. DON'T BUY, wait for a better game and get the (inevitable) GOTY/definitive edition or whatever... and NEVER preorder.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
IntroFIrst off, I'm a long time Civ fan, and turn-based strategy may be my favourite genre. I was NOT as big of a fan of Alpha Centauri as many of the other games, but I was really excited nontheless. TL:DR: I went back and forth multiple times on whether or not to give this a positive. If you're a fan of the series, buy it, you'll have fun, but be a little disappointed. On the other hand, some newcomers to turn-based might be able to stomach this.ObservationsFirst thing you'll notice when you download this game is the size - only 2-something gigabytes. That will be nice for those without a solid internet connection.Unfortunately, that size hints at one of the biggest problems I have with this game.  There seems to be a general lack of quality artwork. Dating back to Civ 2 (my first, which I played when I was 9) I loved the animations, music, and artwork associated with technologies, wonders, and ultimately, victory. (Probably a bigger deal as a kid) Games back then made up for the inability to create kickass graphics with awesome animations, graphics, and audio as rewards along the way. Age of Empires 1 was the same way.Nowadays, the work goes into nice 3d gameplay, but the artwork, lore, and music just aren't there. The older Civ games put tons of time into writing beautiful descriptions and background for each technology and game concept. In BE, it's mostly short blurbs. Technology has no real artwork.Wonders are even worse, only having some vague blueprint thing and short clip of text. I have no idea what I built most of the time, and the bonuses are spotty and generally uninspiring.Victories are similarly lacking in artwork. The glorious travel to Alpha Centauri featured in all the other Civ installments is replaced by a quote and kind of crappy artwork. This is especially sad since the authors had so much potential to work with. Some compelling storylines with clear conclusions would have also been nice.PositivesThe world itself is beautiful, done much better than Alpha Centauri in my opinion. It was a joy to play in. Units are designed well, and it is bright. Alpha Centauri's interface was always a little dark for me.Tutorial system - Yeah yeah, a little annoying at times, but I thought the click-through tutorials that pop up were really well done, and might help casual gamers get past the initial curve.Unit progression - I like that units aren't just obsoleted, but that they are carried through the game and automatically upgraded. The unit experience system is MUCH better in BE; they split out the experience system from V and made the more impactful decisions globalTech Tree - The tech tree in Beyond Earth is less linear than any that I've seen, and it gives a lot of freedom for advancement. My strategy is usually to go balls-to-the-wall science, and get an age up on my competitors in order to blow them away with modern technology. Not so straightforward this time around, and I like that.Civilization concept - Instead of civilizations with their own bonuses, the player chooses their 'race' based on the technology choices they make, and gain unique units as a result. I think I like it, but at the same time, it was an easy way for them to get out of making a lot of quality art. Reminded me of Planetside 2.Intrigue  - I  liked the diplomacy concept. Stealing tech is actually pretty useful. I wish it would show the tech popup when I discover a technology by stealing it though.More NegativesThe diplomacy was lame, characters were downright uninspiring. I never got offers for anything other than 'favors' from the AIThe trade system has some cool concepts, but my biggest gripe is that it seems WAY overpowered. Close to the end of the game, I could build a settlement literally anywhere and have it capable of building almost any unit in a couple turns. There was also never a good reason for me to trade with one of the outposts or another civilization. When I play $50+ for a game, I expect replay value. One way that the older civs achieved this was with a high-score system that would berate you for how crappy you were. I miss that. No such mechanic here. Tell me how bad I am!This probably won't affect most of you, but as someone who has been gaming with Eyefinity (3 monitor setup) for the last few years, I'm getting really tired of companies calling a game 'Eyefinity approved' and slapping an AMD logo on it when in reality they have done nothing of the sort. It plays fine with Eyefinity (and I imagine nVidia Surround) but the interfaces are on the far left and right. So I'm always looking back and forth. It would have been SO easy for them to allow the UI to be centered on the middle display.ConclusionOverall, I enjoyed it, but I'm not about to go play another game right now. I would recommend that you all buy it when it comes around for $10 this summer, then give it a play-through.

number of helpful: 291 of 484 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 23, 2014
												Civilization: Beyond Earth will look and feel familiar to Civ V players, but this is not simply a sci-fi remake of Civ V. The game is far more tactical, which will please long-time strategy game players. The alien worlds are gorgeously detailed and provide new challenges to players. The integrated quest system serves to highten your game experience by giving you opportunities to mould your civilisation beyond the endless build, expand, build gameplay of previous Civilization entries, thereby allowing a great deal of customisation. Alien life is complex enough to be pleasing and genuinely terrifying if you don't keep an eye on alien nests.Diplomatic functions are exactly the same as Civ V's, which is not a surprise given that BE is built on the same engine - there are some expanded functions but nothing inherently noteworthy. Future expansions might play with diplomacy a bit but for now, if you've played Civ V, you know exactly how to run the diplomatic system.The Virtue system works incredibly well. Gone are the nine policy trees - you now have four, called Virtues, but they are divided into three tiers, and completing each tier gives you significant bonuses. This allows the game to acheive a far more interesting level of complexity than Civ V's policies. You can choose to max out a Virtue tree, or mix it up a bit depending on needs. Each tree is as viable as one another, so gone are the days of maxing Patronage to secure an easy win.The technology web, so highly touted by Firaxis, is implemented well. Each technology has high strategic value, and Firaxis did well to incorporate Harmony, Supremacy and Purity points throughout the tree. You don't need to research everything, and in fact can research any branch at any time - no need to wait forever for that one technology that will confer that bonus you've wanted since turn one. There are some slight graphical issues, but those will be fixed in an upcoming patch. Tiles can and will flicker occassionally, which gets annoying, and the only way to fix it is to save and reload the game. It's not a huge deal though - the rest of the game is beautifully polished.Don't be surprised if this is the AAA game of the year. 10/10.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2015
												This game continues to fail to work.It can be casually enjoyed  as a 4X  because there are no showstopper bugs.  I don't know why I would recommend any game for that purpose, though.Technical problems:Trade routes have an arbitrary and obscure value determination.  Trade routes are still clunky to renew.  Trade routes received a total redesign after complaints of absolute imbalance ....  resulting in their being arbitrary and strange, and will continue to spiral into weirdness without some solid sense of what they're supposed to even be.The affinity quest bug persists.Unit combat is fundamentally imbalanced.Wonders do not even do anything.  This is not hyperbole - they literally do not function.Titanium is imba.Miasma continues to defy the interface, forbidding intuitive options like "wake when miasma starts killing this unit."Aesthetic problems:You don't love the planet, you don't love the leaders.  You don't even love your own civ.  You cannot care less about what's going on.  The alien taming is a novelty, not enjoyable.Health dominates the entirety of the virtues decision tree, strategically speaking.  There is nothing but Prosperity into Colonist into health virtues.If you want to roleplay.... roleplay with what?  The leaders aren't psychotic (as much)... but they still can't express any personality because there's nothing to express it in.  There is no diplo interaction.  This game has no luxes so there's just one -less- thing to pretend to mutually support each other about.And the irony being that the entirety of gameplay involves building, as rapidly as you can, an industrial complex that exploits every hexagonal inch of the planet's surface... because that's all there is to the game.  There are no subcity elements to contend with.  No sustainability problems.  No corruption or empire contentment.  The affinities actually have no natural animosity for each other, the A.I.s just act like they do.Sci-fi is cool.  4X is cool.  And Civilization maintains its certain style of branding that comes through in the tone of things, in the character designs, in the  look-and-feel of the advanced gameplay elements - the "wow cool" of the components that comes from the designers' enthusiasm.  And the game sucks.

number of helpful: 95 of 149 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												A terrible disappointment. From the announcements, it was supposed to be a SMAC spiritual successor. What we were given is a re-skin of Civilization V with lackluster writing and shoddily-coded stubs instead of new features.Here is a short list of most annoying problems.Affinities, one of the core elements of the game, are poorly thought out and implemented. There is nothing that prevents you from trying to max out all three of them, but the AI will only count the highest one and chastise you for your choice even if you have more points in their chosen affinity than them. Other than that and requiring different resources, they don't change your gameplay too much. Harmony doesn't make you more at tune with the planet; in fact, you will probably kill more aliens than ever, because their nests tend to spawn on Xenomass which you need for your units. Supremacy and terraformation don't upset aliens one bit and one of the first bonuses you get actually make them never attack your explorers, Beyond the flavor, all three paths to victory are pretty much the old Spaceship victory.Aliens are a non-factor. They will rarely ever attack your units and won't go through your borders most of the time. Once I were taking potshots at the siege worm with ranged units for about 30 turns and it seemed content to just wander around and mind its business. I'm not sure why they are even in game, because they certainly don't hinder or help the player in any way.Braindead, passive AI. It doesn't explore too well, expands quite slowly and doesn't even try to compete for resources. It also doesn't engage in any meaningful diplomacy. Three leaders will repeatedly pester you with cooperation and open borders treaties, speaking the same line every time. The rest will almost never interact with you except to complain about some random things (like removing miasma from your own city or exploring Progenitor ruins beyond their borders which they didn't touch since the beginning of the game). Sometimes they also ask you for free stuff. They will rarely, if ever, go to war. When they do, they tend to never send enough units to even make a dent in your city. You can spend an entire game just sitting in your corner of the world and researching technologies, never having to fight anyone.Blandness and bad writing. Building a wonder usually gets you something that looks like a technical outline and +x to Production/Science/Food/something else. Leaders are devoid of any character whatsoever and you won't get any information about them without actively searching for them in Civilopedia. The devs promised the characters' appearance will change with each path and it kinda does - they wear slightly different clothes. The factions are: Space Russia, Space France, Space USA, Space Brasil, Space China, Space India, Space Australia and Space Africa. There are 5 different ways to win the game, except that 4 of them are pretty much the same one but requiring different techs and buildings.To sum it all up, the game simply isn't worth $50. I could maybe justify buying it for this price if it actually had decent, but unpolished content that needs a few patches and maybe an expansion to fully shine. The main problem with Beyond Earth is that it doesn't actually show much potential - the new core features simply don't work out and the poor quality of the game content suggests it was done on a budget. It's better to wait until it's cheaper.

												Civ V with a new skin. The game feels stripped down, like something is missing. At the end Civ V you have X-Com jump troops, so why, after 600 years, do I have Infantry plodding about on foot, 1-2 hexes per turn? Oh that's right, the basic infantry in this game are the warriors in Civ V. Waiting until the Gold Edition with all DLCs is released, on sale, to pick this one up. Anyone want to play Civ V?

number of helpful: 53 of 77 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
Beyond Earth is an unfortunate moniker. There is nothing "beyond" about this game. Damned near every feature that one expects from a Civilizations title is inexplicably missing in this itteration.And there is absolutely no reason for it.What Firaxis has offered is a stable late-beta "demo" game for $49.99. As a finished product. There is so much missing that you can't help but notice them and mention to yourself that you'll see 'em in the later "expansion" DLCs. Which means this lackluster game was purposefuly made, as is, to be geared towards taking more of your money just so the player can have the things that have been expected and seen in past Civilizations base games.I no longer trust this company for producing good product. Xcom showed us the direction they're going and Beyond Earth confirmed it.Other game companies out there (notably Iceberg Interactive and Stardock Games) are producing better, prettier and smarter strategy games for fractions of Firaxis' production costs. These same companies also have a history of providing quick updates and extra material free. Their DLC's of the past have always been expansions of already well crafted games.Any Beyond Earth DLCs will not be expansions, but finalization of game mechanics and artwork that should have already been in there.The game is bland. It has next to no honest replay value. There is no "push" nor needful purpose for finishing the game. Consequently you'll find yourself quickly bored.The AI is more or less a joke, their drive-by diplomatic messages become incredibly annoying and are quickly nonsensical in most contexts that they're delivered in. The AI's use of military units on the harder difficulties are a study in confusion, especially accounting for the fact that there aren't that many unit variations.Faction choices (Civilizations) are appalling. They're not distinctive. The larger maps will leave one or two factions out in the♥♥♥♥♥end of nowhere. Adding more factions to counter that means having clones, which will definitely knock immersion.Ability choices that are used to set apart your factions from others really don't accomplish the job. Too many choices aren't good ones, compelling the player to choose from the same set. So you'll be seeing the different factions making the same variation of choices you do in multi-player.The story enters with a whimper and then quietly dies. But that's okay because you barely notice its passing anyway.I told myself and I told others that I wouldn't be getting this game on launch. They really dropped the ball on Xcom but I figured, "Hey, it's a Civ game...there is no way they'd screw that up!".I was wrong. To my vast sorrow.This game is a blatant cash grab. You'll be required to purchase DLC's for the many, oh so many, features they purposely left out.Goodbye, Firaxis.

number of helpful: 33 of 43 people (77%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2015
												Relative to the other Civ games out there this is more than a step backwards. There are a lot of little things done wrong and I’ll try to hit on a couple as concisely as I can, addressing people familiar with Civ5.One of the problems is your opponents don’t start the game on the map, they drop in randomly at later turns. The same is true with this games version of city-states called outposts. So when you’ve explored at little like other Civ games you start to think about where your second city will go, but it’s extremely unlikely you’ll get to put one there without a fight because of outposts popping up. Instead of just worrying about other nations building a colony unit and grabbing the land you wanted, you have to deal with that plus cities and outposts popping up literally anywhere. All Civ games are random, but this adds a dynamic randomness that is just annoying.Another thing is the map is filled with “miasma,” which is green fog that damages units. It makes the game more tedious exploring and colonizing especially with the large amount of aliens (barbarians) floating around. You can also gain the ability to make this miasma not harmful to your units. But, even when your units are immune to it your automated workers will still clear it from tiles when it can only benefit you if your opponents aren’t immune to it. This just shows a lack of polish they were starting to gain in the series.Even little things like the quotes when you gain technology or build wonders aren’t as good. In the games where the quotes were tied to historical figures they were a lot more interesting. The made up quotes try to be funny or show personality but are mostly just stupid and don’t add to the flavor of the game.Another issue is all the buildings have secret abilities that you don’t know until you build one. Like you get to pick between two resources that all of the buildings of this type will produce. If you knew that ahead of time you might have chosen what buildings to build in a different order. As it is there is just more things to remember for the next game if you want to get good and play the game smart.The fluid technology paths just add to the sense that you’d really have to play the game a ton of times to make good choices on which order to do your research.It’s not complete crap, but it compares poorly to other Civ games in pretty much every way it is different.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2015
												I do recommend this game if you expect the same as previous Sid Meier's game releases.If you expect something new, you'll be in for a disappointing déjà vu.I have been a huge fan of previous versions of Sid Meier's Civilization: I loved Alpha Centauri.Now, many years later, I bought Civilization: Beyond Earth.At the beginning, it was all fun. The graphics looked good; I liked the music a lot. But after some turns (about 100 or so) I realized there was NOTHING NEW about this game. For me it is a HUGE DEJA VU of Alpha Centauri.After being such a succesful game programmer, I really expected Sid Meier and Firaxis to turn up with something NEW; something innovative; something we hadn't seen before. I didn't expect this cheap program recycling. Because that is what it is, disguised in some modern graphics and sleeker design.- The aliens are boring. They're more of an obstacle on the road you just need to get rid of.- The landscape isn't very "beyond Earth". Except for some exotic resources, boring alien insects and fish and a greenish fog, I don't see anything "beyond".- What's with the resource pods? What the hell? Is that all the game designers could come up with for this "beyond Earth" world?!?! How boring and unimaginative! What about some alien technologies hidden in artifacts? Or strange ruins of civilizations long since disappeared? Nooooo: resource pods, abandoned outposts and bones. That's very, very "beyond"...- I got HUGELY irritated by the stupid, moronic, illogical and backwards "diplomacy" in the single player game. The diplomatic behaviour of the other faction's "AI" is erratic at the very least. Wars are declared, condemnations are spoken for NO apparant reason but some random algorithm. The "forgiveness" in the diplomatic area when it comes to covert ops is extremely one-sided and highly undervalued compared to the "AI's" blatant and ongoing incursions despite made promises or demands. It is highly unbalanced, illogical and stupid. There is nothing "I" in the AI...This will probably be the last time I ever spend money on a Sid Meier's recycled game. It's Siphilization Beyond Boring.

content:
Posted: July 27, 2015
												The biggest thing holding me back on this game, compared to other Civ games (or the like), is the affinity system.  In theory, it is really cool.  I like how you can shape your playstyle and it is reflected in your units/buildings/victory type.  However, it really becomes apparent that if you are going to go for a specific victory, you really need to know that right at the start.  It doesn't really allow for adaptive gameplay.  Militarily, I find that it also makes the game suffer.  The biggest advancements come from seeking a specific affinty right from the get-go.  Choosing a research becomes a game of "Which _____ would be quickest" just to get a (devastatingly good) unit upgrade.  Again, you become really locked into what you choose right at the beginning.Civ 5, I felt, was completely polished by the last expansion; and it's kind of a shame that they didn't apply everything that was learned from that to this addition to the series.  Leaving out certain things such as the religion system or U.N. (rather, a setting-specific alternative) seems very short sighted.

number of helpful: 154 of 253 people (61%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
												First off, let's talk about the cons. It's easy to praise and speak highly of something, but to give a fair and honest overview is another thing entirely.The leader choice, although not particulary very important, is limited. Seeing the same couple faces every game is a bit of a letdown, but not a real detriment. The look and feel also is very similar to Civ 5. It feels like a glorified reskin when it comes to the basic look of the game.On a neutral standpoint, the game is also very challenging. If you are coming here from Civ 5, prepare to be overwhelmed. Though I personally find this to be a good thing. A high skill ceiling means it will keep you entertained for many many hours to come.Now, onto the sugary bits. The most shining thing this game offers is its customization. It's as if they took Civs system, stripped it down to the bare bones, and gave the players the ability to customize their Civ to the T. You can be a focused empire or a hybrid empire and it is quite effective. The tech tree is overwhelming, but golden and offers so much creative freedom. Every game you will pick and choose the flavor of techs that matches your situation best. Mix and match to achieve what you deem worthy as the perfect Civ.Some say this should have been a Civ 5 expansion. I disagree. It has it's own standalone atmosphere, and offers one of the most flexible and robust tech trees i've ever seen in a 4x (And I'm a huge Endless Legend/Space fanboy). The music is also delicious, and the game flows very smoothly.I highly recommend this game. It will be a gem for years to come.

number of helpful: 152 of 250 people (61%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												A B- game from a AAA publisher. It's like a bad Civ 5 mod. There is no polish to this game. Building the wonders is unspiring. All the voice acting is done by one person regardless of who the quote comes from.DO NOT BUY THIS GAME. YOU WILL BE SEVERELY DISAPPOINTED. I AM VERY SAD I SPENT ANY MONEY ON THIS.INTERFACEThe interface is extremely lackluster, with very poor choices about how to navigate through menus. Even the menu design itself looks boring. All the icons are flat puesdo-gray scale images that would look better on a mobile app than in a AAA game. The trade route interface does not sort to maximize by science, energy, food, or production (as it did in Civ 5) and every 15 turns you have to renew each trade route, which becomes a huge time waste when you have 4 trade routes per city in the mid to late game. Trying to send people through the earth domination gate requires you to send military units one at a time for ~20 turns or so. This is a super frustrating experience.This bad UI is pervasive throughout the game. If you highlight the technologies based on a certain type, you can't select anything else but the ones you've filtered by, so you have to go back and unclick it.Moving a spy around requires multiple clicks through submenus when it should just be a single one.The workers seem much, much stupider than the ones in Civ 5. I've seen them get stuck multiple times while multiples are automated near each other, and they will bankrupt you with the -6 maintence improvement if you don't watch them. They also don't proiritize maglevs at all, which are just railroads from Civ 5.SatilletesThis is probably one of the most interesting, and equally dispapointing parts of the game. The satilletes come so late in the technology tree, and have such limited effects, that there are no interesting choices in boosting your production with them. You also can't stack them in any way.CombatThe combat is actually less interesting than in Civ 5 which is pretty painful. I don't know how you take a step back here. There are less units, and you can only upgrade them by researching one of the three foundational systems, and then you upgrade all of them exactly the same way.ResearchThe web tech tree is definitely a better setup than the linear one from Civ 5, but because of the three paradigms, it's much less expansive than it looks, you're virtually forced to pickup useless technologies because they happen to have a paradigm increase on them, which is super frustrating.MISCWonders have no visible improvement on the city. Energy and health are just money and happiness. The three paradigms of Adaptation, Purity, and Improvement are super boring. There's nothing interesting about them compared to the society alignments of Alpha Centarui.

New tech tree and affinity system just seem like hassles more than anything, the non-linear change to culture was nice though. Same base units stay with you pretty much through out the whole game and the little bonuses you can choose from don't diversify them well. I'd go on more but I'm tired and some other people covered real well why this is just watered down SciFICIv5.

number of helpful: 45 of 65 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												I want so very badly to recomend this game, I dearly love the franchise and think firaxis is among the best studios out there today. However, this game just doesn't live up to the hype or the reputation that they have worked so hard to build.Where to begin with this game. I think the most obvious and perhaps worst aspect of this release is that it is such a thinly veiled clone of Civ 5. I feel ripped off paying $50 for what amounts to little more than a reskinned game from 2010 with a cool intro video. Sure, its fairly pretty, but its so unbelievably dull. I'm baffled that with a concept as fantastic and well-loved by fans they couldn't think up anything even slightly more engaging. There's no wonder videos (static pictures only), no dynamic cities that show the buildings they contain (already done for Civ IV), no interesting AAA voice acting for the tech tree, and paltry number of playable civilizations that differentiate the game exactly not at all. Unit design is also absent, with a very linear affinity-based upgrade system that is extremely unsatisfying next to the fully custom unit design system in Alpha Centauri, which made unit design a combination of economic, technological, and strategic considerations. While trade routes are a cool and immersive idea, they are done so poorly here that I wish they weren't included. Having to reassign these units every few turns makes my blood boil.This game was hailed as a "spiritual successor" to Alpha Centauri, but it shares nothing with the original, it's a obviously a functional game, but if you already own Civ V I highly reccomend you just keep on playing and wait for someone to do a real remake, which is what everybody was praying for, but sadly sometimes Sid Meier answers prayers with a resounding NO!Now if you'll excuse me, I need to go play some Alpha Centauri.

number of helpful: 53 of 79 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												Feels like a cash grab tbh. Not worth $50 at all IMO. Plain and simple, the game is boring.-No matchmaking or anything so you have to play against AI which really isn't that well done. I'm not sure what the devs really expected here... I can't see anyone playing against the one(?) difficulty AI for all that long. If this game had some sort of matchmaking it might be a bit more replayable but the archaic lobby system doesn't offer much in terms of a PvP experience.-No real attempt to immerse you in the game. Textures, audio, cutscenes, are all average at best. Experience just feels stale and unimportant.-Going back to my first point there's no real campaign and overall there's just a lack of content and things to do. The "quests" are all shallow and unfun. You're basically playing the same game over and over again against inadequate AI.-Little bits of innovation here and there that really don't do much to enhance the experience. It's not quite a Civ 5 reskin but what it does try to do doesn't really accomplish anything.-As far as strategy goes there really isn't any. Just a bunch of meaningless choices. They try to make the game seem "complex" but if you can see through the abitrary number crunching and superflous tech trees then you realize the game is relatively simple and rigid.Overall just feels like a game that knew it could ride on the name it had already made for itself. Clearly the devs weren't very interested in making this title and it showed. Really just a lack of effort IMO. The game isn't completely terrible but it really isn't worth the $50 and you can find much better games for much less. Save your money, this game isn't anything special, and that's probably being generous.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												Rather disappointed, but I did let my expectations get too high. Just played a game with Vostok (medium) difficulty .Pros:- I rather like the unit system. Upgrading the units with affinity levels creates immersion. With a little bit more love it would be great addition.- Quests and victory conditions are a good innovation. I like the way you progress through them in several steps.- Strategic resources. I find the affinity related resources a good idea. Creates some strategic levels for the game.- Wildlife feels immersive.- Affinities. Although the factions are bland, the affinities are not.Cons:- Game is short. Just finished the first one in 10 hours. Thats bad for a civ game.- Wildlife is too weak. By midgame you just overrun them with no consequences attached. Don't know if this one scales up by difficulty levels.- The AI doesn't seem to mind you winning the game. It would be great if by the time you start progressing in the victory conditions, the AI would react in some way. This feels like a lost opportunity to create more content to this game. Perhaps something that was cut off to make the deadline?- There is no city specialization. Not even on the level of Civ V. You just build everything everywhere. This makes for a bad strategy game.- Contact victory seems to be too easy.Grade for the current state game with the pricetag of 50 euros observed: 7-I had a nice (second) game of Warlock 2 going on, which I plan to return to. CIV: BE can wait for the huge content patch or DLC. And I will be very wary of paying the full price for that. The DLC content notes will be read with a magnifying glass and I will still wait for the early adopters to rate it.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												As it is now I cannot recommend it. After playing the game for about 11 hours I grew tired of a Covert Ops bug (where you cannot redeploy your agents, and this is a known bug since October and hasn't been fixed up to now.) There is also a lot of unneeded micromanagement that is simply driving me crazy. Having to reassign my trade routes (to the same route they were already doing even..) every so many turns and that for every single trade route. Also having to redeploy my satellites to the same positions every so many turns. And having to build the same type of buildings in every city every time and time again.The game is really lacking some proper macro management tools like:-Auto redeploy trade route check mark.-Queues for city builds (set up your own preferred queues and let the city follow one of your setups) or even a mayor who can auto build the things for you.-An option do auto replace a satellite when the old one comes down or even some option to relift it higher in orbit at a cost.-An option for your workers to upgrade all your roads. (Instead of having to do that manually.)I'm also missing some chances they had to make it more fun, perhaps some real terraforming where you can change the actual terrain, lower it, raise it and so on.Basically the game is a lot of fun, but it could be so much better, but with all the unneeded micromanagement there is now it's simply not my type of game. I will probably pick it up again though after a few patches and perhaps some dlcs if those bring the game to a more complete package like civilization.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												Disappointment.. .. .. .. ..  Has already been said, and I second this, but Civilization Beyond Earth is basically 'an extension of/to Civ V. . . .  Civ Beyond Earth could have easily been a simple $20 MOD to patch Civ V!  Why is it so tough to find corrective patches to the gameplay of Civ Beyond Earth......  Having purchased and downloaded the game through STEAM, I am not sure that the issues I am having are related to missing input through the online download - as apposed to having a physical PC CD copy. . . . . . . .  Every time I have run and attempted to play Civ Beyond Earth ((Which has completely ruined any excitement I once had to play it)) the land masses are spattered in a rainbow-like pattern as if it were meant to be looked upon with 3D glasses....  Another hindrance in playing the game for more than 2 friggin' turns is that all of the sudden the 'Next Turn' button does not work.... Click - Click - Click - CLICK of the mouse button to function THAT option. . . . . . . .  Have to turn the game off and re-run it for it to work........  But this continuously happens...  And I cannot find a patch for these issues!!  As for Civ Beyond Earth, If somehow I am able to play it for more than 2turns the only enjoyment I expect to glean from this is my own Sci-Fi minded personality which will allow me to find other enjoyments of this game beyond its dated game play!  There is nothing futuristic about this game, isn't it 2014/15.......  There are games like WOW or even Call of Duty which depict fantasy worlds and are FAR MORE Graphically detailed; isn’t that the point of PC gaming that there are more components to assist with and providing in delivering an Avatar world like landmasses…????!!!  Civ Beyond Earth is very Cartoon-like, and maybe I feel this way because of my current rainbow-3D like lands, what is this a 5bit game – Nintendo gaming provided a more well-thought out detailed graphics experience than this current Civ game!I have always felt it would be cool if from Civilization V, that once a player reached modern times in the gameplay that the Civ world would be invaded by Aliens that each country would have to thwart off the alien foes ~ or something to that affect.   I mean, the intro to Civ Beyond Earth makes you believe that you start out on Earth in a depleted state, as to the reason for humans needing/wanting to leave Earth…  I thought that you would get to choose where in the galaxy, you the player, would be able to determine where to explore.  So, you start the game already on some planet….  Have played the Civilization Games for years now…  Anticipated THIS game and it was a fail.  Tres disappointed!

number of helpful: 25 of 31 people (81%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												Civ 5 - 236 hours played on steam (probably more like 300 if including off-line play)Civ BE - 33 hours (been 4 weeks since I last played it.)It's not a terrible game on its own, but after playing Civ 5 w/ all their factions, special units and buildings and unique faction perks it honestly kind of feels like im playing a civ game made for a cell phone. I loved this game when it came out... I played it for probably 20 hours in the first week alone, but for me, the replayability of the game was just not there. (one of the greatest achievements of civ5 imo)There are no factions like in civ 5... just starting perks you can choose.There are no special units that only you can get because of your chosen starting perks... Every player can get EVERY unit w/ the required research and resources. There are the 3 branches of tech which kind of makes the appearance of race/faction... but I think this system is just a few steps down from Civ 5.There is alien life!!! But they are simply barbarians ie: unintelligent cattle with chitinous armor, sharp teeth and the occasional acid spitter.There is no challenge!!! Even with the difficulty on higher diff's it is extremely easy to maintain peaceful relations with every other NPC faction on the planet for the duration of the entire game.I could go on, but its basically a list of things I would have wanted to see or things done differently.My bottom line is: It just gets boring really quick, and after a handful of games (33 hours played), I find little reason to launch the game again, which in my opinion is the polar opposite of the last couple civ games (sorry didn't play very much of the earlier civs so I can't comment on those)The next time I feel an urge to play a civ game, I will probably be launching Civ 5 rather than Civ BE. It's not that Civ BE is a horrible game, It just doesn't come close to being as good as Civ 5, which to me was a huge letdown.

number of helpful: 156 of 260 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
												So I'm 7 hours in and I can already tell you what this game is worth to me. Honestly I really don't want to say this but a lot of those who said that this should be a paid scenario for Civ 5 are 100% correct. This game is essentially just a reskinned civ 5 with a few added gimmicks (tech web doesn't count, all thats changed on that front is its no longer a linear path from left to right) and some minor changes here and there.So lets begin with my first irk, the factions. Normally in a civ game you'd have all the historical factions from every era like the Romans, French, Vikings etc with their own unique bonuses, units and city layouts. Well that's certainly not the case here with Civ Beyond earth. For example you have the Slavic Federation and the ARC (American Reclamation Corporation), now you'd expect the buildings and units to look like futuristic Russians and Americans right?, well you'd be entirely wrong there. All units are exactly the same with no visual difference (even the special upgraded units are the same for each faction) or stat changes from start to finish, making the experience of choosing a faction completely pointless as they are exactly the same.What makes this even worse is that during the custom game set up screen you are literally given the faction logo and a paragraph of text to help you decide the faction you want to play as, but seeing as they're all the same anyway there isn't any point in deciding a faction beyond choosing the one with the name that you like.The only true addition to this game is the affinity system with its three selections to choose from. The latter being Harmony which allows you to acquire alien units, Supremacy which turns you into a robotic cyborg race and Purity which gives the middle finger to everything non human. This is where all the visual changes take place and the higher you go up an affinity the more your faction changes, but that is also pointless as all the factions are the same anyway and will always have the same units as you meaning choosing an affinity is purely a cosmetic choice.The aliens themselves do add a bit more of a challenge as opposed to the barbarians of old, being more of a mini faction that you have to deal with and will become stronger the more you play. But even they are just as easily dealt with just like the barbarians as you can simply put up force field barriers that repel all aliens, regardless of strength, from as early as turn freakin 50. One of the most reported strongest aliens during the early game stage, the seige worm, was easily dealt with as I simply put up barriers in all of my cities and had them shoot at the worm until it was dead, and all it did was move back and forth trying to get to my units just behind the force field, making what I thought was a terrifying enemy into more of a simple pest that is just as easily swatted away as the barbarians.Honestly I could go on but right now I'm too tired from all the bland dullness that this game is emanating so I'll just wrap this up with a final verdict. Don't buy this and just stick with Civ 5, wait for mods to come out and for the price to drop before even thinking of buying this. Whilst it's not a game that's on par with horrible games like Big Rigs or Air Control, it's so incredibily dull and bland that you'd be better off playing those games instead, just so you don't end up falling asleep after only 200 turns.So with all that the final score is:5/10Come back in a month or two when all them smart modders make this game worth £30P.s Might write a full review once I play a bit more (god help me on that one) and post it on youtube so this score isn't final for me.

number of helpful: 91 of 147 people (62%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												As has been stated by many others: This game is NOT the spirtual succesor to Alpha Centaruai. It's basically a mega mod for Civ V.Had this been a $25-30 title and advertised as a modified Civ V then I wouldn't feel so robbed by it. As it stands I'm just really, really disapointed.I see a lot of people hoping that this game might get better with future expansion packs but I have my doubts. The core game is a stripped down Civ V experience. In order to make this game stand on it's own they would need to introduce some very unique game mechanics to capture the feeling of taming an alien planet. One would think said mechanics would be in the launch title, right? So if they didn't bother with getting creative at launch why would they get creative down the road with an expansion? Let's face facts, any expansions this game gets are going to be modified versions of GK and BNW.At this point I'm wondering if Firaxis does not have the capability to give us a successor to Alpha Centauri. You could feel the passion the devs had for AC with each game you played. But this game? This game right here is completly devoid of passion. The world leaders are lifeless and generic. The aliens are Starship Trooper knock offs. And the wonders! Seriously what is with the wonders? In Alpha Centauri you were treated to a full FMV with an epic and long quote from one of the faction leaders. Here? You get a picture of a bland blueprint and a sentence from the same VA that's been reading all the other quotes in the game. Prime example of the total lack of passion and life in this game.Trying to cash in on the demand for the next Alpha Centauri experience was a pretty low blow from Firaxis. Unless future expansions are simply mind blowing I think I'm done with this one.

												If you come in with an expectation of a game at least as deep as Civ V you will be disapointed. The game needs work ... more work than the Civ V needed when it was released.The quests are a cool idea, the units models are nice and epic but ....... it has almost no depth, parts seem overpowered (trade routes - you feel like playing as Venice) while others seem pointless (favors - you get them for big chunks of strategic resources and AI will give you a bit of energy in return). The AIs are rather random, asking for favors a turn before attacking you. Automated workers will either ruin you, waste your precious resources or sometimes just get stuck in a cycle of replacing one upgrade with another. Etc etc ... and that's just after a couple of games.I hope I really hope I will rewrite the review after a major patch ... or a couple, it just should be so much better than it is. Civ V became a great game but it took a couple of years, I hope BE will not take that long.

												Underdeveloped, rushed, impossible to recommend. Easily the worst game in the Civ series so far. Nothing seems to be finished or refined. Here's a list of problems:- The factions have no personality whatsoever. The faction leaders are nobodies, I can't even remember their names, much less any interesting quotes. I can't even remember what factions are available, they're that boring and indiscernable.- The buildings, the technologies are filler, they are not carefully thought out.- The "wonders" are not really wonders - they barely affect the flow of the game, they are uninspiring, and when they are built the screen is just stupid and ugly.- The affinities are cosmetic, make no difference to how you play your game.- Same goes for terrain improvements and orbital units.- The aliens are not "challenging", they're just "cheap"- Trade: Once you create many trade routes.... it becomes a hassle to recreate them, so I end up just deleting them- There's not even a proper ending! When you win the game, you literally get a "victory screen" and that's that. No statistics, no nothingThis game is so underdeveloped it is a huge shame, coming after the immense success that was Brave New World, this is a huge, depressing step backwards for the series and not at all recommended.

I'd say this game is definitely worth as much as 13 Arizona teas.
