content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												Over 450 hours. That's how much time I have on Civilization V. So, needless to say: I'm a big fan of the series, especially the predecessor to Beyond Earth. That said, I'm still not fatigued by the game, and I still can go back to Civ V and have a lot of fun on it. So, when Beyond Earth came out I was very excited to see what they'd do now that they're changing the setting to the future rather than the past and present.I'm going to be blunt: this is a massive letdown. This game is Civilization V if you sucked out all of its soul. This game has absolutely no personality, you don't get any of the old Ghandi and his nukes, or the backstabbing of Napoleon, or the wonder-stealing of Ramses. I've clocked up a good few hours on this game, and the leaders from this game are still yet to show any personality or do anything even remotely memorable.This is a big problem, as in Civ V: part of what made it fun was the fact that each Civilization had a unique AI, as well as unique abilities. The abilities of those Civilizations would mean that every game would feel different, not only based on the Civilization that you choose: but the AI you're pitted against, your starting location, and sometimes just plain luck would play huge a part in how the game plays out. In Civilization V, each Civilization got its own unique ability, unit, and/or building. But, in Beyond Earth, when you're choosing your Civ, you get one stat boost, and then you pick three more bonuses. These bonuses lack any depth, it's stuff like "Get a free worker" or "Reveal minerals on the map" or "+2 culture for every city", and it's all just either boring stat bonuses or getting certain abilities or units a little bit early. In Civ V, you would get things that no other Civilization gets, and you could build a strategy around that. For example, the fact that Venice can buy City-States makes them a truly unique civ to play, and offers a unique experience. Beyond Earth lacks that depth and personality, and it really feels like hardly any real effort went into its design. The bonuses that these new Civilizations get are more akin to the bonuses you'd get from religion in Civ V. It's nice that they're there, but they're hardly game-changing. I'd also like to point out that Civilization V has a total of 43 civilizations, whereas Beyond Earth has only 8. You'd expect that those 8 would be really detailed this time, given that they have considerably less things to work on but: no. They feel like the type of Civilization someone would make if they'd just started modding Civilization V.Also, the bonuses that you get from wonders are not very impressive. It's actually kind of hard to tell what is an isn't a wonder when looking at the technology tree, and their bonuses are so lacklustre you could easily mistake them for a standard building. On top of this, there are only 4 culture trees in this game, as opposed to the 13 that were in Civ V, and again: these trees are very boring and they offer things like "+2 production when healthy" and just really boring thoughtless things like that.The graphics in this game are ugly, frankly. The actual models look great, better than Civilization V, in fact. But, the UI is absolutely hideous. It uses blue: exclusively. This just adds to the lack of personality here, and it also kind of makes it hard to understand what's going on on the minimap. I played as Franco-Iberia in my first game, and their territory on the map is represented with a pale blue. This made it so that on the mini-map, my territory was light blue, land was a darker blue, and the sea was an even darker blue. It was kind of confusing to look at, and it made the landmasses (as well as my land) look highly amorphous. On top of that, it looked genuinely ugly. The game's UI is like an Apple store: just a cold colourless environment. Well, colourless apart from blue.Also, every victory type is the technology victory from Civ V. I mean, the exact same. No matter what Civilization you play as, no matter what you do, you are always doing it on behalf of advancing your technology. True, you can declare war and kill everyone, but whether or not you win is entirely based on who has the best technology: nothing else. There are a total of five victory types, but 4 of them are based on reaching the end of a technology tree. This is incredibly dull, because again, in Civilization V, you'd need different strategies to get different victory types. I could use the same strategy for every victory type in Beyond Earth. Why was there no cultural or diplomatic victory? Nope, all of the victory types in this game rely on you reaching the end of the technology tree that you've chosen.The aliens are better than the barbarians from Civilization V, but only by a bit. They're still a massive nuisance, but there are ways to avoid them, and even use them to your advantage. For example, I built a city on a one-tile-island very close to an alien nest in the sea, and I managed to use the aliens as a defence. But, they're still mostly a nuisance, so it's not a massive improvement. They also feel kind of unfinished, as a lot of buildings seem to make it sound as though you can tame the aliens and turn them to your side, but you really can't: they will always be either hostile or neutral.Another good feature is that the planets now have three different types of landscapes: terrain, fungal, and arid. They kind of shake up the atmosphere a bit, and it gives the illusion of variation quite well, which is a good thing. I'm unsure if they effect the resources or actual tile types, but it's quite nice playing on them (except fungal which is a nightmare because it is YET MORE BLUE).Just going back to the factions for a second, I'd just like to say that I highly object to there being no British civilization. In Civilization V I very much enjoyed playing as England and the Celts simply because I'm British and it's kind of cool to build places that you're very familiar with. Do Firaxis really believe that their European fanbase is entirely composed of French and Spanish people? There are more countries that have been completely excluded but it would take me far too long to list them all. In Civ V, they at least gave each country some kind of representation or another. For example, Italy wasn't in the game, but they instead included Rome and Venice, so they still had some representation in the game.It's not a terrible game, but it just doesn't have the personality or replayability of the earlier Civ games. Some of the changes it makes are for the better, like the removal of barbarians in favour of aliens, and the ability to choose to start with a worker rather than a warrior. But, the idea of letting the players create their own civilizations has just made the game feel very thoughtless and rushed.Pick it up only if you've somehow exhausted Civilization V and it is at a significantly reduced price.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												As someone who has put in 800+ hours in Civ V and god knows how much in IV and III, it sucks to admit that I'm pretty dissapointed with CIV:BE. Overall, it's a fun new experience, but doesn't compare to Alpha Centuri and its UI is begging for a patch out of the box. Summary:+Affinities are a great expansion to how your units and cities look like. +Enhanced narrative through sidequests / city state colonies+Social policies have been put into 4 trees and it works well!+Harmony affinity / alien units are pretty rad!+Terrain generation is really cool and has good variety. +Spying has been improved so you can stage a Coup and snag an entire city if you're successful. - [~personal] I'm not a fan of how units are perma upgraded now. - [~personal] CIV:BE feels like it chose visuals over gameplay- No natural wonder equivalents [ Gimme a badass Volcanoe that gives +8 science!]- No religion of any kind [ Gimme cyber future religion!] - UI could use a LOT of color differentiation [ In the Tech Tree I can't tell what's a building and what's a wonder]. - Affinities should function like ideology [Once you pick one you stick with it rather than juggle 3 of them]. - [~personal] Another thing that bogs this title down is the limited expressions and butchered fake voice acting for some leaders (Slavic Federation and Brasilia; Kozlov's voice is just some Berkeley hipster reading off Google Translate with a Russian accent / which is odd because Catharine's voice in V was 100% authentic. )+/- Trade works the same way as in Civ V, and thats ok I guess.+/- Diplomacy is exactly the same and thats ok too, I guess+/- No Nukes / Mass Destruction+/- No Space Mongolians / Space banditsAt the end of the day, while it does offer a brand new experience, an impressive terrain script and an expanded narrative in the form of quests, I cannot recommend this game in its current state at its current price until it's at least patched and some gameplay elements are significantly improved.

												At first, it was awesome. It was what every Civ fan wanted. When first playing, everything looked amazing, the art work is brilliant.But man, did you screw up, Sid.Nothing is balanced. At all. Ever. Your economy is ridiculous, and it never really works, especially with all this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t about satellites, and 2 ♥♥♥♥ing trade routes per city (which can easily lead to you never having a problem with money, which is not at all interesting). And no great people! What the ♥♥♥♥!? No ♥♥♥♥ing great people? After you introduced 10 or something great people in Civ 5? What the ♥♥♥♥! Also, workers don't give a flying♥♥♥♥♥♥about your economy at all on automated mode, and will just build whatever the ♥♥♥♥ they want because #yolo. You have no choice but to manually control them, as this automated mode is ♥♥♥♥ing useless.Also, WHAT THE ♥♥♥♥ IS THE "TECH WEB"? WHY DID YOU DO THIS SID? IT'S♥♥♥♥♥♥ It just doesn't work. I like the idea of going in different directions in technology to have a different outcome at the end of the game, but it just leaves you with major holes in your technology, which is ♥♥♥♥ing stupid and prevents you from doing very important things (like having a basic flying unit).The quest system? Alright, I don't got beef with that, that's cool, no major problems. But, a massive ♥♥♥♥ing problem is the MASSIVE ♥♥♥♥ING LACK IN ACTUAL CIVS. I MEAN, IT'S CALLED CIVILIZATION ISN'T IT? SO WHERE THE ♥♥♥♥ ARE THEY? I mean really, they just don't ♥♥♥♥ing exist at all, you have to download mods to actually have a decent amount, and I'll be damned if I'm gonna wait for DLC to have some more.Art work? ♥♥♥♥ing cool, straight up. That stuff is glorious, and the animations are perfect and awesome, especially the aliens. SHAME YOU COULDN'T USE THAT EFFORT TO BALANCE YOUR GAME, SID. Also, where the ♥♥♥♥ is my adviser counsel? I have no ♥♥♥♥ing clue if some prick's army is stronger than mine at all. How the♥♥♥♥♥♥am I supposed to figure that out by myself? Manually scout their ♥♥♥♥ing territory? ♥♥♥♥ off, my adviser is supposed to do that for me! SO WHERE IS HE? What about demographics? How do I know if I'm actually better than someone else? I mean really, I have to shoot in the dark regularly just to try and win the game, and I have no ♥♥♥♥ing clue if that's overkill or if I'm losing badly anyway. I'm really disappointed in you, Sid. This could have been amazing, but you ruined it. Might as well download some sci-fi mods for Civ 5, and that'll be 10 times better. I mean, I love you Sid, you made some real sweet games in the past, but this? Ugh, it hurts me to think about it. If and when the DLC comes out, it better sort it out, or I'll write another angry review to directly target your feelings, and believe me, this hurts me more than it hurts you. For shame, Sid, for shame.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												In its current state, no, I do NOT recommend this game.  Honestly there is some AWESOME stuff and if they fix it, I would totally recommend it to everyone. It was a lot of fun at first and they introduced some very cool elements and a cool environment. But, they flopped for a few reasons, only some of which are below. In a nutshell, it's Civ 5 with liposuction and a facelift. Unfortunately they liposuctioned out good stuff like city states and replaced them with barely-noticable "Stations" (seriously, all you can do is send them trade convoys, or destroy them for a minimal one time resource gain).Please save your money. Here are a few reasons why:You can't turn off time victory! I only had Domination selected and yet the game still ended when the time ran out. Time is not even an option as a victory condition. **Will not play again with Time victory**Other issues:-Spawning: The map is HUGE and they feel the need to land 2 of 3 other civilizations on MY ISLAND. There are a ton of islands left. Two bigger or the same size. Same story in the other Civ games, putting people on the same land or in the same area when there's a whole wide world out there.Incompetent Civs: Something that didn't change that should have was the stupidity of the other Civs involved. All I did was trade with them and they denounce me. No provocation. Then they go to war with me and say it's because of what I've done. Affinity quest choices that make even a tiny bit of sense:I went Harmony. I have screenshots of the choices I was given for the quest where humans went to another planet, mixed with the indigenous life, then came to mine. For some inexplicable reason, if I send them away I GAIN harmony! And when they ask to trade later, if I refuse to trade, I GAIN harmony! That doesn't mesh with harmony's philosophy. But apparently Harmony followers are Space Racists just like Purity, only they happen to include one more planet than Purity followers. But 3 or more planets, no way, is that what you're saying?Random Outposts: Aside from accepting trade from Stations, do they have another function?

												Wow I could hardly wait! Been waiting for months for this game. 1st the positives great graphics great music 9/10. However that being said that is where it stops! number of helpful: 48 of 80 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												I want to like this game. I loved Civ 5 and for the most part, Beyond Earth plays a lot like it... Which is partially the problem. It plays like Civ 5 with less content and depth.  The new features in the game don't really do enough to make it feel any more than a mod or expansion to Civ 5.There are only 8 factions to choose from, making it impossible to play with anymore than 8 players, even in singleplayer. You can modify the files to allow 8+ AI in singleplayer but it will only result in duplicate factions, rendering diplomacy confusing and practically unusable.The UI is a lot less... informative than Civ 5. Many dulled, grey tones . In particular, telling factions apart on the minimap proves quite difficult with many simply appearing grey. The minimap is also way too small to make out any important details and minor feedback features such as trade route caps and "just finished building/researching" information are completely absent.All in all, this game feels more like an unfinished expansion back or a decent mod than a quality civilization title.

content:
Posted: April 27, 2016
												FIrst of all I've put 180 hrs into this game, and 350 into Civ 5, and I've been playing Civ games since they started being made, so I like to believe this is an informed opinion.If you love sci-fi and love Civilization games, ignore the negative reviews. This game is awesome, it just takes some time getting used to. When I played this game for the first time I felt lost, which I didn't expect after putting 350 hours into Civ 5, expecting this to be just a reskin. The game also felt so flavorless to me just like the negative reviews say, and leaders were without personality.But when I've given the game enough time and started to understand it, I realized I was looking at it the wrong way. The game is not a reskin of Civ 5 unless you want to see it that way, and that's when you'll hate it. There are many layers to the game that gives it its independent personality and lets it walk on its own feet.The biggest thing I'm referring to is afiinities. Affinities are the main pillar this game stands on, and it's the main factor seperating it from Civ 5. Affinities are what give this game its identity and flavor, not leaders. As you progress in each affinity, you get awesome snipets of story unique to each affinity that drives the story forward in a way Civ 5 never could. You start getting awesome unique units, buildings, and even a unique rich-in-story-and-flavor victory condition for each affinity as you tread their paths.There are many other mechanics that make this game cool, like the sattelite layer, interacting with aliens, and artifacts. The tech web, while not beginner-friendly at all, makes for very interesting and diverse choices every single game once you are more familiar with the game.Also the expansion "Rising Tide" makes the game even better, and the positive reviews on its Steam page prove that. Such a shame that didn't reflect on the game main page reviews as well.

Posted: November 17, 2014
												I'm big fan of Civilization series... This game, however, is not worth buying.I just might not like psychedelic colors but aliens are fun. And there ends the fun.Tech tree (or rather tech web) is gigantic messy innovation I was never able to navigate through. In contrast with intuitive tech tree from earlier Civilization series... it is just so wrong and annoying... new player in earlier Civilizations is given choice of tech to discover. Not here. Here you have to bother with the whole tech web since first play and first turn.In Civilization V (and IV) we had upgrades and we could focus these upgrades according to battlefield situation. So we can here, we can heal or add 10% strength bonus... and that's it... a joke...Cities have tons of structures, and here is a great idea to upgrade structure via quests, but other than that structures are just a mess to remember, just too many buildings... I could continue but every other game aspect (factions, units, city states...) is similiar: attempt of innovation, alienish look and feel, and definitely messed up.But everything should be forgiven if the game is fun - IT IS NOT:First play is just chaotic, there is no joy from discovering alien world and game mechanics,And there is not much replayability...The one good thing about Beyond the Earth is that you can finally realize that Civilization V was quite OK.

content:
Posted: March 12
												This game looked cool and I had some high hopes for it, but it seems Firaxis didn't give a ♥♥♥♥ about this one. There's a lot that just simply angers me in this game.To start there's not enough civilizations, and the civilizations only have a single recorded voice line. AI is just far too easy in this game and I'm not even that great in Civ,  this is probably due to being able to win over civilizations by military size or through making them happy by doing certain quests. Which brings me to my next points.Quests, The Tech Tree and Diplomacy.Quests aren't fleshed out enough, and most just feel rushed or last minute attempts to add something else to the game, some seem to be broken or don't make any sense. Although I do like the concept of quests in a Civ game. Moving on to the Tech Tree, this is probably what makes me annoyed the most, it looks very unorganised and just generally all over the place compared to Civ V / VI, I feel like this sort of tree as well could be very confusing for a new player compared to the design used in Civ V / Civ VI.Now talking about Diplomacy, I didn't find it too bad it just felt like they tried something new except it didn't work out. You can use diplomatic points to increase your standing with other civilizations, or you can just choose to lower it and of course go to war. You can also use these points to make agreements with other civilizations but I don't know if it's actually worth doing so yet.I think mainly I just hate the UI in this game along with the fact that it feels empty and not worked on enough. It's good if Firaxis were trying some things but if anything I would've said this is more of a mod/expansion of Civ V than a whole new game. Unfortunately the state of this game has made me lose respect and expectations of what Firaxis will do. So whether I buy Civ VI or not is a tricky one.

Posted: July 16, 2016
												I had heard a lot of complaints about this game and when it was on sale for about $20 including the DLC I picked it up due to my cousin having already bought it when it first came out and he gave it a thumbs up so I bought it.This game may be my favorite Civ game to date, but having only played Civs 3-5 I'll let you guys be the judge of my experience.  That may be considered blasphamy, but I really enjoy this game.  I do enjoy Sci-Fi more than fantasy/medieval type of games though so I fully admit some bias here.  I really liked the tech tree (sorry tech web), in this one.  The web feels daunting at first, yet I enjoy it better than the other Civs.  Mostly because it feels like, no matter what path you choose you don't feel hopelessly outgunned in terms of technology advancement.  Whenever I would play the other ones, if I did it on any higher difficulty level I always felt like my Civilization just figured out gun powder while my cpu compatriots just spliced the atom when I played Civs 3-5.  So maybe I'm just bad at the games.  But the tech web makes me feel like everyone is close to the same level so you can forge your own path without being left behind because you didn't research  a certain tech first and thusly you are way behind.  If you really enjoy Civ 5's tech tree this one could be a bit off putting.I also felt like the game wasn't a drag, you had plenty of places to explore, things you were working toward, but it didn't feel overwhelming.  Maybe Beyond Earth is a bit simpler in that respect, but I personally found that nice.  The AI and companies/civilizations aren't as memorable unfortunately but in a way I also kind of like that better too.  You're an unknown face facing the unknown world leading your people to (hopefully) victory.  I guess I can put myself into the game better than playing as Bismark or etc...I can see the complaints about it being a Civ 5 mod, but the different tech tree/web, the different starting options, and some of the mechanics make me think their complaints are a bit...nit-picky.Anyhow, if you like the other 5 Civ games and the way they work this one may not be as deep or game-changing as you'd expect.  But if you'd like to try something Civ-like but a little different, pick it up on sale with the DLC.

number of helpful: 18 of 26 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 15, 2016
												This is my first real review, but I feel that this game is missunderstood and underappreciated so I hope to improve on that.Beyond Earth is similar to other Civilization franchise games, but different enough to feel fresh. It's like a new game that you already know how to play. With aliens. And lasers.It is not as profound as classic Civ games, but I like the fact that the average game is shorter, with this game a quick skirmish doesn't last weeks. I feel that because of this they removed the cost for upgrading units, changed the evolution tree and made affinities...Without the DLC the game feels like it is lacking, but with the Rising Tide complexity rises considerably; I adore the new hybrid affinities, the new diplomacy is ok, personality traits are awesome. Connection to Sid Meier's Starship is also a neat bonus, ehich enhances immersity in the game universe.It also runs well on non-gaming laptops and steam cloud save works seamlessly; to me this is of a paramount importance, because I like to play it on my gaming PC as well on my laptop.A Steam controller is almost a must have for Civilization games, after a quick personalization it makes everything so much quicker and effortless...The main CON of this game is it's full price. If Beyond Earth, Rising Tide and Sid Meier's Starship came on the market as one complete game I feel it would get the praise it rightfully deserves. With it's current marketing system...well...buy it on sale, as have I.

												I always liked playing "Expand and kill" in civilization, this game out of its way to prevent that.You can no longer "keep playing" after someone wins one of the goals, you can't even turn off the goals and play in global domination mode.Defending is to easy, all you need is a couple of units outside the city the AI is attacking and you're set for the game's length. Posted: August 28, 2016
												Civilization: Beyond Earth is a fresh new take on the CIV game series. While it may not be as addicting as it's predecessors, it's still a good game.Pros+ It's fresh. It's a nice change from the other games.+ The affinity system is a nice addition. Mix with the aliens or exterminate them?+ Upgrading your units in this game is a more fleshed out experince.+ Cool units, buildings and wonders.+ Multiplayer is pretty stable from what I've seen, less buggy than CIV V.Cons- It's just not as addicting. I can see myself putting around another twenty or so hours into this game. I have over 250 in CIV V and I imagine that will reach 300 hours eventually.- The leaders are not unique and are just aren't interesting. Part of the fun of CIV is playing as historical leaders through history, not random characters who you don't care for.- UI can be confusing at times.- Also, not enough leaders. I do like the game, I do, but it just isn't as good as other games in the series. I may one day buy the High Tides DLC, but if not I can't see myself interacting with this game for much more than twenty or so hours, which is tiny compared to CIV V.I would give this game a 6/10, and would say it's worth buying when it's around £10.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												This is not a spiritual successor to Alpha Centauri. This is a thematic re-versioning of Civilization 5, with the same core mechanics, a change of vocabulary here and there, fantastical rather than scientific or philosophical explanations of new technology and research items, less voice over work, less dramatic score, no narrative progression or character progression, no sense of exploring a new planet and building a new civilization etc.One of the dumbest mistake in the game has to be the setting. You leave earth and resettle in a new solar system in a new planet with EXACTLY the same civilization you left earth in. For example, the factions you are rebuilding in this new planet could be from australia, asia, europe or others (the names has been altered somewhat) segregated by geography on earth rather than idealogy, thus effectively making the backstory something like "earth is decimated and its people has to leave the planet to inhibit a new planet all together even though we are are flying off in different rockets just so we can continue our discord and differences in a the exact same alien planet even though theres clearly many different choice of inhabitable destination..." Why not fly off in ONE rocket, to inhibit a new planet as a HUMAN RACE, while exploring and carving out our SURVIVOR in a new planet with alien intelligent lifeform? Why fly to a new planet just to continue what we are doing on earth? Its like if North Korea says "oh hey, the americans chose THAT planet to settle in. Lets spend billions of dollars, fly light years to that same planet at the risk of our entire nation and continue our nuclear threat on them just to♥♥♥♥♥♥them off for eternity!"  Well, with a flawed logic like that to start off with, I just couldnt get myself to believe that I was humanity's last hope in a new planet, the game falls quite flat in most ways since you are essentially just playing civilization on a new map, with new wordings and the occasional alien lifeforms to battle with. Sure, its still fun as a game but compared to Alpha Centauri, its science fiction story is too stale and common with little new ideas and compared to CIV 5 Brave New World, its just not as robust.If you look beyond the new sheen and wordings, its really just a gimmicky rehash of CIV 5. If your a REALLY SERIOUS science buff (and not just science FICTION buff), then its really dissapointing because the subject matter intrinsically hold alot of potential for the stephen hawkings kind of cerebral approach. As a narrative its not Asimov, its more like some high school level science fiction story. I say this with a weary heart, as I grey up playing Civ 1 - 5 and almost all of sid meiers games for the last 25 years and loved every moment of those earlier games....

content:
Posted: January 16, 2015
Civilization: Beyond Earth is a very difficult game to summarise.This is a franchise I have followed for a long time and Civilization V is a game I've spent nearly 500hrs playing. On the one hand it is an extremely enjoyable game and some of the new gameplay systems - the tech web, aliens, enhanced espionage and quests - provide a lot of depth; on the other the game lacks contextual relevance, with technologies, wonders and leaders coming across as rather bland.This is a game I expect to see develop with the release of content patches and expansions. Obvious areas to overhaul would be the satellite system (which is currently overly gimmicky and tedious), the tech tree (it has variety but it's hard to get a sense of what to research for a balanced game) and sponsors (previously called Civs, they are few in number and extremely shallow). The interface is rather lacking, with buildings and wonders using a monotone colour scheme making it extremely difficult to see at a glance what you're constructing and what you should research.However, there is a lot that the game gets right. The new expansion system - whereby you must create an outpost and wait for it to expand to become a city - means that you have to be more strategic with your city placement and defence; the quest system allows you to shape the game around your play style; the espionage system allows for capturing cities and requires you to monitor your own cities; wonders are better balanced, as the tech web means players can focus on different areas with less overlap; happiness has been replaced with health and is no longer as punishing, as well as providing rewards for higher amounts.Those with an open mind and an interest in strategy games will love this. Those extremely attached to previous versions or hoping for a straight remake of Alpha Centauri will be left wanting.Any true Civ fan owes it to themselves to get this and give it a proper go.

number of helpful: 111 of 199 people (56%) found this review helpful7 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
Solid foundation with some questionable additions // Recommended for fans of the series+ The 'one more turn' mentality is still present in full force+ Indigenous wildlife boasts much more of a challenge, of a variety, and of a better collective design than barbarians of the previous installments+ Combat against cities and units is as well-implemented and satisfying as ever; the audio design and smooth animations make for a very fulfilling experience+ Upgrades are free of resources requirements and are universally applied amongst all units of that type; does well to eliminate the need to hunt down and manage obsolete units+ Research tree is vastly improved; it can be daunting at first, but the superiority of this system comes through on subsequent playthroughs (once the player is more familiar with the 'branches and leaves' and what they unlock)+ The three possible affinities are a welcome addition and do much to offer great variety and customization in the mid- to late-game+ 'Favors' are a very welcome concept, and work perfectly to improve productivity of player-AI interactions and general diplomacy+ Sleek, aesthetically pleasing, and functional UI+ Effortless and rewarding to experiment with mods through the Steam workshop+ Satellites are a welcome addition, adding another layer of possible resource buffs to the game without cluttering the map+ Stunning environment designs; flora and resources really stand out in beautiful and creative ways+ Espionage and trade work in largely the same ways as in Civ V, with some minor improvements- Culture is now an empty and lifeless statistic in the absence of art, musicians, etc.- Confusing loss of custom game modifiers as compared to the previous installment of the series- Steep learning curve, mostly due to alien and unfamiliar terrain features- Finishing a game is underwhelming, and does little to reward the player, especially compared to previous installments- Health, as a resource, seems to be a slightly poorer implementation than the happiness of Civ V, and feels unreasonably difficult to manage effectively- There are no more natural wonders to be found, taking a bit of fun and reward out of exploration- Quests are boring and repetitive; they do little to add to the game's dimensions- The available factions feel somewhat bland and uninteresting- There are no faction-specific units; the only difference between factions lies in the starting bonuses- AI have almost no aggression factor whatsoever, even into upper middling levels of difficultyLockeProposal's Big Day OutCommunity GroupCurator PageSerious Steam Reviews subReddit

content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												This is an enjoyable game if you're already a Civ fanatic, but others are unlikely to enjoy.The game is very dense, and puts a fair amount of 'burden of knowledge' on players, i.e. the amount of unique information points in the game.  Civilization I-V have this problem as well, but they're able to cheat and alleviate it somewhat because of the fact that the game is based on the real world - I have some intuitive understanding that grassland or plains is better than snow or desert, I understand that a tank is going to beat a horse-mounted knight, I have some grasp on what the Iron or Gold resource might do for my empire, etc.  I know what the "farm" tile improvement is for.Beyond Earth has little of that - one terrain type is visually indistinguishable from another, it can be difficult to tell exactly what unit you're facing, etc.  There is a lot more to take in, and it isn't communicated as visually as it could be to the player.  There's a lot of mousing over and reading tool tips and not a lot of knowing at a glance.The game is devoid of personality.  Your mileage may vary, but after sinking a lot of hours into it, I just don't see anything endearing in Beyond Earth as compared to Civ V.  The sponsors just aren't memorable, and don't feel unique.  The flavor text that goes along with the tech tree just doesn't pack the same charm.The game isn't well balanced - I was able to jump from the easiest to the most difficult setting (Apollo) with no problem when I realized how easy it was for spies to take an AI capital via coup - domination victory by turn 100 every time.  There are a lot of choices in the game - affinity, sponsor, starting load out, etc - but because one choice is always the clearly superior option, they aren't interesting.  There aren't multiple ways to play so much as a right and a wrong way to play.As many people have noted, the hyped aliens are just barbarians with a few more units and higher strength rating - In nearly 80 hours of play, winning as every leader on every map type across every difficulty setting - I can say there was never a point where the aliens were even remotely a factor in my play.  This feature falls totally flat.All that being said, if you love Civ, or just 4X in general, I do think there is a likable game here, and I would recommend you purchase it if that is the case.  But this isn't Alpha Centauri 2, and with Firaxis having apparently already moved on to new products, the prospects of this game being "fixed" by expansion packs the way Civ V was seem bleak, so the majority of players should take a pass here.

number of helpful: 37 of 62 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												I give it a solid "5"  I disagree that is is simply "Civ 5 re-skinned" and really enjoy some of the new concepts and mechanics but Alpha Centauri it is not.  Gameply isn't streamlined and after a time, you'll find yourself irritated at the turn sequence.  Combat is badly in need of balancing and the various factions really need more depth; perhaps unique units or unit enhancements. They all feel pretty much the same.The health mechanic (aka "happiness") seems broken as well.  As your empire expands it becomes increasingly difficult to maintain a "healthy" empire.  You can mitigate this by choosing nearly every quest choice to go in that direction which then begs the question, "why have the other choices?"  It needs balancing.On that topic, the quests are a nice idea but being given a choice of quests would be better.  As it stands, you get some significant bonuses for completing them but will fail them if not completed in time meaning your game choices are a lot more linear if you want the benefit.In a word, the game quickly becomes - boring....All in all, a disappointment.  Fixable; certainly but it remains to be seen how it is approached.  I expect that there will be enough negativity out there to prompt some action.I have yet to run the Mantle verson of the game which I was excited to see, as I have a R9 series AMD card.  It crashes, displays on the wrong monitor and doesn't allow me to interact with the software when running.  I have had to quit out of it. I'm sure I get it to run but have not had the desire so far to tweak with it.  I note a number of people having issues with it so maybe some more testing would have been in order.On the subject of playtesting - Had this been given to a number of long-term Civ/AC fanes to test, I have to believe a lot of the shortcomings would have been quickly apparent.  Did I mention I am disappointed?  I have been a big fan of Sid games back to the orginal Civ (DOS Version) and the Microprose days.  The orginal Civ is widely believed to be one of the most important games of all time; establishing a genre.  This game isn't even close.

Posted: January 4, 2015
												Having played nearly all of Sid Meier's games, I've come to appreciate the innovation and complexity that each new release brings. However, this one falls short. All of the previews and magazine and website reviews hyped this up. While some of the additions are nice, such as the tech web, other key components of previous civ games have been neglected, or feel like they've just been ignored. There isn't enough "new" in this game to warrant it being a standalone Civ. Where the past Civ games have felt like a true step up and forward with each release, this is a half-step at best. In the end, this is a fun game, but it feels like a piece of DLC for Civ 5, not a new, standalone, breakout game. Please do not buy this game at full price, you will regret it, like I have.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth? More like Sh*t Meier's Sh*tilization: Beyond a Sh*tty F*cking Game. This is the worst game I have ever played. The fact that it was released at a $50 pricetag is a crime against humanity. Every single aspect is a failure. Boring, lifeless factions. Awful gameplay. You will be confirming trade routes 90% of the time. Combat unit strength feels extremely unbalanced and units become obsolete very quickly. Wonders in this game are nothing more than a joke. I remember there was one late game wonder that took or so 40 turns to complete, and then gave +1 food? No interesting dyamics, and an inconsequential effect. Win conditions are tedious and boring. Want to build 40 of the same unit? I know I don't. But if you do, congratulations, you can now look at this static 'you win' screen, leave the game, and play again! The game is also a graphics hog. Everything lags so much even on the lowest settings on my Asus G75. It's like they forgot to test this game at all. The new mechanics that were introduced, miasma and aliens, are simply nuisances that the player is forced to spend time to remove. It's like, here, we're going to stymie your progress until you buy this unit and get this building. It's not fun, and is absolutely a chore. You know what though? It's worse than a chore. I'd rather get up in the middle of the game and do the dishes than play this game. It's not even a game. It's a scam. It's 0/10 trash appended with the names Sid Meier and Civilization to trick suckers like myself and many others into buying it. I am writing this review to warn you not to be one of those suckers. And what's certain to come next is numerous patches and DLC to milk more money out of the poor souls who were tricked into buying this. Please, never, ever think about playing this game. Avoid supporting this garbage.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												I'm not going to lie, after seeing some reviews of this game, and comparing it to Civ V, I was not thrilled by it. But this free weekend has allowed me to experience Beyond Earth for myself, and I was actually quite impressed! My only point, is that this would be better suited as a higher-priced DLC for Civ V, as it runs off of most of the same features.They have made a lot of improvements to the old Civ V to make it seem quite different, and they have added some completely new features which add to the enjoyability of the game. Sure, it may not be AS GOOD AS Civ V, but we have to wait. Civ V became so much better with the arrival of DLC, especially Brave New World. This game shows so much promise and with DLC it could be loads better than it already is.Positives:All of the improvements to Civ V (inc. Tech Web and City States)New factions to play as and starting bonuses are a nice touch, giving each player the chance to be equal to another, so there are no over-powered factions.Generally fun gameplay. I enjoyed played single and multiplayer, the features are largely the same as Civ V so I could adapt quickly to understand and enjoy the new features.Negatives:The colour scheme. It's so dark and, I suppose, dank. There aren't any vibrant colours which stand out and it makes the game feel glum and morose. I hope a DLC can change the colour scheme, such as Brave New World did for Civ V.

												Was desperately hoping the franchise would learn from CIv V's successes/blunders and improve upon it's playability with this new release...However, as it currently stands I can't give this game my endorsement.- the online play is prone to constant crashes.- demographics are more vague than ever and access to strategic information is lacking, glitchy or non-accessible.- the trading post (CS equivilant to civ V) is almost pointless. Until they can fix what looks to be an obvious rush-to-release job with this game I would reccomend waiting.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												Essentially a different skin for Civ 5 without expansions, lacking polish and personality. Do not buy.Due to the way the faction generation and affinity system works, all factions and leaders end up being completely generic, other than the ethnicity of their leaders, which is a lot less interesting than developed characters characterized by their ideologies. Tech-tree falls completely flat as generic baseline sci-fi, lacking the interesting speculation into the development of future technology that was present in Alpha Centauri, and and the combination of the two above factors makes all the tech-quotes completely uninteresting. There aren't even cutscenes for Wonders or Victory conditions. The one saving grace is the quest system, but even that could have been handled better and less predictably (Like the quest system in the Fall from Heaven mod series for Civilization 4).In the end it just feels like a board-game. If that's what you're after, fair enough, but if you an actually good sci-fi game, go on GOG and get Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri. Or get the Planetfall mod for Civ 4.

												Disappointing! - Sid Meier is a guru of strategic depth and balance vs. fun factor. This game does not feel like a Sid game. It feels like a corporate fiasco, rushed to the market, incomplete, overpriced, simplified to allow for more expansions and more dollars. Stay away from it and let's see if Firaxis will have the decency to fix this without a $30 dollar price tag xpack. Its a step back from Civ V even in simple things like UI and Civilopedia. Mechanics are watered down... Religions are gone, world congress is gone, deep city specialization and great people gone, tall empires - gone.What's left? A broken, infinite city sprawl only strategy supported by difficult to manage OP trade routes.Sorry guys, I really wanted to love this, I'm a major fan of Sid Meier and the Civ franchaise, played every game they ever made (anyone remember "Railroads!"?), loved them all, except this... Its a sad sad day today.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												A colossal disappointment. As a huge fan of Civ V, I cannot really recommend this game to anyone that is a fan of that game, as all you're really going to get is a re-skin of the same game, in space. It still retains much of the headaches of Civ V, and creates new ones. Victory conditions are long, drawn out and dull. Faction leaders are lifeless random schmucks with zero personality. The AI is abysmal and still cannot figure out how to play. The tech web is a massive disappointment after you realize that every game, you're essentially going to learn everything with an affinity boost to create your victory condition. Unit upgrades are basically cosmetic in nature and each affinity is nothing more than a "victory condition" and cosemetic change.Everything about this game just seems rushed out the door, and very half-hearted. There is quite a bit wrong with this game that I could go on and on about, but really there is no need. Beyond Earth is a let down in every possible way.**Edit 10/30/14** I'm still putting time into this game despite my negative review and first impressions. I'm also digging deeply into the game to find some qualities that I actually like. I'm having a really hard time finding them, but I think this game does have potential to become good...it's just going to take two major patches and some DLC...or user content.Affinities need work, and research, again like Civ V: BNW, is the most important resource. Now that your "affinity" is directly tied to research instead of your actual actions on the planet, stacking science is again the main strategy for every game. Making Affinities tied to actions, reactions, quests and how you actually handle the aliens and landscape could possibly be patched in, and I think that would go a very long way to making this game a bit more robust. Affinity unit upgrades should also be more than just cosmetic in nature. I feel like just becuase I have the third Tier Supremacy Tank, that it's no different than the third tier Harmony tank other than visual design. Their stats are identical, and the bonus you pick every level is pretty much the same, or so minor it doesn't even make a difference. These units need to become more unique per Affinity.**Edit 12/9/14**First major patch was released so I'm eager to see how the game plays now, but from reading the notes they still have not addressed the main issues with the game. Depite their work, Affinities are still just tied to stacking beakers, so every game is essentially the same. The only way Beyond Earth is really going to be fixed is re-working the Affinity system entirely.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												For anyone totally new to any kind of CIV game who likes sc-fi themes, I can recommend it when it goes on a sale.It is a very solid complex turn-based strategy game which offers different kind of winning conditions. If you don't read guides and etc, this game will offer you hundreds of hours of fun trying to find out what is best under different circumstances. You progress and keep progressing by learning from your mistakes on different difficulty levels. This stands apart from the sci-fi theme which you can like or, like me, dislike.However...Build on the CIV 5 engine and the 100 turns pre-release video you'd expect this game to be CIV 5 in a different theme. A reskined and renamed game. And pretty much that's it! It is easy to relate resources, textures and names back to what they are in CIV 5. Really a somewhat 1:1 copy. I wonder how long it takes before workshop items appear that restores all to what they are called and look like in CIV 5.As BE is being sold as a stand alone game and not as an expansion package to CIV 5, you'd expect the game to progress in terms of bug fixes, system resource hungryness, gameplay and etc. But no progression on that.Random events are back from CIV 4 (or was that a mod?) and is the only additional thing. You can choose between two benefitting event options and that is the only gameplay that has been added in comparison to CIV 5. They claim to have worked on the multiplayer part, but it functions just as bad as CIV 5. Resync in turn 1, free techs being given to your opponents... Sad enough it is build on the same engine as CIV 5, but they removed the dx9 and touchscreen executable. Dx9 offered way less desync issues while playing multiplayer and the touchscreen executable in CIV 5 let you play the game without the game crashing while touching the screen.On the other hand they added mantle support to improve multicore performance, but hell i prefer a better functional product above mantle or a dx12 low level kind of api support.Looking further into the game there is some unbalance, unfinished work or too cheap reskinning ruining the gameplay.Playing on marathon in turn 75 ~ 150 and I have to put my city production to work on energy or research as I already literally build every building that I researched. This is the first time in a CIV game that I can't build anything anymore in a city so early in the game. Ofcourse I can put effort in researching tech so I can build more buildings, but w00t so early in the game and nothing to do.The cityproduction advisor tells me to build a building which improves the energy (gold for civ 5) output by +1 for each desert tile. But, I don't have a single desert tile anywhere near any of my cities so this building is going to cost me energy for each turn instead?Than the developpers crafted some awesome tile add-on called miasma (a marsh for civ 5) which gives you negative health for each turn you stand on it. By researching the correct stuff you can regain health when standing on it. A very neath idea, BUT... they did not change the code of the AI players when attacking defending. The AI idles in miasma losing health or attacks you from out miama... If they declare war you can just do totally nothing and wait for them to die in miasma!They should have made this an expansion to CIV 5, should have worked on the multiplayer desyncs and should have added mantle support to CIV 5 instead of this unlogic split. As a standalone BE is standing in the shade of CIV 5 as it offers less content, more unbalance and the very same bugs that CIV 5 today offers.

number of helpful: 12 of 16 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												I'm going to make this review simple and short.  1. A modder could of done this. You most likely heard it before now you're going to hear it again. The features that the game have added are little and insignificant. They even take some features out like Luxury recourses.  Quest one of the new features. Most are just killing 10 aliens, building some kind of building, getting resource pods or excavations. You get a choice usually when you build a building. All it is a chose of one befit or another. Like +1 Health (Happiness) or 1+ Energy(Gold)  Orbital Layer is nothing but lunching a satellite that you wont see very much over a piece of land with give some kind of benefit in a AOE/AOI (Area of effect, Area of influence). Nothing all that special.   There is only a very small number of units. With only upgrade with your Affinities.   Affinities give bonuses and buffs. These act like you ideologies.  There is now favors which the AI will give you when they want something you have and they don't have or don't want to trade something for it. You can then trade them in for Energy, recourses, etc...  2. Bugs, bugs everywhere. They are so many bug that I can even begin to list them out. It could easily take up this hole review.   Here's a couple, some Aliens turning invisible when attacked, and then making the Attacking animation take a very long time while you look at nothing. Quest bugged, Crashing at start up.  3. Hello, Do you have a Sweet kickass Gaming monitor that can do more then 60hz?   WELL THEN YOU PLAY AT 1280x1024! Oh yea. If you have a high Refresh rate you have to play at 1280x1024! Or you can play in window mode. NO! NOT BORDERLESS Window mode. Window mode. It's been TWO WEEKS since launch, and still no hot fix for it. They don't care. How does this make it pass play testers?  4. Do you have out dated computer that meets recommended  System Requirements with room to spare? You will get a Weird rainbow box pattern Graphical Glitch on the land when you load up a save file, or at random. This supposedly has to do with older GPUs. Even if you meet the recommended  System Requirements.  5. AI is still on the brain dead and weak side, or even worst. The AI never really talked to me or even went to war with each over. Maybe 2-3 time and they were very short.   6. No personality in this game. Factions are bland, have no personality. They nothing different with them other than a bonuses, a color and a flag. They might as well have called them by colors of the rainbow. This game tries to tell a story with some special quest and the victories., but fails hard.  Theres rumors that some features have been taken out of the game to be later resold to you as a DLC.  There isn't enough here to be anything that great. At the time of writing this I have 10.0 in this game. At about turn 200 I got so bored with this game that I did every thing I could just to my victory as fast as I could so i could end this game. Going through turns as fast I can. I still haven't finished my game.I wouldn't say walk away from this game, I would say Run!Update 2/2/15: I thought i would just give a little update about how this game has progressed. It took them a month and a half to fix their game, yet that patch even broke the game for a lot of people. That inexcusable for a AAA Dev. Most Dev have a patch within a week to fix the big bugs, and then patch the rest ASAP. It's been about 3 and a half months and there is still many bugs that haven't been fixed. Firaxis Games has been very silent on what's going on. No one knows what they're doing, or even how long it could be for a partch, if they're even working on one. Please don't listen to the Fanboyism. They will defend their purchase, and their favorite Dev, to the very last drop of blood!

content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												I am sad to say, but I would pass on Beyond Earth as a title unless it happens to be on some super cheap steam sale. There is a lot of new stuff to be seen in BE, including a few features that I would love to see in Civilization proper, such as Quests, Orbital, and a non linear progression. However, many of the bugs that were in the Civ 5 engine come along through space here too.Early game is perhaps the best part of the game. You start off alone and weak, hoping to not anger the planet as you explore and get your feet wet. However the longer you play, the more you come to realize the blandness of the game. Quests are there, but they tend to only play a minor part of the game as a whole. You end up feeling you have a lot to do, but none of it really matters. The AI is some of the dumbest ive ever seen in a Civ game. They almost never directly confront you, and even if they decide to war against you, they wont do anything with it. TL:DR Nice concept, but feels hollow and empty. It has the makings of greatness, but for now, it is just mediocre.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												I wish I liked this better. I wanted to like this better. I made myself keep playing even after I had the sinking feeling that I didn't like this better. It's just not very good, and I say that as a gamer with a broad tolerance range and a willingness to find something to like in most designs. There just isn't much here to praise even with a generous eye. When the gameplay is decent, that's because it's essentially re-skinned Civilization V. The tech web is really the only innovation that changes Civilization V's core design in some intriguing ways.Otherwise, this is totally lacking in polish, in meaningful iterations of Civ V's designs, in anything that would give it one-more-turn attractiveness. The factions are dull and uninvolving, which I think explains why the designers were so eager to discourage comparisons between Beyond Earth and Alpha Centauri. The aliens are just pointless nuisances rather than a major, interesting wrinkle in the Civ formula. The game could barely give a♥♥♥♥♥♥about building Wonders--they get no description and their impact is buried under their incremental bonuses. The interesting endgame units often don't even come into play. The AI is fairly bad, though that's not exactly unique to this installment in the Civ series. The end of the game just sort of happens without fanfare. The whole thing feels amateurish and underimagined, like the job was shoved at some interns. Civ V was underwhelming at launch too, but this has a much longer way to go before it's any good. I'm not sure that it even can be made good, compared to what was done with Civ V.

number of helpful: 12 of 16 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												Civilization: Beyond Earth is a good game when looked at in isolation. The problem with Civilization: Beyond Earth is that it will be compared in one of two ways by almost anyone who plays it, one of which is a unflattering comparison to a huge degree:1: Against Alpha Centauri (not really a fair comparison in many ways, but understandable given that this is a sci-fi setting)2: Against Civilization V (an incredibly fair comparison, since much is reused from Civ V and a majority of players probably owned Civ V before getting Civ:BE).Now, let's deal with the first comparison: Alpha Centauri came out a long ways ago, pre-dates the game that Civ:BE is based on (Civ V) by a good number of years, and Civ:BE clearly was not going to have the same mechanics as Alpha Centauri. So, what's left to even draw a comparison to? Well, the sci-fi setting. Believe me, there are issues with Civ:BE, as I'll get into, but the comparison with Alpha Centauri is mostly not a fair one. That said, passing mention in interviews with those working on Civ:BE was made that Civ:BE would be a sort of 'spiritual successor' to Alpha Centauri, which may be true in one sense but in another sense was only going to encourage comparisons to AC despite the games being rather unrelated.But the big, fatal flaw with Civilization: Beyond Earth is that it fails in every conceivable way when compared to Civilization V. First of all, if you own Civ V with all the DLC, then you have the classic 'Civilization Sequel' problem of every Civ sequel having none of the DLC features of the game prior. Even Civ V launched without religion, which, actually now that I think about it, was a standard feature at launch of Civ IV. But what saved sequels in the past was that new mechanics were brought in that couldn't be added in another expansion: in Civ V, we have 1UPT (1 combat unit per turn), among other things, which really changes combat. But then we have Civilization: Beyond Earth, and whether you call it a sequel or a spin-off, it's still the next Civ game to come out. And it does virtually everything Civ V did, with a few minor tweaks, a less-linear tech tree (that still has distinct paths for certain strategies anyways), and way less content.If you already own Civ V and all its DLC, you have almost everything in Civ V as well as a bunch of things Civ:BE got rid of. Civ:BE eliminated different air-unit types... there's only one air unit now, which has branching upgrades that give you a choice of an ability. That's it. No bombers. No fighters. Just one basic unit. Civ:BE also back-tracked to having no melee naval units. Civ:BE also has no unique music (all music plays for all sponsors). Civ:BE also lacks unique units (no sponsor has any units that the others can't also get). Civ:BE also lacks artistic details for leader screens (very minimalistic  indeed).Add all that to the already in-grained issue of every new Civ game losing some features from the previous games, and you have a really good game that is virtually identical to the last one that probably a majority of prospective buyers already own.Even 'new' features are not all that new: aliens are barbarians with a tiered system of aggression... affinities are basically an extension of the tech system since most affinity levels come through teching and not quests...  the tech web itself still plays out in a way where you will bee-line key techs and follow several linear paths. In fact, the tech web most-of-all is a let-down, because it's really just a different-looking tech tree you already saw in Civ V. To be fair, there are fewer pre-requisite techs for bee-lining certain things, but the new lay-out is not as different from Civ V, strategy-wise, as you might first suspect.In the end, Civ:BE is a really good game... but is one that is likely to irritate its purchasers, as a large chunk will compare it to Alpha Centauri despite the two games being quite different, while an even bigger chunk will look at it and find it to be far less immersive than Civ V and drastically lacking in content *even before factoring in DLCs*. That's right, Civ:BE is one of the first Civ games in a long time that is virtually no better than the vanilla game before it (and Civ V vanilla wasn't even all that good). Which is ironic given that Civ:BE does incorporate some elements from Civ V's expansions (trade-routes, for one). I can't recommend Civ:BE. It's just too much like Civ V, which with all its DLC is not significantly more expensive than Civ:BE. I can easily recommend getting Civ V, but not Civ:BE. In an alternate universe where Civ V does not exist, maybe then. But the fact is that Civ V exists and does everything better, especially the artisic elements. Don't get me wrong: I like Civ:BE and will continue to play it. But not nearly like I played Civ V, because Civ V came out first and was a better game right-out-of-the-box in terms of interface and presentation. And even content-wise, Civ V had far more interesting unique elements for the civilizations than we'll probably ever see in Civ:BE.

												I hate to pile on, but this game deserves it.  I'm a long time fan of the Civilization, going back to Civ I on the Atari ST.  This is by far the worst of a great franchise.  It isn't a horrible game - nothing like M003, but it isn't really worthy of the Civ, or Sid Meier, moniker either.  It is very lack lustre and lacks the famous, "just one more turn" digital-crack addiction of its siblings.Had this game arrived side-by-side with Civ 5 in 2010, it might have been received better, but it hasn't really brought much more to the table than a semi-ambitious fan mod of Civ 5.  The 4x genre has evolved in the last 4 years, and new comers such as Endless Legends really put this to shame.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												The game is fun. It's like Civ 5, but with completely bland leaders. It also repeats things that peeved me in Civ 5, like snapping me away from a unit I'm already interacting with to automatically put me in control of a different unit, or wasting my time by showing me somebody else's low-rank warrior fight a bug a hundred miles from one of my towns.The new aesthetic is pretty neat. Everything is very spacey.  Your towns and units change in appearance to suit one of three general game paths that you go down. There's harmony, which is coexistance with the aliens, and purity and supremacy, which honestly seem to be the same, as I can't tell the difference between the two. One's orange, the other is red, and they're about...being violent, maybe? Or being a militaristic human? I don't know. I don't think anyone does.The leaders? There are a small number of them, and they're meant to represent groups on earth that banded together. I.E., there's the Pan-Asian Cooperative. None of them are really interesting in any way. They have different accents, different colors for zones of influence, and have varying weak and generally non-influential powers. None of them have unique units. It's really a letdown. My favorite is one that speeds along espionage, as that seems to be the most useful. As the game goes on they have some kind of visual effect to denote the path they've chosen (they're subtle, and some paths may not even have ones, it seems), but you will never be able to see yours. That's a dropped ball.I'm new to the Civ series, and while this game is fun, vanilla Beyond Earth just isn't that good. I recently bought vanilla Civ 5, and this is just so inferior. When compared, the rulers in this one are weak and uninteresting, the wonders are nearly pointless, and the names of military units are completely unrelatable (and, by the way, the names of them change throughout the game - have fun keeping track!). Maybe expansions and future patches will make this game better. Until then, I feel like I've wasted my money...tl;dr It's Civ 5, with a new skin, the return of irritating features, and new boring leaders.

number of helpful: 152 of 280 people (54%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
												Absolutely incredible. Gameplay is similar to Civ V only better. There is a lot more decision making that makes you feel as if you were actually in charge of a civilization, and the results have real, almost tangible effects on the game. I felt like I was discovering a whole new world the entire time and really strategizing my resources and decisions, whereas Civ V, I often find myself in the same worlds making the same decisions. Here, the victory combinations and outcomes are endless. My favorite component of the game are the quests. It gave me something to do and incentives to build improvements, fight aliens, go on spy missions, etc. Similar to the quests given by city-states, but self-paced (no turn limit), no diplomatic pressure, and better rewards. AI is much better. I played for about 185 turns and no one declared war on me. I also didn't feel as if someone were nagging me every two turns. There are no city-states, per-se, but there are stations you can establish trade routes with and the benefits are much better (more science, culture, etc.). No one begged me for money, either, which was nice. There was lots of room for expansion, even on the standard map, so border issues were almost non-existent, save one time I discovered artifacts near Brazil. You also get to choose missions for your spies and what they can steal (if they succeed). Alien personalities were pretty random and I had a few explorers killed, but not as much of a nuisance as the barbarians in Civ V. Never felt as if I had to constantly protect my workers or colonists, and they didn't pillage tiles nearly as often. Few drawbacks: 1.) Resources and their management. Rather than relying on the a few basic improvements/resource types (quarries, mines, plantations, etc.) there are a lot more resources (which I liked), and most of them have specific improvements that need to be discovered by exploring the tech web. Thus, resources take a lot longer to obtain, are more scarce and harder to trade, and can drastically effect game play depending on your location and what type of victory you're aiming for 2.) I was a bit confused as to how expeditions work. I did a few, but there were times I would bring my explorer to an expedition site and couldn't do anything. This could very well be a big that requires what I imagine to be a small patch, but nonetheless it was a bit off-putting. 3.)The miasma was an inconvenience.Overall, the strategic value and adventure in this game off-set these things. I would highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys any games from the Civ series and anyone looking for a strategy game that really puts you in control. Still haven't finished the current game I'm on (I believe I left off at turn 185 which put me around 2900 AD from what I remember) or tried multiplayer, but I can't wait to see what else this game has in store. Overall score: 92/100.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												Having played a solid 40+ hours of this, I feel I can give a fairly straightforward review.First of all, if you are a fan of Sid Meier's games, especially in the last several years, then you will likely find enjoyment with this. It feels like 75% Civ 5 and 25% Alpha Centauri. I played very little AC in the past, and don't remember a whole lot, but the spirit of that game is noticable in Beyond Earth.Those familiar with Civ 5 will have no trouble getting started in BE, requiring low in-game-advisory assistance. At first the game feels somewhat like an expansion to Civ 5, but you slowly realize that it separates itself fairly quickly with the tech-web and some of the missions/quests.It's a lot of fun for a Civ-junkie like myself, but I still question the $50 price tag. There doesn't seem to be much change in the Civ 5 game mechanics to warrant a $60, but also feels much more than a $30 expansion. It also feels incomplete. Not like there are bugs of any kind, most of the errors in the game are the same that exist in Civ 5 and they are pet-peeves that could be worked on to improve stream-lining the gameplay more than "bugs". I just feel that the game was designed with limited flair and depth to make way for future DLC. Looking at how expansions were handled in Civ 5, I can see all sorts of additions to BE such as playing non-humans or a reworking of some units and the tech-web itself.One thing I have considered from trying to get a broader view of the variety of quests/missions that are unique to this game is the potential for a much deeper story, something that strays from the usual Sid Meier's style, a bit more reminiscent of Warcraft 3 in how that game introduced characters central to a campaign. Your units in BE improve as your affinity levels rise, giving you some customization and beefing up their strength significantly. This makes you slightly more attached to units than previous Civ titles. While this is turn-based and Warcraft was real-time, it would still be neat to see a sort of campaign mode added to set this title apart from others, since it already seems like a hybrid.Sid Meier's fan rating, despite it seeming prepped to cash in on future DLC: 8/10Overall rating for casual fans of turn-based 4X styled games: 7/10

number of helpful: 11 of 15 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
Like Alpha Centauri before it, Civilization: Beyond Earth breaks the shackles of the third planet and offers up a gameplay experience that is both familiar and alien at the same time.A friend once remarked to me that everything he knew about human history, he learned from Sid Meier’s Civilization games. Well, at least the stuff that he fondly remembers—not the Indian history lessons hammered into his brain thanks to the fear of an impending exam the following day. With Firaxis’s Civilization: Beyond Earth, however, there’s a different kind of learning to be had—you learn more about yourself as a person, or more particularly, whether you will turn into a megalomaniacal dictator with a thirst for blood, a defender of humanity in its current state of technological and social evolution, or a future-ecologist who has a curious love for all things alien.IT’S NEVER TOO LATE TO GO BACKIf anything, Civilization: Beyond Earth made me realise that it was never too late to go back; back from the ocean of triple-a blockbusters with obscene production values and downloadable content to a game that’s mostly about building stuff, indulging in a spot of faux diplomacy and spending several hours to get a minor Tile productivity bonus. This is interesting because Beyond Earth is doing the opposite as far as the series is concerned; it’s going forward. No longer constrained by our miserable little blue planet (which Firaxis foresee becoming uninhabitable in the future), Beyond Earth takes you on a journey to the stars—the story begins with a moving cut scene in which we see a father bidding farewell to his daughter so that she can find hope for us all somewhere else in the universe—a theme that carries through across the game.OF AFFINITIES AND FAN SERVICEThere isn’t much of a departure from the way in which Civilization fundamentally works in Beyond Earth—fans will be greeted with familiar visuals (which could use a sprucing up after all these years) and scenarios that require decisions to be made. While the game does allow for players to choose their own path by picking an ‘Affinity’, of which there are three: Supremacy, Harmony and Purity. Suffice to say, they’re both akin to ideologies from Civ 5, but offering military and other bonuses.With Beyond Earth’s considerably hostile planets, armies are of utmost importance. Alien life-forms can be quite aggressive, while planets are laden with Miasma, a harmful gas that damages units over time (at the beginning, at least). Over the course of several hundred turns, I noticed that pretty much all non-military activity plays second fiddle to the might of your armies and their quest for blood. Yes, you can still achieve endgame objectives without annihilating all other human factions, but having already built up considerable forces to repel alien threats, it feels like a no-brainer to achieve your goals through might. Besides, diplomacy doesn’t always produce good results given that the AI is pretty dodgy for the most part.CLOSING THOUGHTSCivilization: Beyond Earth is the absolute perfect follow up to Civilization V, with strange new worlds to explore and advanced societies to establish. What’s more, Beyond Earth’s sandbox allows you to really play the way you want—made possible by the flexible research tree/leaf system. The quest system gives the game much needed context while easing players into the kind of choices they will need to be making on a macro level, while the endgame is greatly affected by the path you take in terms of Affinity. On the downside, I found the emphasis on combat to be excessive—more so than previous games in the series, while the UI (despite streamlining) can still feel overwhelming to new players.My Rating: 8/10

Pros:✔This is still Civilization experience, so you can actually enjoy this for some time✔Immersive music and sound design that perfectly fits the new space setting of the game✔Overhauled visuals✔Affinity system allows you to choose the 3 ways to build your civilization: Harmony, Supremacy, This system was perfected in Rising Tide expanison by allowing players to create hybrid affinities.Cons:✘Quests system.
