And now dev's abandoning Civ BE (no second expansion pack and further updates) and concentrating on Civ VI. This is how they treat their fans, who actually supported them and bought this game.

number of helpful: 11 of 15 people (73%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												So, my impression after 12 hours: Can I get about $45 back?First, let's talk about the tech tree. I'll compare it to Endless Space's "web" tree fyi. From the first turn, the "web" in BE is fugly beyond compare. There are so many techs and one tech rarely leads to another tech in any way that makes sense. Endless Space (ES) has a nice, orderly web to it. Military tech goes up, science/industry right, growth/happiness left, colonization down. I don't even have to look at anything to know where everything is. If I want a military option, I go up. BE though, there are so many links that have nothing to do with one another. My first game had me research something that required a special resource, where was the tech for that resource? I still don't fk'n know, buried within a million other options. The Web is a horribly ugly thing.Second; AI. The AI is atrocious. Enemy factoin explorers can't figure out how to move, so they move between the same 2 tiles till I destroy it. Autoexplore is garbage, I hit that on my explorer and it sits there till I take control of it. Civ5 had AI personalities like Montezuma or Ghandi, but BE I feel like I'm playing against the same 7 people, all of whom are completely irremarkable. To top off the irremarkable factions though, the AI is completely passive. I've tried to anger it multiple times to no effect.Third; Aliens. These things should make early game a pain. They do not. They will 1 shot an explorer, but they'll ignore my colony or the military that is murduring them into extinction. Seige worms? They are target practice. They don't "seige" anything, they sit there till I've taken the required 20 turns to kill them. Yawn.Fourth; decisions. Here is something I thought BE was going to do well. My first game had me make choices, does my ___ give me extra production or food? Cool....next game I get the same exact choices to make and they all end up feeling boring. I would love to see some randomization, maybe a chance that something fk's up and my thorium reactor does something bad. but no, the same boring decisions each game. I never feel that the choices I've made actually make a difference. Some choices have you allow an invasive species to continue invading the planet or stop it, you choose and your affinity level goes up, but beyond that, nothing. Fifth; UI. So, one gripe I've had with most 4x strategy games is the UI, especially the Civ games. What's worse is that Endless Space has an amazing UI. However, BE's UI is worse than I could imagine. Sometimes the "exit" button is on the bottom of the screen, sometimes It's on the top.... CONFIRM CONFIRM CONFIRM CONFIRM and, you guessed it, CONFIRM AGAIN!!!!! When I make friends, I get the same message from all my other friends talking about how we are friends with their friends....I don't like the "Let's get our names tatooed on eachothers butts and be BFFF(yes, an extra forever)" AI, much less the fact that I have to reconfirm it a million times. ES is amazing because everything I do can be done with the left mouse button or the rmb quickly, completely, and, most importantly, comfortably. This UI though, has me hunting everything down. It's fugly beyond compare.Sixth; A glorified mod. That's all I can see this game as. It's Civ 5 on another planet but without civiliaztions that feel different from eachother. I didn't expect the game to be something so completely different so as to not be a civ game anymore, but I also didn't expect it to play it SOOOOOOO safe. Every design decision I see feels like the accountants decided to design the safest game they could. BE doesn't really do anything remarkable.It's a decent game, but it's a glorified mod worth about $15-20 and not $60. And, worst of all, it's an ugly glorified overpriced mod that does nothing remarkably. I have no doubt in my mind that I will forget about BE as soon as the next competing game comes out. It's a good game, it's just a completely averge good game.Final score: Gonna forget it within 1 year/10.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												First off let me start by saying that like others, I love Civilization. Got into it around it's third iteration and loved it, as well as, 4-5 + Alpha Centauri. I went as far as buying a Surface Pro 2, just so I could have a mobile touchscreen version of Civilization 5, that's how much I love that game. Despite a long backlog, it's the game I tend to play every night after work.Beyond Earth will not be replacing CIV5 anytime soon unfortunately. The first thing that made this game a complete step backwards was the lack of Touch Support. Here is a game that is pretty much a modded civilization 5 and they somehow made it even less optimized and unable to support touch input. Despite lowering all the settings on my SP2 it quickly crashes after 2-3 turns.So then my only option is to play on my gaming rig or stream it to the tablet. So I played through my first game on the gaming rig. While it wasn't terrible, I agree with everyone else. The AI isn't very intelligent, the leader screens are bland, aliens (barbarians) are really annoying, help is non-existent in the game or just not streamlined, it's missing things like advisor pages, etc... Health and energy, affinity and tech are all there to limit and draw out your city's progression.To give an example of the difficulty I had with this game, I was at one point bored enough to attack another city. I could see from their defenses they could easily wipe out some of my military. But a few turns later they were begging to give me a city. Meanwhile I can't even explore the ocean without a group of Kraken ganging up on my ships.The Tech tree is just convoluted and difficult just for the sake of saying "oooo sci-fi." Did I mention that I'm color-blind and the colors do me no favors..? Not to mention the Miasma that just seems to blend into the tiles for my eyes. I of course will parrot the same disdain for trade routes constantly bugging you for renewal.I want to love this game. I want to pretend that my disdain comes from it being different. But ultimately I feel like they got rid of a lot of the good and balance that was in CIV5. I know when CIV5 first came out there was a lot of hate and people felt there were balance issues. Hopefully the same will be said about BE and further patches + dlc will really develop this game.This will be the last game I preorder from Firaxis, next time I will wait for a sale on HB or GMG with all of the DLC at $5-10. Especially if touch support is completely dropped.

number of helpful: 29 of 49 people (59%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												I really, really want to love this game.  There's a lot to like about it.  It's gorgeous, the combat is meaty and satisfying, the core Civ 5 gameplay is as good as ever... but something's missing.I know it's unfair to draw comparisons to Alpha Centauri, and I'm going to try to avoid doing so, but it's disappointing how BE lacks any real, impactful way to conduct diplomacy or interact with the aliens.  There's no global council/UN sort of diplomatic institution.  The addition of "favors" doesn't have much of an impact.  And even for a Harmony civ, there's no real difference in your approach to the aliens; sure, your unique units have aliens in them, but the ones on the map are still as mindless and randomly hostile as ever.The small map sizes and the small number of civs also hurt the game.  Even a "huge" map feels much smaller than a Civ 5 map of the same scale, probably to make up for the fact that there are only a handful of civs--and those civs' leaders don't really seem to have the kind of powerful, identifiable personalities of their quasi-historical forebears.  The few snippets of dialogue each leader has only communicate the barest sliver of personality.  The ARC lady likes money, I guess?  Elodie is French?  The African Union guy is... there?  All of the techs have little quotes, many of them written by one of the leaders, but even these don't have a tenth the personality packed into, say, Miriam Godwinson's furious screed about nanomachine "homonculi" from (drink) Alpha Centauri.But the biggest drag comes from the most boneheaded carryover from Civ 5: happiness, nee "health."  Just as in Civ 5, it's an annoying drag that forces you to spend resources combatting it.  Unlike in Civ 5, however, you can't mitigate it with luxury resources, and you can't turn excess health into a powerful golden age.  You have to either keep building and researching Health buildings--which basically negates the entire point of the game's touted "tech web" system, since you'll need every single Health structure you can get just to stay out of the red--or manually take control of your army of Workers, since their auto-build AI doesn't seem to care about Health and won't build Health-boosting improvements without specific direction.  (They will, however, be happy to build huge swaths of Energy-sucking Terrascape improvements... which also don't benefit Health, which is dumb.)There's potential here, but this game is going to need expansions and mods before it starts to shine.  Don't buy it just yet.

												If you liked playing single player in other civ games, hold off on purchasing this one for a while; the a.i is weaker than ever, with it being ridiculously passive throughout the game despite my attempts to royally♥♥♥♥♥♥it off (unlike a few certain civ's in civ V). The a.i does almost nothing except makes a few cities even on the highest difficulty.The civ leaders also lack any real kind of personality and just come off as boring. They have very few lines and practically all non-spoken dialogue is word for word from civ V.The aesthetic for the tech web and so on is horribly designed. It is very hard to differentiate things or tell if the tech you're researching unlocks a wonder. It's all just boring as hell monochrome.The aliens would have been a great addition if they actually would attack your cities and destroy improvements, currently they just mill around outside your borders (even without city upgrades that force them two spaces away from your cities) even if you start comitting alien jihad. Sure, they'll actively try to murder your units when you♥♥♥♥♥♥them off/are within two hexes of a nest, but otherwise they really don't do anything.Espionage is very fun and worthwhile in this, with you building up intrigue in cities by doing operations with your spies in them, unlocking new operations you can do within them. You also get quit a few spies to conduct these operations with, so if you wanted to focus on that you easily can.Trade routes are a lot more essential in this than in other civ games, especially since there's no max distance a caravan can travel (just need a clear route) and that you can have two trade routes in each city. The changes to them have made the game much more fast paced, since you will have quite a bit of currency to spend to directly purchase buildings/units.All in all, I would wait for a sale and/or for the first expansion to come out to round out the game better, it just feels kinda bare gameplay-wise in some areas and has strange mechanics decisions in others (new cities being founded take a few turns before they're fully built and operational being one of them, it isn't annoying or anything, but it doesn't seem to accomplish that much in the long run). Do not believe the hype.Alternatively, if you have a few friends to play this with, this is probably the best civ to do it with to date, since the games end faster than in other entries in the civ series. Though there apparently are problems with the multiplayer, though I haven't really had any issues yet.

content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
												As much as I looked up to this game and wanted it to be good, it really doesn't live up to its title. Doesn't have the feel of progression that you got in Civilization, and it got pretty dull for me after the first game. Considering you start off with the ability to build roads, farms, mines, and generators(tradingposts like old civ) straight off the bat, and then later you are getting all sorts of tile improvements that are way better so you wind up having to build over half the stuff you allready made making you spend uncessisary amounts of time micro-managing your workers. (I've never been a fan out automated workers.) The Technology tree is, in my opinion, VERY unbalanced. Because of its web-like structure there are pretty much 3 levels beyond the middle. And when you research one of your technologies you realize that it would take around 30-40 turns to get a tech that is further away from it, so you research other techs instead while you get your science up. Not with free technologies though. With free technologies you can jump for techs that will give you HUGE advantages over everyone else. Say you research Physics, then that unlocks bionics which would normally take 60 turns to get from your position, but not with free techs. You can instantly research things that would normally be FAR beyond your reach until mid-late game. So far i've only seen a few ways of getting free techs, Franco-Iberia gives you a free tech after 10 virtues, and Slavic Federation gets one after they launch their first orbital unit. Also another way is if you put 15 points into the Knowledge virtue tree, which doesn't take long because the knowledge tree is focused on science and culture. By combining these you can gain technologies that are normally unobtainable until late-end game. Say you get 2 free techs some time during mid game and you have got robotics allready, You can then grab nanotechnology, meaning you can start building the exodus gate as soon as you reach purity 13. Using free technologies can allso be used to get affinity points quicker than everyone, and it doesn't take much to Upgrade your units into much stronger units. All you need is 6 points to get the 3rd tier Soldier giving it 24 str. where as the marines prior to it only have 14 str. , nearly DOUBLING your units strength compared to everyone elses. And once someone gets ahead in affinity there is normalling nothing you can do unless you can catch up, and catch up fast. Oh yeah and you know how in Civilization 5 you had to build any new units you got or upgrade your now-obsolite units inside your borders? Well once you upgrade a unit in this it automatically changes all of the units to the upgraded version. So you could be fighting a large group of enemys and then all of a sudden all of his men turn into super powerful Centurions (48 str.) who are literraly 2x as strong and the unit prior to them. Oh yeah, and because of that it means someone can build loads of units and then get one more point of affinity, having a much bigger army then if they built them after they got the upgrade. (Upgraded units cost much more production to build.) On the topic of affinitys I feel that purity may be a bit stronger than Supremacy and Harmony. Harmonies units abilities are that they get large bonuses for when they arn't adjacent to eachother and for being in miasma, and supremecies units get bonuses for adjacent unit to them and flanking enemies. Purity on the other hand get bonuses for attacking and defending. Their Soldier units can get bonuses when on defence and/or bonuses for unspent movment, along with the abilites to heal every turn with the Centurion. Then their tanks (instead of getting the same bonuses like the other affinities get for all of their units) get bonueses to their attack strenght and/or bonuses for unspent movement, (kinda the same but still a bit different), and with the Dragoon tanks they get 50% bonuses against cities. Also take note that their tanks are stronger than the other affinities tanks. Not saying that the other ones are bad, I just feel that purity gets move convenient abilities. And on the normal difficulty the ai are very unintelligent, taking forever to level up their purities making them very easy target mid-late game for players. Also I once played on a huge map and meet an ai whos capital was about a good 50 tiles from me who had a good location for a second city near it. Instead of settling there though, it traveled 50 tiles down to my capital and founded their second city in resource-barren location right next to my capital. Speaking of cities and resources, the removeall of happiness and replacing it with this 'health' system has, in my opinion, SEVERELY broken the ways you build your empire. Unlike in Civilization 5 where you could build many cities, just as long as you keep them relatively small until you build more buildings and improve some nearby resources to get happiness, you could have a large, vast empire of cities. In this that is nearly impossible, having more than 3 cities mid-late game you will still be struggling with keeping your health positive, let alone 5 or 7 cities. Why is it so hard to stay healthy? Because the only way to get health is through buildings, no longer is there any resourses to build cities at to make sure your empire stays in the posatives while the city grows. No longer is there any way of getting help from another Ai or Player and trade for a resource to get you out of a bad situation. All you can do is build buildings/and or raze every city that you can. In the end the customization is poor, "Choose good upgrade A or near worthless upgrade B.", honestly, who is going to choose +1 movement when you could have it heal every turn? No actual choosing what weapons, armors, chassis, or reactors like you could in Alpha Centauri. Affinities are pretty much glorified ideologies from Civilizaton 5. It runs off of the same engine Civilization 5 does which kinda makes it feel more like I paid for a overhauled version of civ 5. I could really go on a find more things to say about this game but I'm thinking I'll just end it on this. In the end this game is basicly a unbalanced version of civilization 5, feeling very slow at alot of times. I'm sorry to say this but being a huge fan of the entire Sid Meier's Civilization series I do not recommend it. If you are still intrested in getting the game for yourself I wish you the best of luck and hope that you have a better experience than what I've had. If you'r looking for a game that is like Alpha Centauri and more up-to-date then I would highly recommend you have a look at Pandora: First Contact developed by Proxy Studios. In my opinion it does much better at brining back the Alpha Centauri gameplay elements that we all love along with some newer features. Kinda a shame when the company that has been developing these civ games didn't manage to make a better sequel to their own game...

content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												So much disappointment here.The first thing I learned is that this game was made with the same engine as Civ V. That means most of the mechanics and the tools to modify them already existed. This game wasn't made so much as it was just slapped on top of it's predecessor. With all that I at least expected that the developers could put their time into expanding the game play and adding new features but after spending the last 3 nights with it, it feels like a gutted product. I couldn't find enough to like to justify the price or the name.Here is what I found missing.No religion - Now we have affinity instead. You gain levels by researching certain since paths in the tech "web". All but two of the victory conditions require you to pursue an affinity at the cost of a well rounded society.Confusing Interface layout left a lot of information hidden by default.Neutered Diplomatic options left you with little options when it came to protecting the new versions of city states.Boring victory conditions -You need to research a tech, gain x affinity and then construct a wonder.No cut scenes for wonders/victory 4 hours of playing and I was rewarded with the same tired victory screen from Civ 5.Terrible wonders that take way too long to build. I saw very few wonders that actually had an impact greater then a regular building...they just took 50-70 turns to build.I'm hoping for a patch of some kind soon...I feel like I got half a game here.

number of helpful: 15 of 23 people (65%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												This...well, put it like this: When I bought Civ 5, I played it for hours on the first day I bought it. When I bought-no, sorry, preordered-this, I played for a bit, realized I didn't know what I was doing, because of the nowhere-near-as-useful help system in Civ 5, watched the AI build wonders that I didn't know how to build because of the disorganized tech web as well as the fact that a Wonder looks like a normal building, and then played Civ 5. I really wish I waited for other people's reviews and give this one a miss. There's technically 1000 civs, no joke, but only eight sponsors, the things that would be considered actual civs. Eight's a bit of a step down from the full count of 43 with all expansions and DLC with no mods in Civ 5, plus, there's no feeling of dread if you meet a warmonger, no feeling of awesome when you meet that civ that's always your friend, and, since these are future civs, you have no idea what their personality is, especially their preferred affinity, as, it seems, that decides who your friends are. (Although these may not exist as I saw the Asian civ pick Harmony on my first full completion of the game, and Purity the second time, but since there are preferred ideologies in Civ 5, I'm assuming there probably is.) This game isn't terrible, but there are very few things that set it apart from Civ 5, and pretty much all of them have problems of their own. First, there's the tech web, which is a tech tree with less techs and higher science requirements. The tech web has "branch techs" like Ecology which usually give a couple of buildings, like your average tech from Civ 5. It also has "leaf techs" which, far more often than not, contain a level up in an Affinity and a bonus to an improvement or a wonder which does much less than one of its Civ 5 equivalents. Then there's the Affinities themselves: Harmony seeks to live in, well, harmony with the aliens and the planet, Supremacy turns your civ and its population into cyborgs, and Purity which does nothing but be human and dismiss everything else as "false." These Affinities, as said before, dictates who your friends will be, and it starts fairly close to the start. Even worse, it's quite difficult to change your main affinity, in fact, it's much more difficut than it is to change your ideology in Civ 5. None of the victory paths are familiar except for Domination, but the other ways are...odd. The Contact victory is essentially meeting God, the Emancipation victory turns all the people still on Earth into cyborgs, the Promised Land victory takes everyone from Earth to live on the new planet, and the Trancendence victory effectively makes everyone share a brain with the planet. These are more ridiculous than the Diplomatic victory in Civ 5, because there's just too many people on the planet to have one person rule over them. About the only good thing I can think of that doesn't have a defect somewhere is the Virtues, or Social Policies: Unlike Civ 5, they provide bonuses for adopting multiple policies horizontally as well as vertically. The game certainly is playable-I pretty much only play singleplayer in games in general-and I would go so far as to say it's good, even great if it was the first Civ game I played, but the first Civ game I played was Civ 5, and it's definitely not as good as that. Maybe when expansion packs and DLC come out, it'll be a pretty good game, but for a Civ game, the combination of unanimated character faces, or even the fact that their facial expression changes to anger when hostile/guarded, the slower tech speed, the lack of eras to know how far you've gotten through the game, the lack of unique units for civilizations (Affinity unique units do NOT count), the nerfing of City-States to Stations that give a fraction of what City-States gave you and the general blandness of the game (Civ 5 was a LOT brighter, as in brighter colours, as well as the generally absurd events that can take place during a game of it) leads to me not recommending this game. In the future it may be better, but for now, it is very disappointing, and currently not worth your money.TL;DR: Read the second-last sentence.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2016
												Sid Meier's Civilization Beyond Earth + Rising Tide DLCBeing a huge fan of space exploration and sci-fi fantasy games, Sid Meier's Civilization Beyond Earth fits my taste perfectly. It has enough new content to feel fresh, while also keeping the familiarities of the series at heart.Positives:+ Gigantic tech web where you can research new upgrades for units and buildings, which grant affinity points. These points further your progress in a particular affinity - purity (human focused), supremacy (machine focused) and harmony (alien focused). Each affinity has unique combat units and a different appearance for said units. With the addition of Rising Tides DLC, you can create hybrid armies with multiple affinities. + Many victory conditions exist, from domination to contacting aliens and liberating humans on earth, to name a few - so you'll get multiple playthroughs.+ The introduction of artifacts and research pods at the beginning of the game is great. Sending explorers to derelict settlemens, sunken colony landers, crashed satellites, alien ruins and more results in the chance to discover rare artifacts. Such items give either an immediate benefit or can be merged with eachother to produce a powerful building schematic. + Graphics are good, considering Sid Meier games are typically birds-eye. + I really enjoyed the atmosphere of Sid Meier's Civilization Beyond Earth and how this changed between map types. The terrain detail was superb. Depending on the map selected, you'd have desert or tropics, perhaps a frozen ice world scattered with tiny islands. It changed the way you approached the game and how you felt about it. Variety is important to maintaining interest.+ Another part of Sid Meier's Civilization Beyond Earth that I thoroughly liked were quests. Small decisions which influenced how you built your nation, which resources you acquired and which affinity you would lean towards. Do you choose to eradicate local alien wildlife or study them? There are probably well over 100 of these quest decisions in the game, meaning each new game can take a new direction. Mixed:~ Combat between nations is really fun but not very challenging once you've built a foundation for yourself (even on higher difficulties), it's usually the first 100-150 turns which you struggle in.Negatives:- Really hard to find any cons with this game. Extremely solid across the board. The one thing I would say is that the highest difficulty tends to result in unrealistic diplomatic backlashes, where it becomes unbearably hard to manage relationships and you have enemies on all fronts. I was really keen to try and finish this game on Apollo after beating every other difficulty, but it's too much of a chore than balanced strategy. The AI bonuses are so huge it's stupid. Overall Score: 9/10Definitely worth getting this on sale.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2015
												I dunno where all the hate is coming from regarding this game. Sure there are a few issues here and there but overall it is fun. Although many have compared it to civ 5 and argued civ 5 is better, i disagree. This game is similar to civ 5 but different enough that it has its own personality (i.e. affinity levels are how you level up your units), quests for you to do (which is new) and instead of trying to use characters based on earth history (albeit loosely) like civ 5, this game starts you on a new planet. Sure that path you choose (i.e. affinity) means that pretty early on you have to decide which affinity your going to major in (as this determines which resources you will need the most). Its still engaging. In my opinion this is no different than when I played civ 5 and had historical expansionist leaders nearby to me (i had to formulate a strategy early on to decide whether i was going to woo one or some of my neighbours or go full on military myself and quash my neighbours). This game requires similar decisions as people with similar affinity will be warmer towards you and more hostile towards you if your not. So all in all i don't find it detrimental that early on i need to pick an affinity. In general though the comparison to civ 5 (which is also a great game, but has been around for years and has had expansions and other dlc content added on over time) is not a fair comparison content wise. Civ 5 has been out for awhile and they released content that expanded the game...beyond earth just came out and people are comparing to civ 5 as it is now (not as it was when it came out..which was still damn good). The graphics are amazing, it plays similarly to other civ games so if you have any experience with previous civ games you should be good to go after a few games. New fans to the series will face the daunting task of anyone coming into any civ games (using the civilopedia and advisors often to find out WTF is going on.I haven't played this game as much as some of the negative reviewers simply because i have bought a lot of games lol..what can i say i love games. But i can still come back to this game and enjoy my time spent here (i just have to be in the mood to play a 4x strategy title, and have the time to to so, as i like to play through a whole match in one sitting) as any 4x strat fan knows it takes awhile to go through a whole game. All in all this game lived up to my expectations from viewing the early gameplay videos and developer videos. I read the reviews before i bought it and they recommended it too. overall i am satisfied with this game and have already preordered starships (as this game although a standalone will have some cross over play features with starships). final opinion...its a great 4x strat game, buy it if you like 4x strat games as there is a lot here to do, and its fun and has a good deal of depth.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												Really disappointing. I pre-ordered this game hoping for a spiritual successor to SMAC, and it instead turned out to be Civ 5 in a dull new skin. Actually, it is not quite that either. The gameplay feels more hollow than Civ 5 somehow, which is an accomplishment considering the additional game systems they have added, such as orbital satellites. Visually too the game manages to look underwhelming compared to Civ 5. Narrative-wise, the game does itself an incredible disservice by laying bare all the major plotlines right out of the gate, inside quest/win-state descriptions. There is no sense of mystery to anything, and it really beats me why they decided to do that. What was meant to be the player's new alien world to discover, feels instead like an uninspired sci-fi B-movie reboot where nothing interesting ever happens.  What disappoints me the most is the lack of ambition and innovation from Firaxis at this point of the franchise's life cycle. If you are looking for a 4X style game that actually makes an effort to break the mould, I would highly recommend Endless Legend instead. Those guys are actually trying out new things, building amazing worlds and factions, while Firaxis seems to be sitting on its laurels and living off Civ's inheritance.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2014
												Civilization Beyond Earth, whilst a very good game, feels like a good mod for Civilization V. If you have Civ V, in my opinion, you DON'T need this game unless you collect firax games. The only reason you would want this is if you have played every empire several times and you wnat something new but not too different. New players to the Civilization collection may want to skip Civ V and go straight to Civ: BE - don't. Civ V is a much more rounded game with much better AI and more choice. Ok, there are exactly 1000 different starting situations with the new set up game idea - which is very good but limited to 8 factions - but only three are really good adn meake a difference to the game. Certain factions are OP and whilst the patch fixed this, many are still always going to win.The Ai is awful. I settled 4 cities as close to the slavic federation - the warmongers of the gaem - and they told me to stop 37 turns later. 37. Then they were still 'friendly'. i then declare war and as cities are so weak i capture all their cities within 5 turns. Micro management needs more shortucuts. if you 10 citites you can have 20 trade routes and whislt that is great, there is no key to sewnd them on their previous routes which is not needed in civ as you have only 5 or 6.I promise this is my last groan. Improvements. Tile mprovements are great in this game but they cost TOO much. Really 2 health for a petol well? then you have £2 on top of that. AARRGG. i am just in positive happieness - but i need the petrol to advance on my victory situation. then the better farms - terrascapes - cost 6 energy. If you have to settle near tundra at the start of the game YOU ARE SCREWED. Restart the game immediatly. the affinity system is great and the fewer units makes it all so much simpler - but the affinity system is limited and it almost feels like it has been stuck at the end of the game to allow end game to be fun. I love the virtues as i felt in Civ V there were too many different paths to go down, the four is just the correct amount. in conclusion Civ: BE is a good game but has been shamed by previous civ games and after a long wait I expected more form the best stratagy game maker, in my opinion. Dont get me wrong I had fun playing but i think i prefer Civ V. I would recommend it but it is not worth he money you have to pay. With some patches, I think this could go to great places, but before them DONT BUY IT.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												Disappointing.There are some good changes to the Civ formula here, but it isn't enough. There's just so much that feels unfinished or half baked. If you're looking for a successor to Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri, this isn't it. In the end, it just makes me want to play Civ 5 again. Good: The map feels much more alive. I like that the aliens can be tolerated or destroyed. Eventually those alien nests become valuable, though, as they conceal a strategic resource.Mixed: I don't actually miss trading technologies, but what are favors and why do I want to gain them? Mixed: The addition of the orbital layer is kinda neat, but it doesn't really add that much. It will get some attention in the first expansion, but this is not a review of future potential. It's a review of what I already paid $50 for.Bad: The science fiction technologies available in the tech-web are sciencey sounding gobbeldy-gook. There isn't a solid sense of scientific or technological progression. Thus, the implicit narrative of progress is largely lost. This is a major bummer. It just feel like you're constantly choosing the next bonus. Bad: The endings are largely unuitive, anti-climactic, and unsatisfying. The writing and lore don't bring a satisfying or coherent sense of narrative and once it's done there isn't so much as an animation to pat you on the back. Worse yet, the old series of ranking, replay, and analysis screens are absent. About all the fanfare you get is a ticket back to the title screen. Bad: There's a general sense of unfinished clunkiness to a lot of the UI. It doesn't even bother to remind you what a city just finished building when prompting you to chose the next project.

number of helpful: 9 of 12 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 17, 2014
												17 December 2014: I would not recommend Civilization: Beyond Earth yet, but that might change in the future. See below for details.In short: The game as a whole seems LESS than the sum of its parts. Similar to Civilization V when it came out - Beyond Earth for now is not a good gaming experience. With time Civ V was patched and extended and became one of my favorites. I hope the same will come true for Beyond Earth. But  what exactly is the problem with the game? For me it's two things.First of all the different pieces of otherwise very good mechanics don't exactly come together because of the lacking lore  of the game. The story, the different philosophies of the factions and personalities of their leaders and the overall world setting are far from complete, deep or anything but basic. And when inevitably compared to its spiritual predecessor - Alpha Centauri which had epic lore, Beyond Earth seems pretty poor...for now.As a result the game does not escalate in scope, something that Alpha Centauri did quite well.The second problem is the "Technoabble" used in Beyond Earth. The naming of technologies, build options etc. is "clever", but really not clear in it intent and purpose. That kind of ruins the atmosphere. It makes you feel at times that you don't know what you are doing and prevents you from clearly setting your goals in game. Going through several replays of the game you will eventually figure it out, but IMHO it should be more universal and less clever to be more enjoyable.I'm hopeful that beyond Earth will grow with time to be much better.

number of helpful: 10 of 14 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												I gotta do it, it pains me but I have to write a negative review.I can sum this game up in one sentence: Re-textured Civ 5 vanilla.I defy anyone who doesn't think so to prove otherwise.Basics:1) Energy is gold.2) Health is Happiness (and no, saying they're different because you only get a -10% productivity at -20 health instead of your people rebelling is not making your point for you).3) Virtue is [culture].They function literally the same. Virtue increases your borders, just like culture. Resources, strategic resources, etc.. all of it is just re-skinned. AI? I played on Apollo, not once did the AI attack me, even when I was buying land all up on their border. You get a passive aggressive message saying "I see what you're doing", but that's it. I spied nonstop on people and got caught many times, blew up their satellites, made units defect, etc... yet all I got, again, was "I see what you're doing". You want to know what BE is like? Load up Civ 5 vanilla and play it on the easiest difficulty with no AI and that's BE. Wonders? When you can figure out where they are (hint, it's the smooth hemisphere icon with something under it on the tech web) are just like regular buildings with n+1 modifiers. Oh this increases the virtue in said city by 5% AND counts as a node? Why then did I spend 1200+ production on it? No wonder movies. It's an aesthetic thing, but when you grew up with AC busting out with wonder movies that made you FEEL in wonder, it's kind of lacking. Same thing with the tech. Uninspiring. There is no race to get gunpowder, or friction-less surfaces (AC), it's just clicking for a marginal improvement. And the reason for that is that buildings in the bases are underdeveloped. It's like the wonders are the regular buildings, and they just didn't do the wonders.Affinities? Good concept, atrocious execution. You get them by default for researching things. You want to play harmony but really want that gene tech? Guess what, you're bootstrapped into going purity as well (some people would call this "strategy" as I would have to balance tech with affinity. good point, Unfortunatly, it is irrelevant when I can simply research all the tech and have max affinity. So, I call it lazy execution of another layer of gameplay). Like wonders, affinities do almost nothing for the bulk of the game but give your units a different skin. Sure, there are SOME benefits per affinity. Harmony level 6 heals in miasma, but by the time you reach that level, getting +5 health from miasma is worthless. Same with all other affinities. The only purpose for their being in the game is to trigger some of the end games. Units? SIX (I'm ignoring worker/colony). Rover, Missile, Soldier, Boat, Air, Super. That's it. Sure, you can upgrade them for a marginal improvement based on your affinity level (and you get one or two new ones based on your affinity...yaaaayyyy, but they are, again, virtually identical to what you have already), but Civ 5 at least has the common decency to give you units that vary in skill and use. Better still, AC let you design them. Here, you get SIX. Unacceptable.End games. Too easy. You build gates/flower and then you wait X number of turns or put X number of units through them and you win. There's no race for tech and components. There's no launching with a 1/3 complete spaceship hoping it'll make it, it's either all or nothing.Gameplay: The only other time I've felt like playing a game was a job was when I was going for gold in GT and missing it by .0001 seconds. THAT is work and yet, somehow, clicking the "next turn" in this game felt eerily like that. I've never been as bored playing a Civ game as I felt playing this.The basic problem with the game is this: Like with recent releases this game suffers from one major drawback: oversimplification. X-com did the same (but it pulled it off WAY better), Simcity 5 did it, Deus Ex Invisible war (and to a certain extent Human Revolution) etc... They all did. It seems that now days companies just want to move product. However, because they've gotten so big, they have to move a LOT of product and they are so afraid that mouth-breathers aren't going to be able to handle complex computations and thinking ahead. So, in order to appeal to the broadest base, like Fouchet in Bad Boys, they cut their product with something. In these cases it's with "stupidity". What you get then is Civ 5 in space. Literally.In the context of complicated games being good, Civ 4 took the cake on that. But Civ 5 was a massive simplification. It's like they thought they'd streamline it and people were like WTF is this, and then they took it back to 4 with the expansions. Same thing with BE, but this time it doesn't feel like an honest mistake, it's almost like they knew from the start what they were doing.It's unfortunate. This game could have been so much better, and what is even more galling is that it is GOING to be so much better....five months and 30$ later when the expansion comes out.Save your money and wait till this is either on sale for at MOST 30$ or they do some GOTY edition (obviously with the expansions) for 60$.

number of helpful: 10 of 14 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												I've been playing Civ V for a very, very long time, and yes, when the DLCs came out, it took me a little while to fully understand how the all tied in together, but it wasn't a big learning curve.Compared to Civ V, this game just want in a completely different direction and not in a good way. I've only been playing for less than an hour because that is about as much as I can handle with this game.After playing for as little as I have been, here's what I can take away from this game:- The learning curve is you start out with the game turning on and then it just go right through the roof with the rest of it.- It's not really clear the tech paths and how they are applied to the game.- Yes, they do explain a few of the new features, but my issue with it is it's almost counter intutitive to what was in Civ V.- They put too much, too soon on the game when you first start out. When we started in Civ V, a city, a unit, some hidden ruins, some state cities, and then the other AIs. All of it pretty straightforward. Here, they give you crashed space craft, aliens that seem to be able to kill you out right, AIs who seem to be able to get the upper hand faster than you, etc. and this was all on easy, are you kidding me?!Do yourself a favor and do not buy this game. The only other game that is similar to this and more fun, IMO, is Endless Legend. It's basically like Civ V, but with a more magical theme to it along with some very interesting game play that is difficult at first, but you really get the hang of it.I'm going to try and give Civ: BE another chance and at least try to play one game, but overall, don't buy this game. Just don't.I'll update this review once I get a game fully completed.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												as you can see i obviously havent played a whole whole lot of civ BE so dont use only my reivew as a tiebreaker to decide whether or not to buy this game. during my time playing this game i found some things just outright stupid. health(happiness) is ridiculous. i understand its purpose to keep the player from massing cities everywhere but i feel as though it drops too dramatically. i also deeply detest the same basic units just upgraded to have a different bonus. heres your infantry. heres your land rovers. heres your ranged and heres your siege weapons. can we throw anything else into the mix like civ V did with different factions having special units that would help them out alot at their prime in the game? orbital units are helpful in some ways but too much of a hassle for my taste. aliens will rage to to no end if you hit them once ever until you completely erradicate them, and then be ready for all the other civilizations to be on you for harming the bugs. theres really not much i like about this game. there arent luxury goods you can get to increase health. its like whats even the point of having chitin and resilin. even gold and copper dont give you energy(money) from what i understand. just smh. i wish it was better. im not sure how one would make it better but i expected more.

number of helpful: 11 of 16 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												First, i am comparing this game to Alpha Centauri. Ruthlessly. Why, you ask? Because Beyond Earth was called „spiritual successor“ of that game. And because Alpha Centauri is truly a pearl of a game that sets the tone of every sci-fi Civ-like game in the future. Second, I deleted my original review and added this more improved, more poisonous and better review instead. Now, let us start. -	The factions. Alpha Centauri had sever distinct factions. All of them were given proper personalities, they played different, they felt different, the AI treated them different. From fungus-covered territory of Lady Gaia to industrial lands of Chairman Yang, they were all different. And the quotes! People still quote the words of all of them and remember them. In CBE, the factions lack any personality. Previous Civs had the historic figures that would mean something to you, but in CBE, there are bland characters that add to nothing, are not really different and are completely forgettable. -	The affinities. You can go for purity, harmony and supremacy- meaning staying human, becoming cyborg and hugging aliens. In theory. In practice, they are completely cosmetic and don’t matter much. You get some slight differences in units and cities use a bit different skin. That is all. And it is not logical- you can become purity without killing a single alien and you can become an alien-hugger harmony player and you can wipe out the entire alien population of the world without any penalty. Mostly- you can make a choice that does not matter. -	The aliens. They were supposed to be different then barbarians in the Civ games- and they are. Unfortunately, they are more like neutered space-alien-barbarians. Never in my game had i had one attacking my cities. Especially when there is improvement that keeps them at least 2 squares away from the city. Even in the beginning, they are a no-threat. And even if you murder them by dozens, the aliens don’t seem to mind. Not more hostile reaction, aliens taking the offensive or something. Nothing. Even though there is first level harmony affinity that makes the alien hostility to come down easier and that does basically nothing. -	The victories. Whatever victory you achieve doesn’t matter much. You get an uninspired pop-up text with a pretty picture saying basically „Congrats you won“ and voila, here comes the main screen. And all the victories except conquest one are basically science victories, where you have to build stuff and do some stuff as well. -	The diplomacy. As bad as in Civ 5. Combine that with bland factions mentioned before and the diplomacy becomes a bore. Plus, no clear view on how one faction is feeling towards the other? Are the Polynesians and Africans close or do they hate each other’s guts? No way to tell? In addition, no Planetary Council or UN-like feature where you decide global things. And the city-states, now dubbed as “stations” are even less of a value then in Civ 5. You cannot interact with them diplomatically. You cannot warn other players who are attacking the station you are trading with stop, you cannot declare war on them. Or you can declare war on them by moving your melee troop (yes, the soldiers/marines are called melee troops) and attack the station. That is declaring war- no other way. And the AI is not aggressive. Wars are few and usually end up in status quo. -	The planet. Looks like ye goode olde Earth, but perhaps with different skin and different kind of neutered barbarians roaming around. Terrain types are the same, terrain bonuses are the same, mountains have bluish skin. The resources are a bit different and occasionally, you see floating rocks or green goo. You feel right at home if you have played Civ 5- but is the point of Beyond Earth to feel right at home?-	The military. Less units then in Civ 5. One type of ship and one type of aircraft. Oh, and a carrier. No choppers, no bombers, no fighters, no heavy battleships and light destroyers. Same with land units- one melee unit, one ranged, one tank or cavalry like things and one catapult with missiles. Plus some affinity-specific units. One unit per square, soldiers and tanks are referred as “melee” units. Guess they use the butts of their guns. They also upgrade automatically when you gain affinity level- that is kind of nice. But adds to confusion- suddenly all your soldiers are called Cobras or whatnot. And the combat is quite similar to Civ 5, only you see less, because AI is not very aggressive. -	Quest system. Oh, the system that was going to bring the game to life! Really? Don’t hold your breath… Around 90% of the quest decisions are choosing what bonus to add to your building. So, do you want +1 health or +1 production to your new fancy clinic? Rest of them- you have to work really hard to fail and usually you get bonuses to your currently most advanced affinity. Sometimes you get to choose what affinity. And that is pretty much it. In addition, there are minor nitpicks:-	When the colony produces a construction, it does not tell you what building or unit it finished- just that project is complete. If you have 10+ colonies, you cannot remember what you built. -	Wonder pop-ups- when someone else builds wonder, it does not tell you what it does. It makes sense when you get that someone build Sixtine Chapel, but less so when someone builds Archimedes Lever.-	When you build Archimedes Lever, you get a nice boring blueprint nondescript wonder screen that tells you what bonuses you get, but does not answer the main question: the hell is Archimedes Lever?-	Same applies to all techs and wonders and buildings. You get a name, not-half-as-good-quote as from Alpha Centauri and bonuses. To dig deeper, you have to look into Civilopaedia. Works fine for Civ 5, where for example “Gunpowder” and “Writing” or “Barracks” and “Temple” does not need further instruction, but when dealing with “Soma Distillery” and “Xeno Sanctuary” or “Alien Ethics” and “Dark Networks” in Beyond Earth. There is still more, but the review is already two A4 pages long, so I’ll spare you. The conclusion- Beyond Earth is more like a badly done expansion pack of Civ 5 then a standalone game. It might get better with DLC/expansions, but at its current state I would suggest to wait with buying until the price drops about 75%. Or just do buy Alpha Centauri. If you manage to look behind aged graphics and terrible interface, you discover (or re-discover) a truly great game hidden behind it. Thanks for reading!

content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												If you want a civilization game, this is not the game for you. This game is nowhere near as good as Civilization V, with worse mechanics and  the advanced cultural system from Civilization V Brave New World. This game is still a good game, with the same platform as Civilization V, but do not expect a full Civilization game. If this was an expansion, it would be a great expansion, but since it is a standalone game, I do not recommend it.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												For me and most others the real draw to a civilization game is progressing through the era of humanity, slowly feeling a sense of progression as you discover the wheel and later research particle physics. I stopped lying to myself a long time ago that Civilization is the best 4X turn based strategy game out there, but the sense of progression through time it gives is not matched by it's competitors. However, strip that progression away and the game is nothing. Building a library to introduce education and learning to your civlization feels great, as you really can see what you are doing and it's effects. Building some random Sci-Fi garbage like an Xenofuel Plant gives no sense of progression, that trademark civlilization feeling. Sid Meier's Civilization Beyond Earth was and is a nifty little experiment, but for a civ game it is boring, uninspired, and bland.The tech tree is kind of cool though!

content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												I've played well over 1500 turns at this point and still haven't had what I would call a "fun" game.  The UI is pretty miserable when compared to Civ 5.  The tech tree, for instance, doesn't really *pop* out anything except the affinities.  You get to search and hover over everything to figure out where the wonders are.And on the topic of wonders...why don't many of them build anything at all?  They feel very uninspiring and not very wonderful at all.  I built 3 or 4 last game and not a single one of them had a building on the landscape.The aliens are annoying.  You go from barbarians that can be turned off or at their worst can be defeated in a 100 turns or so to aliens that are never ending, respawn nests, and harass your units ceaselessly.  Or, you can build your tech tree to focus on being friendly and adapting to them.  Who cares though?  That isn't really very interesting, and again, the lack of anything physical from this (other than alien units) is very bland.As for the AI, it is downright annoying.  Diplomacy is one thing.  Being spammed by the competition every single turn with the exact same boring audio and requests is awful.  It doesn't take very long for their voices (especially the Asian lady) to grind on your ears like nails on a chalkboard.  Speaking of annoying, the trading is just awful.  Every 20 - 30 turns you have to reassign your traders.  They should adjust this to only needing interaction if they are attacked, the city is attacked/under siege, or if something changes with your relations with the other faction.  If you have 10 - 20 trade convoys or vessels running, you can easily expect to spend 50% of your interactions in the game just managing them.Oh, another UI problem....the victory types aren't explained.  You can hover over most things in the setup of the game and get some information, but the victory types just say Domination (ok, duh), Contact, Promised Land, Emancipation and Transcendence.  I had to look them up to figure out what some of them were.The game **could** be fun, but it really is just a slightly different take on past Civ games with less of a physical presence in the world.  Most of the things you do augment what you've already built, not build anything new.  It is very common to have the territory and your units looking bland and similar at turn 1 and turn 200.As it currently stands, I would not recommend this game.  Civilization 5 was so well done, has so many mods, and the expansions are actually most of what this game contains.  There is no reason to upgrade, and it is arguable that this is not an upgrade at all.

number of helpful: 13 of 20 people (65%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												This is of course subject to change once it's balanced, but right now I do not recommend the game. This is coming from someone who happily has played 400+ hours of Civ V too.It feels like a poorly balanced Civ V mod. There are some novel things in there - the affinity trees for instance are pretty neat. The questing (done better in Endless Legend) is also ok as is the esponiage. But there are too many annoyances - health severely limiting growth, overly aggressive native life forms, oribtal layer not being very well developed, bad AI - combined with balance problems and a real lack of personality make this one a pass. Frankly, I've found myself clicking "next turn" over and over again because the game punishes you from exploring, the health problems prevents you from conquering and there's nothing else to do. What's the most maddening thing is that Civ V encountered - and then patched OUT - many of these same issues. There's no excuse for them to happen in Beyond Earth.The real killer is the lack of personalities. Yeah, I know that this game isn't a remake of SMAC but it's supposed to be inspired by it. Well, the thing that SMAC did that was so innovative was to give each faction a very distinct - almost unique - personality. The wonder movies, diplomacy and even the tech tree descriptions were all written around those personalities. Instead of copying this strength, the factions here are all faceless until far too late into the game (and by then it's too late). It's an absolute deal killer.Even after patches it's still a collection of half-baked ideas that simply don't work together. There are far, far better 4x games on the market. Skip this one.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												The first 100 turns or so hooked me.  The next couple hundred made me wish I could relive the first 100.  Becomes grindy and repetitive due to simplification and stripping down the Civ formula, especially if your a vet of Civ5 w/expansions.Brief +/- based on my playthrough+ The aliens.  In the beginning they're tough customers.  Honeymoon ends early...+ Great art style from units to cities to map+ The tech tree/map takes some getting use to but is interesting, but...+ The three affinities, but...- - Civilization "Health".  Mine was beyond -100 for the last 60 turns and it didn't hinder my ability to continue on.  Maybe, someday I'll go back and learn more...maybe.- ...how the three affinities are unlocked in the tech tree actually take away from replayability.  You're going to want to     go all in with any one of the three affinities to unlock their full potential thus limiting the paths you take for each tech/affinity. - ZERO improvemnets on Diplomacy and AI (my biggest Civ gripe)- Legacy performance issues.- The aliens.  Once you start teching up you'll start to see how one dimensional they are.  I was really intrigued initially to see what part they'd play in the long run, unfortunately they become little green barbarians.- Unit levelups totally underwhelming.  One option only: +% to ranged/melee strength.  Really lame.- City interface bare bones.  (why are building, construction, details all default "off"?)- Mini map is way too small- No map overlay toggle like CIV5 so I can add resource icons to the map?- No great people- Wonders.  They don't provide a large bonus, but they're also not difficult to build.  Not very "wonderful".Overall, it feels like a WIP total conversion Civ5 mod.  A missed opportunity as the mid-late game really just feels like a feature-trimmed Civ5 with a graphics and names swap.  At best, this should have been a $15 mini expansion to Civ5.  Very disappointing.

number of helpful: 13 of 20 people (65%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												I’m a long-standing fan of the Civ series and I’ve logged over 750 hours (!) playing Civ V. Needless to say I’ve been looking forward to this for quite some time. Unfortunately, while the new setting is welcome, I really feel that a lot of what makes Civ a charming and involving game has been stripped out – the core mechanics remain similar and the new tech web is a welcome departure – but it lacks the satisfying depth of its predecessors. Something that you begin to realise playing Beyond Earth is how much the Civ series depends on a familiarity with its historical setting to give flavour and inform your decisions. You know that Atilla the Hun’s hordes rampaged across China and consequently what he might be like to deal with; you have an idea of who Ghandi is therefore what he might play like – their histories inform their game mechanics, but there are no such cultural touchstones here. Yes, the characters that lead each faction have certain traits, but they might as well be called “blue team” or “red team” – there’s no historical contextualisation or existing character to draw from and because of that it becomes difficult to care about them. I’ve seen it argued that it’s actually the inverse of traditional Civ – that instead of having a pre-formed personality which eventually becomes more homogenised, leaders start out as blank canvasses which gradually develop personalities shaped by their tech. However, in practice I’ve seen little evidence in the writing that this is actually the case, merely that you mentally note that a faction is leaning towards one affinity and they might now shift their focus in one direction or another.Additionally, because of the futuristic setting, it’s difficult to actually tell what you’re researching. Beyond providing stated bonuses to tiles or buildings, there’s no way to actually conceive of what the building looks like or its function. That’s fine when it comes to basic buildings like the early trading posts and clinics but it really suffers when it comes to wonders. I know that a Bytegeist gives me a cultural and scientific bonus but what actually is it? The lengthy text descriptions do shed some light on this, but it’s hard to form an immediate connection with it in the same way that say, The Pyramids or The Statue of Liberty do. Wonders have been relegated to just expensive one-time buildings. While you can argue that that’s all they ever were in Civ, a hallmark of the series is how well it hides the raw stats in each play-through behind charm and personality, something which is completely lacking here. This is actually where I really miss the little wonder cinematics which are also absent in Civ V – a little video could go a long way to showing what kind of effects that wonder has (something that Call to Power 2 did nicely way back in 2000).This also extends to culture. Yes, a culture bar ticks up a few points every turn and yes you can build things to influence it but it’s hard to see what the culture is actually representative of. Culture implies a certain diversity and identity and that’s something that Beyond Earth really lacks, especially because there are no civ-unique units or buildings. That’s disappointing because the intro cinematic actually suggests a cultural dimension which is absent in gameplay. The designers seem to be well aware that a lack of historical narrative is a problem and have introduced quests in order to give a bit of contextualisation and direction to gameplay. However, what these mostly amount to are just “choose one bonus, this or this” or “choose one action, find out what you get several turns later”, neither of which are particularly satisfying.The aliens are a nice idea and welcome change to the usual barbarians, but they’re still more of an annoyance than anything else. They have rather unpredictable AI – they’ll ignore units and trade caravans one minute while decimating them the next – at least with barbarians you sort of knew where you stood. Also, once your Civ has reaches a certain tech level, they seem more of a chore than anything to deal with – all they really seem to do is pick off trade caravans which need to be tediously defended. I was disappointed that there wasn’t more interaction with them. Even when you play towards the Harmony affinity which is ostensibly about integrating with the indigenous flora and fauna, there’s no obligation to keep the original aliens around and as they’re frequently in the way of valuable real estate, they just become cannon fodder. It’d be much more compelling to perhaps allow units to tame wild beasts with a certain affinity level and use them for more than just military units – then there’d be more of a trade-off between exterminating the bugs and keeping them around – and a narrative and gameplay reason to prevent other players from doing so.   Here I also think they missed an option to be really creative – different aliens for different worlds or even simply different habitats (curiously, all types of aliens seem to be found in every type of terrain) could lead you to assess if it was worth domesticating them.The way that difficulty is implemented will be a familiar gripe to fans of the series. The AI has a base level and the way that the game is made harder is by giving the AI more stuff, not making the AI actually better at what it does. It’s no more cunning at higher difficulties; it just has more to throw against you. I’m not really sure if I expected this to change in a new Civ game, but it doesn’t require you to make more creative decisions, just more efficient ones. And the bizarre and unpredictable demands of the AI  - notably the “stop settling near us complaint” – which seems to occur at the drop of a hat, seem to have been intensified here.That’s not to say that it’s not a solid enough game – the Civ franchise has had two decades to develop and the core 4x gameplay is decent, but the inherent charm, the soul of the game, seems curiously absent. It functions perfectly adequate as a collection of systems and numbers, but it doesn’t feel like more than the sum of its parts. All in all, in feels like a re-skinned and modded version of Civ V – but actually with some features removed; the religion stat added in the Gods & Kings expansion isn’t present here; you can’t win a cultural victory and the lack of diversity of units and buildings is disappointing.That makes it hard to recommend even if it’s not actually bad per se but it’s certainly a much shallower, homogenised game and a much less satisfying game experience.

												Civilization Beyond Earth has got to be, in my experience, one of the worst additions to the Civilization series. It is monotonous and has an uninteresting interface. I would consider myself a huge fan of turn-based strategy games and i love Civilization 5. It seems as though this sequel to the rest of the Civs is lacking in factions, interesting units, fun strategy and it certainly isnt as spacey as one made it seem. It makes me just want to carry on with Civ 5. There is a lot of improving to be done with this game to appeal to me. The game needs;1) A better landscape - The current one is hiddeous and unimaginative. 2) More factions - The ideas behind the ones that are there are fabulous, however they lack in being clearly more different from one another so i feel like no matter who i choose i will be playing the same stategy. 3)The release price does not at all reflect the games value in its present state.4) The Diplomacy interface is unorigional and too easy.5) Finally, the level of difficulties are not challenging, it's almost like a game for Civ Noobs.Overall however the game will be improved in the future i hope and it has some potential but right now i would not recommend the game in its current state.

												It has potential to become an excellent successor to Alpha Centauri.  If the developers spent "one more turn" on the game and polished things up before release there would not be so many negative reviews. content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												The game plays like Civ5 but worse. The game doesn't provide information very well. It provides lots of information, but some critical information like "you unit is about to die in miasma" is not displayed. You therefore have to keep an eye out for many things manually and if you forget about something you'll lose units or other important things. The research tree is not good. On one hand you could say it provides options right from the start, but if you don't go for certain techs anyway, you'll get problems in the game. The progression in Civ5 was handled much much better.Also from what I've seen the unit composition is not that huge. You'll always build the same units, the just look slightly different. There is no real specialisation. The differences are very very small.So far the alien race don't seem to provide anything to the game instead of being more annoying than barbarians. I thinka chance was wasted here. Also City-States have been reduced to mere stations that provide just ressources.The technology is solid behind the game, but if you have to choose between Civ5 and Beyond Earth I'd recommend Civ5. It's the superior game.

number of helpful: 56 of 102 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												I have over 1100 hours in Civ V, and over 40 hours in Civ: BE. As of today (30/10/14), I have finished all victory types except domination, and am working on beating the game on the highest difficulty.Firstly I would like to say this game is *not* Civ V. It looks like like Civ V, has many features like Civ V, but it is *not* Civ V. This is also not Alpha Centauri. Much like XCOM, Civilization: Beyond Earth  is a spiritual successor to SMAC. It brings to the table many new features, many of the things we loved in Civ V, and a few things that need improvement.The biggest difference is the new Tech Web. No longer are we confined to a linear path of building, but now we can branch out as we see fit, adapting to our enviroment, and investing our sciences as needed. This is a breath of freash air from Civ V, where going through the Tech Tree was almost formulaic. This allows for each game to be different in how and what you build, as well as allows you to quickly change plans should the need arise, and focus your efforts elsewhere.Unfortunatly, the Tech web is not intuitive. Since Civ V is about history, even those who know little about the past still have an idea what Metal Working would be, or what a unit called "Knights" are. With Civ: BE, as this takes place in a sci-fi  setting, we now have techs like "Transcendental Math" and "Genetic Mapping". Figuring out all the new techs, buildings and units are a simple search in the Civopedia, and though I enjoy reading through the lore and learning about these, I do not believe many have that kind of patience. Most would want to just jump in the game and play.Aliens replace barbarians, and do a good job. More dangerous than the barbarians, at lower difficulty levels they are hardly a threat, but at higher levels they spawn frequntly, and you cannot easily avoid killing many as you have to clear them out in order to expand. This causes the aliens to become more aggressive to you, and if you're not careful, you may find youself not only fighting the AI Civs, but the aliens at the same time.Quests have been added to this itieration in the Civ franchise. Unlike Civ V, where we already know the stories and history of the civilizations, we do not have that with Civ: BE as it takes place in the future. Quests add a neat narritive to the game, and rewards for doing them are minor so as to not cause an imbalace, and can even be ignored should one choose.The AI is no different than Civ V. To many players it poses some challenge, but to long standing Civ players, the AI is about as smart as a wet towel.Worlds are colorful, and Firaxis did well in making the planets feel alien, and the music in the game is nothing short of brilliant!The three aspects you can build your civilization around (Harmony, Purity, and Supremacy) are all unique, add great bonuses, and there's no penalty for putting points in more than one. I persnally encourage people to branch out, as even lower level bonuses are amazing. Much like the tech web, this allows for a different, less linear play style than Civ V did.However, Civ: BE does have it's problems. Automated pathing for Explorers often leave them moving back and forth between two tiles, and automated workers will prioritize the best possible thing to build, which costs energy, so if left to their own devices they will quickly drain your economy! In the last game I just finished playing, I had a mine built on a hill, and when I discovered one of the mineral resources, it did not add the mineral to my total, allowing me to use it, nor could I overwrite the old mine with a new one.Much like Civ V, after a few patches I have no doubt Civ: BE will be just as polished as Civ V. If you have played Civ V, and are looking for something different, this would be a good choice. If you're new to Civ in general, save your money for now, and invest in Civ V's Gold edition, where you will have a more polished game, DLC, and two expansions for cheaper price.Civilization: Beyond Earth will not replace Civ V, but it is a good game to go to when you want something a little bit different.

Posted: October 25, 2014
												Dissapointment in the simplest form.UI = no challenge even on top difficulty.Diplomacy = what diplomacy? no point of clicking and wasting time - AI will do it for you asking for open borders mainly.Aliens? No challenge unless they swarm you at start of game.In-Game Depth?The game feels like an unfinished product and is getting very very boring after turn 150+ each time you play.Tech tree?It looks like an exact clone of tech tree from Endless Space which is good but NOT for CIV genre of games,Its far away from intuitive and looks like someone tried to be creative to make it look different the the regular CIV tech tree form...but why?Its ugly now and you cant find anything in it.Game help (CIV Pedia?) erm...well its nice to read about buildings but what do they do?Wonders?Wait...what wonders?And where are they...oh yes. There are some special constructions but its very hard to make them out in the tech tree in first place to enable them to be built.No need for trading anything with AI/other players.There is plenty of resources and its just a matter of byilding your towns in few places and you dont need anything else.It becomes a boring race for who will have more military units or who will achieve 'science-kind' of victory.Oh...and the game tends to freeze and bug out occasionaly getting stuck  - you can still move and look around map or press ESC to get to the Menus but thats it...only thing left to do is 'save game' and restart the application.In overall....unifinished product with significant lack in merit, very much overrated by who ever rated it officially - those listed in the 'REVIEW' bit as 9/10 recomendations must have taken good money to do so or they try to 'shine' by sticking themselves under a 'CIV' name.TotalBiscuit - A cautious Recomendation = I am a big fan of TB but I wouldn't tag my name to this product even in such a cautious name...not untill they fix it and add more content that will make this game worth the money I spent  on it.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2015
												I had lots of fun beating Beyond Earth. It plays a lot like a full conversion mod for Civilization V, but to say that's all it is betrays the beautiful restructuring of game mechanics that this version posseses. The game feels more dynamic (thanks to a tech web, as opposed to a tech tree), making each playthrough a completely different game. While Civilization V (and its predecessors) was completely addicting, Beyond Earth makes each game a radically different experience, something that Civ 5 did way better than any of the other installments of the franchise.That being said, I wasn't particularly fond of the glitches. I've heard a few people mention them before, but when I sat down and played through Beyond Earth, I found them to be quite bothersome. None were game-breaking, but often they were reptitive annoyances that are completely circumventable... once you learn what they are. The achievement counters also seem to be off, as I found myself occassionally getting two points for certain things when one normally ought to receive only one... Not that I'm complaing about that though!And the achievements are indeed a stellar part of this game. Civilization V was the first game to add them, and they often felt very grind-y and unneccessary. Beyond Earth slimmed most of those bad ones out, leaving in just a few for those gamers dedicated enough to endure the small bits of grind and reach 100% completion.At $49.99 currently, Beyond Earth has quite a hefty price tag. I'd personally wait until a 50% off or more sale, just to feel like you had no doubt that buying this game was money well spent. If you can get it for that price or less, it's simply a steal.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2015
												It's playable, it's pretty, it's pretty stable at present, but it's not terribly gripping, and it doesn't move the series very far.The redone virtues trees with rewards for both breadth and depth are interesting, sure.The tech web has been done before (see, say, Endless Space) -- and it shares the common problem that the techs are a bit abstract and unfamiliar, lending itself to eiher ignoring all the names and descriptions to optimize for in-game benefit (if you're interested in playing *well*) or futzing around and finding yourself on an inefficient course.The sponsors aren't terribly different, the AIs still provocative idiots who aggress at the drop of a hat but have no clue about actually waging an offensive war without massive production bonuses and aren't amazing on defense either, covert operations are still grossly inferior to the Civ 4 mod "White Lies/Black Ops".  The UI is terrible and Firaxis should replace their designers with the guy(s?) who wrote InfoAddict.  And the fact that Firaxis has announced *another* 'SM' game in development suggests that attention and resources have probably already been shifted and that the Civ:BE spin-off won't be receiving much more.It's still on my SSD, but it's not calling out to me.  Valkyria Chronicles is a more interesting strategy game with more soul, and I'm more likely to go back to Dominions 4 if I want some 4X -- at least in the latter I can amuse myself by grafting copper arms onto Gelatinous Cubes and have them wield swords, and other silly things.  The AI won't keep up there, either, but at least I can be gratuitously funny and creative while I stomp them with werewolves using two-handed swords or maybe a moose trained as necromancer.

I'll still play Civ 5, but not until I have all the achievements for BE. Excellent job!
