												Very very disappointed.I'm a big Civ fan, been playing since the origional and I love sci-fi so I was really looking forward to this game.However instead I get a dumbed down version of Civ 5. I'm going to give it a few more hours and will update this if I change my mind, but I really doubt that I will.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												I've finally started playing this game, although it's been waiting in my library for a while now. I kind of forgot about it, but I recently noticed there was a DLC out, right about the time I was looking for something new to play, so I figured I'd get the DLC and give this game its rightful chance.I can't give you a thorough review yet, but I can tell you that at least so far (10 hours in), this game feels just like the previous games in the series, or at least like Civilization 2-5. I've never played the first, so I don't really know what it was like. I'll get to the specifics after spending some more time playing, but generally, it's pretty much what I was expecting, and what I suppose anyone who's ever played a Civilization game before should expect.Anyway, I know this game wasn't received as well as the last couple of Civilization games, and honestly, if there's a good reason for that, I haven't found it yet. I'm writing these very lines after forcing myself to stop playing, so I could get some sleep before a long day tomorrow. I could have otherwise easily kept on playing for a few more hours at least.More info to come as soon as I feel I have a good enough grasp of the specifics, especially in comparison to the previous games in the series.Update (14h+):While my general opinion of the game hasn't changed much since I started playing, I figured I'd share what I now consider to be its biggest flaw, which was also mentioned and discussed by many other reviewers. While the formula hasn't changed much since Civilization 5, the game's main backstory theme has, and in my opinion, it has changed for the worse. Up until Civilization 5, the series, at least for me, was about history, culture and progress. While Beyond Earth is also about progress, it lacks the other elements. Sure, each faction has its own history and culture, but those are totally alien and meaningless to me, as they're not an important part of the game, and I feel no urge to learn about them. If Civilization 5 was based, loosely as it was, on some true historical background, Beyond Earth is pure fiction in that regard. Some people may find this futuristic theme curious and refreshing, but I, for one, would rather have it the way it was before.Having all that said, as of now, there's no other strategy game I'd rather play. Not even Civilization 5, which has my highest playing time count (500h+) on record ever since I installed Steam.

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
												First of all, I love Civ games. I have been playing Civilization since the original. I have 770 hours played on Civ V. Also, I didn't start playing BE assuming it was going to be exactly the same as Civ V. Just like when Civ V came out, there is a lot of pushback from people who don't like Civilization changing. BE does many things well, but it does things differently than Civ V.Pros: - Tech "web" makes game progression much more interesting. Tech is much less linear and you can specialize if you want to. - Aliens are done well. I feel like they updated this part of Alpha Centauri well. Miasma tiles play an important tactical role in combat, and Harmony players can use them to their advantage. - Unit upgrades aren't tied directly to tech. I think this makes the game more interesting, as you have to choose between techs that will upgrade your troops and others that might unlock more buildings, etc. Units can also be upgraded outside the tech tree through quests, and you there is a degree of customization to the upgrades.  - Espionage is improved from Civ V with more stuff for spies to do. You can even have spies add to a project that helps your cities instead of spying. - Lots of choices for tile improvements, with powerful ones costing upkeep. Tech allows customization of improvements as well.  - Setting is cool, although the game could use a few more terrain palettes for variety.Cons: - There aren't enough 'civilizations' to play as. This is inherent in the setting, as they have to make up every sponsor instead of just drawing from history. But there does feel like a lack of variety over Civ V. - Stations aren't done well. These serve a similar purpose to city-states, but they only function as trading partners. However, they always seem to disappear, either from neglect (they just seem to die out), or from other people attacking them. There is no way to enter into diplomacy with them, so you can't defend them from other players. - The game is a little too easy to play against the AI. The non-linearity of the tech web allows you to upgrade your units faster than the AI does. Since they balanced trade routes, this isn't quite as bad.Overall, it is a great game. Is it as good as Civ V? Currently, probably not. There are still updating it, with much needed balancing being done (e.g., wonders have been much improved). But that doesn't mean you shouldn't play it. If you haven't played Civ V yet, by all means, I would say play that instead. But if you want something new, this is a great addition to the Civilization series.

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2014
												Beyond Earth is stylistically and mechanically a Civilization 5 mod.Basing the game on Civ5 is a good idea, but the game feels like Civ5 design principles held the game back.There is a tech tree web, but the freedom this affords is all an illusion because all the victory conditions except total domination (capture all enemy capitals) are technology based.  This means two things: (1) the game is a technology race (2) you don't get to enjoy most of the tech tree, because most decisions are forced in order to win the tech race.Pre-patch, there actually was a good mid-game military strategy.  But that got nerfed into oblivion.  So military option is a tech race, too.Sid Meier has long been interviewed about why the Civ series does not continue into the future.  He has said that Civ game concept is to (re)play through world history.  So there is an overarching fear to not to change too much from original.  While I play these games a lot, Beyond Earth promised something fresh.  It isn't.* Brand new foreign world or Civ 5 resources with different art and icons?  (There's oil and titanium, which serves the same role as aluminum...)  There are 3 faction specific * Tech tree --> not really innovative for reasons above* Combat -- this is stuck in Civ embark units mechanic -- it's 2600 and you don't start with hover tanks.   -- there are no melee naval units   -- your units upgrade for free with tech (hurrah ftw) but also your opponents (IMBA ftl)* There is novel affinity/unit promotion systemOn the whole, this game offers very little in the way of a new play experience.  It's mostly cosmetically atttactive TECH RACE.

												I played through one playthrough of BE, unfortunately, I cannot recommend this. While I am likely to play more of this after DLC is released, this game is hardly different from Civ5. The AI is no different. I knew not to expect any different gameplay, but the new features hardly have a real impact on the game as far as "wow" factor for me. The changes from tech tree to tech web is really nice and lets you focus where you want. The espionage system is much better than in Civ5. Unfortunately, neither of these make a large enough impact in the overall enjoyment I had to the game. It felt exactly like Civ5.The game overall is solid, but it doesn't have the new feeling that it should have, and it certainly is no spiritual successor to Alpha Centauri. If is a shame that I have to give is a not recommended, because I was so excited to give this game a try. It is likely that the DLC in the future will make this better, but it just doesn't feel like a new or special game right now.

number of helpful: 9 of 13 people (69%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												Don't buy this game thinking it's going to be anywhere as good as Alpha Centauri.  It's not a worthy successor to Alpha Centauri and I don't even think it's a worthy successor to Civilization V.It honestly feels like a reskin of Civ V; which would be fine if it was an expansion pack.  However, it's not an expansion pack; it is a full price game that should bring more to the table than what it does.  Civ V was a great game, but I already played it.  The changes Beyond Earth bring are not better, they're just different.Pros:Interface and game mechanics are similar enough to previous Civilization games that there isn't much of a learning curve.Interesting Setting.It's NEWCons:Lack of cinematics: There is only one cinematic in the game: the intro.  Everything else is done through text boxes, with the occasional voice over.  Alpha Centauri was made fifteen years ago and had one for every wonder. TEXT BOXES:  Congrats! You won the game!  Here is a text box explaining the ending(sort of).Lack of voice acting:  There is less voice acting in this game than both Civ V and Alpha Centauri Confusing world leaders, lack of story:  I haven't played Alpha Centauri in ten years, but I still remember most of the faction leader names.  I played Beyond Earth twenty minutes ago and I can't name one.Diplomacy:  No united nations/ planetary council.  Some of the same bugs and AI annoyances from Civ V are present.Tech Web: confusing, non-intuitiveInterface:  Hard to read sometimes.  Oh and if you're color blind you might find the game unplayable.If you're a huge fan of Civilization you might love the game, but you may feel cheated if you pay full price for it.  If you're a huge fan of Alpha Centauri prepare to be let down.

												Currently the game feels as if the vanilla is stripped down to its bone. There are a couple of features that give it a different look and feel as opposed to Civ 5 and SMAC, which is a good thing. But I can't escape the feeling of wanting a more immersive experience in this game. Deciding for myself which way I would like to go, rather than founding myself lost in a maze of research goals, with a fixed capital city unable to move it, an AI randomly asking for 'favors' and declaring war the next turn or not really feeling connected with the building options. This all makes this a too confined experience. Simply give me a map editor, or some sort of option to increase my freedom of play. I seriously felt like I wanted to play Civ5 again, rather than continuing this game and after I noticed on the Community Hub that this game will be 'milked' with DLC incoming, I seriously advice to wait untill a hefty discount comes along. I'm sad that I can't give it an overall general recommendation, but I'm really hoping for a redemption patch in the future or some free or low-priced expansions.

number of helpful: 10 of 15 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												Even going in with the "Civ5 mod" mentality, I was disappointed.  Don't buy this game now.  Buy it once 2/3 are true: (1) The mod community has grown(2) Patches and DLC(3) Steam-sale.[/b]Here's why (Summary):Lack of engaging media content.  Missing voice-overs, game cinematics, digital brushed art.Clicking.  75% of the game is trade re-routing, confirmations screens, and spy re-assignmentDull Civilopedia.   Get ready for paragraphs of meandering, uninspired, useless text.Half-hearted Tech Concepts.  Developed by a team of clueless MBA students Game Status/Infopedia.  Non-existant, even at the end of the game.No Ending.   Sure, you trancended into a new life form.  Here's a "you win" title and button for the main menu.Design > UX.  Get ready for a lot of mouse travel.  Characterization.  Lifeless characters say same the exact same thing, over and over.Structures.  These don't even make sense.Units.  One of the strongest late game units is a man in a power suit riding an alien.  AnnoyancesAuto-turnings skips over the ability to re-assign spies once complete.Broken Building queue.  You can't easily revise your queue.  Max 6 for no reason.Redeeming QualitiesExcellent soundtrackHandy Tech Web Search functionIf you're looking for awesome, inspired, bleeding-edge concepts common to science fiction lore (a la Star Trek, Star Wars, Aliens, Stargate, Battlestar Galactica) and iterations on existing hypothesis of potential technologies to come - you won't find them here.   The lack of content, polish, and deep thought into the game slaps you out of the richness and immersion that Civ is known for, and makes it feel more like a tower defense game with a "cool, sci fi, atmosphere." You know, for the kids.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												I am hugely disappointed, to say the least. I have waited for the reincarnation of Alpha Centauri for all these years, and have bought this game at the first possible occasion. What I got in the end was just a dumbed down version of Civilization V, which was (in my opinion) just a simplified version of Civilization IV in the first place. Alpha Centauri was an etalon, a perfect game, which required only a graphics' revamp perhaps. There is nothing new in Beyond Earth, neither it has all the brilliant features of Alpha Centauri (unit constructor, terraforming, unique leaders' personalities etc.). Some people say that they are really happy that they never played Alpha Centauri. Poor souls, they even don't know what they missed. Even when not compared to its spiritual predecessor, Beyond Earth remains just an empty husk, and no pearls will appear from it.I WILL play this game, and WILL try to decribe all its cons and (if I find any) pros in more detail. Affinity system isn't bad, but it's more boring and less flexible than the social engineering system used in Alpha Centauri. So far, I consider Beyond Earth just a worthless waste of hard-earned money. It seems that the developers haven't even tried to make something worth the name of a successor to Alpha Centauri.P.S. This is my appeal to the people considering buying Beyond Earth. Go and buy Alpha Centauri instead.

number of helpful: 11 of 17 people (65%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												Having been exited for this release for quite some time, I was not disappointed.  Beyond Earth is definitely a Civilization game, though there are many differences that set this game apart from its predecessors.  To keep this review relatively short, I'll make a list regarding the game based on what I experienced on my first full game of it.- Similar to Civilization V's policies, Virtues allow you to pick and choose bonuses which will assist in the development of your civilization.  They are extremely well balanced and work well whether you focus mainly on one of the four categories (Might, Prosperity, Knowledge, Industry) or if you pick and choose throughout.  Synergy bonuses are given for both building wide or deep on the Virtue Tree.- The technology web was very enjoyable for this type of a game.  The old technology tree worked extraordinarily well when Civilization was based on history, though the open web is an excellent change for a Sci-Fi futuristic 4X game.  You can, for the most part, pick and choose which technologies best suit the style of play that you are going for.- Affinity, is somewhat similar to the Ideologies of Civilization V, in that it affects your relationship with others depending on which of the three that they have chosen from.  I focused on Purity, the affinity that seeks to keep humans human.  They seek to hold onto their culture and turn the newly colonized planet into a second Earth.  The other affinities are Harmony, which is the goal of integrating into the ecosystem of the planet, and Superiority, which is the modification of humanity via technology to reach a higher state of being.  Each affinity has it's own sets of bonus, special buildings, and unique units that give each and every affinity a different feel.Though there are many other new features (and others that were cut) these were the three that I thought drastically differed from the Civilization games of the past.  This game is a lot of fun to play and I'm very excited to see the expansions that will be released for it.Overall Rating: 9.5/10

number of helpful: 11 of 17 people (65%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												There are a lot of good ideas here, but most of them feel half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Here are my main gripes, based on 10 hours of play.- At times UI is trying to be cool looking rather than functional. For example, minimap is quite small and contrary to store page screenshots, the color scheme has been changed so that continents and oceans are different shades black and gray. Not to mention you can see through the map which adds to confusion. Colors all in all are quite annoying. Sometimes miasma is quite hard to see, and resources of xenomass easily disappear into green mess that the map sometimes is (at least on lush biome I've been playing on).- Aliens are quite interesting but in my opinion they should be more varied and far more aggressive (note: I'm playing with "frenzied aliens" option on). Even when I killed them in the dozens and raided their nests they didn't seem to get more aggressive in return. Even AI civilizations are too passive. I can't remember a single instance where a civilization declared a war on another (in my 10 hours of playtime), except when I declared a war on AI player, and even then he surrendered without a fight.- Quest decisions are way too linear. About 80-90% of the time it works this way: You built a building and now some scientist/engineer has improved it, choose between bonus resource A or resource B. There, quest done in a couple of clicks. Same thing with unit upgrades, now you get to choose between instant heal or 10% strength. Unit upgrades you get via affinity are a bit better, but the choice is still always a binary one between 2 options. Can't we have more variety in our choices?- Each faction severely lacks personality since their leaders are straight up boring. Their specialties could be better too. For example Brasilia's +10% to melee strength is very unimaginitive. I would have much preferred Alpha Centauri like leaders with strong and well developed personalities, but that is hard to tie into Beyond Earth setting with the affinity system.- Oceans need more life in them. This time only developer's imagination was the limit and they chose not to utilize the oceans in any interesting way. How about super rare and useful resources in the middle of nowhere, guarded by krakens? Alien artifacts sending signals from the deep, inviting explorers? Aquatic cities?- No natural wonders. But why? They should be easy to implement and would add a lot of character to the planet.Tl;dr: Game needs more variety and depth (in quests etc,), utilize the setting better, more aggressive AI and some fixes to color scheme and UI in general. These issues need to be addressed quickly by the developers. It's a tough decision, but at the present state, I can't really recommend this game, even though I'm enjoying it despite its many flaws. There are many good aspects to the game: tech web, virtues, orbital layer, affinity progression... but right now the negatives weigh too much.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												I love the Civ games, but cannot directly recommend buying this one. For a high priced game, I was expecting a lot more.The game may be worth buying when it hit a 75% price reduction, but right now I really feel ripped off.The current feel of the game is an unfinished Civ 5 clone. There is some nice ideas, like the new tech tree and affinity, but the implementation is horrible at best.The tech tree idea is great, but the current "navigation" is horrible. The techs lack flavour. It would have been easier if they had just called it "upgrade 1", "upgrade 2" etc. (Comprared to the Tech description in their older games this is really lacking).The affinity system is a nice idea, but you lack control, and with the way the tech tree/upgrades work, it seem more random what you end up with, not that this is a real problem as all the cool upgrades is in the start of the affinity tree.Some more ranting...Like the old Civ games, there is some ingame documentation (Civ manual), again this is a huge step backwards, as there are no "links" between relevant stuff.All in all, this seems like a game build upon the existing Civ engine, by some interns, with some rough guidelines and a limited amount of time.Now My review may seem a bit harsh, and the game is "ok" just not worth the full price, and way below the usual standards of the Firaxis/Civ brand.Having paid full price for theis "product" I really hope they will do their best to fix the problems (crappy AI etc.), if the fix is in form af a DLC we need to pay for... well then I lost the last respect for the firm. If not, and the problems are fixed/game improved to the normal standard of Firaxis/Civ products, then I will gladly rewrite this review in a more positive tone.

number of helpful: 12 of 19 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												I really wanted this game to be good. I really wanted this to suck in hours of my life so I could pretend to be humanity's messiah of the stars. Sadly, I was mistaken. I'll start with the few good aspects:-"Customizable" Civs: This is a great feature because it really lets you fine-tune how you want to play in order to win. This customization also leads to unpredictability, allowing more replay value.-Tech Web: The tech web also allows you to customize what you're doing and how you're doing it with it's branching paths and tech "leaves" to research. Because it's so non-linear, it's harder to tell what other Civs are researching, and that leads to more interesting, varied gameplay.-Aliens: If Barbarians were cannon-fodder, then these are the guys shooting the cannons. Never have you felt so threatened by "barbarian" units as you have these guys. Naturally they eventually become less and less threatening with advanced combat technologies, although some of the aliens keep their threat kevel high even in the late-game.-Affinity-Specific Units: These are units that can only be unlocked through a combination of the tech web and having enough points in a certain Affinity. These units look cool and are fairly powerful, and create a bit of unit diversity.Now for the bad. With 200+ hours in Civ 5, starting off post-Gods-and-Kings expansion, I'm no newcomer here, although I've still never been very good at playing but always enjoyed the game nonetheless. Even still, I was able to win on turn 317 on the normal difficulty when I had trouble doing something like that in Civ 5. In fact, it was so easy, I barely even played. I more of just micromanaged my four cities after putting up my anti-alien fence building. Near the end I even just went ahead and started razing my neighbors cities with my ultimate Harmony unit JUST TO BURN TIME UNTIL I WON. No one put up a fight against me, even my neighbor-now-enemy had just a few ranged units, one planted in each of his cities! I also found some of the gameplay changes, like Happiness to Healthiness and lack of some kind of Beyond Earth-equivilent of tourism/religion, made the gameplay feel very dumbed down. The game also felt very bland, as I never really saw any other units besides a standard Marine, Explorer, and Worker robot until I got my special units, and even then only saw them (this is more relating back to the AI seemingly being incredibly incompetent, but still a con nontheless). As well, the color pallette seems to have noticeably darkened, and personally becomes much more boring to look at as a result. All in all, I think Civ: Beyond Earth needs what Civ 5 got; A GnK/BNW expansion that adds more to and fixes the base game. In it's current state, I regret spending $50 for what feels like a polished beta of a game.Pros:-Custom Civs and the tech web lead to unpredicatable gameplay with better replayability-Alien AI actually feel threatening and pose a challenge for a good portion of the game-Affinity-specific units look cool and are powerful; I was able to 1HKO an enemy outpost being built with my Harmony Ultimate unit.Cons:-Much easier/AI much dumber than Civ 5-Gameplay changes like Happiness to Healthiness and lack of depth (no tourism/religion or equivilent) make the game feel dumbed down/lacking-Lack of unit diversity; everyone practically has the same units until they start specializing down their Affinity; even then the majority of units are just reskins with some different stats.-Color pallette is much darker; I personally found it to be unattractive after a long session.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
												LIKED THE GAME, NOT THE PRICE OR HYPE THAT CAME WITH IT. DID NOT LIVE UP TO THE PROMISES.NOT WORTH IT. Keep Playing Civ 4 or 5 and wait until its on sale for a couple dollars or if ever a decent mod comes out for it. Or buy PANDORA FIRST CONTACT, I'm sure the game WITH the expansion is less then Civ BE which seems to be an expensive Bad rip-off of it.  P R O S:  Music is amazing! Really good stuff, until you declare war or something, then it turns to the same ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t Civ 5 had, pianos and Very Sad Elevator Music.  Sounds are amazing as well, the rifles firing and the machines working are top notch!  Very Small Download - 1.7Gb download, unpacks to around 3gb  C O N S:   The Sponsor names sound awful. Really, they sound bad. How bad? ... BAD! Very Bad. Some of them sound like something a beauty pageant contestant would come up with, like "My favorite Planet is the SUN! And my favorite country is Polystralia! Giggle, giggle!" NO joke, that's actually one of them. NO matter if they are possible and grammatically correct, they still sound AWFUL! Again take a look at what Alpha Centauri did. Or M.A.X. or Pandora First Contact.    The Research narration quotes are all MADE UP! We have THOUSANDS of years of recorded human history and evolution, and what do we do? We say not today wisdom! Today is the day for re-tar-ded crap to spew forth like a river of retardation where all knowledge and profound wisdom gets swept away,like watching a marathon of Honey Boo Boo or the Jersey Shore! All the Civ games until now had amazing quotes every time you do a research or wonder, Its one of the best things the games had done right. Now, all that is history. Pandora First Contact at least had very witty quotes. This game has turds in word format.    GOD AWFUL NARRATION!!! Civ 4 had Leonard Nimoy narrating the research and Wonders and whatever else the game had to narrate, it was AMAZING! Then Civ 5 came out and everyone ♥♥♥♥♥ed about the narrator, even though I still wanted Spock to be reading them, I actually liked the narrator since he sounded like Charlton Heston, but of course he wasn't, it turned out to be a guy named William Morgan Sheppard. Still, it still sounded EPIC and Awesome and if you could imagine a God-like story teller's voice telling the ordeals of Humans on their existence, you could at least imagine either one being it. ON CIV BE, they, I assume grabbed the nearest east European intern, and had her read all the lines in one sitting. Seriously! She sounds like Katia, the Russian Bride who was US$ 10 more expensive, narrating the lines with all the enthusiasm and excitement of an autistic man reading a phone book. With the budget this game had, they could of picked a real actor, or and old good one, ANYBODY who could act and narrate. I actually think she was probably amazing, spectacularly good at giving head, since that would explain why she got the part.  Last but not least YOU CANT CREATE CUSTOM SPONSORS OR IDENTITY OR ANYTHING. Endless Space, Galactic Civilization, even Master of Orion had a way of creating a custom identity with custom bonuses. Since this is all Science FICTION and all the sponsors are FICTION and the planet is FICTION, why not us play around with it? Maybe the intern who narrated it wanted it this way...  Conclusion, its still a great game, but not worth the money its costing right now at launch.( I assume its US$ 60, for me it was more, that might explain my mood at time of writing). With the exception to the music and sounds, feels like a Civ 5 Mod, nothing new brought to the table. Seems like an expensive rip-off of PANDORA FIRST CONTACT without the innovations like being able to switch weaponry on your infantry or open an Alien Gate and trigger an invasion. Wild life on the planet is crap compared to PANDORA as well, no giant Aliens the size of cities. No day night cycles.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2015
												Though not without its flaws, Beyond Earth is superior to Civilization V (itself a great game), and the closest thing to a modern Alpha Centauri on the market.  Its rich graphics, audio, and art proved delightful, leaving me wanting more.  The formula of turn-based strategy may be archaeic, but it still lets me get up for another beer or drop everything when the wife is calling.  My initial frustration at the near-identical gameplay mechanics to previous Civ iterations was overcome by the smooth graphics and slick execution.  If you're a Sid Meir fan, Civ player, or just generally like turn based strategy, this game is the best available circa 2014/15!

content:
Posted: July 11, 2016
												For you youngins, this game was meant to be a spiritual successor to a game known as Alpha Centauri. Alpha Centauri is still an incredible game worth checking out by the way (and that's where the problems begin). This game gets a thumbs down not only for not being able to live up to its progenitor, but also because it fails to live up to its real parent, Civ 5.Why it doesn't live up to Alpha Centauri:Alpha Centauri had a functional elevation system, you can even change elevations through terraforming later in the game.Alpha Centauri had a more robust troop customization system. Units were 'Chassis' that you could add 4 components to making for thousands of potential combos.Alpha Centauri had a virtues and ethics system that made a little more sense. Rather than pure unlock bonuses, various political philosophies had benifits and drawbacks and colored the ideology of your civ.The aliens in Alpha Centauri are an actual threat, not only that but their difficulty and agression scales with the progression of the humans based on a pollution mechanic.Why it doesn't live up to Civ 5:People have made too big of a deal out of this, but Civ 5 feels more immersive or rather the context is more relatable due to the history. There is always going to be something amusing about Jewish Germans allying Poland that BE will never replicate. That said the personalities, techs and designs of all the civs are so super boring in BE it really made this problem stand out.The AI seems significantly dumber to me. I had to raise the difficulty higher to get the same level of challenge in BE. This makes no sense to me because Civ is always going to be a much more popular and mainstream game, BE should be MORE challenging not less, for people who love civ and want more.By far the weirdest problem that BE has vs Civ is the fact that in Civ each type of point you acquire (aside perhaps from strategic resources) has a lot of utility. If you go science, culture, military, money, these resources are always useful and put you on a path to winning the game. Civ is interesting because of the way these different resources can interact. You can leverage your science to focus on culture for example, and this was expanded and refined in the expansions. In BE however there are a number of resources that just plain max out and become useless. Health can't benifit more than a certain cap (unlike hapiness in civ) and the capital resource becomes more useless even though you get exponentially more as the game goes on.Final Thoughts: What went wrong? I think when it comes to failing as a spiritual successor to Alpha Centauri, this game showed a failure of imagination to look at how to take the creative aspects of that game and bring them into the new Civ formula. It looks like they didn't even bother trying to be faithful to the source material in a lot of key areas, including the aliens and pollution, the elevation mechanics, the ethics system, and most importantly unit customization. It seems whenever they had the opportunity they chose to err on the side of Civ 5 and that resulted in basically everyone agreeing this game was a bad reskin. They aren't wrong.The more curious question is, if all deference was given to civ 5 how could they possibly fail in that regard? Really the only explanation I can come up with is the Civ formula of expantion packs. Whether it was an intrinsic part of the design plan to wait on developing certain content for expantions, Firaxis genuinely needs more money, time, and player feedback to develop the game further, the designers have gotten complacent in their ability to deliver a half-finished product that can ultimately be fixed through expansions. Players had no patience for this in BE because Alpha Centauri and Civ 5 both already exist and boast a number of features BE clearly just didn't have. I think Firaxis was planning on weathering this criticism like it did with the civ series and hoping that it would iron out the flaws, however with critics panning it, fans hating it, and new people seeing all the negative reviews on the basegame won't even consider buying and expanding it. Their gambit failed and after one expansion it looks like Firaxis won't be speaking about BE again.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2015
												Bought and played the game the day it was released.  Played it for a few days and stopped.  Year later I picked it up again and after a few hours I remembered why I stopped.Fun at first, but after a while the issues creep in.  The game is a decent improvement from Civ 5. The mechanics are identical but they were never a problem, graphics/animations/sound are good, the units are exactly what you’d expect from a Civ game (with a few interesting twists), and the tech web is an interesting addition.But, as with the last Civ game, performance gets exponentially worse the longer you play it.  I play marathon games, and by turn 900 it’s taking 2+ minutes for all NPCs to go through their turns.  The interface is clunky and unintuitive – worse than Civ 5’s since they’ve crammed in more things.  Navigating the the planet is a chore - aliens (like the barbs in Civ 5) are annoying, there are miasmas every other tile (which damage your troops), the other 1/3 of the tiles are canyons or mountains which your troops can't traverse (you'd think if you have the tech to colonize another planet you might be able to get over a hill).  And ffs let me rebind keys.  Let me use WASD to control the camera and hotkey things the way I want.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												After reading the reviews for this game I was really hesitant to purchase it, but when it became free-to-play, my dreams came true; I would actually get to test out the game before I bought it.Now, a LOT of people are saying that this is too similar to CIV 5 and that the gameplay is sub-par, but I don't think that. CIV:BE, while sharing a lot of aspects from CIV 5, is a completely different game. This game does not focus on a historical context at all. The methods in which things are done are different. New Concepts: Hoards - large groups of aliens together in "nests"Technology Web - Instead of an almost linear timeline, this acts as a web. There are sub-points to each point in the web. You are not required to research the sub-points to move to the next major point. They are completely optional. Which direction you take, however can aid you in how you win the game. Orbital Layer - Fight and defend from aboveMiasma - A thick poison fog that harms your workers/soldiers/etc when standing in it until clearedFavors - Need a resource, but don't have anything to offer yet? Give favors. This allows them free resources at the expense of this favor later in the game, however.Quests - Tasks to complete set off by an event that give you added bonuses.Choices - A part of quests, gives you the oportunity to choose how your technology works. (The Thorium Reactor giving you either +2 Energy OR +1 Production depending upon your choice)"Reskinned" Concepts: Health - Previously HappinssAliens - Previously Barbarians (7 different species of aliens, however)Energy - Previously GoldAffinities - Similar to Ideology, but not quite. /almost/ a new feature.Covert Operations - Previously SpiesIn my opinion, all of these reskins were concepts that needed to stay, but needed to be altered to fit with the game. What's so wrong with that? Removed Concepts: ReligonGreat PeopleCultural & Diplomatic VictoriesNatural WondersLuxury ResourcesResearch AgreementsIn my opinion, most of those don't fit with the game to begin with and they aren't huge game-changers. It got rid of Cultural and Diplomatic Victories, but it also gave you other victories that fit more with the theme of the game.Ways to win: Domination: Essentially, a military victory. If a player captures all the other colony capitals while retaining control of their own, they achieve this victory. Players who don’t have control of their original capital can’t earn this victory.Contact: The player makes contact with a benevolent alien race by discovering certain sciences and building certain Wonders.Emancipation: Achieved by players pursuing the Supremacy Path. The player constructs a warp gate and sends a “liberation army” back to Old Earth.Promised Land: Earned via the Purity Path. The player constructs a warp gate and brings the population of Old Earth through to the “promised land” of the new world.Transcendence: The option for players on the Harmony Path. This victory is earned when a player triggers the merging of the planet’s latent sentience with the consciousness of all living things.In my opinion, while this game is NOT perfect right now, it has a lot of wiggle room to expand into something great. However, it is a game that I recommend because it is not CIV 5.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2015
												The simple Yes/No answer is not really enough when it comes to this type of game review. If there was a "maybe" button, I would choose that for this game. It is not a bad game, but it lacks the same depth and playability as Civ V. It's got some great ideas and fun concepts, but there are too many parts that either don't make sense, or just fail entirely. The upgrading of units is a good concept in its self, however it is also quite restrictive. In early to mid-game you have a very small selection of unit types that are quite weak and by end game a wider range of powerful units become available. By this point however, unless you deactivate the victory conditions, you are not left with a huge amount of time to use them. There is also the big problem of Affinity specific resource. You choose your affinity quite early in the game, however you may find by mid-game you do not have enough of the affinity specific resource and so you cannot build the new units you have spent so long waiting for.There is also the issue of the tech tree, which is just not user friendly. You really must take time to plan out your discoveries at the start of the game, otherwise you could find yourself missing vital technologies. Also, due to the affinity upgrade system, you end up targeting the affinity technologies to get the better units, and so fall behind in other basic areas.The intrigue system was quite an exciting concept with some great sounding abilities at the higher levels, however you rarely get to use them (if ever). You can place one agent per city and give them missions that will raise the intrigue level in a city if they succeed (level 0 to 5). The problem is that it takes far too long to raise the level and relies on multiple races targeting the same city. This means you tend to end up only using the level 0 through 2 skills, which are just a bit dull.In all I was disappointed by this instalment of Civ. I love Civ 5 and just feel they have missed the target with this update - a real shame as Alpha Centuri was a great game. I recommend you save your money, and get Civ 5 instead.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												Many reviewers expected Beyond Earth to be Alpha Centauri 2, which it is not. Neither it is a Civilization V mod. It IS a new game, which, although share some features of Civ5 (hex grid, battle system, unit classes, wonders, resources, neutral units) and AC (ideologies, sci-fi techs), is played differently.The main focus in BE is on affinity (ideology) choices. As you specialise towards a particular victory type, you need to focus on specific technologies. Each next progress level gives you an affinity point, which in turn provides you with useful perks (upgrades) for your units + bonuses. These specific perks will radically change your units as you progress on specific affinity path (alien-like units, machine-like units or human units).The culture works in a similar way as in Civ5. After certain level of culture is reached, you can acquire virtues (4 virtue categories – Might, Prosperity, Knowledge and Industry - in 3 tiers), which work in a similar way as social policies in Civ 5. There are synergy bonuses for focusing on same category virtues or same tier virtues.Also, there are quests, research pods and exploration areas, which substantially can boost your progress over the time. As well as the destruction of aliens and alien nests, especially with certain Might virtues.The victory types are following: Domination - conquer all other players; Contact - contact alien civilization; Transcendence (requires Harmony specialisation)  - civilization fully adapts to the new planet and becomes enlightened; Promised Land (requires Purity specialisation) - bring Earth population to the new planet; Emancipation (requires Supremacy specialisation) - conquer ("free") Earth.So, it's a completely different setting in Beyond Earth. And you require a different approach from what you're used to in Civ5. Although, the same basic rules are still in place: e.g., a) food is population, population is everything; b) science is progress, progress is victory.When I played Beyond Earth for the first time, there were certain innovations that annoyed me, but after playing a while, I got used to them and they started to make sense for me.For example:1. Technology tree is replaced with technology web, which makes it hard to find things, unless you haven't played few sessions. However, with filters and search option, it becomes quite easy to find what you're looking for and to plan your strategy.2. Miasma - spore clouds on some tiles that damage human units. This was really annoying in the beginning. However with right technologies, it actually is kind of cool way to have something to transform. And besides, it makes sense, that alien planet is initially hostile towards humans, but as human population adapts to the new habitat, it learns to use the nature for its own good.3. Aliens – very hostile, very procreative and (some of them) very strong. Initially, it is very hard to avoid them or kill them, so it might be annoying experience for beginners, but, again, with right technologies and strategy, there are ways to overcome this problem and turn it for your own good. After you have the right technologies and units, it's a great opportunity to gain XP for your army. You can have neutral relationship with aliens (by not destroying their nests), but I have never tried this option, because they are always in your way and threaten you on each turn.4. Colour balance - blue and green are dominant colours, it's hard to distinguish miasma and resources. By turning resource yields and icons on, it's possible to minimise this problem, but, still, why couldn't they make miasma red or purple?5. There is a radical shift towards agressive playstyle compared to Civ5. It's almost a must to constantly build units and to defend or attack somebody. It's not something I was used to in Civ5. And at first I didn't really like it. But then again, the overall gameplay is more versatile and balanced and the player gets to use and enjoy all of his strengths in a versatile way. It really freshens up the TBS feel in this game.6. AI behaviour. AI players are either nasty or stupid or both. The diplomatic relationship and deals do not make any sense. There is no solution for this. Just forget about reasonable trade offers, when playing Beyond Earth. You're on your own. I hope Firaxis will change this with future updates.So, with that said, I think Beyond Earth is really a great game. Not perhaps as good as Civilization V, but it certainly feels fresh, runs smoothly and each game session offers a different experience. I would recommend it to all Civilization fans, not perhaps for its full price, but with atleast -40% discount (30 €), it's worth the price even in its current Vanilla state. However, I do hope there will be new expansions, scenarios and maps.My overall rating: 9/10.

number of helpful: 21 of 37 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												Where to start with this title? Firstly I'll get it out of the way and say it's a good game, no question. It's far from perfect but if you like civilization then you will like this title.I fear the single downfall of this game lies in the development. It's as if Firaxis did not have a large enough budget to fully complete this game to make it unique. There are a couple things that bother me with the game so far, the voice acting and it's oh-so-similar CIV 5 likeness. Maybe this was my own fault coming in to this game expecting something COMPLETELY different or something similar to Alpha Centauri. Not that any of these reasons are terrible but I think I worked it up in my head that this game was going to be the perfect blend of Alpha Centauri And Civ 5. It's not, it's good but far from a breakout series. The sole thing I would say about the voice acting is that it needs more work. Each civ does have a unique voice actor but when wonders are complete or you're read a definition you get the voice actor who also voices the Kavithan Protectorate. Should this bother me? I think I was just spoiled with Civ 4 and Civ 5.On to the good stuff - There were a few things I really liked almost immediately after starting. The futuristic theme lends more capabilities and options for the familiar civ player to start with. I love planetfall, this is basically the enactment of your ship touching down and establishing your first colony on the planet you choose. Before this you are allowed to tweak how you start and what starting benefits your sponsor and civilization get. These options range from scientific, cultural to militaristic benefits to help you mould your civ before you start planetfall, Pretty cool stuff.The addition to upgrading your military was a very nice change. Depending on how you steer your civilization this can define what type of militaristic units you get. The 3 directions you can split in to are determined by how you research your technologies. Researching technologies can give you points towards an affinity which can affect your military in very unique ways. This is in addition to veterancy which was not removed but instead improved on.Overall I would say this is a great title. I have been playing it since release and don't foresee stopping any time soon.Go out and get it!

content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
												Civilization Beyond Earth truly deserves the title of spiritual successor of Alpha Centauri. Although it requires a bit of unit diversity, even with the upgrades, you'd still miss the custom unit creation that was available in Alpha Centauri. Factions are diverse but not too distinct from each other, which makes them somewhat easier to get used to quickly. Gameplay and turn times are much smoother than in Civ 5, especially in later phases of the game in a very large map you'd feel the difference of ai completing their turns much quicker.As i read the comments i see people who haven't played Alpha Centauri but fans of Civ series are a bit confused and calling this an expansion pack of sorts. It simply isn't. Just take it as exploring, or rather migrating to an alien planet because earth is no more habitable and imagine all that 'future tech' in Civ games are new set of techs in here. Sure it takes time to get used to but it doesn't prevent it being so much fun.It will become a legendary successor when they add more factions, a little more unit diversity and some other dlc add ons but it's still a must buy right off the bat for any Civ or Alpha Centauri fan.Update as of 23.11.2016 - It's still the closest thing to Alpha Centauri whether you like it or not.

												I usually like the Civilization series of games, but this one has a couple of serious problems.First of all, when the game ends it just gives you the option to go back to the main menu. However, the "hey, screw you, you lose" aspect of the game makes it feel like you just wasted a number of hours playing. At this point I can't recommend the game. If Firaxis gets their head out of whatever orifice they have it stuffed up, they should be able to fix this problem fairly easily. At that point I'll revisit this review.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												Charging full price for a mod of civ 5 that's worse in every way.Remember all the cool content and extra effort that sid meier's games used to have, like the little movies after finishing wonders (civ 2,3 & 4), the well written dialog and attention to detail (Alpha Centauri) and god tier voice acting from Leonard Nimoy and William Morgan Sheppard accompanied by music you could listen to for hours on end it was so good.Nope, that's all gone now, welcome to the future, now with 90% less effort.It's all screaming Indian women and UI's that burn your eyes with how horribly dark and unreadable they are, Sid meier's should be dead so "spinning in his grave" references could be made, that's just how far from grace this franchise has fallen.The game play so far is a total mess, easily winnable through mind numbing micromanagement (the trade system in Civ 5 was a terrible Idea, and it's even worse when you have 3 per city asking for directions every 30 turns (get more then 7 city's and you'll have to order them about every turn) through the garbage UI where they've remove simple features like sorting by resource delta)Wonders are now just flat stat sticks, the bonuses compared to previous civ games where they could change the flow of the game relegates them down to completely pointless, and easily reproduced by land tiles and general buildings.my only consolation is they will continue to polish this turd with future DLC... but it's potential will never be more then a well polished turd.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												Tons of hours off-line.Alright, so here are the questions I wanted to ask before buying this game.WOW, IS THE GAME REALLY AS BAD AS THE RATINGS SUGGEST???Most (not all) of the negative ratings are people uber♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥they paid $50-60 dollars for the base game back in the day.  If you paid $50-60 for the base game, you'd be uber♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ too.  If, however, you paid $20 like me (or even less with recent sales), you'd be fine with your purchase.  The base game really isn't that bad; it's not particularly memorable, but pay $15-20, and you should avoid any buyer's remorse.DOES THE DLC HELP? IT'S KIND OF EXPENSIVE.Yes! Rising Tide boosts Beyond Earth from an okay game to a very good game.  If you even remotely liked Beyond Earth, pick up Rising Tide immediately.  If you have neither, you should be able to get both Beyond Earth and Rising Tide together for around $40-50 in a future sale.  While the DLC might have too high a price tag, the two items combined are definitely worth $40-50.LOTS OF NEGATIVE REVIEWS ARE SAYING TO STICK WITH CIVILIZATION V.  SHOULD I BOTHER GETTING BEYOND EARTH IF I ALREADY HAVE CIV V?Most defintiely.  Beyond Earth is NOT just a poor man's Civ V with a space skin thrown on.  Instead, I would say it's built on a Civ V chassis.  Players will recognize many of the same concepts and game mechanics, but also notice significant differences.  Just a few: 1) "aliens" function quite differently from "barbarians" in older games 2) the tech "tree" is really more of a "web" now, and many of the technological choices have no equivalent in previous Civ games.  They didn't take the existing tree and say, "Ooooooh, let's just call it 'space bronze working' now."3) affinity levels -- how your civilization will relate to the Old Earth and your new home -- have a significant impact on the types of buildings, military units, etc available to you.4) there are some cool new types of victory scenarios.  Ahhh, nothing like the feeling of sending giant alien hybrids through a warp gate back to old Earth to "emancipate" them from their petty bickering.It's a decent base game, well worth a $15-20 investment.  As with Civ V, I think it will become a truly great game once all the DLC dust has cleared.  Jump on the bandwagon now and enjoy the ride.

												First of all, I have to say that I am a huge fan of Civilization games. BE starts very promising, but after a serious amount of rounds the game is repetitive and in my opinion , a bit pointless. The choices in the tech web are giving me the feeling that they are random and they don't have a serious impact on the game. Also, after so many rounds , the aliens are still doing the same stuff. I feel that the battle between another civilization it's a bit meaningless , because you left from Earth to find a better place to live, not to conquer. I am sorry to say that, but the game is boring. I am going to stick with Civ V. I hope in the future the DLCs will help the game, but i am not willing to gamble another 40-50 € for this game. If you love Civ V , don't buy this. The space theme it doesn't work for the nature of this game.

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												It's hard to describe this game and give it a grade. On the one hand, it was a lot of fun playing through my first victory and going through the tech tree and so forth as Kavitha. But it just felt so....Civ V-like. Yes, the graphics are different, the sponsors are different, and there's different buildings, units, and wonders. But the mechanics feel like Civ V-reskin. First off the good stuff: I like how the minor powers/city states only occupy one tile. You were probably annoyed one way or another when Monaco took that fountain of youth tile or another natural wonder. It's good to see that the sponsors get a lot of land to use. Also, I like the outpost criteria. I think that should be in Civ 6. Giving an output/settlement a few turns to fully develop is something unique. Rome wasn't built in a day right? :)I also really like the quotes. Now the things I don't like: boring leaders (they sound dull and uninspiring), boring units (there's only to be 3 types of units, vs unique units for each civ in Civ V), boring music (I played my own music when I play, and I  - Civ V's music was awesome with the peace and war themes), boring wonders (I had to look through all the wonders the first time, although it's quite easy to see that the ones that need more production are the wonders), some virtues are OP (propserity - bottom right with -25% health - and the other health benefits in that tree, make that area the new Tradition tree. YOU HAVE TO TAKE IT IF YOU WANT TO WIN. YOU HAVE NO CHOICE, unless you want to enter -20 health), and by far, this feels like an unfinished game. When I won through victory, the ending was so anticlimatic, and I went "That's it?". It's quite obvious that similar mechanics like religion will be in the game eventually: I want to worship Space Gandhi. But until I can, I can't really recommend this game at the regular price. Review subject to change with future patches and expansions.

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 16, 2014
												Beyond Earth feels like an entry title into the series. With that I mean that it sure is a nice game on some fronts and it rolls with the alien theme, it let's you down if you are looking for that Brave New World vibe. The game feels and acts like a reskinned civ 5. The units let your expectations down, the year is somewhere in the future, and at this point still you have 'melee' units which in civ 5 style exhange hits with other units. The addition of satelites is a nice touch, however that feels like its the only thing added. You still have your Civ 5 units being a Melee unit, Ranged unit, Artilery unit and cavalery unit. However instead of the upgrades of these units being tied to your technology they are now tied to your affinity (basicly your ideology).How I do like the affinity system it does force your research, and strategy with that into a singular path. Since discovering certian technologies grant you affinity points you are forced to pick those techs up, which give you a false hope of an immense tech web with lots of choices. On top of this you'll find that (especcially) on higher difficulties that you don't have a free choice of affinity, with that your playstyle as well, either. You will be looking at what strategic resources are nearby and you will pick the affinity that goes with the specific strategic resource which happens to be in abbundance near your landing zone. On top of this the unique feel you used to have for your civilization is gone. Leaders talk less and feel less interactive as well. Furthermore instead of the leader sitting in their "Throne room" they now just show the leader without any background. The uniqueness of your civilization and your games you'll play are gone as well since there are just 8 factions. If you enjoy playing larger maps then these games will always be with the same factions. Factions have a random personality now as well it seems, so no more war mongering shaka. Along with the uniqueness of your civ missing, you'll find yourself looking for a lot more if you compare this to Civ 5. The victory system is simplified now, you have 3 basic victory types, 1 is bound to your affinity (basicly build a wonder after researching the right techs), 1 is bound to finding an artifact using the new scout system and the final one is domination. However the first two victories basicly feel like research X asap and perform action Y asap after that. So dumbed down you have 2 victory paths which is a huge letdown to the 4 victories in civ 5, which also felt unique in their playstyle. Performance wise civ BE runs great. I have had no crashes and it doesn't seem very taxing on the machine either. The game looks very nice from an observers viewpoint. However from a players viewpoint this is no longer the case. Be prepared for a lot of blue. The techweb feels like a blue hive which includes vague options and lacks color in general. You really can't find any tech or wonder or any other distinction in the tech web easily. On top of this the overall view of the game is messy. You cant really see terrain clearly and this results in you hovering with your mouse over all the terrain to see the yields (or turn the show yields option on). All in all this game is a great let down for the expectations set up by its predecessor. If you are new to the series you can pick this up to get a general feel of the Civ series. However your bucks are better spent on the full edition of civ 5 which all in all still feels like a superior game. Rating = 4 / 10, the game feels like a rushed product where Firaxis did not utilise any of the experience build up in making the previous civilization games. The good:* The terrain looks good visiually and offers a nice change* The new system of picking your cargo etc allows for more diverse games* The alien system makes "barbarians" a some what city state like faction of their ownThe bad:* The game feels messy and lakcs distinctive features in all parts (tech web, buildings, general overview, etc.)* Very  low amount of factions in the game of whoms abilities feel lack-luster for some and overpowered for others* Low diversity of units, everything is dumbed down to your basic units which use the affinity system for upgraded units* Units and buildings dont feel like what you'd expect from space faring civilizations* No more religion (or new equivalent)* Less diverse games by less victory types* Leaders feel a lot less personal and even more as just annoying pop ups* Spacing between civilizations (map size) seems less forcing you to have contested borders relatively fast. Short conclusion:Rating 4/ 10. Stick to civ 5 Brave new world, either as a new player or as an experienced player.

content:
Posted: March 21, 2015
												At first glance the game does seem drastically different than Civilization 5. There seems to be quite a lot of negative reviews but I personally find it to be a very pleasant addition to the Civilization series. I started playing the civilization games way back when I was in middle school and Civilization 3 had just came out. Here was my experience of this futuristic take on the civilization series:At first I had a hard time trying to get focus on the game and understand what was going on. I played very on and off for a few days and stopped playing for about a week. I later resumed playing the game again and took the same approach I did to learning civilization 3. Once I understood the new mechanics and got a handle on the terrain, resources, improvements, and the daunting orbital aspect ( which actually turned out to be very simple to understand and is a fantastic element I have come to enjoy. Especially because you can create resources ;D ) so on and so forth of the intricate elements of the game. Once I played through one game, all the way (win or lose and I actually lost this one though it was close haha I started my first game on Vostok difficulty) I honestly have not been able to stop playing it. A lot of the nuisances that were present in civ 4 and civ 5 such as battling happiness and upgrading military units to compete with higher level ai (these are just a couple).I really like how the virtues truly give you the ability to customize your sponsor (civilization). When the virtue tree has 2 bonuses branching to a higher tier bonus, you no longer need both of those bonuses to grab that higher tier and only need to pick one. The way units upgrade is a really cool approach as too. Again, it gives you full customization of your nation. Even when behind you can still put up a fight, albeit a struggle, but it is doable and winnable. It also gives hope to being able to win a game when quite a ways behind. The instant upgrade of all units once the upgrade has been earned (affinity level reached a certain level for a particular unit) is a very nice adaptation. I remember in civ 5 losing games becuase I had no money to upgrade units and continue to fund new units. Ultimately, I found this game to be very challenging, rewarding, and so many different ways to play the game and enjoy! I highly reccomend this game for someone willing to put in the time it takes to learn a game. Even if you are a civilization veteran, approach this game with some new eyes and it is all the more rewarding.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
Pros-*Choices at the start of the game - (e.g. +2 food, production ect in each city) with "quests" giving optional bonuses for different buildings (e.g. an extra point of culture for monuments or no maintenence cost for them) allowing greater specialisation. you are never limited by the fact there is only 8 factions. Unlike civ 5 where some factions were especially powerful perhaps even inbalanced.*Ideologies - The three main ideologies are all realistic, compelling and ultimately lead to different styles of play and win conditions. Solving one of my main gripes with CIv 5 in that your civ almost always favoured a victory so doing your best to win involved simply repeating a tried and tested strategy.*Tech web - While confusing at first glance and for a couple of playthroughs time it really does allow you to specialise. In civ 5 that one player with the highest science got first dibs on every wonder, not anymore!*Aliens replace barbarians - More than just a cosmetic change the aliens are not inherently hostile and will treat you differently based on how you treat them. Some are hilariously overpowered at the start of the game but can be avoided. The difficulty setting probably has an effect too.*Orbital layer - Allows another layer of military conquest where you can rain death from above with massive units or orbital weapons. But also satilites that can create new resources on blank tiles allowing you to develop the map in very new ways. I would love to see this be pushed further to allow a more earthlike climate for the purity ideology.Cons-*The game is outright missing some of the features that came with DLC for civ 5 and will probably end up being DLC later down the line. Including: religion, natural wonders, world congress, tourism/culture victory.*The game does not have distinct phases like Civ 5 which were based on different eras of human civilisation. As such it the game doesnt really have the same flow of technological advancement making it hard to see how well you are doing in comparison to your rivals. In times of peace this can make the game feel extremely detached almost like no progress is being made at all, at least in war you can see new units duking it out!*Unlike barbarians the aliens do not not gain any new units over the course of a game. Making them very strong to begin with but the weaker ones quickly become little more than wasted movement points as your units effortlessly plough through them.*Very little interaction with AI players - The only new addition being that the AI will compliment you if you same the same attitude towards the Aliens or for choosing the same ideology. Civ 5 was lacking in this regard as well, it simply isnt interesting to deal with them in any way.*Visuals while functional arent exactly amazing. Beyond earth being a stand alone game rather than a paid DLC for Civ 5 means there was an opportunity to up the visuals, which was clearly missed as the game looks to be on the same level of graphical fidelity as civ 5.tl:drDifferent enough from Civ 5 to be worth trying (I have enjoyed it thus far), similar enough to make you realise whats missing or hasnt been improved.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												Hello readers.At the time of making this, I have had only 6 or so hours of game time. Normally this would be far to little to write accurate review, and you are right!The first thing I did when I start the game was of course the settings, see how everything is set. First thing I noticed, no 1920x1080 resolution supported in full screen. I got confused, which game in 2014 didn't have it?!I went on the web and found out this is normal for those with a specific refresh rate of a their monitor, I guess this somehow got pets the superb Q/A testing.Fine, I will play it in windows modeI looked at the choices I could get, and I noticed that you only have 8 Civs, this was kinda mediocre to me when you compare it to the previous game, and because they aren't  the 'known' civ's of the world, it felt very lacking.The bonuses of each civs as well made them far less unique then I thought. But ill just go ahead and pick something.After 'personalising' my faction ( which with the limited choices you cannot really call it that ) I entered  the game!First thing I noticed, no awesome voice overs of William Morgan Sheppard or  Leonard Nimoy.I started, settled, and explored with my unit, already felt a bit CiV 5 but that doesn't have to be bad. I found something to use my explorer on, started to dig around and then it already started, next turn, next turn and next turn. Not much going on.I started fiddling with the UI and noticed so much is missing and its all very blend, while in previous civs it all looked quite nice with art and stuff, this game is just made out of bars that anyone can do! The minimap is very annoying coloured, everything is very dark which means you got to suck the player in for that next turn. Then suddenly other civs joined, landed on the map and I could see where they were,  meaning no exploring what so ever to find that other civilization. Played some more, heard my first research completed, no cool pop up, a very average voice over ( sorry.. ) made a new city with a oversized settler, started seeing the other civs units, all the same, as me, no uniqueness. I started looking some more throught the UI, Affinity, Virtues, Researching.I had a quest popping up asking me for a station to drop near me, I made my choice, it dropped down and well that was it, you can trade with this station but for the rest it does nothing. Imagen a city state without workers and units around it while growing and feeling sort of alive, no here they are just dead buildings. Speaking of quests, at first, I loved em, they do give a bit of lore BUT they the bonus is always very small, in the end, its just picking something you go for or what you need. You quickly just pick and forget.While I don't mind the Web of researching, its not good and it is very boring, while you see cool artworks from CiV 5, this again feels really cheap.Other civs started to ask for things, when I read what they had to say, it was pure copy paste from CiV 5.. and that is when I started to have enough. And I saw flaw after flaw and flaw. Wonders, I build them, never knowing I actually made one! Why? They aren't 'wonderful' I honestly thought they were just a building! When I started upgrading units, ah a bigger gun! Awesome!...150 turns in, trade spam became annoying, you can have as low as 2 trade routes on a city.(as you can tell by my writing I start to become a bit more unforgiving, exactly how I felt during my play session for the first time )I noticed that sure, affinity will make your units look different in end game, but they will still be exactly the same as any other civ that has it, while I know that in CiV 5, modern age it is the same as well, before that you had a couple of ages feeling relatively unique compared to the rest. Mods made this even better.As you have noticed I said nothing about the aliens, that's because they have nothing to do with the game, they are there, being annoying but nothing else, even when you kill nest after nest, nothing. I then gave up on the game, it was just to boring, to tedious and it has no soul, i feels like almost no effort was made into this.I do have one positive, I have to say, is the music, its beautiful  and I am 100% sure, that's the only reason I played it for this long.I will not recommend this to anyone, not at full price, perhaps at 10 euros max. I will also never recommend this to a CiV Veteran, because he will see this too. As far as it goes for me, this is a MOD, and a bad one at that.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												First of all the game is not bad per se but for me it is lacking overall in general and especially compared to its predecessor Civilization V. The first thing you will realize is that most of the game is just like Civ V so there is not really a change there. But unlike Civ V, especially with all its addons, has a lot more to offer than Beyond Earth. The different civs are only a few and not really interesting. The difference between the civs is also negligible. The progression via affinity according to Supremacy, Harmony, or Purity is a nice idea but they are only 3 options compared to the numerous in Civ V via religion or culture. If you wanted you could win the game within a short time because the different goals, with the exception of domination maybe, is fairly easy. The tech you need to research does not take too long and then, if you have a strong town with good production, build the wonder fairly quickly and after about 75 turns it is over. Meaning the computer can also win easily in higher difficulty. I do not know if the AI actually does that because I did not get to those above normal difficulties yet. Marathon feels like normal speed in Civ V and is over quickly as well.The diversity of units is very limited. You basically get 1 unit of each type. 1 ship, 1 plane, 1 artillery, 1 infantry and so on.In general diversity is what I think is the problem that is most lacking. Nothing that they cannot add with mods or updates but at this point I rather play Civ V or Endless Legends.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												I'm giving this a 7 out of 10, because as a stand-alone game, C:BE a good 4X strategy game. But, I'm so used to the masterpiece that is Civilization 5 : Brave New World, that this rendition sadly pales into insignificance. Many of the features that made Civ 5 what it was have either been heavily simplified or removed entirely - good examples being the unit variety and faction identities/bonuses.Good/New features :I like the addition of the orbital layer - it adds another dynamic to empire building and warfare.The new Affinities (Ideologies) are a different spin on Civ 5, and I think do give you a feel of what your Civ represents in terms of values.Miasma - it feels like a major pain to start out, and if you play as Harmony, you can turn it to your advantage - a nice touch.The Virtues tree (social upgrades) are a nice touch giving you the option to progress either in a single tree or multiple trees - each having bonus boosts (i.e. you get bonuses for spreading across multiple trees - unlike Civ 5).The Quests - it adds a nice way to customise buildings to your specific playstyle, and gives nice little boosts to your empire. Ultimately though, it's a mechanism to reduce the number of buildings in the game.The favour system in diplomacy is a nice touch. If you don't need anything from another faction, they trade you an IOU which can be called in later.The visual appeal is a nice change from dull and boring earth :o)  Although, the graphics overall aren't really an upgrade over Civ 5 (not that it was needed tbh).Things that disappoint me :The tech web - although a decent idea, it just seems to be a random collection of upgrades that you stumble into. I never get a feel that I'm progressing towards something meaningful. Example : In Civ 5, acquiring Dynamite was a major boost for your Artillery capabilities, and you would often divert resources to getting it as early as possible if you were planning a war. You don't get that feeling in C:BE.The wonders are........Meh. They are small and fairly insignificant boosts that have little synergy with each other. Again, Civ 5 often required you to build/acquire certain wonders to achieve certain victories.The lack of "atmosphere". This is a new planet shrouded in mystery! The quest system is good for customisation, but they could have done so much more with it to give you that feeling that this is a weird and wonderful new place that you have to grapple with to get the most out of it. The Aliens are basically the "Barbarians" of Civ 5 - but they seem to flip a coin as to whether or not to attack you. Once you get to mid-game, they are irrelevant as a force - you might as well terminate them on sight, even playing as Harmony! Would have been much better if they made the natural inhabitants an AI-only faction in their own right, and link quests to them depending on your Affinity.The "health" system. It's basically "happiness" from Civ 5, but seems to be more forgiving. You can expand very aggressively in C:BE and not suffer too much. If you did that in Civ 5, you'd find life very difficult if your people weren't happy. The "softening" of this expansion bottleneck means that you are engaging far less with your neighbours to acquire happiness or manipulate the game in your favour via a league of nations/UN - oh wait, luxury goods don't exist anymore either. Why do I need to talk to anyone again?The NPC stations; the C:BE equivalent of City States. They are a trading option for a single trade route - nothing more. You don't fight over them. They don't fight for you. They don't consume land and foil your best laid expansion plans. You can't take them over. They don't give you a bigger voice at the table of international diplomacy - nope...they just sit there and give you a few extra resource points - and if you're unlucky they appear out of the blue and stop you from planting an outpost where you want it. Meh.Economy - I never feel like Energy (Gold) is a bottleneck. If you had an abundance of gold in Civ 5, you could do so much with it. If you weren't a gold friendly faction, you'd sometimes struggle to make ends meet - to field that Dynasty crushing army.  Where there were big gold sinks in Civ 5 like maintaining alliances and control over city states, upgrading units etc - the absence of this limits the use of excess energy to rush buying units and buildings.  So far - Energy is just something I casually look at. It's rarely in the negative per turn. It's just not a resource that needs to be carefully managed like in Civ 5.Lack of unit diversity - There are not many units at all. Only different ways to customise them via increases in Affinity. It's like the buildings - less of them, but you can customise them.All in all I'm disappointed - After Civ 5 and X-COM, Firaxis were the only software house I'd ever pre-order anything from. I'll be thinking twice now.That said - this game does have potential for modding and future expansions. My advice is to park it until that happens. Civ 5 only became truly great after the second expansion.For people who are new to the Civ franchise, you'd probably enjoy this game.  For Civ 5 veterans like myself, it's a bit of a let down that leaves you chomping at the bit for an expansion.

												I was so hyped for this game, i'm a Civ veteran, been playing every game in the series since the first Civilization game. I have over 150 hours on Civ5. So i was looking forward to this game as an advancement to the franchise.What i got was a cash in on a famous franchise, that has all the mechanics of civ 5, but none of the personality or features. And some people will say that it will get better in the expansions, but even civ 5 vanilla had more soul, features, and appeal than this game does in it's current state. It feels hurried and un finished.To put it in perspective, i have more hours put into Euro Truck Simulator 2 than this game =/Very disappointed, i feel a little betrayed by one of my favorite game studios.
