content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												I foolishly decided to trust the positive reviews and am now left with a buggy and to be honest, a rushed game. Sid meier's is making a habit of releasing unfinished games that require patching and then releasing a paid patch cough cough brave new world to try and drain his fans of their earnings. This game is lets face it dull, the graphics are vibrant but not in the good way as i often felt my eyes being strained. The ads show off a wide new range of victories but once you play the game you'll know thats its just bs. These 'new' victories are basically science and domination victories, all 4 of the new victories require extensive research and are basically the equivalent of building a space ship in civ V. Don't buy this game till the patch comes and or the price drops.

number of helpful: 10 of 16 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												This is easily the weakest Civ in modern memory. It would have made an excellent mod for Civ V, but is absolutely not worth paying the full price for. If you are a massive Civ fan, it might be a good purchase but Civ V still remains a stronger game in every single measurable aspect.Presumably, until the first DLC release there are only eight playable civs. However, it does not make a difference as the civs do NOT have unique units. Instead, what units you can build depends on your 'affinity'. As you level up through the enormously complex tech tree, you will gain points towards one of three affinity trees depending on what skills you train- Harmony, Purity or Supremacy. Essentially this means that there are actually only an absolutely pathetic three sets of units possible to build. Wait until the Christmas specials for this one, folks.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
												I'm only downvoting this because I feel this game needs a 50% rating. Really, it's not a bad game. If you like the 4X genre, it's very well done. Pros:Graphics are well doneTech Tree is unique and well made. (If not a little confusing)Overall Gameplay is engaging, if not a little repetitive.Affinity trees finally have been paid attention to, and are moving in the right directionThe engine runs very smoothly. Even on Huge maps my slightly above mediocre computer runs it smoothly, with minimal load times for textures.Cons:AI is blah.Diplomacy is not only utterly confusing, but also very 1 dimensional.The range on units feels off. How can a guy on foot travel half the distance in a year as a boat can? Really, beating it once or twice is all you can really do. Civ as a whole suffers from End Game goals. At this point, I'd just wait for Civ 6. But if it's on sale, I'd pay maybe 20 bucks for the base game and the DLC. (You definitely need the DLC for this one)

content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												It's totally proper to say that Beyond Earth is an imbalanced game. Some aspects of it is just simple and even silly. It needs a crucial upgrade to revise its systems, especially the trade routes. Moreover, you actually have only 3 ways to win since your affinity is the subsidiary of the alien resources near your capital city and you might not choose the affinity you like if you want to win the game. The positive thing is that the icons and buttons in Beyond Earth are flat and you could control your troops easily and accurately with your fingers touching the screen of your Ultrabooks.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												Something is seriously missing from this game that was in every other Civ.I can still spend 10+ hours playing a game of Civ 5, but this game... after an hour I'm bored and wondering what's on TV.Pros:- I didn't know any of the techs or buildings so I had to read all the descriptions which was kind of novel for me.- The UI is pretty to look at.- Not as bad as the latest Sim City.Cons:- Tech web is confusing.  Why not leave it as a progressive tree??- Flat, over simplified UI.  I really have to learn what all these symbolic monochromatic icons mean?- Visually, the map is hard to look at and determine what land types and resources are what.  Not enough contrast.- Units upgrade automatically and they all get the same upgrade.- Of the three games I've played, I lost all of them very abruptly with no explanation why, or inclination that i was about to lose.- Very few and bland wonders, units, civs.  Let me guess - DLC?- Game pace (techs, building times, etc) seems off to me.  It might be the way I'm playing though.- Missing a certain 'je ne sais quoi' (I'm totally serious about this.  play the game and you will see.)

												Game is nice, looking good, and gives a lot of fun to play, but there's a lot of stuff that makes this game not worth to buy:1. This game looks like Civ5 graphics mod, cause nearly no new mechanics was added.2. All "uniqe" options that are here, Ive already seen in Civ5 or Pandora:First Contact.3. "Prepare your ship, and choose what you will take on Your journey" is actually choosing couple of benefits that were connected to nations in Civ5 (+2 food from cities or +2 culture from cities, free worker or free soldier etc).4. First game Ive made was on marathon speed and took me like 5 hours to finish it, and i havent even build a single combat unit. On fast speed You wont even reach your enemy with your army, and You will already be winning by tech victory.5. Theres only like 8-9 types of units in game, that can be upgraded (by a doctrine - no cash or comming back to your territory required).Conclusion:This game is not worth its price - it should be Civ5 DLC for like 10-15 euros max. Instead its standalone game that costs 50 euros, and it can be clearly see that it has only basic content which will be expanded very soon buy a lot of expensive DLC's. This game can be clearly named cashgrab. Playe Pandora: First Contact with no nukes mod instead.

Posted: October 26, 2014
												I'm very early in the game,   But so far this is the least engaging Civilization game.  It is, at best, an expansion pack on Civ 5. They combined efforts to streamline the game (which removes the Civilization early-game, effectively) and make it alien (so the tech tree takes more time to understand).  Together these make it so that you don't get engaged quickly and the game will take a lot of effort to really understand.  Effort that it isn't clearly deserving of.

number of helpful: 12 of 20 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												Just terrible, the game is nearly unplayable in a literal sense. Any online play takes several tries to get off the ground because the game crashes constantly in multiplayer, although it is admittedly better in LAN play than over the internet.  It tends to be a toss-up whether or not the racial faction bonuses will work at any given time. The mechanics are unimaginative, with a completely uninspired tech-bubble that lets you decide exactly the way you wish your civilization to be the same as everyone else's because the techs are scattered all over the place and full of requirements from other techs placed far away on the tree. In the year 2014 there's apparently no way to make an algorithm that even attempts to balance starting conditions. In effect, it's pretty much the exact same deal as with civilization 5, although the tech bubble is less intuitive and harder to construct a proper build out of.Barbarians, one of the most annoying and random features of civilization 5, has been given a steroid treatment so that the game can rocket into the dull trope of all alien worlds somehow inexplicably playing host to naturally bullet-resistant life-forms. Rather than being an interesting event and object of interaction with the world, the aliens pour out of nests, meaning that depending on your location they will either be an insignificant nuisance that you don't really need to take a stance on or absolutely obliterate any chance of staying competitive with anyone who was placed elsewhere on the map. Their aggression is mostly tied into the nests - if you are surrounded by them then too bad, if not then you might not even need to escort your workers and colonists to new locations. This is unmitigated by the techs for dealing with them, due to their being placed on high tiers and randomly around the tech bubble.You're not alone in dealing with the alien threat, however. Every now and then an unafiliated outpost will land somewhere in your expansion circle, forcing you to go to war with them or 35 turns before they go away. Sometimes two outposts disagree about which one of them is going to ruin your day, and make you decide - never give you the option to tell them both to screw off. This happens at random times throughout the game, and you have no control over it. These are the exact two random events that will happen - outposts taking your spot, and aliens taking your spot. Other players may also take your spot, but that's to be expected as you can also take theirs, being that they don't fall from the sky without warning.This game is lazy at best, more of a late beta than a full release in most of the ways that matter. If you preordered, but are intending to play with friends who did not, you can't use the bonus map types - which is pretty stupid, but the blow is softened by the fact that the new map types are basically small variations on the old ones. In their botched attempt to basically recreate Alpha Centauri, Firaxis has managed to leave out most of the interesting parts of this predecessor - the tech bubble is bad, there is no lore to speak of, the factions are bland, even the quotes are terrible - and mashed it with the worst parts of Civilization 5's engine. Just awful.

number of helpful: 12 of 20 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												This game is not a bad game. It just don't think that it is worth 50 dollars. If you are a huge civ fan buy this game but keep in mind that it is basically reskinned civ5. Civ5 was  a great game but this game looks too similar.Pros:-As addictive as civ5. This game whittles away much time easily.-The planets look pretty good. This is running on the civ5 engine so it does not look next gen but it looks good.-The aliens are great. There are quite a few varieties and they pose a good beginning game challenge.-The tech tree is cool. There is a lot of customizablity.-the affinity system is good but could be more extensive. Most ways to get affinity points are passive (research this tech or choose a quest) but it is a nice addition that I'm sure will be enhanced in DLCCons:-There are not very many different units types. There are no civ specific units, and there are very few types. -This game is obviously built around DLC, there is a lot that should be here (more than just 8 civs) that have been left out-The few civs each feel identical and have almost no differences. At least the civ5 rulers were actual people.-There are not very many victory types. There is domination, first contact, and one affinity specific vixtory open to you. No culture, monetary or science victory can be won.-The AI is unpredictable. They attack without pretext and are almost the same as in Civ5.All in all, this game is not bad. I just find it hard to recommend this for 50 dollars. If it is on sale then I think it is worth it.Score: 6.5/10

Posted: October 28, 2014
												1) Although Firaxis is charging a full price this isn't a full price game but essentially just a Civ-V mod.2) Welcome back to Civ-III micro-management. Having a dozen workers switching between two improvements over 100+ turns instead of assuring a basic road network is not the exception but the rule.3) Be sure to have a working internet connection since the Civilopedia lacks the most important informations. E.g. is there no list of all unit types but a nice article^W paragraph about "unit types".4) Victory around Turn 300 is not the exception but again the rule. Favouring the contact victory.5) The AI is either crap or will overrun you at turn 50.6) Dont expect a revenge of the planet like with the locuts of chiron in SMAC. This is Civilization, stupid.

number of helpful: 30 of 55 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												Once you're able to translate the new "tech/space" speak into Civ V terms, you realize you already know how to play and beat this game.There is really no difference between the three affinities other than the skin of their units. The tech web is an interesting idea on paper but in practice the web takes the exciting tech race and throws it out the window. No improvements to the AI. Also, if you ignore the Aliens then they'll ignore you right back... and that is it the Aliens are out of the game. The outposts which were city-states in civ v are dumbed down so that you can only send trade routes to them. The orbital layer is underwhelming to say the least. And the favors system in diplomacy is useless.The good news is that it is a very very pretty reskin of CIV and the good Civ V game play dynamics are still there. Additionally, Multiplayer is pretty good.My Advice: Wait for either good mod or a great dlc to improve this game. Until then it is unfortunate that I cannot recommend this game.*Just like everyone else I am a long time Civilization Fan.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												I was expecting a great game like Civ V, but revamped. All I see is a reskin, and a very poor one at that. You just dont feel acomplished even when you have the best runthrough you can. Rather than getting new units, all you do is upgrade existing ones, while this is ok, again, it doesnt feel acomplishing when you upgrade them. Before the new unit would replace the existing one (like replacing longswordsman with Minutemen, or Tanks with Death Machines), why they couldnt impliment that is beyond me. Also, rather than working towards the end of the tech tree to win, now theres a cluster F*** of a tech tree that will make new players heads spin. Another problem, the map itself. You see that "Floatstone" or "Fireaxite", well dont bother with it for half the game, because thats when your able to even harvest it. WHATS THE POINT OF HAVING REVEALED RESOURCES THAT YOU CANT DO ANYTHING WITH? What happened to Revealing it on the map at the point of when you need it. Best example of doing it right, Civ 5. In Civ 5, you reveal almost every strategic resource when you progress the tech tree. Here, most of it is shown you you outright. Not all, but most. Also, there doesnt seem to be alot of resources in total, and most dont have the same effect it did in Civ 5. Happyness, i mean "Health" is not controlled anymore by the resources you have, which makes it very difficult to keep the "empire" "healthy". Probably the worst part though, the part that really pisses me off, are the victories. I beat the game doing the promised land victory. Heres what you do, you launch the tellalink satalite and then you can get the Exodus Gate. Once you build that, you think the ending is right there right? WRONG? NOW, you have to teleport 20 earth settlers to settle on the planet, and they cant settle within 3 tiles of eachother or cities. This game ending is so ♥♥♥♥ed up its unbelievable, and to top it off, theres a glitch in the game where it wont give me the achievment for it. These are just some facts and my oen opinions on the game. I think they should have exapnded Civ 5 firther rather than give us this game, here here we are. This game is unfinished and unpolished in terms of gameplay and the victories are just ♥♥♥♥ing horrid. Avoid this game until proper DLC content make this game hopefully as complete it made Civ 5.P.S. I also forgot to mention that a bunch of animations either seem to be missing from the game or just not there. When I was attacking enemies, i didnt see anything that looked like they were getting shot it. What it looks like is the gun flashing w/ sound effects but no visuals of them getting shot, just them dieing. Best example, using the Rocket vehicles. I dont see any rockets fireing, just the red sparks of wat i believe to be them them coming from the end barrels.

number of helpful: 17 of 30 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												This simply isn't a "full game". Much like Borderlands: The PreSequel - it's a full price game without the content to justify the price.The AI is weak, the units are worse than ever before - the interesting veterancy system has been stripped away and replaced with affinity choice that affect all current and future units. All you can choose when you units lvl up is instant heal or more damge.The factions are confusing and due to weak voice acting lack personality. There are overwhelming balance issues which allow you to trvialize the game if you are willing to spam health buildings/improvments, found after city to create internal trade routes and send out spies to steal energy from everyone you can. There are essentially no downsides to this play style.Online play is also unstable and prone to crashes.The game also feels like it was made on a very small budget with lots of cut corners. There is very limited voice acting, there are no movies for wonder, no ending cinematics, no faction specific events or anything that would make the game interesting.  In short - this game is an uninspired unpolished cash grab.Just buy Pandora First Contact for $35 - it's a more interesting game at this point.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												This game is unfinished, it lacks the diversity of units, of technologies, of gameplay overall. The game has too few interactions between the players, in between with the outposts, and in between with the aliens. Long gone are the days of "barbarian" defending, exploration of world wonders, and having to form and manage alliances, luxury resource trades; not to mention the happiness' replacement health statistic just does not appear to work properly. Beyond Earth relies too much on the modding community to improve the gaming experience, as well as certain DLCs that are planned pre-release. This is not okay and if I could sell this game back, I would; and just go play Civilization V instead.

number of helpful: 20 of 36 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
												I almost didn't buy BE after reading so many reviews damning it all the way Hades. But I'm a big fan of Sid Meier and went ahead and purchased.  At first I could totally relate to all the negative comments. It really did seem like Civ 5 had been reskinned and renamed, but without the good stuff. What I discovered after sticking with it awhile, determined to get my money's worth:- This is not Civ 5, therefore you cannot play with exact same strategy as Civ 5. Similar, but different enough you will need to adjust a bit- There is a learning curve. Most overwhelming I found was the Technology Web. Definitely takes a while to wrap your head around what is important and when to research.- Wonders do help ALOT. If you build the right ones. Again, there is a learning curve- Read up on the Affinity's, pick one and go hard - Unless you only want to go to war for a Domination Victory, check out the ingame help, learn about the Victories, pick one and go for itOn the down side:- Trade routes are a nuisance. You always seem to give away more than you receive, but it can help things keep ticking over. You can more or less put them on auto pilot if you want to- Overall the game is a bit bland. In an effort to make it look futuristic all the developers have achieved is making it "samey" imho- Lack of variation in the color scheme adds to the sameyness feel of things, it also makes identifying different types of units etc challenging at timesOverall I am greatly enjoying this game. Each time round I discover something new and find a new depth. If you enjoy strategy and are prepared for a learning curve then you will enjoy BE too.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5, 2016
												Civ Beyond Earth is an interesting game. Fans had been wondering when they'd see a spiritual successor to Alpha Centauri for some time, and Beyond Earth takes it into the modern era nicely, very much its own thing but with nice consistencies in lore and in some returning unit types, but apart from that, everything is redesigned from the ground up and is balanced pretty nicely for whatever type of game you're looking to get, from long and epic on huge planets to short, sweet and scrappy with a handful of opponents in close proximity. There's also a plethora of different map types and features to keep you occupied for hundreds of hours if you let it, particularly with the Exoplanets map pack. My favorite is a fixed-orbit planet, with scorching desert on one hemisphere, frozen wasteland in the other, and a sweet spot around the highly-contested equator area. There's a lot of little touches that add a lot of depth and replayability, which I like very much.A lot of people I've asked about it have given it flak for feeling like a mod of Civ 5 they charged full price for, but they're forgetting that Alpha Centauri was just an improvement on the Civ 2 engine, and it was just as unique and brilliant. I don't mind this, and I really feel like you get what you pay for with Firaxis games. Their QA has never been perfect, though. Even this far down the line, there's still graphical glitches and spelling errors remaining deeper into the tech tree. Not as many as there used to be, and I recommend just a little bit more power than Steam's recommended settings if you're looking to buy the right hardware to max out the graphics in this game.I am torn between recommending the expansion at this point or not. It adds a LOT to the game and distances itself further from what could honestly be called "just a Civ 5 mod." The gameplay is expanded into the ocean, with enhanced graphics for undersea tiles a welcome feast for the eye, with all-new tile enhancements and coastal graphics. Sea bases are finally a thing again, and the way they acquire territory and contribute to Culture is interesting. In other ways, though, it makes the game feel less complete and cluttered. I dunno why you can't zoom out in the tech web anymore, but the redesign with added color coding is at least very nice. The hybrid affinities are great, but at this point I feel like they're accomodating multi-class play styles a little TOO much. You can basically just blindly whisk through the tech web, researching whatever, and at any point you'll be pretty well-equipped with good options for any situation. I don't know whether to call it an improvement or a lack of focus. I've had some good games with it, anyway, and it does seem more effective in the short term at least to focus on one direction, whether it be an endgame plan or a particular affinity or powerful unit you want to go for. I think the clincher for me is how the alien AI behaves differently on different planet types in Rising Tide. It's such a small touch, but one that adds infinite variety, which is important in games that have a randomized element.In the end, if you like Civ, definitely get this game, and if you want a truly unique and rich experience, get the expansion too, but with that, it feels like they focused on some areas more than others, and like they might be gearing up for a second expansion at some point, like with Civ 5. In particular I hope for them to focus on the combat AI a bit more. It's a little too easy to steamroll them on the battlefield, even an expansion down the line. Word of advice: Even if you're just starting out with the game, play it on at least Gemini, because it is way less challenging than some Civ games.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
												It's like Civ 5 but not as interesting. There are many things missing about it.PROS1. Like Civ 5Easy to pickup since it's like Civ2. Nice VideosIntroductory video is cool.3. Satellites / OrbitsInteresting. Something novel. Like auras.4. ObjectivesI like the way you can complete objectives to accelerate the game.5. QuestsI love the quests where you get to choose between benefit A or benefit B. Gives you choice that may or may not be important to you.CONS1. Missing the FunYou just don't have the fun in this game.2. Tech WebVery boring, very slow. Just a mind map.3. MiasmaIt does not make the game fun. It actually slows things down as your exploration is hampered by -10 life.4. Nothing uniqueEvery race is the same.5. AffinitiesRevolves around the Miasma. Why? What does your affinity have to do with Miasma immunity? Harmony, Purity, Supremacy. Doesn't really make a lot of sense.Specialization resources? You land, you find Xenomass(Harmoney)/Floatstone(Purity)/Firaxite(Supremacy), you beeline to using that particular resource. WTF? Just a replacement for Horses?6. Build Expeditions (limited by Expedition Module)They are randomly generated as you explore. They give good benefits but they are so slow. You have to move a Explorer onto the Progenitor Ruin, then build a expedition and you are limited by the number of modules.Not to mention aliens and Miasma.

number of helpful: 93 of 178 people (52%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												Hmm...i have mixed Feelings about this Game.First i was amazed by the new Hud, Fractions, Units, by the new research System... but now after about 50 hours its already boring and im happy when im done with my Achievements to uninstall the Game.Pro and Contra	 + New Fractions, Units, Hud, Techtree/Researchsystem + The Graphics and Animations are a little better than at Civilization V. + Nice sounds and good ambient Music.+ Steam Workshop Support+ The Multiplayermode seems to work fine, but take this with caution, only played 2 Matches.+ Running smooth and didnt crash a single Time in 50 Hours.- The AI is terrible. Sometimes unable to build Units, just bulding Cities and even more Cities, not gathering ressources. At other times they attack you out of the blue, for no reason.And this happens like a gamble, totally random and can happen on every difficulty. Often all the AI does is a) nothing besides spamming Cities or b) Steamrolling you with a an Army that contains mostly just one Unit type. If you play with AI vs AI, your AI is mostly nothing more than a victim. On higher difficulty they just get rushed without resistance. For fun i tried several settings like 2v1, 3vs1, 2vs2  and even 6 AI + Me ( playing defensive) vs ONE Enemy AI, and guess who won? the Enemy rushed one unable Teammate after another. Also hilarious, when the AI ends up with a cashflow of MINUS 7000 per turn, like this- If youre not familar with Civilization IV or V, its hard to find into the Game, the Settings, Hud, and Overview are very confusing.-  Wonders and Quests have an insufficient  or confusing Descriptions. Also some Quests are bugged in case that they wont be completed, even if you did all required tasks, and sometimes they just repeat themselves over and over again. - No Match Statistics after the Game. I loved to see a Gameoverview at CiV 5, but here it seems to be missing. All together Beyond Earth has some nice new Changes, but also a lot of Civilization V in it.Thats not bad, but considering the high Price, Broken AI, confusing Descriptions&Menus and that the lack in variety makes the Game boring after "only" 50 Hours, its a tough decision. Currently I would say that you better install and try the DEMO before you buy it!  ( You can find it on the right side of the Game's Storepage )   To be fair, there is hope that it will be patched soon and even with its flaws it kept me entertained for 50 Hours, so it gets a "YES" from me, but please dont expect it to be Fun for hundreds of Hours, like former CIV Titles, because it just isnt.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
												I don't mean to rehash other reviews, so I'll try to be short:I'm running it on max settings with a good, large monitor, btw and still:* Hard to distinguish what's on each tile.* Unlike Civ V, many resources and technologies have unfamiliar names. There's very little intuitive about what you're getting by researching or building certain things. Especially since sometimes the bonuses aren't fully explained or apply to other new or renamed concepts.* Tech tree pretends to be less linear, but it's not. The exponential tech required for each subsequent trie means that you still end up going in a more n-level preferential pattern. I tried digging deep initially and paid for it.* Maybe my game was bugged or I did something wrong, but I was constantly surrounded with 2+ Krakens and 2+ siege worms at all times. For reference, since that doesn't mean anything if you haven't played, these are alien monsters that one-hit the majority of units in the game. They take about 5 turns to kill from a distance with mid-game units. I was unable to expand due to the siege worms and being surrounded by "miasma," which damages and hinders units on tiles with miasma. While I'm aware there are techs to get rid of it, the rest of the AI didn't seem to have the same problem.* I kept wishing I was playing Civ V, or something that more closely resembled it, actually--even the base game without the DLC's. They should have used more familiar concepts with regard to resources, technologies, and buildings.* While they could be an interesting game mechanic, the constant quest popups get old quickly.On a positive note, I really liked how intra-civilization trade was a viable option in this game, with included techs and culture (or whatever) options to boost that option; most especially because I was surrounded by aliens that would blockade my trade routes otherwise.Maybe with updates and DLC this game will be better but honestly I think there's a fundamental problem with the art design and the general naming conventions etc. that would stop me from playing--again for context, this is coming from someone who loves scifi novels and has an engineering BS and is a year away from an MD, it's not like I'm unfamiliar with the pseudo-scientific terms they were trying to use.Last, sorry I know I didn't keep this short, I found the interface overall more difficult to use than Civ V. They repositioned many of the old menus, and there's no longer the top-left drop down menu with the most important views (units, tech, etc.)--I made significant use of that panel in Civ V and its exclusion was frustrating. WRT menus, the art design used a very monochromatic theme with poor visual differentiation. Hard to read.

number of helpful: 41 of 77 people (53%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												Sid Meier's Civilization has been one of my favorite PC series since I first laid hands on Civilization II. With the more recent release of Civilization V, my love for the franchise was rekindled; the revamped, addictive gameplay model was remarkably difficult to put down. When Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth was announced, I figured developer Firaxis would keep the trend going. Thankfully, that's definitely the case.Beyond Earth, as its name implies, is a sci-fi-tinged take on the Civilization formula. On different alien planets, you establish an outpost that becomes a full-fledged city. The names of the planets matters little; instead, each planet represents different map layouts. Some feature multiple land masses and smaller bodies of water separating the land, while others may have an extremely large land mass surrounded by ocean. There's a decent variety to choose from, along with more advanced types that feature tougher climates and layouts than the standard set. You can also dictate the overall size of the map, allowing for two, four, six, or eight different sponsors on any map.As you might suspect, a sponsor is essentially a nation or faction controlled by you, another player, or the AI. Beyond Earth features a total of eight sponsors. If you're willing to delve into the optional Civilopedia, you get a lot more information on the background of each sponsor and how each relates to real-world cultures. Each sponsor also has a distinct attribute.There are even more options at your disposal when beginning a new single-player game. Aside from picking the size/type of map and sponsor, you also choose a colonist type. You can also choose your spacecraft, which grants additional bonuses, like the ability to see all coasts or see all alien nests on the map despite the standard "fog" that needs to be lifted via exploring units. Finally, you can choose what cargo to bring on your journey, essentially providing another bonus.Having all of these starting options and choices helps to make each single-player game feel unique, regardless of how many times you play the game. The options aren't uncommon for the Civilization series, but I enjoyed the sci-fi spin. Every bonus or ability provided by cargo, spacecraft, colonists, etc., helps you mold the game to your play style. Any game can be won in a number of ways, so you're pretty much free to explore the victory condition that you'd prefer.Most victory conditions are spread across three different affinities that you can explore: Harmony, Purity and Supremacy. You either choose to live in peace with all forms of life on the planet, wipe out alien species or dominate opposing sponsors. You can devote time to all three affinities or focus on just one. Each affinity "levels up" as you gain points by completing branches of the Tech Web. This in turn provides you with new technology, units and buildings to further enhance your cities and sponsor.Leveling up your affinities provides special bonuses, often to military, land and sea units once you hit certain milestones. The different affinity bonuses do a solid job of complementing their intended path, but some of the military-focused upgrades get a little generic and repetitive.While the Tech Web is chock-full of various technologies to explore, it's a bit clunky and difficult to navigate. The biggest issue I had was pinpointing the natural progression of the affinity on which I was focusing. It doesn't feel as organized as it should, and for a new player, it is absolutely overwhelming. While Civilization V focused much of its early game on battling against barbarian hordes in order to gain footholds and experience for starting cities and units, Beyond Earth has a slightly slower pace. Barbarians are replaced by alien bugs, which are generally peaceful unless you attack first or get too close to their nests. Instead, many of your early turns in Beyond Earth are going to be focused on exploring. As you roam the map, moving from one hexagonal tile to the next, you'll luck into resource pods, which can provide quick boosts to base resources like energy and science.Once you've mapped out a sizeable portion of the area and have likely run into rival sponsors, you'll want to begin expansion by designating new outposts. Once an outpost is established, it slowly grows as long as it remains healthy. Health essentially replaces the happiness stat of other Civilization titles, but maintaining it doesn't feel nearly as problematic as it did in Civilization V.As cities expand, they occupy more of the surrounding tiles. These tiles can be modified by worker units, which enhance or mine the natural resources. As in other Civilization titles, you can automate a lot of unit functions, but you'll likely want to be hands-on with most of them. Unit speeds are pretty quick, so most turns pass quickly.The only real issue I've had with Beyond Earth is that the opposing AI is remarkably docile. On various difficulty settings, I've had to really work hard to trigger any sort of diplomatic incident. When you encounter new sponsors, they're generally jovial enough to immediately engage in a dialogue with you. You often receive notices to open borders or establish trade.While perfectly playable via local means, with both LAN support and single-machine "pass the mouse" modes, Beyond Earth also hosts online multiplayer. There don't seem to be many players still using it, as I'd only run into one or two hosted rooms at any time of the day.Passive AI and lackluster online support from the community isn't enough to make Civilization: Beyond Earth a total wash. If you've enjoyed the series over the years, you'll likely spend many hours with this entry as well. It deviates just enough from the excellent Civilization V to be a worthwhile experience, and it offers a different pace than its predecessor, so even though it's not a significant upgrade, it's still pretty remarkable.

Posted: September 16, 2015
												Until Rising Tide is released, I simply cannot recommend this game. It's been out for around a year now, and only then did Firaxis realize what was wrong. They released it in an incomplete, unbalanced, unforgiving condition. I'd lovingly pay to actually have the complete version of this game, and I already have. But for now, let's outline some details.-The diplomacy of the base game is absolutely halfassed, and the AI's are way too predictable.- Affinities are a fantastic addition to the civ formula, but it seems like the Harmony affinity trumps all every single time. Thus surfacing some serious power balancing issues.-The miasma. Who's idea was this.... it makes the difficulty so artificial it's crazy.-The amount of tile improvements you can build gets extremely overwhelming. It would have been better to just upgrade each existing one and and a few new ones, rather than have a new one for every other technology on the absolutely massive tech tree.To sum up my thoughts on beyond earth, wait until rising tide comes out.EDIT: This NEGATIVE REVIEW is for the standalone base game. If you want a fantastic Civ experience, then play this game with the Rising Tide expansion.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												Unrefined, cumbersome, broken, yet still seems more fun than Civ 5.  The virtue tree is neat.  The unit upgrading system is fun, yet inconsistent (if you don't select an upgrade because you're looking to take a different upgrade path, your unit will still cost more, but have no benefit from the increased cost).  City managers for automated improvement building are gone.  Just finding the building queue and where to set your specialists is beyond poorly designed.  Actually, the city screen as a whole has taken a huge step backward from Civ 4.  Workers have no command to build a road network of their own, aside from the most basic route-to command.  Dozens of times, I have had to reapply the go-to command to my units.  Practically zero explorable objects on a large map.  Trade routes become quite annoying as your empire grows, as you have to re-apply the trade routes every 30 turns.Oh, and the game is occasionally unwinnable.  The game bugged out when we dominated the opponent.  Team 2 was removed, but no victory was given.  We even went and finished a second victory condition, but that simply made my game crash.  I was unable to rejoin the game, as it won't allow you to join a game where there is only one team.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												As a huge fan of Alpha Centauri, I was longing for this game, hoping it would recapture that magic and bring it back to us with updated graphics and an UI that didn't suck.In short: It doesn't.The general atmosphere does a decent job at imitating SMAC: SciFi Setting, fictional tech quotes, aliens, and so on. Beyond Earth even goes - well - beyond Civ 5 by adding the orbital layer, covert ops, quests, excavations and the affinity system.Unfortunately (based on my limited trial run) the affinity system feels like a slog and doesn't even come close to replacing the custom unit system of it's inspiration. The rest of the disappointment can be filed under the one thing that Beyond Earth absolutely nailed from Alpha Centauri: The terrible UI. Obviously 15 years are not enough to fix that. The trade route system is annoying busywork, the help system is even worse that in SMAC but the most brain-dead design decision must have been to blur out the most essential stats every time you enter a management window.Firaxis could salvage this game with nothing but some UI-teaks (coincidentally exactly the same thing that SMAC would have required for a re-release). But as it stands now this is a waste of enormous potential.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												While the game is fun to play hundreds of turns one after another. There is a few issues that could make anyones gaming experience a nightmare. My laptop operates on Windows 8, which as you may know loves to update all the time and when ever it feels like it. In order to play a game off steam I have to keep my windows 8 up to date. But thats not a horrible thing.  What really sucks is while in-game a message prompts you to decide to help a friend, ignore him/her and etc. The message  requires a decision in order to move on because it is that players turn. While in this prompted message I can click on any button and all the visual and sound effects still work. Except nothing happens. Message stays there, game doesn't do anything (let it sit for an hour to think). The game has a lot of bugs, that were cheaply brought over from the previous games interface. What you get is what you bought, right? I suggest staying away from this game, the $50 is a sunk cost. The game is worth only $25 for the amount of content it brings forth. Overall the gaming experience is long, lacking a good bit of fun and drags out everything. You will be playing for 300-1000 turns probably.Visuals: 4/5 Zooming in further would be nice to look at details, even with the graphics up almost the whole way.Overall: 3/5Lacks content, and fun.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												Updated Review:The game has a lot to live up to. Civ 5 Was released in 2010 and is still a game I can say that I still love to play 4 years later, which is a pretty impressive feat. It is also the 3rd most-downloaded game on Steam after TF2 and Dota 2. Unfortunately for me, Beyond Earth just can't live up to its predecessors. At this stage, we've all been so spoiled with just how amazing Civ 5 is that it ends up being boring for most of us. I think there's more to it, and i'll elaborate below. Here's a quick pros & cons list:Pros:Graphics are good and appropriateOpening cinematic is greatMusic is interestingTrade Routes have been improvedWorkshop is availableDecent capturing of an Alien landscapeGame is Balanced Orbital level is coolCons:Gameplay is boringVictory types are confusingTech Web has no real sense of direction Affinities don't add to gameplayQuests are randomUnit selection is supremely limited (no AA, no submarines, no missiles)8 Civilizations... (we have WAAAAAY more in Civ 5)Storyline is nonexistent (aside from an amazing opening cinematic)Game is too balancedNaval Combat is dumbGame is overall a boreFor me, I've gone through two playthroughs of this game. Honestly after that, I can't really find a good reason to go through and do it again. The game is okay, but compared to what was available with the first iteration of Civ 5 (which changed almost everything) This game, despite not being a DLC (which would have made more sense to me, this is just what happens after a space victory.) Doesn't feel like it was meant to be a standalone game. All the units, despite their distinct looks, are very obvious reskins of eachother, and really the differences are negligible. Affinities serve no real purpose in-game other than cosmetic appearance, and a few unique units only available to certain affinity levels. The tech web, while it is different, doesn't really add much to the game--and it's not very well explained as to what your goal is supposed to be with it. The game feels too well balanced. There's no definite reason why you should go with a certain affinity over another depending on your playstyle. As a person who's accustomed to seeing similar skins in RTS games like Wargame and Command & Conquer, there are definite advantages to playing for a particular side/team depending on your playing style. Affinities, are a half-baked attempt to do so. They don't actually add any elements to cater to a particular playing style, and given the lack of unit variety ultimately don't add definitive advantages to  choosing a particular affinity over another--they're ultimately cosmetic.Conclusion: All in all, I did sort of enjoy my two playthroughs of the game. I didn't feel quite like I do when I play Civ 5, and have to cater my strategy to each person. The graphics arent better, nor are they different enough to actually consider it a separate game from Civ 5,  it would have made more sense as just another DLC. There are some improvements to the game over Civ 5, but not enough to justify the high price it's been given.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16
												The most underrated game in the Civ series. BE has a steeper learning curve than the earlier Civ games, but after a few playthroughs, it's really fun. The tech tree is replaced with a tech web that you can traverse in many different ways, and the optimal choices for how to play it are much more map-dependent in this game than previous Civ games (though probably less character dependent, unless you have rising tide). I recommend playing it both with and without the expansion because it's a completely different game. The original game is about coping with scarcity and the expansion is about exploiting abundance. One drawback of the game is that it feels a little too much like a race, at least at the higher difficulty settings because the win-conditions are achievable without exploring all that much of the tech web. It's possible (and even likely) that the strongest/richest/most technologically advanced civilization won't win because you can race to the victory conditions faster by skipping a lot of the improvements to your civ. Internal trade routes are also broken (way too valuable, and even more so in RT where health -- the one thing that checks expansion in BE -- is easier to come by).

												I was excited when I learned about this Civ because it looked awesome on paper, so I preordered it. When I first started playing it, I found it awesome. New ressources, trade routes, aliens, different affinities. My first few games were really fun and I suffered a lot from the "one last turn" disease... But then I realize that after 20 hours of gameplay, I pretty much made everything that could be made in the game.. and this is not normal for a Civilization game... I still don't feel that way in Civ5 and I have over 75 hours of gameplay. Things that should have been in Beyond Earth :-Different types of map, not always the same green-blue thing all the time-More factions-ScenariosThings I don't like in the game-The technology tree is pretty confusing and you'll often choose a technology randomly because you have no idea what else to do-Every game I did, I had to press next turn for the last 30 turns without doing anything else, pretty boring...-The simulation for all the A.I. is awfully long, I mean really really long even with a good CPUBeside that it's not a bad game, it feels more like an expansion to Civ5 than anything else... So the 60$ pricetag is not approppriate in my opinion. Buy it if you can have it at less than 30$ or it's not worth it

												I love Civ! Been playing it since Civ 1. Racked up a silly amount of hours saying 'one more turn'. But Beyond Earth looks, feels and plays like a FanMod 'skin' of Civ V. I paid 70 bucks for it - and I was ripped off. Dont make the same mistake I did. If youre a Civ fan like me, wait till the price drops way lower. If you've never played Civ before, buy Civ V instead.

number of helpful: 24 of 44 people (55%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 14, 2016
												Don't buy. Don't support money grabbing developers. This game is completely abandoned and will not receive anymore updates. They have moved on to Civilization 6 and will never care for this game ever again.This game lacks everything Alpha Centauri was and much much more. Beyond Earth draws alot of parallels with Civilization 5 despite tech tree changes and ocean city building. The only redeeming factor is the alien lifeforms, which shares the same mechanisms as barbarians with a hostile/friendly switch depending on whether you attack them or not. Alpha Centauri does this dynamic much better by incorporating the player's enviromental impact on the planet, with the planet's innate terrestrial lifeforms.The AI in this game plays very defensive and is relatively easy to dominate on the hardest difficulty. Diplomatic power plays well with the different tradable doctrines. However, falls short when it comes to the classic Sid Meirer narrative.This game costed 60$ upon release with the Tidal expansion DLC 30$. Anyone who payed that amount is to this day, disappointed, and very likely never to trust Firaxis' compentency ever again. Including the upcoming Civilization Six. If you buy this game now, know that you are supporting complacency within, the already ever growing pretentiousness of, delusional game creators and artists.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2016
												I got this game out of the Humble Bundle and it ended up in my backlog.  I played through a few maps on Quick, with medium difficulty.  This is a review out of that, coming in March 2016, with a map pack of DLC but not the expansion pack DLC.The "Not Recommended" is on this game as the thought that it is a $30 separate release.  You can usually get Civilization 5, Gods and Kings and Brave New World for that on sale.  Spend your money on that.Value:  I normally don't put a value review in my reviews, but this game needs an exception.  It's simply not worth what has been asked of it.  It's a total conversion DLC that was sold as a separate game.  It's not a full game, it's a reskin of the Civ 5 engine that was already 3 years old when this game came to market in 2014.  In 2016, it's simply tired.  It's not worth $30.  It's probably worth $15.  The price should adjust accordingly, because it is tactically stale at this point, and I have less than 30 hours in the Civ 5 franchise (Civ 5, BNW and BE aggregated).Plot and Mechanics: 6/10.  You play a nation of colonists freshly landed on an alien world, who must survive through turn based strategy to a number of varying victories.  Unlike Civ5, the goal here isn't military, it's resource management and city-simulation.  You'll need a military, but it is not the best way to win in my experience on PvAI.  As a result, the games feel overly long, because there are long periods of downtime where you're not doing anything.  The plot is absent.  There's literally nothing. The leaders don't have personalities, the planet doesn't have a history, the aliens are basically background pageantry.  I'm getting angry with how little was realized out of this while writing my review.  Let's move on.Graphics: 8/10.  This game looks amazing, and some of the community mods make it look utterly stunning.  I'm giving half credit to the map texturing to the devs, because the textures were their doing.  The sandy planets, volcanic fissures, oceans, stations, aliens and soldiers all look freaking cool.  I love the motif and the design decisions to differentiate the human colonists based on their colonial decisions rather than their heritages.  With that said, there are so many UI problems and readibility problems on the map that I turned to the community to resolve some of them.  These are easily resolved issues that could have been fixed at any point in the last two years of this game, but it's still really hard to tell which tiles are unhealthy, which units are in a hex and who owns them.  I had to look up online how to access my trade and diplomacy maps because the information isn't adequately presented on one screen (like Civ5's diplo bar).  The information interface is a chore, but the quality here is very good even if the usability and presentation is lacking.Sound: 6/10.  The backing tracks are really enjoyable, and addicting.  I found myself thumping my head along with the ambience music a few times.  The leader vocals are horrible, however, to the point of being an absolute chore to listen to in the game.  I am fairly certain a university acting troupe could outperform this script.  It's dreadful and drags the entire immersion of the game down.   Unit sounds are bloody amazing, however.  The action sounds of Marines, CNDRs and even the Siege worm sound epic and crisp.  It's clear Firaxis put a lot of work into this part of the game and it shows.Gameplay: 7/10.  I'm going to make a few specific ratings, because this review is a comparison setting BNW Civ5 at 10/10.  I'm going to justify to you why this game is seven-tenths as good as Civ5.The Tech Web (Good):  The tech web, which is an utterly unreadable mess of organizational progress, replaces the Tech Tree from Civ 5.  It's a good change.  Yes.  A good change.  The progression is much less linear and it fits the motif of this being a post-human civilization made by humans.  Every game I've had plays really differently, and there aren't the obvious power spikes of Civ 5.  That's a really enjoyable change to the game that was an excellent decision, even if it takes getting used to.Victory Conditions (Bad):  The victory conditions being largely non-military really makes the game lag between turn 100-250.  You might have a military, but it's hard to use it, and you won't want to, owing to the amount that all of the AIs will absolutely hate you.  Most of the AIs do a peaceful route, and I haven't once been attacked in two separate 300 turn games.  That's not Civ, that's Sim City.  So what replaced Domination victories?  There are 5 separate thematic victories that encourage you to do things like terraform the world, or reconnect with Old Earth.  They're thematically cool but really randomly granted.  If anyone ever played the Dune Total Conversion mod for Civ 4, they feel just ripped from that mod.  Once again, it feels like these are DLC add-ons to a Civ5 that should have provided non-military wins to a military game, but instead we got a new environment that places non-military wins in a non-interactive game.Alien AI (Good):  The aliens really behave like a huge powerful faction.  They are neutral towards those that don't bother them and are vicious to those who seek and destroy them.  It's a nice change from Barbarians.Early Game (Disastrous):  There is no early game.  None.  You can't rush anything and swarm an opponent.  It's too had to get good production going and too hard to pressure anyone with how utterly crippling health values are.  The bonuses from Virtues is too strong to not go for early culture, and as a result you wind up with a very insular and passive early game.  This isn't unenjoyable, but it's a disasterous change from Civ 5, because it's just not fun in this game to do these things.  Exploration of the map doesn't feel as tactical as it did in Civ 5.  You're not looking for early military experience to fuel a great person, because you don't get awarded great people.  Wonders are basically non-existent, so there's not really any goals to work toward if you aren't being a warmonger.  It ends up really ruining this game after the first few times you play it.Quests (Mixed):  The idea of quests is super cool.  You have these quests that let you mold your civ after every time you build a new building for the first time.  That's the not-cool part.  Each building has a corresponding quest that will fire the same every single game.  It's repetitive customization.  It would be nice to see more dynamic events that have a mean-time-to-happen implementation instead of triggered events from the construction of buildings.  It doesn't seem like you're really doing anything with these quests, just that they're some form of gameplay for the early game.Replayability; 5/10.  I have no interest in playing this game multiplayer.  It's an unbalanced mess of a game that I imagine would be really really frustrating playing against another human being.  Hell, it's kind of frustrating playing this game against an AI.  The question of building wide vs building tall, building economy vs building military, building culture vs building science ... have all been ruined.  The economy of tiles is a mess in this game, and resource starts and location typically dictate if this game is even playable.  There is no story to complete, and I feel like you can see everything this motif has to offer in maybe 5 games.  While there is some replay added by Affinity specializations, this ultimately falls short of the rich environments and synergistic gameplay that Civ5 offers.Verdict: 5/10.  This is an ultmately forgettable title from a developer that has made some really wonderful and enjoyable games throughout the years.  What's frustrating about Civilization: Beyond Earth is the abundant potential teeming everywhere in the game.  This could have absolutely been an excellent title.  However, any brilliance shown is short-lived.

content:
Posted: January 25
Short story: for the TL.DR people.Years after you’ve launched your first satellite into space your people have taken to the stars, in search of new hope for humankind among the stars.Game Story:You are one of the leaders send into space to find a habitable planet, in order to do so you are sponsored by a corporation, a cooperative, a union etc. They all have different outlooks into how the world works and so you must choose carefully your sponsors before you set for the stars.Scale:GreatGoodDecentNot badBadNopeGame:Graphic: GoodSound: GoodAnimation: GoodAI: BadGameplay: GoodModding: DecentClarifying the scale:- Graphics are good, of course there is always room for improvement especially since it doesn’t look all the different from previous titles that I’ve reviewed Civilization V. Although that being said it does have this added flavour of Affinity which we will delve a bit more in Gameplay and of course the whole sci-fi feeling to it.- Sound is good, but like previous titles has its hiccups sadly it’s to be expected when the level of change in other aspects it’s not that huge. Of course it’s not to say it’s bad or any of the sort, but it’s good enough that it’s not annoying.- Animations are good, albeit not great, that being said it does bring “new” explosions and somewhat different textures. Some places could’ve used more love than others, of course that can be said even more about the AI and few changes it has to it. Now the feature of changing the clothes of leaders compared to their Affinity was a nice move, which I’ve been waiting for in other previous titles to happen that being said the changes are so minimal you won’t even notice them if you talk with the leaders a lot.- AI sadly is still a mess and will probably will still be a mess, even with the Rising Tide update it didn’t do much in terms of learning the AI. So you will go to war or do peace in the most ridiculous of moments for the most mind boggling reasons.- Gameplay is of course good since at first glance it does look just like a reskin of the previous title, that being said it does add its own small flavours such as being able to control if the trade routes will keep doing the same route or not by ticking it on and off. Affinity which changes not only the look of your troops but also their stats and what they are specialized in, with the Rising Tide update there was a nice change which I was eagerly expecting which was to be able to make hybrids of the Affinity. Albeit not all troops were able to be hybrids, to my sad discovery. Another cool feature was cities on water, which I hoped of before the game came out, which comes with being able to ram units if you are moving the city on that tile.Affinity was a newly added feature that was divided into 3 categories later on having +3 sub categories (for the hybrids) in Rising Tide. Those being Harmony (alien and human DNA), Supremacy (robot and human DNA) and Purity (enhanced human DNA, purely human).- Modding is decent mostly because I haven’t bothered to delve too much into it, from what I can see it does have some mods whether they are good or bad I can’t say for certain so I will remain on decent for now until I do more research if I get time for that.Conclusion: for the TL.DR peopleGame is not bad, but it could’ve been a whole lot better unfortunately I would not recommend buying it for full price, wait for sale and see if you can get Rising Tide in there as well. With that out of the way, if you are looking for a more sci-fi less religion kind of game it’s worth the try. It’s not a bad game but Civilization V isn’t good either without it’s expansions and countless DLC milking. Keep in mind this comes from someone who was looking forward to this game and hoping not to fail completely, kind of did in my honest opinion and I am sad that I spend so much… I would still recommend it but only if you get it on sale! And I do mean sale I don’t mean 10-30% I mean 75% the game had/has potential if they are willing to fix it and do it better. If they decide to pick up the mantle and give it a full overhaul, I might change my outlook on the sale.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												This game fails really hard on almost every new feature its implementing. It is really a shame, because all the ideas behind new mechanics are great and promising, but poorly executed.Affinity system - just another way to track your science progress and it is not about your gameplay style. Also not really suitable for upgrading units as is, could be done SO much better.Espionage system - clearly not tested enough, anything beyond "steal tech" is too risky and too hard to execute.Health system - not rewarding/punishing enough, when you are higher than -10, you are totally okay. Also makes Diplomacy nearly useless without luxury resourses.Aliens - great replacement for barbarians, fun to fight with. Also, siege worm is amazing.Virtues system - great.Visual look - great.New science "tree" (more like web) - confusing as hell and all the icons are poorly done.Really dissapointing Wonders - too basic and lacks Civ5 unique feel and artwork.Quests system - basic and repetitive, also buggy.New victories - seems kinda cool, but not tied in with gameplay at all. Emancipation victory is amazing.New races (sponsors) - really basic bonuses, bland and dull characters.Only 8 leaders presented. Also - why the ♥♥♥♥ can you take artists as colonists and they apparently give you health bonus? Why? Who would do that? I dont get it.Unit upgrading is amazing. Just need some work on affinity system.AI sucks as much balls as in Civilization 5. Maybe even more.No soundtrack. Almost.Overall... meh. Needs some expansions and overall work. Not worth the money now.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												This game has a massive amount of bugs in it. Two that affect me the most are not being able to run it in full screen mode on 120Hz+ monitors or via HDMI and AI that doesn't remember options that you've chosen and constantly asks you the same question over and over. Just yesterday, my game ended at the same time AI had asked me a question and it locked up the whole interface and I had to force quit losing any chance of saving it. This game lacks any original content and is very underwhelming. There aren't many civs, and the victories are too easy and disappointing. I cannot fathom why Sid would put his name on this. It should be titled "2K's Civilization" because it's rushed, full of bugs, and there is no communications about what's going to be fixed and when. This poorly made and expensive re-skin of Civ 5 is making me re-think ever ordering another civilization game again. It's shameful.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												This is literally worse than Civ 5. There a bunch of different victory types, but they all basically involve building some kind of late game wonder and waiting x amount of turns until it makes you win.You can't have a culture victory because they removed culture, tourism, and religion.You can't have a diplomatic victory because they removed the world congress and turned city states into a single hex that you can make trade routes to. They also removed luxury resources and severely decreased the importance of strategic resources so you don't have anything to trade for. You can have a domination victory, but it's almost pointless, because as said there's no luxury resources and barely strategic resources. A domination victory doesn't flow over fighting for valuable resources. You just fight because there's nothing else to do. The game plays the same way every time. Look around at what strategic resource the game started you with, floatstone, firaxite, or xenomass. Then choose an affinity based off of that. Research all of the techs that increase that affinity and get your end game wonder. Spend all your culture on the prosperity tree and choose health on all the "quests" so you don't have negative health (happiness). Ignore your neighbors completely because they don't do anything. Wait for your wonder to win the game.

												Civ 5 but stripped of everything the ideolgy progression is cool as you see you troops becomming more cyporg or alien like (if you go down the right affinity) but other than that I don't like it at all. Maybe with some very good expansions it might get good but... that sounds just like a cash grabbing machine and I hate it.  AND SOME HOW the multiplayer is even worse! Civ as always had a buggy multiplayer and would give civ 5 a 3/10 on multiplayer this one gets a whooping .5/10 just because it has it.

number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
												It's actually a step down from Civ V in a way. Civ V with the expansions has more options regarding things like the world congress and tourism. Civ V obviously also has a broader scope if you consider the techologies and stuff available in each age.The reason I recommend it however is that I find the pacing in Beyond Earth to be a bit faster and more dynamic. Things start to get interesting a lot a quicker. The early stages of Civ V can be a bit boring. The music is really top notch as well and the graphics are good. The wars can feel pretty dramatic.It fall short of the greatness of it's spiritual forefather, Alpha Centauri however, which was arguably better than it's counterpart, Civ II. Beyond Earth is certainly not better than Civ 5.Yet if you are a Civ fan looking for an alternate challenge/scenario, or new to this genre I recommend it as it's very easy to pick up and play. The faster pace does make campaigns quite interesting and if you are new to the genre and like sci-fi I would recommend. Especially if on a promotion! But if you are a Civ 5 fan looking for something better than Civ 5, i'd avoid it.

												I can't reccomend getting this game. Maybe when it's a couple dollars on sale...The game was released with major bugs and overall feels unfinished. number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
												From the third person I had all but assumed this a heartless copy of Civ5 and now thanks to one of Steam's free weekends, I can now say it very much is. Although I cannot recommend it now, for such a steep price when Civ5 offers so much more, expansions could remedy this problem in time. So unless you're a fanboy, I don't see why any reasonable informed consumer would buy this until expansions are released.That said, the new tech tree is convoluted and innavigable. Clearly its a spin-off of Endless Space's and they somehow managed to make it impossible to know anything about what's in it unless you mouse over every last technology. I've been at it for some hours already and I've seen a slew of "this guy made a wonder" messages which I much rather have seen as pop-ups in reference to me but I still can't figure out what tech unlocks what wonder from a glance yet because its represented so terribly. If anything, I'd rather uninstall this right about now and dive back into Civ5, that is if Age of Wonders or Endless Legend didn't exist and weren't almost unquestionably entirely better games.The only thing good about this game is the slight branching-off of everything. Dependent on your affinity, you can eventually make this or that unit along with choosing one of two passive boons to a unit every now & then. Otherwise the new culture mechanic just splits off into four stale long trees of military, growth, science, and production choices. Factions are nothing more than someone from some vague area of the planet; African faction being a black guy, the French-Iberia one being some old French woman, and the Russian guy being a generic Ruskie. Nothing about this game stands out and the prospect of inevitable overpriced expansions doesn't provide much hope for the future of this game, as again this is certainly no longer the best 4x turn-based game series.

number of helpful: 62 of 118 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
												Civilization Beyond Earth is without a doubt an excellent and fun game, sadly most of the reviews are trying to compare it with Civilization 5 + Gods and Kings + Brave New World or Alpha Centauri, but lets remember that expansions and dlcs should be released eventually and the game will become even better and also the game balance will come with time so dont expect a recently released game to be 100% balanced. I really dont get why so many bad reviews, this game definitely doesnt deserve it. Below I will point some pros and cons of the game and stuff that i would like to see on future dlcs/expansions:--> Pros:- The new aliens are a nice challenge on the early game, especially Siege Worms because you never know how they will react.- The new Affinity System is great, it gives players an option on how to devote their colony, so do you want your colony to remain pure and follow Old Earth ideologies? Or maybe make cybernetic enhancements on your people and spread chaos and havoc with robotic armies? Or maybe be one with your new planet and domesticate and integrate the alien lifeforms for your own purposes? Well, its your call!- The new map exploration is awesome, with your explorer units you search for Supply Pods which will give you small yields of Science, Culture or Energy and even a free Solar Collector or you can reveal the secrets of Ancient Ruins that will give you boosts on researches or the option for an affinity level or even investigate a crashed space ship which could countain the logs of a failed colonization mission giving you acess to new quests.- The new quest system is very interesting and offers the players many challenges across your games, the quests are generated based on how you are playing the game. Example: Spotting a Siege Worm will activate a quest that involves killing it and the reward will surely pay the effort, or making a trade route with a independent Station may trigger another Station to give you a quest to destroy their rival Station and as a reward they will give you a boost on the yields they provide. There are also quests that involves affinity levels and they will help you to develop you colony based on your actions during those quests.- The new orbital units are a great new feature, it allows you to deploy from Solar Collectors to boost the energy generation of your city to satellites armed with giant lasers that you can use both for defend or attack.--> Cons- There are very few sponsors (only 8) so there isnt much diversity on the games, at least they can pick different affinities.- The combat on Civilization Beyond Earth surely need some balancing, cities are much more powerful now and if you want to play Space Atilla early game it will be kinda hard since most units will be melted by the cities defense on the early game so you need to spend a lot of time on making very large armies if you want to conquer cities early on, however later on that is not a problem because the units at around 12 Affinity Level are already very powerful and it takes less than 5 turns if you are well positioned to conquer a capital, based on this the game pratically forces you to go for a domination victory on the late game where everyone else is at around 50%-75% on another victory type.- Trade routes are waaaaaaaaaaaaaay overpowered, every city can set 2 trade routes and if you get an auto plant you can get another one so basically its 3 trade routes per city. In my opinion a good number would be a max of 4 Trade Routes per Civilization and you can improve that to maybe 6 or 7 by making wonders, affinity bonus or quest reward.- The wonders on this game provides very weak bonuses, so most times you dont even bother making them because the bonus they grant you aint that great. The ones i usually make are the Ectogenesis Pod and the Gene Vault mainly to aid the city growth on the early game.- All the units are of the same color, ok you can see the colored icon but it would be nice if the units had your sponsor color.- Only 2 naval units, there is a ranged cruiser and a carrier, it would be nice if we could build submarines or a melee naval unit to conquer coastal city using only naval force.- The User Interface is confusing since everything is pretty much of the same color, seeing what is your city producing, on how many turns it will grow or how many turns to finish that beautiful wonder is very confusing and hard to see because everything including the small numbers are of the same color of your sponsor but im sure that can be polished.- The tech tree is nice and gives you freedom to focus on what you want, but it takes some time to get used to it and know what leads to what or what you need to reveal or improve the resources.- Covert Ops are waaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaay overpowered.--> What I would like to see on the future- A religion system that could work with your choosen affinity- More military units, especially naval ones- More sponsors, i think a number of 16-20 sponsors would give a good diversity to the game- Sponsors should have unique units/buildings. For example the PAC could have a special worker unit that improves tiles a lot faster and have +1 movement since they are focused on production or the ARC could build a special Spying Agency or another build which improves the spying activity.- Different alien types, it would be badass if there were different types of aliens based on the map type or something like that, that would add diversity to the game.- Improved military AI, sometimes the AI takes some very dumb decisions when you are at war with them.Well, thats my review for Civilization Beyond Earth, Im really enjoying the game and i believe that this game just need some polishing and im sure that with the future dlcs/expansions it will become even better than it already is.<<UPDATE>>Its a shame that Beyond Earth didnt receive all the love it really deserved, the expansion did good but the game sure could use of more content, sadly 2k left it to die and now the game barely gets 5k players, but the game is still amazing and u can have as much fun as u would have with civ5 but with an sci fi theme

content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												How do I begin? I love Civilization Games. I have been here since the start. I did my best not to get too hyped about this game. I had been scared that this game would totally flop. I would have preordered a collector's edition without any hesitation. My fears were many.After really thinking hard and playing this game and trying so so hard to like it, even love it. I have to say that I am truly disappointed. I am too upset about it. Everyone else have made great points and I am in total agreement. This game lacks personality, creativity, and polishing.  User Interface is a mess, diplomacy is non-existent, the races are too bland, so vanilla.   So much potential, This game feels rushed.  Why did you do this Firaxis? Must I wait for an expansion for you to fix the content? I like the fact you took risks with the new affinity and tech system, I like the orbital layer, but it all falls short. There is only a small definite amount of units to choose from. None that are unique, no upgrades that are unique.  I understood the favor system in trade. but favors are treated like a commodity in this game, you trade it just like you would a resource. Which is terrible idea. Favors are called favors for a reason, and they should have more weigh. What went wrong? There are many major bugs? I couldn't play fullscreen with the correct resolution? You didn't care enought to play test this game?  Anyone would have been happy to? No need for paying anyone for beta testing!As much as I appreciated that you tried to take Civilization to the stars, you failed. I am sorry. Let's see how you can fix it.7/28/2015 - Dev still had no fixes, and decided to make us pay for a new expansion to fix it.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												This game... is clearly is half-done.The AI is brain-dead, and turtles. There's NO threat at all of having war declared upon you.Even at higher difficulties, this game is a city-building sim, except you can't make more than3 cities until 200+ turns in.The UI is not intuitive, there's a lot of information that is missing that you should be ableto see in various interfaces, the civilopedia, diplomacy screen, etc. that is just missing altogether. You don't actually understand what everything DOES until you try it by playing a few times through.Aliens are only a threat to your trade routes and units that get too close, not to your cities.Affinities are mostly broken, wonders are underwhelming and aren't worthwhile - none aremuch better than a regular building, but at several times the production cost?!All of the faction leaders are bland. There's NO difference whatsoever in any of their behavioror characteristics in game - it's like eating a big bowl of cardboard.Don't buy this game until... actually, don't buy this game AT ALL.Don't buy anything else Firaxis develops from now on either, for that matter.This is yet another lesson, in NEVER PRE-ORDERING A GAME, EVER, FOR ANY REASON......not even if it's an overhyped, overpriced Civ game.
