												When I play first time Civilization, I'm maybe six or five years old. Civilization III is my childhood game and I always start playing from Civ III. I really like this game - because of soundtrack, gameplay and one other thing - classic theme doesn't change. After I don't play Civ IV and V, I stop playing Civ III. When I heard somewhere about Civilization: Beyond Earth I get it. I think: why not. It's a few years when I last time played this series. My first reaction is: "Wow. That game is really good." Then I can't stop playing. In two weeks I played 40 hours and I love this game. That was the best strategic game what I ever seen. Now I played 210 hours - and I still love this game. I like this game and I would recommended it to everyone.Good things in Civilization Beyond Earth is:- really good graphics,- good AI,- nice dimploacy and culture system,- nice ways to win,- a lot of interesting quests,- hotseat games,- fun for a lot of hours.Bad things in Civilization Beyond Earth? I think there is nothing.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth, takes the Civilization franchise into the Final Frontier. Settling an alien world, with new choices, familiar themes, allies and adversaries, I found the AI to be more sophisticated than even Civilization V, with alien creatures capable of wiping out soldiers with a single strike in the beginning of your campaign. You must be on your guard as the terrain itself can be hostile, with miasma deposits that damage you when you get near. The research tree is much more extensive than previous Civilization games, and is more dynamic, as opposed to linear, with branches and leaves to the research tree. I found this game to be more difficult than V, but it has a decent tutorial system to help you through the transition. I think for hard core lovers of the Sid Meier's Civilization series, you will have those who love it, and those who hate it, due to the changes. I think it is a pretty fun game, even with it's new features.

Posted: November 10, 2014
												Probably the weakest game in the Civilization series - coming from someone who has played II, III, IV, V and SMAC/SMAX.As many people have mentioned, Civ: BE is like Civ V, but stripped of half the gameplay elements (no luxury resources, no "proper" national wonders, no research agreements, no religion, etc.). Even the supposedly interesting parts (affinities, unit customization) don't make much of a difference, and the classic "wonders" fall flat.Outside of that, there are a quite a number of glaring issues with the UI (poorly comprehensible tech web, poor way to ignore unit upgrades for later, no way to truly tell how close players are to victories (simple scores don't cut it)) and bugs (uncompletable quests).Do yourself a favor, and stick to Civ V with GnK + BNW.

content:
Posted: November 12, 2014
												Basically a reskin of CIv V with a new tech tree and affinities as a secondary culture-driven perk tree.  The game feels not just lacking personality, as other reviewers have mentioned, but soulless.  There is nothing to distinguish the factions.  The technology sounds like a lot of neologisms without any underlying science fiction ideas to tie them together.  There is very little really new here for Civ V players other than the colorful terrain and units.  One of the biggest disappointments for me was to complete a special victory for my affinity and find out that there was no cutscene, no aftermath, not even a classic Civ-style graph of progress.  What is the point of having special victories attached to a story if there is no completion to that story except a 'You win' screen?  Very unfulfilling.  Not worth a premium price, wait for a sale if you want to try it.

number of helpful: 8 of 13 people (62%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												Look, I love Civilization. I've been playing Civ since I can remember, it's where I learned probably <70% of my world history, and I'm 20 years old. I've been playing since Civ 2, and I can actually remember Test of Time coming out. I should love basically anything Civ. But for several reasons, I feel completely let down. 1. Several game crashes. I was prepared for this, lock ups happen and I set autosave to every other turn just because of this.2. The aesthetic is just terrible. It's a bland mix of greens and browns even with graphics maxed, you can't see units in cities at all and it's incredibly annoying to try to figure out what miasma is, and as a strategy game, losing 10% of your units HP can be a game losing mistake. 3. The tutorial SUCKS. Like, big time. I've played 14 hours and I still have absolutely no idea how I'm supposed to progress through the affinities. It seems like it's just random quests + using the gaudy tech web, which takes a lot of my agency away.4. The tech web is interesting, but it's unbelievably confusing. There are so many options and halfway into the game you've got 18 options and none of them are a clearly useful tech. The constraint of being linear in the previous Civ tech trees added elegance to them, this time the freedom has made tech wildly unfun. I could very easily see what my path was going to be in other Civ games, and lining up timings with other facets of the game was not just fun, but it was exactly why I played those games. 5. Combat unit upgrades might as well be random. They tie into the affinity system that is already murky with no explanation. Your affinity level translates directly into how strong your combat units are. This means that if you keep getting quests that require end game techs or to destroy Alien Nests when there are none near you, you lose to your opponent who ramps up 5 affinity tiers ahead of you and busts into your base. More lack of agency.6. UI falterings in hotseat. I wanted to show my friend this game because I was excited about it, but after 5 turns or so the graphics started disappearing, like the prompt that your city needs a new production. Some of the prompts also don't show up in single player as well, like city growth. Not being aware of what's going on in the game can be really taxing, the reason that Civ V had so many prompts was to free up the player's mental resources and make it more about the strategy and less about the memorization.There are a few more smaller problems, but all of these are core issues with the game. Look elsewhere for your 4X gaming for now, it will be a LOT of work to make this an enjoyable game for me.Edit #1 After playing another game, I ran into affinities being rewarded through excavations, another random element which the player has little control over, I got 4 affinity upgrades and destroyed my opponents because I had a massive unit upgrade advantage.Edit #2 After another couple of games, I've actually come to realize that the choices you make as a player don't really matter against the AI. So, if you're only wanting to experience an easy game in single player, go for it. There is a turning point at which you're just always ahead of the AI. Which is okay I suppose, if it weren't for screwy multiplayer.  Anyway, if you want to play single player alone, you'll get about 30-40 hours before you feel like you've done mostly everything.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												As a hardcore Civ fan I have to say I was more than a bit let down by this release.  I completely understand some issues are bound to be in the release version of the game.  What I am mystified about is the sheer number of obvious game play breaking bugs that were in the initial release.  And when I mean obvious I mean glaring in your face omissions.  I have to wonder what the internal testers were up to?  If core mechanics are barely functioning then maybe you should have just disappointed the community with a pushed back release instead of dumping a half finished game on us.  Sadly this game feels half finished.  The lack of even the most basic ending sequence was a major let down.  Want to see some stats on what you did? Too damn bad.  Expecting some neat cut scenes for world wonders?  Too damn bad.  The tech web was a let down as well.  In the end you have virtually cleared the whole thing anyway.  They only real choices you are making are within the leaves that concern the affinity system.  So the hype of "choose your own path" was complete hogwash.  Another let down were the actual units.  I get the affinity system changes the looks and abilities somewhat of the units.  It just seems very sterile.  Very few options for units.   I guess I was simply spoiled on older Civ games with a much wider selection of units.  In the end I can't say I am satisfied with my purchase.  I have hopes some patches will fix some of the ciritical problems.  So if your planning on buying I would wait a few months until the dust settles and pick this up on sale.

content:
Posted: August 22, 2015
												The main issue with this game is a matter of expectation. Many negative reviews were written by people who bought Beyond Earth at $50, at which price the expectations outweigh the reality. This game is not a revolutionary addition to the Civ franchise; it is a high-quality, space-based DLC for Civ 5. The combat mechanics, diplomacy, and overall "feel" of the game are virtually identical to Civ 5. In that respect, Beyond Earth is very similar to the Final Frontier mod in Civ 4 Beyond the Sword. Both games do not deviate far from their parent platforms, and they both introduce new ideas to the series. The only difference is that one is $50, and the other is free.Of course, Beyond Earth is different from Civ 5, chiefly in the artwork, which is great. Even in design, though, Beyond Earth has a hard time escaping the clutches of Civ 5. Sure, the units look completely different, but the same 12 man formation for infantry is present in Beyond Earth. Even the menus are identical to Civ 5, with sleek, futuristic text being the only change.However, in the areas where Beyond Earth really needs to be different, it succeeds big time. The affinity system is great, and it lends much needed variety to the game. Also, the tech web gives a new perspective on research, forcing a player to choose one technology at the expense of another. These two features give the game replayability, something needed in any good Civ game.I bought this game when it was on sale for $20, and I'm very satisfied. At $20, it's about the same price as a Civ 5 DLC, which is what Beyond Earth is, essentially. I'm perfectly willing to buy another Civ 5 DLC.Conclusion: Buy it on sale.

												Beyond Earth brings a good look at what humanity might have to face when it reaches a new world. The game play is similar to nearly all recent Civ games, you need to research for technology, culture gives you certain bonuses, etc. I do like how they integrated alien life and how they vary in strength. They seem to be similar to the barbarians in the normal civs, but they also have super strong units like the worm/leviathan that you still need to watch out for later in the game. it's a well balanced play, I would like to see maybe playable alien races incorporated in, but that might change the direction of the game too much. Overall, pretty good game if you like the civs, I wouldn't by it for $50, but $35 seems to be a good price for it in my mind.

number of helpful: 11 of 19 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												I wouldn't recommend Civilization Beyond Earth at this point. It is extremely basic and barebones of a Civilization game, like playing a demo of something that was supposed to be grander. It doesn't feel like an alien world experience at all, the random roaming aliens are very generic, and every tile in the world (excluding miasma which is a hard to see and annoying unit damaging element that the AI is unable to pathfind around) is direct copy of Civilization 5 tiles. There is barely anything new to see in Beyond Earth, even though it's supposed to be an hostile alien world it ends up being less hostile and less alien than our very own Earth.The civilizations of Beyond Earth are also plain, there are only a few small statistic changes between them. They have exactly the same units, same city graphics, and obviously they are all human too, just different races / genders) so they definitely don't feel alien, just generic.Many of the things are just reskinned to look new, but underlying mechanics are the same. All alien resources are just normal resources in Civilization with sci-fier names, all alien tiles are literally the same functionally but just have a different visuals to them. Sadly even the visuals of the alien terrains are a bit bad, there are barely any variation (like visual difference between desert and plains, or tundra and grasslands) and everything is similar shades and covers. Mushrooms are alien, right? Lets put mushrooms everywhere. Purple is alien too? Yup, lets shade everything with it. Obviously every terrain type has their own textures, but the contrast between visuals of area is very very low.Happiness has been removed and replaced with health (it works the same, except your citizens don't get super healthy when they get ecstatic :D). Gold has been replaced with energy and at least I haven't seen much difference there. Policies have been replaced as Virtues and the Virtue system is more interesting (with bigger talent trees) but barely different from Policies of Civilization 5.Pure complaints aside, there are good things in the game too. It is nice to see a non-linear tech tree, even though they could have gone a bit wilder with it, instead they were afraid of really mixing things and ended up with half-linear tech tree that is more realistic but less fun as game mechanic. The satellite overlay is a nice concept, but they only work as temporary boosts. There is a simple unit tech upgrading system and it seems really nice.Perhaps at a later date in DLCs they'll fix and add things to spice it up. Currently it is not worth buying at a full price and you'll end up with very bad value for your money if you pay a full price now and add expensive DLC later.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												After playing a game of this, it feels way to similar to Civ 5.  I still love the one unit per tile strategy system but I would prefer to play Pandora with the expansions more.  There are more systems in Pandora than what Beyond Earth currently offers.  I am not a fan of the instant spy network and leveling up intrigue to cast huge capital decimating powers.  Feels there is little risk to just pumping this up.  There are really 3 different paths to take and to level up your military you should be pumping into an affinity to get more powerful units.  So instead of going for a specific research, any research with that affinity or quest will get you more powerful units - assuming you unlocked the basic version of course.  So to get the most bang for your buck, you can get a social/economical research upgrade and later on grab an affinity with it to boost military as well.  Overall I would not recommend this game in it's current state but that is about how I feel with every Civ game that first comes out.  This game really is about a $100 to be recommended and that is when the expansions come out.

												If I had to give the game a grade, would a B, not the best game I have ever played, but it holds its own, and is fun to play.First off, comparing to to what everyone will do - Sid Miers Alpha Centauri - It looses out here, the main things I enjoyed in AC, the movies, the voicework, and the dark focus, are all gone. Beyond Earth has a much brighter outlook in most ways, the aliens aren't horrifying, the factions are kind of tame, and in general, things feel less intense.But, not comparing it to that, its an extremely solid civilization game. It feels much more streamlined than everything so far to me, with passive unlocks and techonoligcal boosts, units never don't feel like they go obsolete, and buildings steadily increase in worth throughout the game. The quest system provides customization to your buildings which is nice, but I still feel like there is one fundamental thing that dissapointed me in this game-The game is fun and streamlined, but it could have had so much more worked pumped into its story and presentation, and would be awesome if it had.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												As someone who has played Civilization 5 for 250 hours I can say that while this game is very similar to Civilization 5 it has enough differences to be worth the price tag in my eyes. However as the game is likely to recieve expansions and dlcs that will take it from a great game to a fantastic game it may be worth waiting for a sale before buying. My review will mostly be comparisons to Civilization 5. With this in mind here are my thoughts:Interface;The interface design on the game is tightened up a bit on the main screen. Its a bit more sleek. However as a result some information is a bit small and hard to find at first as a result. Very functional and works just like Civ 5 for the most part. The biggest interface complaint is the Tech Web. The mostly blue and white coloring along with the almost unnoticeable difference between wonders and buildings on it makes it a chore to look at and sort through. Fortunately mods are already coming along to fix this so its not as big an issue as it might otherwise be.AI:A little better but the same as always. The game explains why the AI hates or loves you though so their reasoning is a bit more transparent. Unfortunately the AI is as dumb as always and having played on Gemini difficulty mostly they seem to barely present a challenge to an experienced player. As usual it seems like the main thing that keeps AI players afloat is the massive amount of cheating they do but in this game it seems like they don't do quite as much of it. The staggered spawning doesn't really matter because the AI returns to parity quite quickly. All in all its the same as its always been with the AI in Civilization. I  personally find the AI to be the weakest part of this game just like in Civilization 5.Civilizations:What has been lost in variety from Civilization 5 has been made up for by balance and customizability. Providing a series of mostly balanced options the game offers you a chance to customize how your Civilization starts and prevents the first 5 turns from playing out mostly the same every time. While I do miss some of the more fun and unique units and buildings from Civilization 5 I think the system used here is overall better. The loss of Civilizations with terrible bonuses is good. These Civs do seem to lack personality but to be honest they never had personality in Civilization 5. Any personality attributed to the AI by players was created by the implied history of America for example. Gameplay:On the surface it appears to be incredibly similar to Civilization 5 and in a lot of ways, it is. Units can't stack, the map is hex based, resources are reskinned but the same, ect. Despite this the game plays quite differently with aliens proving more dynamic and challenging than barbariens ever were. Spies have been revamped and are both more useful and interesting. Trade routes work on a by city basis as opposed to a global limit encouraging massive trade empires. The culture trees promote far more diversification and interesting strategies with their synergy bonuses. The tech web, a huge change to the previous tree system of Civ 5 diversifies each Civilization far more than unique bonuses ever did and allows for many interesting strategies. Except for the Domination all the victories have been revamped creating interesting ways for players to win and allowing for a lot of time for other players to interfere. Expeditions and resource pods create more variety and must often be fought over by the aliens squatting nearby. Miasma while often irritating makes positioning all the more important. Sattelites, one of the bigger new additions have many varied and useful effects on the land beneath them. I could keep going on but in the end while most of the changes feel small in my opinion they all add up together to create a game that feels and plays very differently from Civilization 5. It is certainly an iterative sequel but it is a different game from Civilization 5 in a myriad of ways.I am greatly enjoying my time with this game warts and all and I look forward to the dlc and expansions that will make it even better.

number of helpful: 12 of 21 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												I have 676 hours logged in Civ 5. It was my first experience with the Civilization franchise and I loved the game from the beginning, though as expansions were released I came to realize just how lacking the game had been when first launched. Despite this, I would still have rated vanilla Civ 5 as a pretty good game. Naturally, when I heard about Beyond Earth I was very excited. I expected it to be very similar to Civ 5 but more polished and with innovative new systems that would enhance the user experience. I expected to get a Civ 5 game that was worth being its own game. I have been VERY disappointed. The jump from Brave New World to Beyond Earth seems to be the same as from Vanilla Civ 5 to Gods and Kings. This is a stand-alone expansion, not a full game. I can see the potential for it to be great, but it feels unfinished. I've played for only a few hours and I don't really feel any urge to play any more.In my first play through, I noticed the following negatives:-Some buildings don't actually work. I built a Progenitor Garden (+20% health in that city) and it did nothing. I spent a lot of energy to build it immediately and the building didn't provide any boost to health. I haven't built all of the building and wasn't really paying attention to most of the buildings that I did build, but I can't help but wonder how many other buildings didn't actually have any effect at all and were just wasting energy.-Units weren't cleared from the Unit Upgrade window. As I upgraded more and more units, they simply overlapped each other graphically in the window. This is not a game ending issue, but I would have expected small stuff like this to be smoothed out before release. It adds to the rushed and unfinished feel of the game.-Baffling AI. I actually had an AI offer to renew a trade with me and when I accepted it, they refused and demanded that I offer them more to continue the trade. THEY WERE THE ONES THAT OFFERED TO RENEW THE PREVIOUS TRADE IN THE FIRST PLACE!!!! There are too many examples of bad AI in this game, but this example really epitomizes the players experience in dealing with the AI in most aspects of the game.- Related to the previous point, general diplomacy sucks. The AI holds onto old grudes FOREVER. For example, if you tell them to not build cities near you, that has a negative effect on your relationship for the rest of the game. I know that this occured in Civ 5 too, but I really expected some better diplomacy and international relations in this game. It's been 300 years... get over it already!-Each colony feels the same. Each sponsor gives a unique bonus, but this is not enough to change the feel of the game. Playing as any of the sponsors feels exactly the same with no appreciable difference in cultures. Each of the sponsors is obviously supposed to represent some faction that controls some large portion of Earth, but aside from the accent of the leader, there is no difference in the look or feel of the resulting colonies these sponsors produce.-Affinities. First, I like the concept of the affinities: that each group would have a different approach to the alien world on which they landed. That said, I would have preferred to have a system in which I could choose affinity abilities like with ideologies in Brave New World except using these new affinity specific resources instead of culture.There were some things that I did like:-Quests. The quest system adds a new level of customizability to the game. After constructing a building, a quest decision is presented to allow the player to choose one of two effects to add to that building. For example, you might be able to add +1 culture or +1 production to all of a certain building for the rest of the game.-Improved espionage. I like the changes to the espionage system, though this aspect of the game also suffers from feeling a bit unfinished.-Tech Web. Rather than a linear progression through a tech tree in which you will inevitably end up with all of the technology eventually, the tech web requires more strategic planning as to which direction your colony will take.These are really fairly minor changes for a full game. It seems as if the developers decided that because Civ 5 already exists and was a big success, that they could get away with minor improvements, change the art, and pass it off as a full game. If this was a brand new franchise, Beyond Earth might have worked as a fresh concept. Civilization fans expect more than a passable game though. I will probably buy the inevitable expansions and/or DLC, but only when they are on sale; the improvements that are sure to come should have been included in this release and I refuse to pay top dollar for upcoming additions.I am actually very upset that I spent $50 on this game; if I could get my money back, I would. I will keep this in mind if you somehow manage to make another new Civilization game, Firaxis. Lesson learned... don't preorder because the game won't be finished.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												TLDR: Fun early to mid-game mechanics, no soul, no end-game graphs.....  3/5. Would give a thumbs up if I at least had gotten the graphs at the end. The gameplay mechanics for this game were really fun. I liked the new terrain, the tech web (if not very intuitive), and quest options. Best part - definitely the quest options. Being able to customize what buildings do was really neat. The affinities were pretty cool too. I liked seeing my units get upgraded and change into the harmony units. Now for the bad. There was a serious amount of character lacking from the game. The silent characters seemed unfinished. I really wish that one of the leaders would actually speak. I almost missed the, "Would you like to make a trade agreement with the Queen of England?"There were glitches with the character upgrade screen. I had a carrier and a cracken like creature all jumbled up in what was supposed to be the screen for the kraken creature.Also after beating the game, I got to the end, NO GRAPHS. I'm sorry but that really♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥me off.After spending all that time playing, I really enjoy seeing my empire expand, seeing how much better I did than the other civs. It really feels like an ending. Instead you just get a, "You did the ________ Victory!" "Exit, or Just one more turn."That's when I felt like I got robbed. Where are the graphs???Overall 3/5. Fun mechanics for the most part. There seems to be a waiting game once you create one of the various final projects, that was annoying. I had two projects complete and had maxed out the harmony scale, and was at 8 on supremecy just waiting thirty turns to contact the other civilization.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												I wanted something with the depth of SMAC, I got CIV V with a space tileset and most features gutted.Improvements over Civ5* Quests are somewhat fun* "Overpowered" tile improvements, gives a little more depth than farms everywhere, similar to SMAC* Satellites are neatWorse than Civ5* Combine Health and Happiness to make the game dumber* Get rid of luxury resources to make the game dumber* Get rid of research agreements to make the game dumber* Get rid of great people to make the game dumber* Iteractions with city states is reduced to trade with them or pillage them for cash. Nothing else possible.* BORING QUESTS! Every time they're the same. At least give me 10 different ones that rotate or something. Nope, always "Solid State Citizen"* BUGGY QUESTS! The quests ask you to do impossible things (improve a resource that doesn't exist, etc).* Aliens are boring so far (I'm not in the endgame).By far the most disappointing thing is diplomacy and the other factions. They all have no personality, beyond the vaguest sketch. (I spy on stuff, I like money, I am an African Villager(!), I am a soldier)  They pick affinities (roughly equivalent to ideologies in CIV V, except they give you units too) randomly with no rhyme or reason. Even the diplomacy text is the same as CIV V! "Our disagreements have become too much to bear", "What do you think of this deal". Add a LITTLE personality guys. It's pointless to even engage with diplomacy because theres nothing to trade! No luxuries, no research agreements, no votes. They just ask you for open borders, and want to declare war on eachother.

												Only Mods and DLCs can save us now..........While it's nicely put together and bug free so far, those of you looking for a new "out there" experience are going to be disapointed. The majority of changes from civ 5 are cosmetic, renamed and/or reskinned, the new mechanics are superficial and lite, with even the opening movie looking cheap. Simply put, wait for a sale or you will feel like you have purchased a DLC at full game price. "Poison gas!!!! Oh wait in 2 tecs i can get rid of it and become immune to it......really, stay up all night thinking that up?"

number of helpful: 14 of 25 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 13, 2015
Sid Meier’s Civilization: Beyond Earth – The Collection is a turn-based 4X strategy game. Fleeing Earth after the Great Mistake that ruined it, you land on a distant planet to establish a new world, building cities, dealing with rival factions and determining the ideological path you want humanity to take for its future to come. This review takes into account the Rising Tides expansion set.Pros: After picking from one of twelve sponsors and customizing your faction, you start off with a single colony, building units, researching technologies (through an improved tech-web) and expanding your borders. You also manage (or automate) trade routes between your cities, other factions and neutral outposts. You can now build floating cities that behave differently from land cities: land cities expand their borders through Culture points, while floating cities claim territory by moving around. Also, while land has plains, grasslands, hills and forests, the sea bed will have coasts, reefs and oceans floors with its own lot of strategic resources and unique bonus resources. The five biomes are more than land/alien color palettes, they determine the map generator's algorithm, defines alien strength, speed and behavior (much more varied than the barbarians from Civilizartion V), and each biome has a unique Marvel quest. The reimagined diplomatic system is a breath of fresh air from former games of the franchise: gone are the resource trading and tribute paying, you now accumulate Diplomatic Capital points from buildings and agreements others buy from you, which you then spend in purchasing agreements from others and picking personality traits (each unlocks bonuses and unique agreements). Peace treaties are now negotiated with the new Spoils of War system, comparing scores from both sides' war accomplishments, the difference is then used to determine the "payment" (technologies, cities, resources) the loosing faction grants the war's victor. Furthermore, A.I. behavior is now defined in fear and respect levels: fear being your military strength compared to theirs, while respect rises and falls over time based on how well your faction is performing (ex: production rate, health, land improvement, each rival caring about different things) and actions you take (ex: build wonders, attack common enemy's city, sign agreement with common friend). Through science and a few mini-quests, you accumulate points in one of three different human evolution paths: human purity, cybernetics or gene tempering, eventually settling into either of six paths (the three affinities and three half/half hybrids), giving a much needed variety to factions' tactics and appearance. Archaeology comes around with its own twist, as you dig up artifacts that can be consumed for an immediate bonus, or collected for a larger bonus (including unlocking unique wonders). The game looks awesome graphically, and the soundtrack is worthy of a space opera epic.Cons: As is was case with previous games of the franchise, it's an incredible resource hog, each passing turns getting slower as the game progresses no manner how powerful your PC is. The performance issues also cause textures to occasionally load wrong, and the game is constantly re-applying textures as you move around the map. The fact that each factions are randomly customized for each playthrough removed a lot of the individual personality rival civilizations had in past games. You get so many bonuses (affinities bonuses, building bonuses, sponsor bonuses, diplomatic agreement bonuses, Wonder bonuses, etc) that they become meaningless as they aren't as fun to get anymore. Even with all the biomes, planets, and customization, the game still feels somewhat repetitive from one playthrough to another and I can't put my finger on exactly why.Verdict: ★★★★☆ - Next on your list!This is not Alpha Centauri 2, but it's still a pretty good game (just as long as you get the Rising Tides expansion set. Seriously, it's required). The re-thought diplomacy, its twist on water-cities and archaeology, and all the flexibility for buildings, units and factions, are enough to make it its own thing. It might not live up to everyone's expectations, but I'll nevertheless be getting a few hundred hours of gameplay by the time my focus turns to Civilization VI, which in my book is plenty of bang for my buck. For all its flaws, it's still a game I recommend.—————————————————————————This was just my opinion.If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up, and feel free to check out more of my (purely opinionated) reviews.

number of helpful: 20 of 37 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
												I reccomend this game with heavy reservations.Having dumped 40+ hours in it, I'd say it definitely is still fun. I had such a hardon for this game, but I was pretty disappointed in the end. The AI is terrible, I played normal in a massive Domination match, and was never attacked even though I played very aggressively and constantly spat in the face of my opposition, allowing me to slowly plow over the massive map over the course of 600 or so turns with little-to-no retaliation. Even mass-scale assaults were met with maybe 1-2 gun ships buzzing my infantry before being shot down.The spy system is a bit more advanced the previous ones, but it's the only thing the AI is good at countering, making it almost useless, but I haven't played it against a live person.The aliens, after you upgrade your infantry to level 3, aren't at all a threat, making clearing them a very, very easy task using a single of the mid-to-late game infantry to plow through them. Though, near the start of the game, the aliens can make expansion and resource aquisition extremely difficult, adding to the fun.In Civ 5, the barbarians leveled with you, making you constantly need to contend with them in heavier force than they had, but the aliens stay a measely 8-16 strength, and you'll have building defences that prevent combat altogether. The Seige worms (equal to a mid-level unit) are either far too aggressive early on, or not at all, leading to a quick death or a slight irritant. I enjoy the difference in technology routes, using Xenos as allies through Harmony, staying "pure" to humans, or going the cyborg/robot route, and the units aesthetics reflecting as such, but it doesn't really affect gameplay much, the individual perks barely changing between the three factions, as they're all more-or-less the same in combat, save for slight differences in mobility, which play much less of a role in combat than you'd think.The starting of the game can be an uphill battle, but once you're at the top, it's far too easy and smooth, even on higher difficulties.But, with some more expansions or mods, I feel this game will be one of the best Civs yet.Buy it if you've got the money, but I'd reccomend waiting.

number of helpful: 14 of 25 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
												I've played every Civ game including Alpha Centauri.  I'm a pretty big fan of the games in general, but this one is a lame duck in my opinion.   The tech tree is messy and nonsensical, there are no faction specific units or buildings, and the unit progression is lame.  It is in every way significantly less good of a game than Alpha Centauri.  The fluff is boring, the end game is boring, the world interaction is boring.   Even though Alpha Centauri was an alien world,  it was easy to 'understand'.  The tech blurbs were sensible, the 'memoirs' phase of leadership added great fluff, units were awesomely customizable, the tech tree made sense.Beyond Earth doesn't make much sense, doesn't really seek to appeal to the user.   Building a wonder feels boring.  Resources feel somehow both boring and disconnected. It is literally like they took the worst parts of Civ 5 and the worst parts of Alpha Centauri and made a game from that.  There are some tiny UI improvements, I guess.

number of helpful: 124 of 240 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												If you enjoyed CIV5 and love a sci-fi flavor on the best empire building strategy franchise out there, then I highly recommend you pick this game up. Nevermind the whiners crying about a lack of content, comparing this game to CIV5 + $80 worth of DLC. More content will come, and there is already community submitted content via the Steam Workshop. The new additions to this game from CIV5 are worthy of note, and definitely give the game a flesh of it's own; the covert ops game mechanic alone makes for an interesting addition to the different strategies you can use to achieve victory, the tech tree is an interesting visual interface change from the boring list you had in the previous game, the new quest mechanic is also a nice touch in giving each playthrough a unique feel.  If you are on the fence, I recommend at least trying the demo. I pre-purchased this game, and I have no doubt that it was worth every penny. I really look forward to what else Firaxis has in store for this game. Cheers.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2015
												Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth was not good. Hmm, maybe, that's putting it lightly, it kinda sucked. For a game that could have been great, it was sub-par. A glorified Civ V mod.Then Rising Tide came out. The 1st eXpansion for Civ:BE, quickly followed by two patches. What we have now is a good game.That's right, Civ:BERT (I love this acronym) is a good game. Is the AI perfect? No. It needs to learn how to wage war. But it does eXpand fairly well on the higher difficulties. It does a decent job with diplomacy. It has a reasonable mix of units. It reasearches well enough to beat me to wonders. The affinities got better with the new hybrids. Lots of improvements everywhere. I love the aliens and how they differ from one environment to the next, I just wish they were smarter is all.All in all, the game has improved, and dare I say that with another proper expansion with quick post release patching the game could really shine? Yes, I dare.If you want to read more, go check out eXplorminate.net for the in-depth reeXamination and Audible eXtension podcast.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												I would have liked to enjoy this game. I'm a big fan of the Civilization series, and anything scifi is always a plus in my book. However, this game... Starting off, you have extremely limited options as to where to start your first city, which can seriously set you back in the early game. The science tree or graph or whatever is an absolute mess, nearly unreadable, confusing for old fans of Civ and completely overwhelming for any newcomers. All the tiles look the same (I had to hover over most tiles to figure out what they were), the aliens are absolutely everywhere, stopping your explorers and then randomly killing them for no reason... And the miasma, which could have been interesting, is just far too abundant to be anything but a serious annoyance. The actual civilizations themselves, or the colonies as they were, in addition to being very few in number, are also extremely bland and seem to have practically no differences from each other. The leaders have next to no personality, and all their little log excerpts seem to be dime-a-dozen platitudes about the loss of Earth and the squandering of natural materials - or then destruction of the aliens.It's such a shame, because this could have been the best game in the entire series with a little development. The basic idea was there, and there were so many ways this could have gone. I would give wads of cash for something more akin to Civ meets Mass Effect, where there's an actual variety of species and planet types. The civ leaders could have actual character, and the aliens, too - why were they not sentient? Why could I not play as them? Why are the aliens so meaningless to the game?And don't even get me started on the problems with the multiplayer. I got kicked out more times than I can count, and I probably stared at loading screens more than I got actual playtime in. Finally, I had to give up without completing the multiplayer game, because my constant dropping was making it stand still for everyone else. Additionally, the game would occasionally freeze for no reason and force me to restart it to be responsive again. I've never had issues like that with any other game. I don't know if the free weekend was crowding the servers or what, but it was basically unplayable.Such a shame. I guess I'll have to get my Civ fix and my scifi fix separately, then.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2016
												A great twist on the Civ 5 engine. Keep in mind this game is not the next entry into the Civilization series, and that this game is essentially a large expansion pack, similar to "Beyond the Sword" in Civ4. This game is very enjoyable for a Civ vet like myself. I found Civ5 far too easy and Beyond Earth adds a very refreshing twist on the Civ 5 engine. The graphics are very similar with a redeisgned UI and heavily skinned scenery, but it does still look like Civ 5 in essence, which is good. The diplomacy system is heavily reworked here and reminds me of what we saw in Civ4, which is a very detailed lists of events and their impact on diplomacy. The techs in Beyond Earth are somewhat confusing, even after playing several times through it is still difficult for me to remember what is what. I don't want to spoil too much about the Affinity trees, but I think they are an incredible addition. They are essentially the idiologies from Civ 5, except now what you choose affects the appearance and abilities of your units.I feel this game is priced well for it's content, and the Classics Bundle is an amazing deal.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
												A highly addictive game with plenty of room for improvment.After several days of gameplay you come to see that this isnt just another civ game, there are subtle differences such as aliens instead of barbarians that react to how you treat them. More focus on the strategic resources and three visually different worlds to explore.However you can see that the developers have some future plans, but could have gone further into the realm of scifi to make this game stand out more than previous titles. There is too much focus, I would say, on the strategic resources with plenty of late game units and city buildings requiring a vast quantity of these three rare minerals. Probably some further ballancing required. The tech web is a nice take on a new form of tech tree, you dont need to have each tech on the web to win, you can focus on what your colony does well, but even I, after some time of playing now have a prefered path through the web.The game to me is more finely tuned to exploration and an attempt to make each game different and allow you to make the most of the landscape or world you are on are quests, of which many allow you to make slight adjustments to your city buildings to give them some extra resouces. Dissapointment comes from some minor areas, few unit choices, theres only one aircraft that you can upgrade through the game to suit your needs, but this aircraft is a combined bomber and fighter. The same aliens no matter what 'biome' you see. An AI that can be a little too predictable with diplomacy that doesnt go as far as some fans would like. Dont get me wrong, I am an Alpha Centauri fan boy but like I have already said, this game had a lot of room for improvement, and the obvious holes are probably going to be patched with DLC or future expansion packs. Personally I would like to see more diplomacy options, further work on the randomness of the worlds, maybe more alien types each with a slight difference. More choice of units away from the generalised one for all options units. A deeper look into espionage, a couple of more factions as not to have the repeated leaders each time. For now, this is a great game and one I have been looking forward to since the release of Alpha Centauri. Im actually glad this isnt a clone but rather a close cousin to the game. Highly recomended and I look forward to what the devs come up with for the future.

												Great 50 dollar DLC.What? It's not DLC? You're kidding me, this is like Civ5 with a reskin.Oh. It turns out this is a full game, which was quite literally a reskin of Civ5 which they couldn't even polish up most of the things that shot that in the foot like bugs, bots, and not to mention an incomplete game. Seriously, Civ5 was like an incomplete game without DLC, and yet it felt more complete than this.I guess I should say something nice about it, fine, let's see. Uh... Graphics are pretty? Alright, alright, fine. It's semi-interesting and absorbing. The Miasma interested me on paper as a hazard to avoid, but with so much of the ♥♥♥♥ing stuff it just became something really inconvenient. Don't get me started on how clearing out aliens and miasma pisses off bots, what am I supposed to do? Learn to adapt so my lungs don't end up looking worse than after fifty years of smoking? Alright, so the combat is... ... Half-heartedly interesting. Not as absorbing or unique as the last games and your tech web can really stun your♥♥♥♥♥in place in the dark ages trying to figure out which part of the tech web gives you what you need.Overall, no. Just no. I felt like it was bad enough in Civ5 they cut out the spies and sold it on DLC, but now this is worse and only making me glad I got it on the free weekend.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
												A highly addictive game with plenty of room for improvment.After several days of gameplay you come to see that this isnt just another civ game, there are subtle differences such as aliens instead of barbarians that react to how you treat them. More focus on the strategic resources and three visually different worlds to explore.However you can see that the developers have some future plans, but could have gone further into the realm of scifi to make this game stand out more than previous titles. There is too much focus, I would say, on the strategic resources with plenty of late game units and city buildings requiring a vast quantity of these three rare minerals. Probably some further ballancing required. The tech web is a nice take on a new form of tech tree, you dont need to have each tech on the web to win, you can focus on what your colony does well, but even I, after some time of playing now have a prefered path through the web.The game to me is more finely tuned to exploration and an attempt to make each game different and allow you to make the most of the landscape or world you are on are quests, of which many allow you to make slight adjustments to your city buildings to give them some extra resouces. Dissapointment comes from some minor areas, few unit choices, theres only one aircraft that you can upgrade through the game to suit your needs, but this aircraft is a combined bomber and fighter. The same aliens no matter what 'biome' you see. An AI that can be a little too predictable with diplomacy that doesnt go as far as some fans would like. Dont get me wrong, I am an Alpha Centauri fan boy but like I have already said, this game had a lot of room for improvement, and the obvious holes are probably going to be patched with DLC or future expansion packs. Personally I would like to see more diplomacy options, further work on the randomness of the worlds, maybe more alien types each with a slight difference. More choice of units away from the generalised one for all options units. A deeper look into espionage, a couple of more factions as not to have the repeated leaders each time. For now, this is a great game and one I have been looking forward to since the release of Alpha Centauri. Im actually glad this isnt a clone but rather a close cousin to the game. Highly recomended and I look forward to what the devs come up with for the future.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												Firstly a thank you to the devs for giving us a free weekend to play this. However as much as I love the Civilization 5 series, I cannot bring myself to buy or play this version.The game looks like a modded reskin of Civ5, and not a good one either. The maps look dark and ugly, and no care was given to improve the engine or the UI (in fact the UI is significantly inferior). There are still heavy black loading artifacts as you move through large maps, some tiles still fail to load unless you zoom in, on and on. But worst of all, in many areas Beyond Earth is much worse than Civ5.For example, when a pop up window appears in Civ5, it darkens the rest of the screen to get your attention. But you still have access to all your vital stats like happiness, gold, culture. In Beyond Earth, all this information is blurred out, making it unreadable. So when you get a quest popup giving you a choice between health or energy, in order to check which one is more useful to you right now, you need to cancel the quest, see your values, then reopen the quest. Such stupid design choices.Then there are the trade routes. They are no longer limited, so then you have massive colonies with dozens of cities and trade routes, almost every turn it pesters you to reset a trade route. No care was given to optimize this.The use of screen space by the UI is also very poor. When you click on your city to see which buildings you already have, or want to construct, the physical size of those buttons is twice as big, and for no reason at all. They just added blank space. There is so much scrolling now that in most cases it's not worth the effort.The game setup UI was never a thing of envy in Civ5, but it's even worse in Beyond Earth. There are still no user-friendly visual aids to show you how the map may look with your settings, and they even removed features such as disabling aliens (the new barbarians).Moving on to production value. It does not stand up to Civ5 at all, even before its expansion packs. One my biggest disappointments (and there were many) are wonders. When you get a Wonder notification, all you see is a cheap blue-print sketch. Combine that with the lack luster map environments, it makes the game look even more monotone.My conclusion? This is not a good deal even when it eventually drops to 80% off. Civ5 is a superior game in every way.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2015
												Honestly what can I say? There's just so much wrong in this game and most of it has been summed up by the previous reviewers. The characters are worse than some of the faction mods found in Civ 5, the game isn't that much of an improvement over Civ 5, it is very very expensive for absolutely no reason. The replayablity isn't too great, the mods are too few, the multiplayer isn't that good. I can go on on about why the game isn't worth your cash (or in my case, the 2 day free trial given out and even then I barely wanted to play it), but if I had to sum it all in one message it would be wait until the next sale, and get the Civ 5 complete edition with all DLC for $12 like I did and you will not only enjoy it more but also save a lot of money. I'm very upset at how poorly this was thought out considering I was really hoping to have a good Sci-Fi Civilization game because Alpha Centaruai is way too old.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2015
												I've played just a few hours of this and the thought that kept popping into my head was: "I'd rather be playing Civ V".BEYOND EARTH is not a bad game. However, it seems like some kind of a missing link between Civ IV and Civ V. The main problem with it is that the factions are pretty much all the same. Instead of taking advantage from the Sci-Fi theme and come up with some really eclectic, interesting and MEMORABLE factions, everybody has the same generic units and buildings. The faction advantages also so balanced that they don't matter at all. It doesn't keep you involved and rooting for your own guys, because your guys, their guys, they're all the same guys. It was on my wishlist, now it's not anymore.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												The concept behind this game sounded pretty sweet, but in practice, this just feels like an incomplete Civ 5 with a fresh (and confusing) coat of paint. The base mechanics are all the same, only renamed to sound space-y and futuristic and barely any of the improvements brought by the Civ V DLC are here. Whatever new mechanics are added, they feel poorly implemented at best, like they know they're gonna release 30$ DLC in the future to rework them (as is likely the case).-The Affinity system looks interesting at first, but it's entirely reliant on the the tech tree (or rather "web"), so if you're not focusing solely on producing Science, you're not gonna get anywhere, fast. -Everything depends on Affinity now, from Victories to Unit upgrades, and unless you're devoting yourself to one Affinity, you can't do anything productive.-In fact, apart from Domination, all the victories are basically differently flavoured Science victories now, as Diplomacy and Culture have been all but removed.-The new Tech Web also seems interesting at first (a common theme with this game, it seems), but it quickly loses focus, because you have to go for the Affinity-adding techs, wich are spread seemingly at random on the Web. So on one hand you need to concentrate on Affinity, but that means randomly picking different techs... It quickly becomes a mess, considering the next point.That new tech-y coat of paint... The great thing about Civ was how quiclkly you could get into it. The Units, Buildings, Leaders, even Wonders - you took one look at them, you knew who they were and what they did. Now, it's basically stabs in the dark. You have no idea what each unit is by glancing at the name (like when you're deciding what to Produce next), the Leaders are completely interchngeable, the Wonedrs are basically random bits of words stuck together to random effects... And since you can't help but to compare this to Civ V (and you have to, because the gameplay is identical), it looks just awful.-Oh, and the worst part - instead of Spock's (or at the very least Spock's sound-a-like) soothing narration you get something that sounds like a teen girl, narrating random quotes by the fictional "leaders".. Yeah, actual quotes from actual people have been cut too....There are good points - the Espionage system is expanded and the new Quest and Decision systems work really well. But that's all, really.Most of all, this just feels like a big new scenario for Civ V. And if that's what it was, instead of a full price game with several full price DLC coming soon, that would be pretty awesome. But now, it feels like a big step beck for the franchise, not justifying the full price.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												I really cannot say I recomend this game, nor would I disrecommend it. It uses the same engine and same diplomacy trade ect ect ect as CIV V. Which is not a bad thing per se. As I understand when Civ V first launched it was not received well but with the additions of DLC it became a much better game. Both good and bad. It is bad because we will have to purchase a 30 dollar DLC to make this a truly great game. I will say however that the other civs were useless. I suppose I am only mostly though my first game but I found little interactions between the other Civs. This is probably due to the lack of luxury resources however. The aliens will be your primary threat as the other civs are rather docile. I am disappointed by the wonders in this game. In Civ V it was something special with music and a picture and a quote. Now its just meh. The affinities are a great new addition and it is neat to see them mix and mingle with how the other civs leaders look. and they provide nice little bonuses as well. According to the affinity you have the highest rating for some civs will love you and others will hate you. Either way this game is very similar to civ V. if you liked civ V than chances are you will like BE as well.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												(Version fr de mon commentaire plus tard....)Well.... I played the free week-end version until the end (5 turns before the end of my game by Emancipation) and..... well.... where I must start?ok, the goods points for this game (Better to call that beta mod):- The Idea of the 3 ideologies are good, like religions in Civ 4, especially the point where you can use different hybrid ways for upgrade unity.- Science star instead of tree is a good idea, but a bit confuse when we want increase the 3 ideologies...- Graphics are good, I like the futurist-style interface, too bad, this one is... incomplete!.- Different way to victory- Quest are various and are the best idea in this gameBUTAll of those ideas and quality are not complete!- The Diplomacy is very bad in comparison of Civ V (By the way, you copy-paste the diplomacy text from Civ V...), I talked with pacifist hippies who give to me everything I wanted, and I liked the "Atrocity" parameter in Alpha Centaury, where is it? Too bad, you put it in the trash, like every good idea in Alpha Centaury (The only one thing I disliked in AC was the graphics).- IA stupid: (By information, I was at the 4th difficulty level, with no bonus for me and normally an IA more offensive) He let many ruins alone around him, my explorers get them easily. In add of this, one of them (india) had an opportunity to kill me with a big army, but he doing nothing. And let me the time the build a better army after spying them...- low level Spy too much powerful!!! I mean, all science progress and energy was from them! The option in risk 2 is useless (why stole technology when you can stole science with less risk?), the one in risk 3 is less interesting than the precedents, and the risk 4 and 5 are impossible to execute, but are they more useful, the city is usually at 2, 3 maximum, good luck to get more access.... in all Civilization, stole science was the most dangerous option for a spy, so here..... why?- Some bugs (not important), and some options was disapear in the option screens: where is the overview of the army? The inventory of all resources exploited? They disappear! That was useful in Civ 4 and 5 for the player, so.... why????- Culture is useful only for the science section, that all! Prosperity, industrial and military section are no enough efficient!- In fact, the only difficult I get is the wealth, always negative until you get a final technology who change radically this problem...- This game is chronophage, but not in the good way!I see you have many good intention and Idea with Beyond the Earth, so, please, Firaxis's Civ-team, rework that game before sell it for 40€! Even 30€ is too much!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 8, 2015
												I've been holding off getting Beyond Earth since it came.  I've been a huge fan of the series since I was a wee child.  I used to play civ 3 with my brothers, then i played civ 4, and then onto civ 5.  When I heard they were making another civ I was really excited,  each new installment had been an interesting new development.  I admit I was rather skepticle of civ 5 and took awhile to get into it.  I really hope Beyond Earth turns out to be the same although I don't see it happening.When I first saw gameplay of it i thought, hey... this looks a hell of a lot like civ 5.  I was right, except it's worse.  Whereas civ 5 gives the clear progression of technology, beyond earth has this horrible confusing tangle, which lets you (try) to jump straight from what would be ancient era, into the modern era.  I say try because the tech will let you sit there researching your butt off for 150 turns until you get it.They tried to reimplement health, from civ 4 into Beyond Earth but really it's just a replacement for happiness from civ 5 except without a good way to generate it.  I found myself, after settling one new city struggling to even maintain net 0 health.  Being attacked by, and capturing a city of some randomly named♥♥♥♥♥hole only plunged me deeper into unhealthiness, when annexing the city said it would give me 0 increase...Aside from gameplay issues this game just doesn't feel clean at all.  I started it up for the first time and immediately noticed how jerky everything seemed to be going.  I was moving the mouse across the screen as if my fps was 2 when it said it was 1200.  I figured of course it would be because the "optimized" starting graphics would have messed it all up as always happens so i went in and reset them all.  As soon as I changed the resolution everything seemed to clear up.  The mouse moved smoothly, just the way it should and I was relieved.  I thought I'd solved the problem. How wrong I was.  See, changing the other graphics settings from minimum to maximum said it required the game to be restarted, which I did without fuss.  Only to find my horrible stuttering mouse returned on startup, not only that, but for some reason my mouse was overlayed on the screen during the opening cutscenes, as well as the loading screen, before turning into the regular civilized mouse you see in game.  I went back into the options to make sure everything was set how it should be, which it was not.  Everything had returned to minimum settings.  Feeling slightly miffed I set the resolution back to 1920x1080 59hz and instantly noticed my mouse had smoothed up again.  "This isn't right I thought to myself, what's going on here."So I decided to have Nvidia GeForce Experience set my graphics for me.  It worked, set everything to max just like it should and I started up the game.  Again, mouse overlayed over the startup, no sound until i get to the menu, horrible buggy mouse.  I go in, change the resolution to something else, then back to clean up the buggy mouse and decide to start the game out for real.  Give it a test drive.  I must say I did enjoy the starting bonus selections.  It was like taking the best parts from all the nations in civ 5 and putting them into one perfect nation to suit your play style.  However I was quickly thrown by layout of the UI.  Small things were annoying, the map was in the top right, instead of the bottom right like in EVERY OTHER CIV GAME EVER.  The buttons to exit various menus were all in different locations so there was no "go to exit button" which you don't really notice in most games because it's not a problem.  I decided I was going to get a mod to replace the UI with one more similar to civ 5, just so things felt a little more comfortable.  That's where I went wrong, see.Upon opening the in-game steam window with shift+tab i knew something was very wrong. Nothing was responding when I clicked it.  The "hover over" indicator on some of the buttons would light up when the mouse was nowhere near them.  It was like everything was offset and I couldn't tell where I had to click to do anything.  Then the game crashed and the whole thing starts again.  First fix the jerky mouse, then go to mods, open the steam window and bam, it's still all messed up.  Surely restarting the game should have fixed it.  But no.All in all, the game just feels horribly incomplete.  Things don't work the way they should, small errors on top of small errors compound into a game that's no longer enjoyable to play.  Add that to the fact that the game is really just a retextured version of civ 5, with a less cohesive research screen and city modifiers that make no sense and you get a game that's just not fun.Civ 5 has its bugs, many of them, but compared to Beyond Earth it's a well thought out, planned, and implemented game.  Civ 4, a masterpiece if a bit dated.  Don't get this game.  I got it when it was on-sale for like 75% off and I still regret wasting the money.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												Civ Beyond Earth or Civ VI as I guess you could call it... what can I say about this game that people haven't said or thought about already? Well... to be honest, I rather enjoy this game and maybe, just maybe. Not for the reasons you the reader think I enjoy this game for... or at least possibly some other reasons which you didn't expect or believe.Let's get the biggest issue out the way first, the Faction Leaders, no matter which way you look at them or analyse them, they will never hold the weight of the previous games historical leader. That was part of the charm of Civ V, you could have Nobunaga Oda, the demon king of Japan go up against Alexander the Great in an epic war. Part of the charm of Civ V was that you could create this entire parallel world where these leaders are all alive round the same time and at each others throats, that was part of what made Civ V great.The Leaders in Beyond Earth will never be able to compete with that, they won't. So don't expect them too, Beyond Earth in my opinion was an experiment, using a new idea and a new setting that is completely different from Civ V.That being said, I do agree that the new Factions are a little bit in-balanced, especially when analysed together. I do like how the cultures and the peoples of Earth have banded together in the future to create these new... almost Mega-Cultures I guess you could say that which to gain control of this new planet... planets depending on which map you pick.One thing I will say about the Factions and the Leaders, is while they will never live up to the weight of the historical leaders of the past, I do believe they hold potential. Here is how I look at Civ Beyond Earth compared to Civ V. I look at Beyond Earth as Civ V was before Gods & Kings and Brave New World. That is how I look at Beyond Earth, I see it as a diamond in the rough that has a massive amount of potential and I pray, I really do pray that Firaxis follow through with this potential and continue to polish Beyond Earth because, it truly does hold a massive amount of potential I would be devastated to see wasted.As a lover of the Civ franchise I read, watched and basically hunted with purpose, everything I could about Beyond Earth before I purchased it only 2 days ago. I currently as of this review have 25 hours logged on Steam playing Beyond Earth compared to my 239 hours logged for Civ V.So, you could claim that this review isn't valid if you don't believe I have spent enough time playing the game to give a fair opinion and review, fair enough but I am giving it anyway. Recently I saw one of my favourite YouTubers give a review on the game, AngryJoe. He said and I quote "Beyond Earth feels like an incredible opportunity wasted." I do not agree with that, I agree the game doesn't live up to the expectations that were presented for it then again, we are talking about a Civ game, possibly the best strategy game franchise ever, in my opinion. I don't know, maybe Total War is better I have yet to play a Total War game but I plan on getting Shogun 2 which seems to be the best choice.Back to the point, I do not believe the game is an opportunity wasted, I believe it is a diamond in the rough that with the proper care and love and grow to become something close to Civ V, I doubt it will ever beat Civ V mostly due to the weight the historical leaders brought, but it has a fighting chance of being close. However, you must remember, Civ V has G&K and BNW whereas Beyond Earth has nothing so far, which, is why I look at the current state of Beyond Earth as of the post date of this review as Civ V was before G&K and BNW enhanced the experience and made it something truly amazing.I feel I have ranted on a little more than I should of about the comparison between this game and it's older brother Civ V but it was a point I felt I had to explain my own opinion for.Let's move on before this review goes on for longer than it should. I've heard Rythian of the Yogscast another of my favourite YouTubers talk about the graphics of the game, how they look dirty and muddy. Honestly, I cannot tell as I haven't played the game on High or higher graphics, I play on Medium level as I use my laptop and the game runs perfectly so I may try a higher setting so I can look at it in full detail and have a better opinion. However, I agree and disagree with the comments they made, about the graphics.I agree they do look dirty and muddy, they definitely have a darker colour palate for some terrains and a brighter one for others. These are enhanced through Mods which are easily integrated with the game through the Steam Workshop and if you play with the Distinctive Terrains mods, you will see more detailed terrains so I do recommend playing with those Mods just for the visual effect.As for the graphics for the units and the cities, I honestly am not too sure. I feel they suit the purpose enough, they suit their purpose enough. I don't know, maybe as polish is added to the game as I believe it will, this is Firaxis we are talking about, as more polish is added to the game they may upgrade the textures to make them more pleasing or eye catching but for the most part they are descent enough.Hmm... what else is there for me to talk about... I seemed to have focused a lot on what other people were saying about the game and what I believed so I am a little stick... bear with me a moment here. Okay, the Aliens, something you will be seeing a lot in Beyond Earth.Personally, I believe these Aliens are done well and they are impressive to look at, especially some of the unique Harmony units like the Rocktopus and the Xeno Titan. However, the only game in which I got the Rocktopus it seemed to be bugged and wasn't able to move to the orbital level, whether I was doing it wrong and it needs something to latch onto I don't know but while I wasn't able to make full use of the Rocktopus, it is impressive to look at, as with the Xeno Titan which... as it's name suggests is like a Titan.Talking of bugs, I have encountered a few but like I said, I do consider Beyond Earth is the state it is currently as of the post date of this review, do be a diamond in the rough so I can excuse these bugs because they don't really take away from the overall enjoyment I get from the game, other people might disagree.The unit models when getting to a level three upgrade for the Soldier, seem to stay around when upgrading a different unit, meaning you'll have two conflicting unit models when upgrading but it does seem to go away or you just stop noticing it.Oh! One thing I will say annoys the hell out of me, is that bloody ADVISR, I'll admit, it is nice to actually have a voice giving you advice and offering you guidance but for the love of all that is sacred in creation, turn it off the moment you can because it will constantly tell you about trades and pointless advise that you've already been told. That is a problem I have with the game but you can turn it off fairly easily so at least it can resolved that way but, I do believe they should patch it so the ADVISR doesn't keep annoying gamers with constant reminders on Trade.Also, the new Tech-Web instead of the traditional Tech-Tree as we are used to, I think is a nice addition and it does add to the atmosphere of the game, you get this sense of, what the hell am I to research which, you will. It is confusing as hell when you first see it but you get the hang of it quickly if you take your time to learn it.Another thing I will say, the Tech-Web incorporates the affinity system into it well, you can research techs that will give you affinity in either Harmony, Purity or Supremacy which basically means Aliens, Humans and Robots.The Tech-Web while designed like a confusing web, actually has some tree like traits, each main Tech on the web is known as a branch and within each branch there is usually one or more additional specialist techs known as leafs, and it is usually these leaf

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												I've never written a review until now because I've never felt like making a hard positive or negative recommendation for everybody to read.Do not buy this game, especially if you've played any Civ game in the past. They take out more features than they improve. Firaxis released a half-finished game, they're going to do some patching, then expect us to pay $30 for an "expansion." Here's a list of some of the things wrong with the game:-There are only 8 civs.-Unless you have the map pack, there are only 3 map types: pangaea, continents, or archipelago/islands. Fun! The map pack maps aren't very interesting either.-The AI is extremely passive. I have had the AI declare war on me one time in 30 hours. Marbozir, a long-time letsplayer of Civ games, has had it declared on him 3 times in 100 hours. He only plays on the highest difficulty. (The 3rd time happened today in his stream). Even when you ARE in a war with them, they don't really try to invade you like in other Civ games. Even if they have more, stronger units, you can just scare them by spamming a bunch of weak ones. Sometimes they do absolutely nothing even if they could kill you. It is broken.-Each "Civ" only has a unique ability now, no more unique units and buildings. They have been replaced by an affinity system that functions independent of your civ choice.-Internal trade routes are stupidly broken and overpowered. The game as a whole screams that it hasn't been balanced and tested well.-Do you want to feel like you're in space? Screw you, all you're getting is a coat of paint. The audio and visuals change, sure. But it's all the same thing. Beyond Earth: Where Everything is the Same as On Earth. The leaders don't even have space-appropriate AI when you interact with them, and they say the SAME STUPID LINES over and over when they offer to trade or whatever. Yes, diplomacy is still broken.-All this was removed: Nukes, religion, the ability to organize trade routes, the diplomacy web (BASIC FOR A 4X GAME), ideology, luxury resources, the world congress, and more have been removed.-There is no reason to interact with the AI because luxury resources and the world congress are gone. Basically the only purpose is to sell resources for money. Diplomacy is extremely boring.-There's no sense of progressing through time anymore because THE WORLD CONGRESS HAS BEEN REMOVED, which was perhaps the most fun part of mid-late Civ 5. Some things are better, but it's clear they're holding features back for money. This is a $50 game and it's not even well-tested, it's extremely buggy and poorly balanced. Please Firaxis, stop trying to squeeze money out of your fanbase. The way to become more profitable is to RELEASE BETTER GAMES, not slapping a coat of paint on an existing one, taking out features, and expecting us to pay $30 for the first expansion, $30 for another, and ONLY THEN it's gonna be as functional as Civ 5 with Brave New World.That's horrible business.
