content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												As much as I would love to reccomend this as it's a great game I simply can't. It feels too much like Civilisation 5 just more confusing. The tech tree is a huge improvement over Civilisation V but along with the affinities feel like the only new things to the series. You may now only play as 8 different civ's which is fine as you can customise them but this means that you can no longer have the large 12+ player games. Another problem is that for the same price you could get Civilisation V + all of the DLC's (Civ V Complete Pack) which is much more completed than this.I played it for about 4 hours when it went out and haven't played it since due to me just not wanting to play it. Which is the opposite of which Civ V made me want to do!Finally, the multiplayer is absolutely godawful, worse than Civilisation V awful. In Civ V you could play multiplayer but it was nowhere near stable and with this I've practically given up on trying to play multiplayer at all. Until Firaxis gets their crap together I will have to say that Civilisation: Beyond Earth is no where near worth the money!tl;dr Civilisation V is better in almost every wayWhat I'd give Civ V: 8/10What I give Beyond Earth: 4/10Thanks for reading.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												Post-DLC update: With Rising Tide, many of the negative issues highlighted below are gone, and there are a lot of new features that make the game an improvement on its own. I no longer add the "on sale" disclaimer if you're going to go ahead and get Rising Tide, too.-------Wow, first off, I'm only bothering to add a positive review because I just realized the review rating right now is like 53%! Holy shnikes!I understand, though. Really, after playing Civ 5 with all the DLC, Civ BE is kind of underwhelming. I think the biggest reason it comes short though is because of the limited number of factions. Only 8! If you want to play with more than 8, you either have to mod up (especially a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥for multiplayer or nigh impossible for non-Windows users), or overlap different players with the same "sponsor." Yes, the game does make it possible to do this and changes the color for the players using the same team, but, it's kind of a turn off to me to have to keep track of purple Brasil and green Brasil...On the plus side though, and overall I do give this game a thumbs up (when it's on sale!), it does add a number of cool things ..... the Affinity branches and the technology web (that's right web... not tree) come to mind. The way units upgrade across the board as you increase Affinity levels is kind of cool. Being able to pick your upgrade bonuses and even mix Affinity branches up a little bit is kind of cool. Barbarians (aliens) are now much more interesting and can actually change hostility toward individual civs. And purely for flavor, the sci-fi battles and multiple terrain textures (desert / fungal / terran planets) are fun.So, for Civ 5 + DLC fans, Civ BE right now is indeed not worth the big $. You'll miss nukes. You'll miss 20+ unique factions. However, if you enjoy sci-fi flare, it's worth it on sale. Get it for $20 or maybe even $30, depending on your impatience levels. Meh. Poor game deserves better than a 53% rating. Awww.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2015
												My first thought here was to talk about a single playthrough of CIV:BE. The choices, the changes, paths to victory, 'challenges' of the alien worlds, etc etc.Let's not do that. Instead, here are a few key factors that - inevitably - lead me back to playing CIV 5 until BE has a few expansions to bolster its depth.+ Games play faster. I don't mind a 10-20 hour round of CIV5, but it's also being able to finish a round in 3-4 hours.+ Technology is not quite as linear as in CIV5, which serves to add some variety between nations.+ New Mechanic: Satellites, they add some fun new features but would benefit from tougher choices or greater diplomatic drawbacks.+ The Soundtrack. I enjoy it.- Victory objectives lack variety. Aside from Domination they boil down to "Build Planetary Wonder (occupies a tile) and complete Wonder's unique condition"- Military Upgrades rely on Affinity rank, which forces most tech choices towards increasing your Affinity.- Fewer military units. No bombers, no melee boats, no submarines, no anti-air, no 'airdrop' units.- No Great People.- No World Congress. What, we just abandon the idea of coming together as nations to discuss the future of our planet?- The Leaders (aka Civs) have lackluster bonuses.- There is simply less going on. It feels like a game of solitaire, racing to win in the fewest moves.+/- The presence of aliens and miasma (poison clouds) hinder early game Domination rushes.If you just want a number to judge it by:6.5/10Not a terrible game, but in my opinion there are better 4x games one could play.By Comparison, CIV5 (w/ both Expansions):8.5/10

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4, 2015
												Really enjoyed this game. Sure its not like Civ V, but I love the Sci-Fi theme. You're able to choose from three different paths that will shape how your civilization plays out and interacts with not just other players but also the environment itself. You really do feel like you're in a strange new planet with some beautiful and strange visuals that make up the planets you're trying to colonize. You have to interact with players and the environment (as stated before) and it adds quite a unique element. The aliens you encounter could be compared to the barbarians of past Civ games, but they act a bit different. You can either kill them off, leave them alone, or tame them, and your actions do have consequences with the aliens and the other factions. All in all, its a great civ game that adds some great new elements, but its not as fleshed out as Civ V is with all its DLC. In time with more updates and DLC this game could be something amazing!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth, you want the short reason as to why I wouldn't recomend it? It feels like a re-skin of Civ 5 with to many of the core features pulled out.The long reason?The aliens are an annoyance, they don't add a fun challange they just zip around eating your units while you can't do anything to defend them. The research is a pain, half the time you've got no clue what it is you're researching. Take the "transgenics" research for example, it gives you a gene smelter. Great. Somebody mind telling me what a gene smelter is or what it does before I waste my time on this research? Also the research is a mess, people can end up with aircraft before you have any form of anti-air units that can defend you. basically meaning that your units get bombarded by cities twice. Finally, and most annoyingly is the lack of explanation of how to do anything with the trade routes. I, wrongfully, assumed that as every other unit in the game can embark onto the water the trade convoy could as well. Nope! It's the only type of unit where you've got to build a differnt unit to travel across the sea. So to summarise a ranty review, the reasearch is in a stupid order and you generally have no clue what you're doing, trade routes make no sense and aliens are plain annoying.Are there any good points? Sure, the affinity system is a great addition in my opinoin and the unit upgrades that come from this system are relly cool. That's about it for the good though. Apart from that, lazy re-skin of Civ 5.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												This game has been on my wishlist since it first came out in October of last year. I'm not a direhard fan of the Civ games, having played Civ IV and Civ V, but I was looking to pick this up, because Civ in space sounded pretty cool. I didn't buy this game right away, because 1) I felt like it was overpriced for what essentially looked liked a Civ V clone, I perhaps would spend $30 on it, but no way was I going to sink $50 into it, and 2) This is Steam, and a new game from a very renowned developer as Firaxis was very likely to go on sale during the winter sale. So the game was released and I waited until Christmas to check it out. I went onto the store page, and noticed that this game got 'mixed' reviews. What? A game with the Sid Meier's Civilization name not getting at least above average reviews? I was skeptical about the reviews, but ultimately decided to hold onto my money. And then, to put the final nail in the coffin, the free weekend rolled around. I could finally try this game out for myself before deciding if I wanted to buy it. I no longer regret my decision to hold onto my money. This game is unfortunately a reskinned Civ V, with pretty much every good feature of it dumbed down. AI personalities are boring, the tech tree was interesting, but confusing and eventually just became a game of "research the technologies that will get you affinity points". There was hardly any intro or help when starting the game, aside from choosing your previous Civ exposure. My first, and only, game essentially became a game of finding research to gain affinity, minimal interaction with the AI nations, and waiting out to victory.TL:DR; reskinned, dumbed down Civ V in space. Only buy if you really, really enjoy Civ V and are willing to overlook the many flaws, then maybe for you it will be enjoyable. I personally, however, am glad to remove this game from my wishlist.

AI personalities are boring, the tech tree was interesting, but confusing and eventually just became a game of "research the technologies that will get you affinity points". There was hardly any intro or help when starting the game, aside from choosing your previous Civ exposure. My first, and only, game essentially became a game of finding research to gain affinity, minimal interaction with the AI nations, and waiting out to victory.TL:DR; reskinned, dumbed down Civ V in space. Only buy if you really, really enjoy Civ V and are willing to overlook the many flaws, then maybe for you it will be enjoyable. I personally, however, am glad to remove this game from my wishlist.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
												A spiritual successor to Alpha Centauri that aims to be different yet familiar to those who had played the venerable Civ-in-space from decades ago. Unfortunately, it falls short of reaching the same excellence of AC let alone surpassing it. Although it has some great graphics (based on the Civ V engine) and uses almost similar mechanics from Civ V, albeit with differences to depict its futuristic setting, the Civ:BE at times feels shallow and seem to lack the depth and engagement of other Civ titles.An expansion entitled Rising Tide is suppose to improve upon the base game and it is hope that the new content will be able to lift the game from mediocre to awesome. Despite its flaws (other reviewers have already pointed them out so I won't repeat it here), Civ:BE still has potential. It is hoped that Firaxis will continue to support the game by releasing more content that not only improves gameplay but also establish it as a standalone but excellent title that inherits AC's DNA without replicating it.In short, it is a recommended purchase for those interested in sci-fi themed colony building sims. However, I would only get it during sales as the current status of the game does not warrant its full price.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												I've never written a review until now because I've never felt like making a hard positive or negative recommendation for everybody to read.Do not buy this game, especially if you've played any Civ game in the past. They take out more features than they improve. Firaxis released a half-finished game, they're going to do some patching, then expect us to pay $30 for an "expansion." Here's a list of some of the things wrong with the game:-There are only 8 civs.-Unless you have the map pack, there are only 3 map types: pangaea, continents, or archipelago/islands. Fun! The map pack maps aren't very interesting either.-The AI is extremely passive. I have had the AI declare war on me one time in 30 hours. Marbozir, a long-time letsplayer of Civ games, has had it declared on him 3 times in 100 hours. He only plays on the highest difficulty. (The 3rd time happened today in his stream). Even when you ARE in a war with them, they don't really try to invade you like in other Civ games. Even if they have more, stronger units, you can just scare them by spamming a bunch of weak ones. Sometimes they do absolutely nothing even if they could kill you. It is broken.-Each "Civ" only has a unique ability now, no more unique units and buildings. They have been replaced by an affinity system that functions independent of your civ choice.-Internal trade routes are stupidly broken and overpowered. The game as a whole screams that it hasn't been balanced and tested well.-Do you want to feel like you're in space? Screw you, all you're getting is a coat of paint. The audio and visuals change, sure. But it's all the same thing. Beyond Earth: Where Everything is the Same as On Earth. The leaders don't even have space-appropriate AI when you interact with them, and they say the SAME STUPID LINES over and over when they offer to trade or whatever. Yes, diplomacy is still broken.-All this was removed: Nukes, religion, the ability to organize trade routes, the diplomacy web (BASIC FOR A 4X GAME), ideology, luxury resources, the world congress, and more have been removed.-There is no reason to interact with the AI because luxury resources and the world congress are gone. Basically the only purpose is to sell resources for money. Diplomacy is extremely boring.-There's no sense of progressing through time anymore because THE WORLD CONGRESS HAS BEEN REMOVED, which was perhaps the most fun part of mid-late Civ 5. Some things are better, but it's clear they're holding features back for money. This is a $50 game and it's not even well-tested, it's extremely buggy and poorly balanced. Please Firaxis, stop trying to squeeze money out of your fanbase. The way to become more profitable is to RELEASE BETTER GAMES, not slapping a coat of paint on an existing one, taking out features, and expecting us to pay $30 for the first expansion, $30 for another, and ONLY THEN it's gonna be as functional as Civ 5 with Brave New World.That's horrible business.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												Review of the game:The game plays a lot like Civ 5; that's not a bad point. It's only natural that a developer will try to build from a previous game when they put a lot of resources into it and in this case, it's not even a bad match. There are, naturally, a lot of differences.The game uses a hex-based stategic map, just like Civ 5, and just like Civ 5, you can only have one military unit and one civillian unint per hex. This avoid the doom stacks that previouse verions of the Civ games suffered from, but in fairness, the amount of military units per hex seems low; having three units or so would make more sense to me -- this will allow you to build stacks which build up a diversity of strengths, without making them entirely invincible.Tech development uses a tech grid or wheel. Each node allows you to branch into new techs as well as open up for sublevel tech -- this is, technically, not at all different from how things have been done since Civ 4. The branching is just less linear, which is.. well, what it is. It makes sense in the context of playing a few decades or even a century of game time, not to have tech which represent major technological breakthroughs in the history of humanity.The game plays a bit on some of the ideas of Alpha Century, but it's not a clone; barbarians have been replaced by aliens and there's some sort of biomass covering a large portion of the planet; unlike in Alpha Century you have very good reason for exterminating the aliens since they will attack your units, even if you try your best to be on their good side and the biomass hurts your units and can kill them.Designable units are not in the game, which I think is a shame, but then again, I never really used it in AC, as it was just too damn time consuming with virtually no benefit. Instead your units can be customized through advancement of "affinites".Affinities are very important in the game, as they unlock certain unit upgrades but also give you permanent bonuses and unlock victory conditions; you can't build an emancepation gate without being high developed in the superiority affinity for example. I think this makes sense and fits the game nicely.Religion is (more or less) gone. You can found a new religion by researching the right technlogy and then it's more or less just a flavour thing (I believe it unlocks a victory condition as well)."Complex" espionage has been added and, well, it's not entirely done IMHO. You get spies, which can be relocated to cities to either do counter-espionage (in your own cities) or do something else in foreign cities, like steal money, technology or outright take over the city. The problem with this is that in order to do anything beyond stealing money, you have to advance the "intrigue" level of a city; this is done by perfoming espionage missions in foreign cities, and it's lowered by doing counter espionage. There are also buildings which can permanently lower the maximum intrigue level of a city. This is a big problem, since you, virtually, cannot raise the intrigue level of a foreign city beyond 3. I think I've been able to get it to 4 two or three times, having about 10 spies doing espionage in foreign cities. The intrigue level will drop over time as well, which means you don't even have to use your spies to counter foreign spies, simply because doing any espionage takes too long. Great idea, unbalanced implementation.Overall:I think the game is great but heavily overpriced. I would recommend it if the price was sliced in half, without discounts.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												My interest in this game began when I realized it was a "spiritual successor" to Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri.  (Their words, not mine) and I have to say that the result both impresses me and lets me down.On the one hand, it is (mostly) what I would want from a sequel/remake/redux of Alpha Centauri.  Updated graphics, same concept, familiar storylines and turn-based, sci-fi-fun!  I love the addition of the Virtues and Culture along with a better laid out tech tree.On the other hand, the personalities of the factions are stagnant and impossible to really be surprised or developed.  The diplomacy of the previous game is far more limited than before, the alien races are unplayable (and sterile) (however it was not until Alien Crossfire, the expansion that this became an option).  With these fixed parameters, it makes replay value depreciate as each game goes through almost the same motions time and time again.  Also, I miss the victories from the previous game (getting elected to world leader, corning the Energy market, etc).That being said, I still really enjoy the game.  Maybe it is the nostalgia, maybe it is the storyline but I appreciate the challenges each world, starting location, etc can bring.  The bonus is the fact that this game came MOD ready and there already tons of great add-ons that players can add to spice up the game.  As of the time of this review, I have yet to sample any as I'm still enjoying the vanilla version of the game but will find myself adapting it to my preference as time goes on.  Final words?  The gameplay of Beyond Earth is on some levels far better and more interesting than Alpha Centauri ever was and at the same time, simplified and well, vanilla.   As of right now, I do recommend the game, I really do.  It is a lot of fun and there is a bit of a learning curve for players to understand things like Health, Culture, Science, and Energy balance.  My hopes is that there is a shake-up to the factions with more dynamic personalities and increased diplomacy options.  I would happily purchase DLC like that and if they take this down the route of Civilization, we can certainly expect tons of updates and DLC to emerge over time.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												Civ Beyond Earth or Civ VI as I guess you could call it... what can I say about this game that people haven't said or thought about already? Well... to be honest, I rather enjoy this game and maybe, just maybe. Not for the reasons you the reader think I enjoy this game for... or at least possibly some other reasons which you didn't expect or believe.Let's get the biggest issue out the way first, the Faction Leaders, no matter which way you look at them or analyse them, they will never hold the weight of the previous games historical leader. That was part of the charm of Civ V, you could have Nobunaga Oda, the demon king of Japan go up against Alexander the Great in an epic war. Part of the charm of Civ V was that you could create this entire parallel world where these leaders are all alive round the same time and at each others throats, that was part of what made Civ V great.The Leaders in Beyond Earth will never be able to compete with that, they won't. So don't expect them too, Beyond Earth in my opinion was an experiment, using a new idea and a new setting that is completely different from Civ V.That being said, I do agree that the new Factions are a little bit in-balanced, especially when analysed together. I do like how the cultures and the peoples of Earth have banded together in the future to create these new... almost Mega-Cultures I guess you could say that which to gain control of this new planet... planets depending on which map you pick.One thing I will say about the Factions and the Leaders, is while they will never live up to the weight of the historical leaders of the past, I do believe they hold potential. Here is how I look at Civ Beyond Earth compared to Civ V. I look at Beyond Earth as Civ V was before Gods & Kings and Brave New World. That is how I look at Beyond Earth, I see it as a diamond in the rough that has a massive amount of potential and I pray, I really do pray that Firaxis follow through with this potential and continue to polish Beyond Earth because, it truly does hold a massive amount of potential I would be devastated to see wasted.As a lover of the Civ franchise I read, watched and basically hunted with purpose, everything I could about Beyond Earth before I purchased it only 2 days ago. I currently as of this review have 25 hours logged on Steam playing Beyond Earth compared to my 239 hours logged for Civ V.So, you could claim that this review isn't valid if you don't believe I have spent enough time playing the game to give a fair opinion and review, fair enough but I am giving it anyway. Recently I saw one of my favourite YouTubers give a review on the game, AngryJoe. He said and I quote "Beyond Earth feels like an incredible opportunity wasted." I do not agree with that, I agree the game doesn't live up to the expectations that were presented for it then again, we are talking about a Civ game, possibly the best strategy game franchise ever, in my opinion. I don't know, maybe Total War is better I have yet to play a Total War game but I plan on getting Shogun 2 which seems to be the best choice.Back to the point, I do not believe the game is an opportunity wasted, I believe it is a diamond in the rough that with the proper care and love and grow to become something close to Civ V, I doubt it will ever beat Civ V mostly due to the weight the historical leaders brought, but it has a fighting chance of being close. However, you must remember, Civ V has G&K and BNW whereas Beyond Earth has nothing so far, which, is why I look at the current state of Beyond Earth as of the post date of this review as Civ V was before G&K and BNW enhanced the experience and made it something truly amazing.I feel I have ranted on a little more than I should of about the comparison between this game and it's older brother Civ V but it was a point I felt I had to explain my own opinion for.Let's move on before this review goes on for longer than it should. I've heard Rythian of the Yogscast another of my favourite YouTubers talk about the graphics of the game, how they look dirty and muddy. Honestly, I cannot tell as I haven't played the game on High or higher graphics, I play on Medium level as I use my laptop and the game runs perfectly so I may try a higher setting so I can look at it in full detail and have a better opinion. However, I agree and disagree with the comments they made, about the graphics.I agree they do look dirty and muddy, they definitely have a darker colour palate for some terrains and a brighter one for others. These are enhanced through Mods which are easily integrated with the game through the Steam Workshop and if you play with the Distinctive Terrains mods, you will see more detailed terrains so I do recommend playing with those Mods just for the visual effect.As for the graphics for the units and the cities, I honestly am not too sure. I feel they suit the purpose enough, they suit their purpose enough. I don't know, maybe as polish is added to the game as I believe it will, this is Firaxis we are talking about, as more polish is added to the game they may upgrade the textures to make them more pleasing or eye catching but for the most part they are descent enough.Hmm... what else is there for me to talk about... I seemed to have focused a lot on what other people were saying about the game and what I believed so I am a little stick... bear with me a moment here. Okay, the Aliens, something you will be seeing a lot in Beyond Earth.Personally, I believe these Aliens are done well and they are impressive to look at, especially some of the unique Harmony units like the Rocktopus and the Xeno Titan. However, the only game in which I got the Rocktopus it seemed to be bugged and wasn't able to move to the orbital level, whether I was doing it wrong and it needs something to latch onto I don't know but while I wasn't able to make full use of the Rocktopus, it is impressive to look at, as with the Xeno Titan which... as it's name suggests is like a Titan.Talking of bugs, I have encountered a few but like I said, I do consider Beyond Earth is the state it is currently as of the post date of this review, do be a diamond in the rough so I can excuse these bugs because they don't really take away from the overall enjoyment I get from the game, other people might disagree.The unit models when getting to a level three upgrade for the Soldier, seem to stay around when upgrading a different unit, meaning you'll have two conflicting unit models when upgrading but it does seem to go away or you just stop noticing it.Oh! One thing I will say annoys the hell out of me, is that bloody ADVISR, I'll admit, it is nice to actually have a voice giving you advice and offering you guidance but for the love of all that is sacred in creation, turn it off the moment you can because it will constantly tell you about trades and pointless advise that you've already been told. That is a problem I have with the game but you can turn it off fairly easily so at least it can resolved that way but, I do believe they should patch it so the ADVISR doesn't keep annoying gamers with constant reminders on Trade.Also, the new Tech-Web instead of the traditional Tech-Tree as we are used to, I think is a nice addition and it does add to the atmosphere of the game, you get this sense of, what the hell am I to research which, you will. It is confusing as hell when you first see it but you get the hang of it quickly if you take your time to learn it.Another thing I will say, the Tech-Web incorporates the affinity system into it well, you can research techs that will give you affinity in either Harmony, Purity or Supremacy which basically means Aliens, Humans and Robots.The Tech-Web while designed like a confusing web, actually has some tree like traits, each main Tech on the web is known as a branch and within each branch there is usually one or more additional specialist techs known as leafs, and it is usually these leaf

												A fresh look at the Civilization formula, with great aspects of the old with lots of new and exciting fetures to distiguish it as a unique game, rather than a parasite on the success of the franchise. it seems lacking at the moment, but it is the same feeling as playing civ 5 without Brave New World, and has just as much potential with future expansions. It comes with a more personal gameplay experience, alowing a degree of cousomization to your army, and quests that shape you future based on your own decisions. This is a game hat deserves to be under the Civilization banner.Rising tide is a step in the right direction, adding more unique aspects, and expanding existing ones. I love ocean cities, hybrid affinities and new units. the game feels more fleshed out now, but it still has ways to go. The update is like gods and kings for Civ 5, it's good, but BNW is around the corner. i would not reomend playing without the expansion, because the base is undeniably lacking.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												I really, really wanted to like this.However, I was no great fan of Civ V, and this is, when all is said and done, just a reskin of Civ V with a few bits and bobbles added. So ultimately: If you enjoyed Civ V, you'll probably enjoy the gameplay here. If you didn't like Civ V, nothing is improved here whatsoever.When Civ IV did a total conversion with a few new mechanics, new graphics, but ultimately the same engine underneath  -- with "Final Frontier" and "Fall From Heaven: Age of Ice", both tucked away as part of the mods for Beyond the Sword -- it was just an added part of an expansion pack that gave you more in Civ IV itself.With Beyond Earth, I'm expected to pay the price of a new game for it, and I cannot deny I am disappointed in what it adds, and more importantly, where it fails to live up to its spiritual predecessor, Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri.The Virtues system seems like it could've done so much more, but instead it's just power-ups with no tradeoffs. The Affinities are clever, but ultimately fail to end up truly drawing you in. (A tiny suggestion there: it would've been nice to see your own leader as he or she is transformed by their affinity, just as much as it was interesting to see the other leaders transformed!)A bizarrely minor gripe: the tech descriptions are all read by one voice; even though they are frequently attributed to the leaders, who are voice acted. Why not pay the VAs a bit more and get them to read those things? (Heck, could we have had the voice actors actually read the lines for their dialogue in the diplomacy screens? Nah, not that either.) It would have done a great deal, as with Alpha Centauri, to help make the leaders seem more alive. CEO Fielding isn't even in the same ballpark as CEO Nwabudike Morgan.  These leaders didn't feel like actual characters, and I managed to get through an entire playthrough without a single one of them declaring war against me, despite numerous threats.In summary: I wanted to love it. I don't. I can't recommend it at the price it's at.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												My first ever review...and sadly a negative one. I have been a CIV fan since the first game, which btw was the first PC game I ever bought, somewhere in the 90's. From CIV to CIV 5 I completed 1 game every 10 or 20 because I loved the early game stages...the exploration...the early choices...the first encounters. Then you had to decide which civs to befriend, which to attack, how to specialize your cities, etc.. By the modern age it was clear who was going to win so there I go to a new game, with a different civ and a smile in my face.I don't know exactly what is the issue with BE but I could not endure more than 4 hrs in the first game and maybe 2 in the second. The tech web is confusing and it is not clear where I am going, the world is colorful yet dull, and I am not sure I am making meaningful choices throughout the game. Everything seems sooooo boring...Not to mention a very annoying bug which prevents me from playing at low res (1,280 x 720).Maybe I didn't try long enough but it was the first CIV game I gave up so early, and I played every single one of them. I sure hope Firaxis didn't lose its touch.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2015
												Really enjoyed this game. Sure its not like Civ V, but I love the Sci-Fi theme. You're able to choose from three different paths that will shape how your civilization plays out and interacts with not just other players but also the environment itself. You really do feel like you're in a strange new planet with some beautiful and strange visuals that make up the planets you're trying to colonize. You have to interact with players and the environment (as stated before) and it adds quite a unique element. The aliens you encounter could be compared to the barbarians of past Civ games, but they act a bit different. You can either kill them off, leave them alone, or tame them, and your actions do have consequences with the aliens and the other factions. All in all, its a great civ game that adds some great new elements, but its not as fleshed out as Civ V is with all its DLC. In time with more updates and DLC this game could be something amazing!

												Having played several Sid Meier's games, such as Locomotion and some among the Civ series, this feels right at home. Although it is outshown by it's predacessor (V) in many aspects, it feels like very much like a civ game. The web tech system is very much welcomed, giving you a different game every time you play. It feels quicker than V, with great manuverability of units and impactal buildings coming within one or two hours of playing, rather than halfway through the game. The affinity system is unique to me, as a direct focus towards that gives the advantages one would expect later game. Downsides include factions with reduced character, a shorter games in comparison to Siv as a series. Overall, I have had a wonderful time playing this game, and will be occasionally playing it on and off.

												I have 300 hours in Civ 5. Well over a thousand hours in Civ 4. Beyond Earth:-Lacks personality. content:
Posted: August 15, 2015
												Normal gripe with Civilization games for me is that you usually need the DLCs to either fix or make the game playable, and this one is no exception. Only thing I can really give them credit for is having a demo.Only thing memorable from my playthrough was the very beginning when you "accidentally" pi*s off the aliens and get swarmed by them. I had this outpost with 5 marines and a sniper squad. A bunch of alien nests respawned around them (yeah you fight to kill the nests and they just respawn). they quickly got surround by aliens and were decimated. By the time I got reinforcements there only the snipers remained.Aside from the aliens theres not much else done new. There new vinity system (sorry for misspell) has you choose one of three specializations: Supremecy, Harmony, and Purity. Nothing really interesting about this. all it really does is make it which unit you have late game is specific to your vinity. Yes there are bonuses, but you can have levels in different vinities.They messed up the unit level up too. Now, when one of your units level up, you can either heal them or increase damage. Nothing else. Instead they moved it to the new specialization system. Instead, you level up your units as a whole, giving the upgrade to everyone. you can upgrade when you reach certain vinity levels. All this suceeds in doing is making your units simple clones. there aren't unique in any way.Diplomacy sytem is completely messed up. no personality at all.As far as sci-fi goes, there really isn't any except for the aliens. There are orbital units, but they just provide buffs and crash back down to the surface after a while. Yep you have to build a completely new one.Honestly, there really is alot more stuff I should mention, but I simply can't be bothered to. Instead Im going to go place Galactic Civilzations. Or maybe Endless Space. go play those instead.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2016
												Beyond Earth vanilla feels like an unfinished game. It's basically Civ 5 but with a futuristic make over with a few changes. I feel like it's gonna be like Civ 5, when it got released it was bland and boring and it took a few great DLC's that were developed over the course of a few months and years to make it a great game. CIVBE has a lot of potential and even with the new DLC which makes the game much more enjoyable it still has it's issues. VANILLA:The Good:Aliens/Barbarians: The aliens in this game is much more intelligent then the barbarians in previous games, they don't go on blatant suicidal attemps to ♥♥♥♥ with you and waste your time. For the most part they leave you alone unless you get close to their nest or if you have killed a bunch of them. They also play more of a crucial part depending on what path you go down.Affinities: Is a really awesome system. Basically the tech you research gives you EXP towards a certain affinity which is like an ideology. Once you level up in a certain affinity you can level up your units which will give them a cool design and stats based off of what affinity you went down. Like if you main in Supremacy you get to build giant siege robots and have robotic looking boats it's pretty cool. It's better then everyone having the same unit just with different colour pants. Tech Web: It takes a bit to understand, but it lets for more personalization towards what kind of game you are looking for. In old civ games you would pretty much research everything but in CIVBE you have a giant web to choose tech from which is really cool, you aren't forced down a certain path.Ways to win: There are much more ways to win now. Each affinity has it's own way of winning if you either want to take over Old Earth, or save the people of Old Earth or have sex with a bunch of aliens. There are also much other ways of winning like making contact with intelligent aliens or domination stuff like that.Spies: Are really much better then previous games, you can send them on certain tasks. So instead of sending them to steal tech, you can send them to steal gold, research points, and recruit deserters. So depending on the situation you can send spies out to help you.The Bad:Leaders: have no charisma and aren't interesting in the slightest, whenever you talk to them they all have the same blank expression. In other Civ games when you talked to leaders you would be warped to their environment, it being a castle, boat, sacrifice chamber, or deep in the forrest it was really cool, with the new leaders the background is just transparent and bit fuzzy which helps strips the leaders of any charisma. All the resources, buildings and wonders: In other civ games when you build a libary you know what a libary is going to do, but in CIVBE when you're researching something you don't always know what a certain building can do just by looking at it so when you have an entire tech web staring you in the face it can be hard to figure out what you want by just looking at it. Same things go for wonders and resources, in other Civ games you know what iron does and what you can build with it, but in CIVBE when you have Xenomass you are probably gonna be confused for what it's utility will be until you need it to build a unit.Affinities: Even though affinities are pretty awesome they still can get annoying because you need to focus in on one affinity and if you don't you will be left in the dust.Just the game in general: Is pretty bland and can get boring very fast.RISING TIDE:The Good:Diplomacy: They COMPELTELY revamped diplomacy. Now you get diplomacy points which you can get from doing certain tasks and you can spend them on getting leadership traits that give your civ abilitys, you can also spend the points on other peoples traits, if they accept the deal which is pretty cool. It is much easier to become friends with Civ's now. CIVs have a respect and fear counter which basically means the more they respect you and like you the "respect" points will go up for that CIV and they are more likely to make deals with you and accept to be allies, instead of completely sucking a CIV's♥♥♥♥♥to be their ally you can spend diplomatic points on becoming their ally or trade partners if they accept of course. Fear is basically like it sounds like the more they are scared of your tech and military and the more conflicts you have with them the more "fear" will go up, the higher it is the more likely a civ will declare war on you.Building Civ's on ocean tiles: Is pretty awesome, no longer are you confined to a tiny continent or island you can build small cities on ocean tiles and if you want move the city to a better spot. They are completely op tho, they don't generate culture and they don't expand much unless you but the tiles.Hybrid Affinities: Are what affinities needed to make them more fun to use. It's what it sounds like you can make a hybrid of two affinities with their own special units, make for more fun customizable units. Declaring War: Now instead of having civs being completely anal and not giving you anything even though it's clear you whopped their♥♥♥♥♥now depending on how much a civ kicked an other civs♥♥♥♥♥they will be forced to give you stuff.The Bad: Diplomacy: Because of the "Respect" and "Fear" points taking stage you no longer can actually make choices and talk to a civ or call them out you can only change your relationship with them. Also "Fear" needs some more work done with it. If you've gone to war with a civ and completely decimated them their "Fear" for you will be pretty large, this will compel them to goto war with you at random times even though they are not prepared in the slightest to attack you. I've had civ's just randomly declare war on me three times with only one or two units to attack.Trading: You can no longer directly trade rescources with other leaders which is absurd, the only way to gain or get rid of rescources is to set up a black market with your spy, but it costs 50 diplomacy points per turn WHICH IS A ♥♥♥♥ING CRAZY AMOUNT. So far I'm lucky to get around 40 late game. I think they should just bring back trading normally.Declaring War: I feel like this system is so close to being awesome but it falls short. See, you don't get a choice in what you want a civ will just give you what they calculated to be fair which is good sometimes and annoying other times. Because sometimes they will give you a trash city they just made which is a half the planet away and you have no choice but to take it because you probably don't want to continue the war. Alliances: Can get VERY annoying VERY quickly. Because if you are allied with someone they will pull you into a war that you have no interest in, even if they started it. One day you will be making nice, nice with everyone then you ally warmongering mc♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ will declare war and will ♥♥♥♥ everything you worked towards over.Conclusion:All in all, even though this game has it's failures I feel like it has a lot of potential and most of my problems with this game will be fixed with updates and DLC's, for example the rising tide dlc fixed a lot of my gremacies with the vanilla version. With Rising Tide I have a lot of fun with it but I feel like it will lose it's magic soon.  I would recommend buying this game and it's DLC on a good sale if you are looking to play a new interesting game.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												This game is lightyears better than civ 5. (yes, without rising tide!)Why?Every decision counts! In civ 5, early game doesn't really matter, more or less. Expand, kill some bar-bars, make alliances. By mid to late game the decisions you made in the entire first half don't really matter at all. In BE, every decision counts. You start towards your choosen affinity from turn one. What affinity to choose largerly depends on your surroundings (resources, abundance of aliens, etc...), and from there, you can beeline for specific techonologies. All this means that every turn matters, which I would not say of the first ~1/3 of civ 5.Research Net: Only go for tech you need. That simple. This means that every civ in game is very different from eachother, which changes up the fighting a lot.Combat: There are fewer military units, even when you are around halfway through the game you may only have 2-3 good specialized units. Combat is much more fun because you are fighting against units different that your own and how you fight depends a lot on what affinity and units you have. Rather than knowing what side will win from the beginning, based on who has slightly more advanced units (civ 5) its hard to tell what units each side will have and who will win. Combat is interesting every time. Orbital units add a entirely new element to combat as well.AI: The AI in this game are simply better than the AI in 5. AI in BE will ambush you with a full army that can sweep cities in a turn, as opposed to the AI in 5 which will try throwing a few units at you now and again in pathetic attempts to wear you down. The only thing that irritates me still about this game is that diplomacy is a little messed up. I hear this is fixed in rising tide. But, it's no worse than the diplomacy in 5. In short, this review is so long because I felt everyone was really wrong about how awesome this game is.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												I was hoping for Alpha Centauri 2.0.  I got Civ 5 with a new skin.... Definitely not worth the full price.Do you remember Alpha Centari?  Do you remember the Datalinks with all it's cutting edge information on technology?  Do you remember the secret project videos, with insightful commentary from the leaders, or quotes from Aristotle's Nichomachean Ethics or Sun Tzu's Art of War?  Do you remember the brief videos when you finally cornered and defeated the leader of a rival faction? How about how you could terraform and change the landscape to your liking?  Do you remember how you could customize your troops from top to bottom with weapons, armor and special abilities?  Do you remember how you could create floating cities, if you wished?Well, Beyond Earth has nothing like that.  The biggest innovation, which I am not even sure is a plus is the technology web.  Instead of it branching off, you work your way from the middle to the edges of the web, and and each main technology has a few sub technologies.  I found myself just researching as many technologies with the particular affinity I had chosen, because that is the way you upgrade your troops in this game.  You focus on one affinity, then as you acquire more technologies that are in line with that affinity, you get to upgrade your troops, and pick one out of two  attributes.  The terrain is quite interesting, and I still do not know what all the resources I can get are, or what they do.  But some are required to produce certain buildings and others for certain troops, kind of like marble or stone is to buildings and horses and iron for troops in Civilization games.Most aliens you encounter are quite weak.  They are merely the Beyond earth counterparts of barbarians and do little to hinder your exploration, unless you run into an aggressive Siege worm on land, or an aggressive Kraken at sea.  The Aliens get relatively weaker and eventually disappear once you and your fellow humans have settled most of the planet.You get quests througout the game, but they seem a bit forced and do not add much to the game.  Most of them consist of picking an extra attribute to a building you just finished.   There are others that compel you to research a certain technology and explore a bit.  But even that is very superficial.Diplomacy is the standard stuff, but actually leaves a lot off the table if you do not have a cooperation agreement.  You can give away stuff in exchange for favors, so that the other faction "owes you one", but these favors are usually not worth much.  Oh, you need an ally because half of the leaders declared war on you?  Well, guess how much those favors are worth.  Pretty much nothing.  They don't bring people to fight a defensive war on your side.  If your enemy is the one who owes you favors, they can't be traded for temporary peace.  No, you will get a measly revenue stream much less valuable than what you gave up.The leaders are uninspiring and generic, presumably because at first they should be blank canvases ready to get affinity all over them.  Either way, not much to these guys.  Nothing unique, nothing that sets them apart.The game is entertaining enough, but not worth the full price.  Especially if you already are playing Civ 5.  This is basically the same game with aliens

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												Beyond Earth is a decent CIV5 spinoff, but suffers from a lot of balance issues and design problems. It also fails spectacularly at the idea of being the spiritual sucessor of Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri (SMAC). The game has a lot of interesting ideas, but fails to implement them in a balanced and meaningful way. The Tech Web is interesting in theory, but does not work well in conjunction with the Affinity system. After a few games you will find yourself using the same early game tech path over and over again - and during the late game you will ignore most other techs and just focus on those that grant you points for your preferred affinity, regardless of the actual tech benefits. The tech web ultimately fails to promote player choise and, once more, locks him into first-order tech strategies.The Orbital Layer is another mechanic that has potential, but there is little incentive to use it. Even the highest difficulty levels can be won without ever launching a satellite. Interaction is limited to button pressing to shoot down other satellites with cities or artillery units.The victory conditions for the Affinites sound interesting in theory, but in practice they just boil down to clicking "NEXT TURN" once you have setup up the prerequisites. Purity also requires the player to manually summon a unit each turn and guide it to a settle location, while Supremacy needs to send military units back to earth - again one unit at a turn. This turns the last stage into tedious micromanagement, boring the player instead of hyping him up for the victory.The aliens in Beyond Earth are another interesting idea, but feel quite passive. Unlike barbarians in CIV5 they will never pillage improvements (except for random siege worm movement) and never attack workers or cities unless the player provokes them. While aliens present a challenge during the early game, they fail to scale past that phase and become utterly pointless during the mid and late game. Even the first unit upgrade is enough to tilt the balance in favor of the player - and once you have the first Affinity related unit you can one-shot every alien unit but the (rare) siege worm. To add insult to injury, the game offers an early game building that prevents aliens from getting close to your cities - and this building also has a secondary ability to grant alien immunity to all your trade routes.Stations are the successors of city states from CIV5, but are less interactive and more often than not less useful than other trade route options. They also have the annoying tendency to drop down in your primary expansion areas, blocking large chunks of the map for your settlers unless the disappear from having no trade or you forcefully remove them - which requires early military investment, a quite bad strategy.Lore-wise the game has actually a lot of interesting details, but it utterly fails to present them to the player. The only way you will have access to the lore is reading the (not very eye friendly designed) CIVpedia. AI leaders only have two main lines in the diplomacy screen that they will repeat over and over again. The techs feature quotes from different leaders, but fail to grasp the depth of the quotes from SMAC. In addition to that, all voicework for techs and wonders is done by a single voiceactor, so they feel even more bland. All of these issues combined give the game a lifeless and uninspired tone.Many useful features from CIV5 are gone. You can no longer continue playing after being defeated by the AI, there is no strategic view and the game provides no direct post-game info. The UI design is pretty bad and in some cases hides important information from the player (like quest rewards). The aesthetic design is not very pleasing. Pale colors make it hard to read the map, more often then not you will have trouble to see if a tile has Miasma on it unless you zoom in quite a bit. Borders can be barely visible and different terrain types look confusingly similiar.Apart from these huge design issues the game suffers from severe balance problems. To name the biggest ones:- The health system is mostly pointless. You can drop deep into negative without suffering any significant consequences. You can only stay positive by selecting the Prosperity virtues.- Trade routes are so powerful that they dwarf all other options in the game. They also require manual adjustment every 25 turns - which is more than annoying, because you will have 3 trade routes per city.- These two problems combined make ICS (Infinite City Sprawl) the best strategy in the game: Just place as many cities as you can and you will have an advantage over your enemy. Disregard the terrain to search for a good spot - just place them at minimum distance.- Unit balance is terrible. Tier I affinity units dominate everything and as your unit upgrades progress some units fail to fulfill their specified roles - for example, gunners are better at sieges than artillery units during certain affinity levels.- The AI is utterly incompetent, even worse than in CIV5. I have been able to win on the highest difficulty level in my 3rd game - and I rarely played past medium to high difficulty in CIV5.- Only a handful of wonders are actually useful. Most of them are simply not worth an invest of science and production ressources.- Diplomacy is pointless. There is no need to ever trade with the AI unless you desperately need a certain strategic ressource. Deals offered by the AI are extremely one sided, so you have no reason to ever  accept one.Now this is an impressive list of shortcomings, but I would like to remind you that CIV:BE has to go up against the well polished CIV5 and the stellar SMAC. The game itself is not a complete failure, but compared to these two other titles it is lacking in many areas. Until the problems with balancing and basic design issues have been resolved, I sadly cannot recommend this title for full price. If CIV:BE  goes on sale for 25 bucks you may consider getting it if you liked CIV5. Overall I'd advise you to buy and play the original SMAC - if you can bear its 15 year old graphics and the horrible UI. You will get a great game with interesting game mechanics, better immersion and a more interesting story - at a much lower price.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												From what I've played, seems worth it for $30 if you're a huge fan of 4X games and you're burnt out on Civ V. But if you aren't burnt out on Civ V, I'd go for the Civ V complete edition instead. Civ V: BNW has more features than BE and is better polished. It also has a better multiplayer scene and better replayability.I personally won't be buying the game from what I've experienced in my half-playthrough. I think the game needs a few expansions before it's worth playing over Civ V BNW.A few things I do like about BE:(A) Aliens replacing Barbarians. They're much more aggressive and dangerous than Civ V barbarians, and they add a lot of gameplay depth in conjunction with the Harmony affinity.(B) Affinities. They're great.(C) Orbital units.(D) Upgrading base military units.Things I dislike:(A) The victory conditions. They're similar to the Mass Effect 3 ending -- exactly the same, but different colors/flavors.(B) Air units. I expected them to be overhauled, but they are exactly the same as the air units in Civ V -- clunky and not very useful.(C) No full zoom-out like in Civ IV... I want to see the whole planet, since I'm playing a sci fi themed Civ.(D) Nations are not distinct enough.(E) AI is♥♥♥♥♥♥awful.My recommendation: Unless you're burnt out on Civ V: BNW, wait until Firaxis releases an expansion. The game has potential though, and I'll probably be returning to it in the future.

												i feel people are being far too harsh on this game,it really boils down to 2 things,do you want civ 5 a game set in the past with historic racesordo you want a civ 5 like game set in the future where you dictate the evolution of humanity?the 2 games are very close with some key differences, you still build towns and cities, you fight, you trade, beyond earth, BE, has a really unique affinity feature that modifies what you turn into and every building and choice has a quest that modifies stats, adding up to layers of depth and some interesting insight into the future and all that.the sponsors are few yes, some features are lacking but civ5 before all the patchs and expansions used to take dozens of mods to get right so i have faith that future patchs will lead to good stuff, like that new and upcoming one that adds sea based cities, more sponsers, new trait systems and more!do i think this game is a souless shell of a reskin for civ 5? no.did i expect this to be a flawless and complete upgrade to civ 5 that improves everything? no.i expected a civ like game set on a different planet that is in the future and we got that.oh and the mods add so much good stuff and fix many problems.8/10 very decent but needs a few patchs and expansions to really get moving.

At this stage the game isnt recommended, only to try it and see how it is, but if you want to play more than 300 hours with this game (I have played nearly 2000 hours since civ 5 g&k), then this game isnt for you. Its always crashing in multiplayer games, most of the time only max 4 players map working good, but with 1 leaver it could be already a problem...There is too much luck factor in the game. If you get a startplace without aliens and with a neighbour not so far, but also not too close, you won the game if you can play good ofc, but if you get a startplace with 3-4 alien nest, you will never expand, cannt trade, and you already lose at early game, its clear to see.Best tactic is purity with prosperity, all other stuff is only just "there", but useless if you want the best output from everything. Same goes for waging war. Only melee troops needed, forget rangeds, and the cities are very easy to capture. Also if you make a city, you put 2 trade routes to it, and you have the most expensive troop in your brand new city in max 5 turns, and normally in all other cities 2-5 turns to make the best troops available, BUT there isnt any demographics window, and you just step at your neighbours borders, and we already have -1 player in the game, GREAT. All this happening from turn 75 usually (cause of aliens...), so I have to waste 1,5 hours of game time, to start again a new game.I really wanted to play with this game, since I am a civ 5 freak, but this game needs more patches, and maybe also an expansion pack, until that I cannt recommend it, its a half ready unbalanced game, nothing else.If you would like to play civ 5 instead, I have sad new for you, at 27. october new patch came, and since that day you can play only 1v1 in multiplayer, cause even with 3 players we get crash online. Thank you firaxis, now I have a very good civ 5, what isnt working online, and I have a half ready civ BE, which isnt 100% ready yet, and working only max with 4 players good.Please fix at least one of them, so I can play, cause I am not interested in any other games.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												I want to like this game, I do, but it has so many bugs and glitches present in it at the moment. I couldn't possibly recommend this game to someone in good faith, simply because they probably won't be able to play it for one reason or another. It gets stuck on random screens (especially diplomacy screens, which completely lack the "accept" or "refuse offer" buttons and do not respond to ANY input from keyboard or mouse). It has the worst resolution issues I have ever seen in ANY game on pc. Did they even do any QC testing on this game? I find it hard to believe that such horrible UI and resolution issues (pretty much the first two things you notice in a strategy game) could go unnoticed with anyone actually testing this game. Until the devs can get these blatant and obvious issues sorted out, don't pick this game up, even in a fire sale.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												As a big civ 5 fan I'm really disappointed by this one. They cut down so much from civ 5, all the great person system, tourism and religious. They might return later in the expansions but they aren't here now. Also the spy system is kind broken and the trade routes are very op and annonying as you get 2 for each city and have to rearrange them every 30 turns. In civ 5 you can only get few routes for the whole empire but now if you have many cities you will hate the trade routes soon. The health system is equal to the happiness but much less effective on you as the lose can be balanced by the powerful trade routes as they cancel the golden age system....Why there are no more great person? Why every leader is kinda same? You can no long find characristic ones like Gandi and some warmongers to help you put pressure on the other civs cause they all so passive they will only fight you or not at all. I really miss the leader screen in civ 5 as you can tell each country is different. In here (although you can argue they did for the affinity system) you just feel every leader is the same and you can't even remember them after few plays not like in civ 5 you know someone is always looking for trouble and the others will backstab you.One thing I'm really mad about this game is when you finish a technology instead of in civ 5 they give you some qoute from famous people they just give you a qoute from these in game characters (many of the characters don't even appear in the game other then the technology quote) which sometime you won't even understand what they are talking about. Also when you finish a wonde (in civ 5 they give you a great art shows that wonder) you get a blue base white drawing looks like a blueprint or something EVERYTIME. Come on, the wonders building become a very boring thing as all you get is just some status not a fulfill thing like you actually complete a wonder.This game might be much better after 2 expansion (not small dlcs), but I don't think it will ever be as good as civ 5. I don't recommend this even you just want to play civ 5 in space mode, cause you will be disappointed.

content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												If you're the type who enjoys turn-based strategy, but are somehow new to the Civilization series, this will seem like an amazing game.For anyone who's played Civilization V, this will feel like a professionally-done mod of that game, and probably not worth full price. If you're looking for a "Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri" nostalgia trip, this is not likely to scratch that itch.Also, note that there are still a number of bugs that have been reported, but the game hasn't yet been patched. (Read forums for details.) Personally, the only bug I encountered was the inability to play full-screen at full resolution. If you have a modern monitor (120 Hz) or above, you'll probably want to wait until that issue is patched. (So far, I've been forced to play in Windowed mode.)My advice it to wait for patches and probably for a decent (30-50%) price drop.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 18, 2015
												Alright, lets get down to it. As a die hard Civ fan, I was anxiously waiting up until release; where I started getting some mixed feelings. (Note that I have nearly 200 hours played, all of which are offline.)So, whats good about this game? - A fresh, but familiar feel. - A large graphic overhaul from the previous, Civ. - A very impressive Tech. Tree. - The true introduction of a "Third Party". Aliens>Barbarians. - The initial depth of the game is very impressive. Where as Civ. V didn't really pick up until the release of Brave New World. - A much more relevant, and sophisticated espionage system. - Finally, it runs near the effeciency of Civ. V. Key word here is, "near". The not so good:- Religion is now a thing of the past. This has basically removed a fairly large layer of the game. - Technology at and around the early phase is dreadfully slow. - The story is relatively boring. There's no real immersion, I don't lose track of time, and suddenly find myself playing 3 hours later. - The maps. This is a doozy. It feels like they just took the Civ V design, and then took a colour pallet and just re-painted it. There are no real texture changes. Just colours. It just looks, boring? All in all, the game meets my expectations. It's hard to come up with another Civ. game after the arguably best Civ game from the franchise. However, I believe Fraxis has the potential to make this game better. Which alone, is enough for me to recommend it to any strategy game player out there.

												i feel people are being far too harsh on this game,it really boils down to 2 things,do you want civ 5 a game set in the past with historic racesordo you want a civ 5 like game set in the future where you dictate the evolution of humanity?the 2 games are very close with some key differences, you still build towns and cities, you fight, you trade, beyond earth, BE, has a really unique affinity feature that modifies what you turn into and every building and choice has a quest that modifies stats, adding up to layers of depth and some interesting insight into the future and all that.the sponsors are few yes, some features are lacking but civ5 before all the patchs and expansions used to take dozens of mods to get right so i have faith that future patchs will lead to good stuff, like that new and upcoming one that adds sea based cities, more sponsers, new trait systems and more!do i think this game is a souless shell of a reskin for civ 5? no.did i expect this to be a flawless and complete upgrade to civ 5 that improves everything? no.i expected a civ like game set on a different planet that is in the future and we got that.oh and the mods add so much good stuff and fix many problems.8/10 very decent but needs a few patchs and expansions to really get moving.

												This game has a ton of nice features that can't be found in the other Civ games and I really appreciate the new environment but ultimately it feels very shallow. There simply isn't enough content and it's missing things from Civ V that would've been really appreciated. Also something that bothers me a lot is that the aliens and resources don't change even though you're supposed to be visiting different planets. Wow we sure are the exception when every other f'ing planet in the universe has a specific breed of aliens and floatstones. I know that it would be difficult to produce the variety that I'm asking for but the issue is that they put this goal on themselves and not surprisingly failed to produce any real variety.I think DLC could make this game great but for now it's just too expensive to justify when it's competing mechanically with Civ 5 and thematically with several other 4X space games (endless space and galactic civilizations just to name a couple).

content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
 A very deep and thought provoking 4X...if only for a few hours. Only can recommend for those who are very hardcore Civilization fans and are willing to shell out $50 for about as much content as Civ 5 had at release.  Pros and Cons further down, TL:DR version here. DO NOT purchase this game if you have not played Civilization V with all the DLC and are looking for a good Strategy game. You can get Civilization V Complete for the same price as this and have hundreds of hundreds of hours of content between the DLC and the Workshop. I only recommend this for the very hardcore Civilization fans who can deal with not amount of content. Firaxis always has expansions to their games now, so I would wait until the first expansion is out to consider this game, if you're in need of a new 4X play Age of Wonders 3 or Endless Legend, you can even go old school and kick it with Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri. If you have $50 to spend then go for it. This is a really good game and it shows, but the lack of content will leave you wanting more and the price tag is not enough for me to recommend it to anyone but the most fanatical Civ fans.Pros:+ Deep and thought provoking narritive into the victories and how you advance as a civilization. Augmenting yourself with technology or becoming more alien, or rejecting the two.+ Huge UI improvements, everything is much neater than Civilization V, no more right-clicking through 200 Citystate messages and quests.+ Non-Linear technology web, allows players to plan and use more strategy in their game.+ Steam Workshop Support+ Builds off the Civilization V engine, allowing newcomers to feel welcome and experts to jump right into the game and expierence the new features themselves.+ Revamped policy system,  lots of bonuses and extra goodies allowing for a much better time for those who don't rake in loads of culture, while rewarding those who do.Cons:- Lack of content is HUGE in this game, especially coming off the wealth of content Civilization V with all the DLC had. Games take nowhere near as long as in Civ V. You will find yourself out of things to build reletively quickly, not many buildings and units.- Maps are reletively small and barren, there aren't any landmarks to discover and there aren't enough Civilizations to have a large map akin to Earth like in Civilization V, there's no real thrill to exploring, just getting slaughtered by aliens.- Diplomacy is non-existent. It's just like how it was in Civilization V, but doesn't take intol account the futuristic setting very well. Trading resources means nothing because you don't need any (besides oil), the ones you need are granted to you by developing affinities, and they do not do anything for your people (no happiness increase, no city-state quests to fufill, no we love the king day)- AI is brain dead. Every game I've played the AI doesn't go for a victory other than Domination. They end up warring with each other eternally, attacking aliens (attacking aliens make every alien on the map more hostile to any civilization) and just having so many units that they lose hundreds of energy (currency) per turn. - Barely any buildings to make, no units either.- No Great People, even Generals and Admirals.- Games take a short amount of time, even on Normal and Epic times due to the ease to achieve victory and lack of other content.I'd give it about an average score, 6/10. What's there works well and blends nicely into the game, it runs very well and everything looks gorgeous. But it's not enough to keep your attention for more than a little bit at a time (you can obviously tell from my playtime. I have ten times this on Civ 5.) Wait until more expansions come out and the price drops. This game is NOT worth $50. It's worth $20.
