content:
Posted: October 9, 2015
A New Beginning...Beyond Earth started out as a game with much to learn. Keeping the format of Civilization V, but a different idea in victories and social aspects, the story advances through a number of challenges, three specfically. Obviously, you are settling on an alien planet, you're not gonna be the only sentient one there. The first challenge you encounter is learning about the aliens on your planet, and what it takes to make them not a problem. Three affinities are available to choose from to lead your civilization in a certain manner of belief and social aspect. -Harmony, the affinity of peace and alliance. If you think you can find a way to co-exist or to "bond" with the aliens on your planet, and think your civilization would best prosper with the help of the neighbors near you, then you're someone meant for Harmony.-Supremacy, the affinity of technological bondage and neutrality. Look back on yourself, and your past life or current interests. Were you that one guy who knew almost everything about technology, were you the one always called "computer geek" or tech-guru? Supremacy is the belief of bonding technology with humanity, literally bonding, no we're not gonna talk Borg or whatever hivemind thing Star-Trek has going on there, we're talking about mixing technology with the human body and discovering what and how technology benefits the human body and what enhancements comes with it. Aliens were never a problem in our world, we don't have the need or desire to eradicate them. They don't cross our borders, we don't cross theirs. Thats the view of supremacy.-Purity, you know, you will always find the one guy in your life that always sticks to the old-time Earth. The one guy that doesn't let history go and that one guy who just was meant to be born and pass away on Earth. In the life of a "pure" man, we will seek to lead a pure world, to convert this new world to Earth. We will see to it that the legacy and heritage of Earth will live on to new worlds and not die with it. But, to restore old-Earth on this new world, this must mean to restore "old-Earth". That means everything we saw on Earth will be everything we will see on this new world. To make that happen is to erase all alien life on the planet and restore it with as much Earth life as we can. Purity is not to be looked at as the more hostile belief, but to make things the way they were and should be.Now the different victories are quite the different topic, there are only three victories that are associated with each of these affinities. One other, being the "other" one. Four victories total. The "other" one, is known as Contact. First it starts out with your first explorer. This explorer happened to stumble upon some wreckage or ruin of some sort. But it wasn't some natural ruin, it was definitely made by some being. Some being very similar to our human race. Which means, that we were not the first ones to settle here on this new world. This obviously, is not an everyday discovery and definitely catches the public and scientific communities attention. So you put more research into it, thus you discover something known as "The Signal". "The Signal" is that one bit of data and information roaming out there in the depths of space that can only be caught by technology similar to our kind. We finally discovered that one bit of information and gave us a great amount of data to find more about this earlier civilization. What they are, who they are, what they need, why they need. Are they in refuge? Do they need settlement, could we provide that for them? Can we make Contact with this civilization. The answer is, Yes. We will make contact with this past civilization to learn of their mistakes and how we can prepare for the same occurences to come. We will provide them with what they need, and we will do that with a powerful and monumental beacon. To make Contact, with the beyond.The rest of the victories are for you to discover.But this doesn't end here. Now there's something coming, something we never expected before. There's more of Earth to send to our planet, more of what we did not know. The Rising Tide is coming, and now..The Wait is Over.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												As usual, Tom Chick of Quarter To Three puts it perfectly and much more eloquently than I ever could:http://www.quartertothree.com/fp/2014/10/25/occasionally-thrilling-beyond-earth-cant-quite-get-beyond-civilization-v/I'm a huge fan of the series, there is no other franchise I've spent so much time on as Civilization. So after a dumbed-down, disappointing Civilization V I had high hopes for this installement. Unfortunately it completely failed to deliver. The AI is about as smart as a loaf of bread. The much touted tech web is just a more confusing version of the tech tree. Technologies feel random and arbitrary. The entire setting is very hard to get into. While ordinary Civilization allows you to develop a good intuition about the relative strength of various units (e.g. musketeer vs longbowman) in Beyond Earth you have no idea (quick, is a CNDR or an Apostle the stronger unit?). This is made worse by the fact that you can't even hover over enemy units to find out how strong they are or the fact that there are only a handful of unit categories and units within a category look nearly identical. It is very hard to get the information you need in this game. Want to quickly see who's at war with whom? No luck. Want to see how you are faring in comparison to other civilizations? Except for a rough victory progress and points comparison you cannot see technologies, production, energy output and other vital statistics like this.The game forces you to make decisions all the time. Not in the good kind of interesting and relevant decisions, but random "quest" decisions that pop up dialogs and force you to make a mostly meaningless A/B choice while ironically blurring out the very information you'd need to make an informed decision.Diplomacy is even more useless than usual. Except for declaring war you cannot really do anything meaningful. While resource and technology trading used to be an important part of the game it is unnecessary here. You can trade for "favours" with the AI, but they seem to have no discernable value whatsoever.The game is dumbed down to the point where I could automate everything, including end-of-turn, and watch the game auto win itself. On one of the difficulty settings where the AI gets a bonus too!Wonders have been castrated to the extend that a first time Civilization player I introduced to the game didn't even realize he built one until I told him. Compare that to the race up to be the first to finish a wonder in older Civilizations. You'd get a rewarding mini video, a building on the map and a significant bonus. Here it's just one more random thing you click on.On a technical side the game doesn't work in fullscreen mode for some high resolution, high refresh rate settings. And, even more annoyingly, AI turns take inexcusibly long. I don't know if anyone has the patience to finish a huge map - I certainly don't.Summary: A string of repetitive, boring decisions with no real pay-off to show for it. Civilization IV Beyond the Sword remains the pinnacle of the series. I recommend sticking with that instead.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												It's actually not that bad. I do like new mechanics, music and looks. New factions could've been more defined and there's A LOT of bugs at the moment but its worth playing anyway, at least if you don't have Civ 5 with most of the addons.The main issue for me so far is the lack of patches. The game often crashes, gets stuck, even on the first turn or while loading saves. There are bugs with quests and aliens too.There's also a noticeable issues with maps - they all look the same, there's NO DIFFERENCE in landscape, planet colors and vegetation, despite planets supposedly being different. Even worse - there are issues with map generation and tiles connections, even though they fixed similar issue in Civ 5.I would've also liked hints for "advanced start" options to be finally included in the game.Just wait for the discount and some patches before buying it.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												First off, I disagree with the reviews that say this is simply Civ V in space.  Yes, it is superficially similar in appearance, but there are myriad differences.  It is a very different game in the same family.  It is not a reskin.That said, would I suggest buying it at new-game price?  No.  There are some design decisions that make the game unfun, especially on repeated playthroughs.  The AI is pretty bad, and it is very, very non-aggressive.  Unless you go out of your way to annoy other leaders, they don't declare war.  A military is barely necessary.  Instead of interesting tactical battles, you'll spend a ton of time micromanaging trade routes, which is really tedious.Almost all the victory conditions involve building major projects, then waiting while they do stuff.  Yes, they can be interfered with with military units, but the AI won't declare war.  So, the end game is basically always pushing the next turn button for 30-50 turns waiting for a win that is never in doubt.There is a LOT here to build a good game on, and I expect that Firaxis eventually will, through patches, and expecially through DLC, but it's frankly worth waiting on.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												I have been trying to get into this game, and I have played the civ games since #2, but there is no real experience to be had with Beyond Earth.  I'm not saying that it is no better than the others, I am saying that it is the worst civ game I have ever played.  There really is nothing to do.The following sentence sums it up:  Nothing more than a poorly implemented Civ 5 Mod, which claims to be a full game of its own, but fails miserably.I have played three games, and have never been attacked ONCE.  Not by aliens or other factions.  Factions?  Thats not an accurate word.  Templates is more like it, as they are all the same.  No personality, no back stories, nothing.  A faction makes itself a faction by their beliefs on how things should be, but these templates have no beliefs.  Later in the game, you choose what direction you want humanity to go down but the only thing that changes in the game is the faction leaders pictures change.  The way they talk and what they say are just generic responses still.There is nothing to hold interest, no dramatic artwork when you build a building or wonder for the first time, no voice overs, and they actually used the begining movie clip in the game as the trailer, and that was nothing.Very little imagination went into this game.  There is NO writting as there is NO story.If you want to get a description of anything new (building or creature), you have to manually search the civilipeedia.I have not been playing because I am enjoying it, I have been playing to desperatly see if there is any content that I missed.  But there IS...NO...CONTENT...Any new feature they are promoting actually turns out to be an annoyance or in some way a repetitive action that just gives you carple tunnle.But the worst, the absolute worst issue I cannot get over is the terraforming.  THERE IS NONE.  It is a technology but you don't actually shape the world.  It just gives you more +1 this or +2 that.  You start with a bland looking "alien" map, which consists of reskining food, minerals, etc, and you can cut down forrests (which are already there).   I can 100% verify that you there is NO point in exploring, as it does nothing to benefit you.  You can literally just stay where you are, develop a few cities, and have absolutely no interference from "factions" (the blank template people) or aliens (barbariens made into bugs - NOTHING special or unique).Because of this game I will never pre-order any game from any game company again.If you are a civ fan, stay away from the game, save your money, and stick to Civ5.  Civilization: Beyond Earth has no content, no story, no writing, no artwork, and no cut-scenes worth mentioning.You have no idea how crushed I am in writing this review.  I have no doubt that some other game company will create a proper intersteller colonization game one day, but this is far from it.I want my money back.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												When compared to Civ 5 it adds nice new mechanics, unit upgrades, and space ship benefits. However it does just feel like Civ 5 with some spacey themes added in the not too distant future. The game does feel empty a lot of time, lacking animations for stalite launches seems like an easy oversight. The factions do not have any history as to why they left earth or what their ideologies are, while this allows you to make them your own it plays little importance to who you start the game with. Trade routes are a nightmare and if anything way over powered when doubled with the coastal space craft add on. Miasma apparently hurts despite all units wearing 21st century space suits. One major bug was also free unit upgrades when a higher affinity was reached. This encourages you to spam cheap units and upgrade them for free.Now lets compare it to alpha centauri. Its♥♥♥♥♥♥No unit customisationNo unit upgrade managementNo sea basesNo terraformingNo spy armiesNo trading technologiesAliens seem limitedFactions (sorry sponsors) aren't anywhere near as deep or as exciting to play as.To put it blunt my views reflect most players who loved SMAC.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 20, 2015
In spite of a puzzlingly weak AI and an overall lack of adequet game balance and personality, Beyond Earth‘s unique theme, excellent presentation and engaging gameplay ultimately won me over.I will give this game a cautious recommendation for dedicted 4X strategy fans only. Although I enjoy playing CivBE, I'll be the first to admit that there's still a lot of work to be done for this game to reach its full potential.If you're not a hardcore fan of the Civilization series then I would advise waiting for the upcoming "2.0" patch and Rising Tide expansion that the developers have showcased for the fall of 2015.It’s far from perfect then, but Beyond Earth has still succeeded in delivering an utterly absorbing strategy title that will likely hold my attention for a long time hereafter. But can we try and add a little more feeling in the first expansion please, Firaxis?Read the full review at my blog »[www.celjaded.com]

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												I've been playing the Civ games since the very first. I think Civilization is one of the best franchises ever. Sadly, at this point, SMC:BE is a pale imitation of prior glories. Even on the fastest setting, the pace is glacially slow, and once you have the aliens under control, you are in for a boring slog to endgame. The unit upgrade mechanics mean that your force cycles between "can't hurt anything" and "instawin battle" as far as opponents go. Because unit upgrades are tied to affinities, you end up choosing tech research based pretty much completely on if the apporpriate icon is present on the tech. Positives? The AI leaders are actually reasonable when it comes to trade (who hasn't had a Civ 5 leader turn down a 3-luxury-unit for 1 trade?). I've dropped about a week  into it now, and am about to delete and re-install Civ 5. Maybe it will be a good game by the time the third DLC pack drops, we'll see.

												WOW!! It has been so long since my last review I honestly can't remember what game it was for. What, you might ask, could have possibly convinced me to finally end that  hiatus? Paying for a game I cannot play.  The support for post launch bugs from Firaxis has been near nonexistent. I have never had a large game studio fail to deliver a playable game before. Sure I have had my fair share of games with bugs, games that required some kind of fix or update to work, or games that just sucked from the get go. But having a game I cannot play at all is kind of a distant memory for me. It hasn't happened in so long I had forgotten what it felt like. I have already attempted the re-install, updating my drivers, changing a video setting the .ini file. None of this has worked and I am not alone. There are forum posts here on Steam filled with people having the same problem. I like to preorder games that I know I am going to buy anyway. This is so I can get the early access or gimmick items but this game has left a bad taste in my mouth. I know one experience will not be enough for me to stop that practice altogether but it will be enough for me to never preorder another 2K game again or pay full price for another Firaxis game.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												As a great fan of Civilization V, I have been looking forward to Beyond Earth all year. My expectations were pretty high, and I expected at least all the things that were good in Civ 5 to appear in Beyond Earth, but that hope was idle.The problems with this game are numerous, and I doubt I will address all of them here. However, before we get to the bad, let's start with the good.The good- There are no major bugs that I have seen, except for some odd behaviour when loading the game sometimes.- The engine runs very smooth.- Some bold choices have been made, including a tech web and specializing your civilization through an affinity. There are a number of "quests" but for reasons I will go over later, they are extremely shallow.The bad- Civilizations are bland and boring, and there is almost nothing to set them apart.- You can choose a few starting parameters for your civilization, but there are clearly "better" options here to the point where taking anything else nerfs you even before you begin.- Wonders are in the game but are weak, boring and sometimes outright silly.- Except for Domination, all victory conditions are pretty much the same: build a building, wait around 30 turns, and win. They are completely non-interactive.- Diplomacy is a complete mess and just doesn't work. It was already bad in Civ 5 but it's worse here. Luckily, because there is no interaction needed for winning, it can be completely ignored.- Tactical battles are poor. In Civ 5, the 1 unit per tile was good but sometimes a pain. It could be alleviated by choosing certain promotions or getting later game units. In Beyond Earth, the terrain is much worse with lots of mountains, miasma and other impassible terrain. This makes combat horrendous.- Promotions: these are just utterly boring. You can choose to get either a 50 point heal, or 10% combat strength when your unit levels up.- Unit upgrades: You get these by increasing your affinity level. You do that by quests or teching. The problem here is that with some luck, you can get affinity pretty fast, in which case your units completely dominate the opponent very quickly.  If not, then you are forced to research in a certain way, meaning that the tech web might as well be lineair. Even if you manage to upgrade your units, they stay bland and boring throughout the game until the very end, when they change from boring to utterly broken.- Quests: Most quests consist of: build two of this building to choose an extra effect for it. Those effects cannot be seen anywhere, so you can only know what you need to build by committing all of that information to memory after numerous playthroughs. The stat bonuses do not necessarily make sense.- The removal of city states, great people and luxuries: These three things added a lot of depth to strategical choices in Civ 5. They are completely removed in Beyond Earth and not replaced by anything.- Happiness: This has been replaced by health, which is an almost irrelevant mechanic. Which is good because staying healthy is reliant only on social policies and buildings, forcing you once again to give up the non-lineairity of the tech web.- Visually this game is not pleasing at all. Not only does everything look the same, but that same is depressing, unclear and intentionally blurred near the edges of your screen. There is no option to turn that off yet, but they will fix that they said. That doesn't change that everything looks dead, the color scheme is: brown, purple, dark green. It gives me a headache.- The "story" that develops ends in oblivion after a few quests. No explanations are given anywhere and the end texts (there are no end animations or anything) just say something vague that means nothing at all, under the guise of "we leave it to your imagination".- Enormous overhead in micromanaging workers and trade routes. This takes up more effort than actually building your empire.- Orbital units, the new "thing" in Beyond Earth are not very satisfying. They once again add some passive benefits, and some can be used offensively, but it's a mechanic that doesn't add much to the game.Unfortunately, I cannot recommend this game to anyone. If you don't already own Civilization V, then it's a much better choice than this. If you do own Civ V, then play that instead unless you are completely bored with it (although this won't alleviate your boredom for long). If you are a big fan of Sci Fi, then please just wait until this is on sale and has gotten an expansion.

content:
Posted: January 28, 2016
												Pros: It is not just civ 3 with new graphics.  That is about it.Cons: AI is terrible.  It reminds me of Red Alert 1 where the AI was just ultra aggressive regardless of being allied or not.  There is almost zero point in diplomacy as the "favor" system does not work at all (At least not in the way it is described in game) and even your best allies will spy and steal from you.   The fact that it takes place on another planet is pretty pointless as the planets all have the same things.  The "affinity" you choose does not matter beyond what special units you get and those units are usually completely worthless for the resources they need.  There is little to no consistency in city health and almost zero ways to improve city health beyond using specific virtues.  The Virtue system is also terrible in its implentation.  The "advisor" in the game is terrible.  It gives suggestions that you actually cannot do.  It also seems to just fixate on one thing.  One game it would not shut up about spies, after they were all assigned to a task but it kept telling me to go look at the covert ops tab.  Another game it kept popping up about trade routes.  While I had all my routes full.  The AI is terrible.Basically, they took all the terrible things from Civ 5 and ignored all the good things.  From what I have heard, the newest expansion is supposed to "fix" it.  But I do not think I should have to pay $90 to get a game that does not give me a headache to play.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												I should have learned my lesson with both Civ IV and Civ V - and that lesson is, wait until the first 'bundle' edition that includes several expansions (at least 2) before buying any Civ game. Along with many in-game traditions, the strongest and most visible tradition of the Civ series is that fixes and balance tweaks are hidden inside of many of the expansions, so much that the vanilla version of the game is exposed as having been released incomplete.While this version is very playable (I did not experience any crashes or other performance issues), it was far tou simple at the default settings. The AI of other 'nations' is lacking any dept and it appears that whatever the 'default attitude' of each NPC happens to be at turn 1 is going to be how they behave entirely, regardless of your actions or how you treat them. I destroyed nations that wanted to trade with me to the bitter end, defiantly offering gestures of friendship and taking time to tell me how much we had in common. I had AI nations throw their entire army at me and reduce me to ruins before I really had an idea where they were on the map. One of them crossed through the territory of two other nations to get to me.So basically, wait for 2 expansions, and buy the bundle - everything should be fixed and completed by then.

This is the worst of both worlds; let me elaborate.2 things are common knowledge; 1} that we cannot travel to other worlds and colonize them yet, and 2} the ability to do so would require a major advance in techology and understanding of science and the universe.Why then would Aircraft carriers regress in the future? But alas, I don't enjoy it. I wouldn't recommend buying it unless it was on sale.

Posted: March 30
												I bought it in 2017. It was good at first and seemed like a much less annoying Civ title with units upgrading on their own, simpler interface, etc. After several games, I realized that every play through is bland, victory conditions are practically the same, and AI players are predictable and annoying. Still, I enjoyed the game despite the "rub" for some time.Then in one game, I built a "Promiseland" gate which was supposed to teleport earthlings. After you get 20 settled, you win the game. Nothing was happening. The victory screen said: "the earthlings are coming right now." They were not. Finally, I realized there was a worker unit "stuck" in the gate trying to build a road to it and never finishing it. Ok fine, small bug, no problem. I removed the worker. Now I could teleport earthlings manually (it does not happen automatically like the instructions say) one per turn. Guess what: the automated workers plugged the gate up every turn! This is 3 years after the release date! You can work around the annoinces like those, but bottom line is: the game is a shallow remake of CivV with less balance, less variety, and worse interface.

content:
Posted: April 16, 2015
												I’ve never liked Civ Games in the past as I always had a hard time with kluging of the historical mechanics and seeing Napoleon strutting around with Stalin etc ….I was / am very fond of SMAX  since it did not need the kluge and had very interesting factions / environment. I thought the Units were a little lack-luster however  – even with the WorkshopCiv BE on the other hand has been a true joy:-	No History Kluge (Alien planet)-	Interesting City / Empire development without it becoming too Math / Puzzle-like-	Very enjoyable units with Purity so far  (have not played as the other 2 yet)-	Atmosphere is awesome – love the music. It’s perfect for an alien planet (I really like EL, ES and AOW III – but  Jazz or World-music for 4x …. No way ….) -	A well built up empire with Mag rails, trade routes, various improvements is a work of art … very pleasing to the eye – sometimes I just scroll around a bit and enjoy it like a well-built model or painting … -	Alien life is exotic and adds to the immersion – but would like to see some eventual Cult of Planet / Mind Worm style connections etc  … and some Progenitors-	Stable – not one crash – can Alt + Tab with no issuesOn the slightly negative side , the Diplomacy is lacking – no Trading of Techs, No propositions to have joint attacks on enemy cities ….Also – The Factions themselves don’t have a great deal of flavor so with the somewhat lacking diplomacy, I just keep them under control until I can enjoy annihilating them  …. Overall – it is one of my favorite gaming experiences at the moment and I am looking forward to a nice expansion or 2 to get into the SMAX quality range ….

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												Simply put, the game is flawed.The AI is laughable at best, and this goes for both Civilizations and Aliens. For example:1) The Aliens are always inclined to attack you even when you're peaceful with them or their foe is by far more superior. So, when my Brawler, an Affinity unit stands fortified near them, they will all attack and all die.2) Some units like the Kraken, the strongest Alien in the game (I believe) can only move and attack in deep ocean. Therefore I killed a Kraken with the weakest ranged naval unit in the game.3) The civilizations build armies but of the wrong kind of units. An ironic quote would be one from the game; "You fight with the army you have. Make sure it's the army you want". It seems both the army the Civlizations have and the one they want suck either way.The new happiness system, Health, is dumb. You can really do nothing else to improve a low health level besides building a few specific buildings which are extremely sparse and lacking in the beginning (If you build "tall", if it's still called that in BE), and the system will just end up hindering your progress anyways to improve your level. Because, of course, a lack in health causes a lack in research, which stalls when you can next research the technology required to build something which will improve it. In Civ V, happiness was easy to fix thanks to the luxury resource system. However now it is all based 99% off of population, and that's significantly harder and more frustrating to fix.The Research is fine, though the new Web feature and lack of advisor guidance when trying to pick what you want to research makes it significantly harder to stay decently caught up in worker techs and such whilst being able to grab an important technology for an Affinity.The culture has not changed at all except for the social policies, now called Virtues, forming more around the new difficulties (and one around population).These notes seem scattered, so let me summarize this. The game is flawed. It is a different beast than Civ V, and should be approached as such. The AI choices and Research paths, along with the lack of personality (and animation? I recieved none) in the leaders causes for a large lack of depth in the gameplay. The game was monotonous and repetitive, and when I felt the game was going to get exciting as War broke loose, I left even more disheartened.The spy system was pretty cool though, I'll give them that.So, for the time being, I would NOT buy this game. I don't feel like I was even close to summing up how dissapointed I was when I tried it. In my honest opinion, Civ V with or without complete DLC is equal to or better than Civ Beyond Earth, respectively. Do keep track of patches and note for changes in the AI and such. After a few patches and some DLC (which usually fixes a lot of things), then maybe this game will be worth the $50 Firaxis is asking for. Until then, I do not reccomend this game.Quick edit: Replayability is huge though granted all the options. Also, if you are to buy the game, I highly reccomend you download the mods found here http://www.pcgamer.com/the-best-civilization-beyond-earth-mods/

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												I'm long time fan of Civilization series and I have very mixed feeling about this one - unfortunately on "No" side more then on "Yes". On a good side:First of all, I had a lot of fun playing it for first 3 or 4 times. Everything was fresh new, I had to learn a lot and this side of the game is as always very nice for me. Unfortunately  once I got those games behind me I find it hard to come back for more. I love the quests implemented in this game - they really add a lot of depth - you can make different choices each time you play and your civilization will be affected by them - you can shape it to be a bit different.There are a lot of problems with make this game either boring or annoying to play:- military - auto-upgrading military units sounded like fun at start but then once you start war it's really really annoying. Your enemy's units can at any moment upgrade to a much better unit on the field. There are not that many units overall, which probably could be fine if they were not being upgraded automatically - but with automatic upgrades it feels like you have very limited toolbox to use for war. Also upgrades are way too big between levels, they should be more gradual. You need to get few points of affinity to upgrade a unit again and then it's like major change. So in order to win a war you basically focus just on technologies that raise your affinity for affinity's sake, not for anything that this technology brings to your civilization.- economy - trade is especially annoying, in late game when you have 2 or 3 trade units per city, you constantly have to pick another trade target for them, every single turn. On the other hand trade is very powerful and without it your civilization will be in a disadvantage so you can't just ignore it.- I also hate how this game no longer rewards me for playing. End game? Just one picture, no way to check my progress against other civilization, some pathetic text "you win" and that's all. When you get a new technology, it's described very poorly and quote that is read to you is usually poor, a bit stupid or non-sense entirely. If you want to play this game you should probably wait a bit till it gets cheaper on gets some DLC/expansion to fix those issues. Right now I can't really recommend to buy this game at full cost. Myself I'll go back to Civ V.

content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												I've played this for about a week now on a daily basis and now feel motivated to write my first ever Steam review. This game feels like someone took the engine from Civ V, ripped out the game's soul and all the good bits. The factions are really difficult to remember - why not just have the traditional Civs in a future or alien setting? I don't really understand why the alien planets actually have to be that alien to be honest, it makes it all feel very unfamiliar and after a week, I just can't be bothered with it. All of the technologies have little made up quotes which are either boring or meaningless - why not still have real quotes from historical figures for future techs? Seeing as all techs fulfill a modern day need in different ways, I am sure this wouldn't have been impossible. Instead I have to endure groaningly bad made up rubbish. Trust me, no one would be compiling any of them into a book of quotations. I find that fact that I have to read the Civilopedia info for every item and wonder in detail to know what is going on a real chore. This game is less than intuitive. Also the wonders are far from wonderous. The diplomacy and AI is still terrible - why can't I see my resources (etc.) while in the middle of a negotiation? The tech tree is an interesting development, but that's about it. If, as others have predicted, a paid for fix to the game comes out in six months or so, I won't buy it on principle. This game feels poorly constructed and without any of the charm of the Civ series. If Firaxis can fix it and give out a free update, I may try again.

												This game is basically Civ V that has a nicely fleshed out affininity system where you can choose to become alien yourself, become space nazis and try to wipe out aliens to further the human race or bcome robots. The aliens in the game seem really lack luster but more intersting then barabrians. 												You remember how Civ 5 was fairly straighforward? Where you would choose from 5 different technologie to research at a time, unlock units and buildings along the way. Thats basically the entirety of this game. At least in my experience.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												Simply put, the game is flawed.The AI is laughable at best, and this goes for both Civilizations and Aliens. For example:1) The Aliens are always inclined to attack you even when you're peaceful with them or their foe is by far more superior. So, when my Brawler, an Affinity unit stands fortified near them, they will all attack and all die.2) Some units like the Kraken, the strongest Alien in the game (I believe) can only move and attack in deep ocean. Therefore I killed a Kraken with the weakest ranged naval unit in the game.3) The civilizations build armies but of the wrong kind of units. An ironic quote would be one from the game; "You fight with the army you have. Make sure it's the army you want". It seems both the army the Civlizations have and the one they want suck either way.The new happiness system, Health, is dumb. You can really do nothing else to improve a low health level besides building a few specific buildings which are extremely sparse and lacking in the beginning (If you build "tall", if it's still called that in BE), and the system will just end up hindering your progress anyways to improve your level. Because, of course, a lack in health causes a lack in research, which stalls when you can next research the technology required to build something which will improve it. In Civ V, happiness was easy to fix thanks to the luxury resource system. However now it is all based 99% off of population, and that's significantly harder and more frustrating to fix.The Research is fine, though the new Web feature and lack of advisor guidance when trying to pick what you want to research makes it significantly harder to stay decently caught up in worker techs and such whilst being able to grab an important technology for an Affinity.The culture has not changed at all except for the social policies, now called Virtues, forming more around the new difficulties (and one around population).These notes seem scattered, so let me summarize this. The game is flawed. It is a different beast than Civ V, and should be approached as such. The AI choices and Research paths, along with the lack of personality (and animation? I recieved none) in the leaders causes for a large lack of depth in the gameplay. The game was monotonous and repetitive, and when I felt the game was going to get exciting as War broke loose, I left even more disheartened.The spy system was pretty cool though, I'll give them that.So, for the time being, I would NOT buy this game. I don't feel like I was even close to summing up how dissapointed I was when I tried it. In my honest opinion, Civ V with or without complete DLC is equal to or better than Civ Beyond Earth, respectively. Do keep track of patches and note for changes in the AI and such. After a few patches and some DLC (which usually fixes a lot of things), then maybe this game will be worth the $50 Firaxis is asking for. Until then, I do not reccomend this game.Quick edit: Replayability is huge though granted all the options. Also, if you are to buy the game, I highly reccomend you download the mods found here http://www.pcgamer.com/the-best-civilization-beyond-earth-mods/

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 8, 2015
The head of american illuminati corp is not a fat guy with slickback hair and a tweed suit smoking a cigarit's a puerto rican woman.Poorly enforced gender parity results in out-of-place token characters that have no personality.Previously, the exceptional narrators and other voice actors were the hallmark of any Civilization game. This time we get an ethnically ambiguous female narrator with an accent so thick that it causes physical pain. It's like having honey boo boo read the lines.The 3d artists did a truly outstanding job, especially with the trailers. Thankfully, this is overshadowed by the eye-watering ugliness of the 2d interface, icons, tech tree and civilopedia.Wonder splash screen is black and white concept art that hasn't been coloured in.Every single icon, all of the art and everything in the civilopedia is black and white.The only things coloured in are victory screens and they look like something I could draw.There are no more quotes. No Lem, no Asiimov, no Stephen Hawking, no nothing, just edgy snippets from instagram or justgirlthings.Victory screen speech sounds like the narrative to a porn film in space.The interface is an avalanche of visual clutter that is only partially oblique to make things even harder to see.Leader dialogue is always exactly the same. Each faction has exactly three unique lines, one of each: hello, trade and defeat. The rest are identical for all factions.Most all of the dialogue is a verbatim copy-paste from Civ5. I wish I was making this up.Spend most of the game re-assigning trade routes.The only promotions available from combat are +10% strength or heal instantly.Alpha Centauri had better mechanics 15 years ago (1999).They tried to innovate and it really shows, but we ended up with an unbalanced, buggy, unplayable mess. Events are always the same. One choice always completely eclipses the alternative. Some perks are always better. Multiplayer is completely busted. The game doesn't even try to be fun after the early stage, so you might as well just play the demo which cuts you off after 100 turns or so.This game is a horrendous downgrade from BNW. It's worse than Civilization 5 was before the balance patches and expansion packs and would have been slammed even if it came out 10 years ago, let alone in 2014.The reviews are like Bioshock Infinite all over again.tl;drgameplay dumbed down even more, everything looks like concept art, all the icons are black and white (yes, all of them), the interface is a cluster****, painful narrator, no quotes, uncanny valley gender parity and political correctnessI really wanted a solid Civilization title, but only somebody under hypnosis could claim to enjoy this one. Looks like the devs were given a deadline that no honest man could meet on top of shoehorning in a progressive agenda. Don't be a dummy like me. Vote with your wallet and stay away from this kind of product as well as any expansion packs. This title is beyond saving.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 15, 2015
												I gave thumb up, though it may rather be considered neutral, or even down.Here's why - as a Civ-gamer, I played all of them since the very moment of release, since Civ1 (yup, am *that* old) - EXCEPT this one. I've played on free-days only... still won't buy it...Why (even slight) positive review, then? It's a good game - PROVIDED THAT YOU DON'T HAVE CIV5 ALREADYIt's a good game - EXCEPT WHEN COMPARED TO ALPHA CENTAURIOtherwise, you may be better to wait for (at least) first expansion, which is coming out soon. This was, more or less, true for earlier Civ games (especially Civ5 and less so for others - Alpha haven't even profited from expansion).What it is?-----------Civ5 in space. Bit different graphics, some innovations, but nothing revolutionary.  Factions are bleak, and worse - a handful. Civ5 major flaws are here, too... Diplomacy even uses exact same dialogue lines...What it isn't?--------------Alpha2. With EACH faction wonderfully shade-of-gray, even dark agenda, with highly distinctive gameplay, strengths and weaknesses. With revolutionary solutions, years ahead its time...-----------So, in current state I could recommend it to newcomers or people who would like to play Civ5-in-space.For die-hard fans of Alpha, I couldn't recommend it - they are likely to find themselves disappointed or uninterested, same happened to me with Civ5 - bought it, played 10h, didn't touch it until second expansion (when huge discount influenced the decision). I don't regret it NOW, but it did took 2 expansions to get fixed...There is also a 'third group', which would have to decide for themselves, since I cannot honestly recommend either - read more reviews, forums, watch gameplay videos...----------Will expansion fix it? Well, it doesn't *look* like fix-it-all one, but then again, it's Sid Maiers company. It may surprise me yet... On a positive note, Firaxis seem to be aware of flaws, and it's kind of them to provide free-weekends for a game which received wide negative critics - hopefully, they will do the same with expansion.Don't get me wrong - I'd gladly pay full price (including the expansion) for a fully fixed game, or Alpha2 remake. Mine 'not-buying-until-it's-improved' decision is a matter of general principles and (likely) stubborness - it shouldn't stop other players.It's Firaxis game, after all, which means certain standards of quality are present - a trait which most wannabie-4X games cannot claim.Above was stated clearly which groups of player may like the game, and which may not - at least expansion-less.As for myself, I'll buy it eventually and probably play lots of it - it's just a question of time.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 2, 2015
												I will remove/change this review when Firaxis begins to listen to their Players. After paying $40 for an incomplete game, we are again asked to shell out another $30 for a DLC that should come as an Update, as it apparently Finishes what the development team failed to do in the first place. Civ:BE has the potential to be one of the best TBS games on the market, furthermore one of the better Sci-Fi games on the market. As a Science Fiction fan, i am in love with the theme, the colors are rich, and the overall gameplay is so close to being complete it is literally annoying to play, simply because you feel that if the team took even an extra month, they could've actually put in the finishing touches, making the game what it should be. It is apparent, instead of updating the game, we will now have to purchase Beyond Earth Rising Tide just to get the game to a non-annoying and enjoyable condition. I have 155 hours clocked on Civ:5 because it is brilliant. I have 8.6 hours on this game thus far because i simply cannot sit down and play it, as i find myself just unengaged after the first 30-100 turns, depending on how idiotic our AI decide to be, you know, whether or not they decide to declare war on me for unearthing one of their precious artifacts, even though they've seemingly emptied my surrounding land of anything that had value, while I had no option but to watch from my feable and somewhat boring colony. The fact that even simple things such as changes to the Tech Tree UI are attached to the Rising Tide DLC shows that Firaxis is gobling up money faster than they can put out quality games, this is bad news for any long-term business strategies they may think they have. Figure it out, make the neccessary changes, and throw us a freaking bone!!! and I would gladly recommend this game to even my grand parents!

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
												SMAC was a game about ideas and while the affinity systems introduces a compellling raft of ideas about the future direction of humanity, they are poorly realized and the starting factors lack any distinct Earth ideologies to meld with their brave new world.Maybe after patches and DLC this game will be great but some interesting evolutions are marred by glaring problems.Pros:- Traiding for favors in diplomacy is a great addition and when a trading partner spent favors to get me to go to war.. I listened.  - The refined spy system is quite enjoyable and can form a leg of new stratagies.  Like running energy deficits made up for by periodic "transfers" of large energy stores- The affinity system is interesting and a believable reaction to events on Earth - though the main gameplay is lacking in backstory and writting is not as grand or artful as in SMAC- The ailens are decidely not barbarians and those who handle them as such are not really getting that they are something different and other arrangements are possible- The tech web is actually very neat and I like the non-linear progress.  I only wish thay had been more ambitious here and clearly made more of it optional for certain factors and affinities. -  The new virtures system is pretty good though prosperity is OP due to other health balance problems.  Overall, virtues are as important to overcoming the harsh planet as the tech web.Cons- No diplomacy victor and lack of luxaries means that aspect of the game is stilted as compared to Civ 5 or SMAC - a shame given the potential favors open up- Lots of visual and other small bugs- A step backwards in UI from Civ 5 with less information avalible on why things happen or what your built- AI is still terrible at war - only sheer numbers would work for it- I didn't even realize when I built my first wonder, they are underpowered and completing them feels underwhelming without any videos like in Civ 5 or SMAC- The writting is overall not very godo and this shows with both wonders and completed technologies.  Also many of the quotes don't seem to add to either factor, affinity, or the earth backstory- Default factors just aren't that interesting, it's affinities that matter-  Too many small quest decisions without a sense of direction or purpose.  I hope any building upgrade quests are just removed as they don't really add much to overall gameplay  - Buggy quests, I get quests I can never fulfill due to their requirements being impossible

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2016
												I may have come into this experience with unreasonable expectations.  When I saw the trailers for "Beyond Earth," I immediately got pumped for a spiritual successor to "Alpha Centauri."  After playing many hours of this game, I can tell you this:  Alpha Centauri, it ain't.  My main problem with the game is its drab, unengaging, and copy-pastey factions.  In Alpha Centauri, all of the faction leaders had their own goals and personalities.  The dialogue options were unique and tailored to each faction leader, and gave the single-player experience a satisfying political feel.  Beyond Earth, on the other hand, uses the same dialogue for political interactions with every faction.  Faction leaders have no personality, and as a result, dealing with a faction feels more like hitting the snooze button on an alarm clock, rather than having a wheel-and-deal with the supreme leader of a unique nation.  Additionally, the tech tree feels boring and unexciting.  Almost every technology gives you a percentage increase to military, science, or economy.  It's common to spend twenty turns researching a technology, only to find your reward being a .2% increase in faction-wide economic revenue.  In Alpha Centauri, researching a new technology could give you access to missile weapons, flight, or hovercraft.  Racing toward the Flight technology could give you a dominating advantage.  No such analogue in Beyond Earth.  It's just a boring march of percentiles.Full disclosure:  I haven't played the Rising Tide DLC.  I've been told that it fixes a lot of the problems with faction leaders, making them more unique and fun to interact with.  However, after my disappointing experience with Beyond Eath, I'm not sure if I want to sink more money into what's turned out to be a lackluster experience.  If I change my mind, I'll update this review.  As it stands, I don't recommend the game.  Firaxis is an excellent studio, and I own and enjoy a lot of their games.  This one, however, could have been done much better.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2015
												Only played it during a free weekend, but I absolutely LOVE this game. I'm a big fan of the Civ franchise, and I've been playing since Civ 3. That said, I still suck majorly at the game, I play it extremely casually (but for long periods of time nonetheless). Civ 5 is an awesome game, definitely worthy of the franchise. One of the very few things I very much dislike about the Civilization games is how you are bound to going forward in time. You can chose to start from a later age but you can't chose to stay in one age longer, except if you play marathon or epic (which I usually do) but you're still unable to achieve pretty much anything in, for instance, the archaic age, even though, playing as Babylon, I should be able to have a history-worthy empire at that time (But it's impossible) which makes civ really unrealistic - as if you can't have a big empire with lots of cities 1500 BC. Another thing that bothers me about the original game is how you're always bound to the empires of this world, and always one ruler who somehow lives for 7000 years... It would be cool if you could just make your own culture and empire, not really bound by any of the empires in the actual world so you could more realistically rewrite history. I heard many people complaining that this game is "just like an expansion of Civ 5". I compeltely disagree, the game is different. I played Civ 3 and its gameplay is still similar to Civ 5. It's just a weird conclusion, this game is different and it feels different to me. What I really like about it is how there are these factions that represent more developed alliances that relate to those of the present world, and that you're not really connected to history at all so many of the problems I had with the Civ games, that I mentioned above, fall away. Nevertheless, the game isn't perfect. As I played it, it seemed rather unfinished - just slightly. There could've been a lot more features and fun things in the game, more expanding on how the other nations react to you and one another, especially concerning how to deal with alien life (I really liked how they did the thing with symbiosis with alien life though) and there should be more ways to win the game, and more immersion in the world (this does count for most civ games, though. Lacks immersion. Civ 3 had this cool thing with your palace expanding if your people get happier or something. I don't know why they ever got rid of that. That's the kind of stuff that really catches my eye and gets me immersed.)Other than all that, I'm just a big fan of sci-fi. I love history, but history is written and rewriting it is awkward (americans in mesopotamia with the pyramids and the porcelain tower??) unless you would take away all the pre-determined things (like set culture, wonders. As I said, it would be awesome if we could design our own culture. Sort of like how "Gods and Kings" adressed religion, but very much expanded upon). Sci-Fi, like High Fantasy, however, is completely free of that. This setting, the whole emotional opening cinematic, the whole idea... It just blows my mind. This setting and theme comes very close to my ideal of the future of mankind. I said ♥♥♥♥ yes many times while starting off the game.A bummer: After playing this game for 6 hours straight I was nearing the end of the game. It was a pretty big letdown. I was very close to finishing the satelity thingy for the alien buddies victory, but someone else was ahead of me. ( a freakin NPC, I know I suck.) and the ending was very anti climatic. I loaded an earlier save later on and did it again, this time with me winning but I was still underwhelmed. The original Civ games had underwhelming endings too, I must say, but this just felt like much of the 6 hours weren't  well spent. Again, this does count for Civ 5 too, but not to such extend.Alright, so let me wrap this up. I am a crappy Civ player that only plays against NPC's and sometimes a friend of mine. I am a casual player and this was my impression of the game. I'd give it a 7/10.You don't have to take my word for it though.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												I like the game, but I have many suggestions for new content to make it better: NEW SPONSOR-SPECIFIC UNITS: Sponsors should have exclusive units so that sponsors feel more distinct and important.  Here's some ideas:* American Reclamation Corporation (ARC): Since they are spies, give them a unit that can cloak and enter other colony borders without starting a war.* Brasilia: Since their strength is melee, give them a melee unit that specializes in killing enemy melee units.  * Franco-Iberia: Since their strength is culture, give them a propaganda unit with 5 move speed that can dash into an enemy city and reduce its defenses, based on how much culture Franco has.* Kavithan Protectorate: Since their strength is border expansion, give them a unit that gains battle bonuses for fighting inside their borders, on their land.* Pan-Asian Cooperative: Since their strength is workers, give them special worker units that have weapons.* People's African Union: Since their strength is food, give them turret units that can be built on farms for protection.  One turret per 10 hex spaces, per city (so basically, each city would have 1 max).* Polystralia: Since their strength is trade, give them units that can "ride" trade convoys to protect them.  Or special trade convoys with weapons.* Slavic Federation: Since their strength is orbital, give them a cheaply produced orbital weapon that can crash to deal damage. AFFINITY UNIT CHANGE SUGGESTIONS: Most affinity units are bland and weak.  I can always beat the game with Dominance Victory without affinity units.  I just upgrade regular units.  I avoid affinity units because they have low stats and quickly become outdated, especially since your regular units receive upgrades much earlier than affinity units.   You should give affinity units special abilities, so they have strategic support value on the battlefield, instead of being bland/weak.  Here's some ideas:* Abilities to give to Purity Affinity units:-AEGIS should be able to temporarily "transform" into a jet for increased movement and transform back into AEGIS to fight.-Battlesuits carry flags, so should provide bonus inspiration/attack to nearby allies.-LEV Tank should deal bonus damage vs mechanical enemies, like a tank is supposed to.-LEV Destroyer is sufficiently strong and the only worthwhile Purity unit.* Abilities to give to Supremacy Affinity units:-Per its name, CNDR should deal 10 burning damage to adjacent units beyond its target.-Per its name, CARVR should be able to raze a forest and turn it flat.  Though, the game description says CARVR is a recon unit, so maybe it should fire a beacon that reveals part of the map.-SABR should be able to detonate and explode to deal damage, since they are generally useless in many combat situations. SABR have 1 movement and they require that 1 movement to set up for attack, so they literally don't do anything.  You can just upgrade Rangers for the 3 attack range and Rangers have 2 movement with no set up.-ANGEL is sufficiently strong and the only worthwhile Supremacy unit.* Abilities to give to Harmony Affinity units:-Xeno Swarm should be able to convince neutral Alien units to join its swarm (absorbing the Alien), to gain permanent bonus strength like an upgrade.-Xeno Cavalry should be able to "dash through" enemy units that are blocking its path since they are riding an acrobatic alien!-Xeno Titan and Rocktopus are sufficiently strong.  Rocktopus is currently the only creative affinity unit. GAMEPLAY CHANGE SUGGESTIONS: * Mid to late game, there's always too many workers that you don't need.  Workers should be able to permanently "morph" into other units, such as a militia unit (after researching a specific tech of course).  * Explorers are useless mid to late game.  They should be able to morph into immobile sentries that grant increased vision on the map, so they are doing something useful.  * New unit:  Armored Transport Truck.  A truck with 4 movement that can hold 2 land units.  Has bonus armor, but no weapons.  After exiting the truck, the carried unit will have 0 movement (simliar to when you purchase a new unit in a city).  If the truck is destroyed, then the carried units inside are destroyed.* When you research Magrail, the Construct Road option disappears.   Let us pick between Magrail / Road; don't erase the Road option.  Sometimes, I want to construct a road because it costs less than magrail to maintain and it builds quicker.  Also, the Civilopedia needs to explain the movement bonuses provided by road and magrail (what is the exact movement fraction?  1/2? 1/3?).* Ability to settle a city lodged inside a Mountain for extra defense. * Ability to settle a city inside a Crevice for extra energy (from the planet's core).* Ability to settle a city on a Crater for extra production (from meteor fragments). USER INTERFACE CHANGE SUGGESTIONS: * Allow us to click on an enemy unit to view its stats, without having to attack it or pretend to attack it, just to view enemy unit information.   * Unit queue system: When sorting to the next unit to take its turn, the queue system should select the nearest unit to the one you just finished moving.  That way you can conduct battles and move large forces across the map with less headache.  Currently, the unit queue system, jumps back and forth across the map which is annoying.  * In the Cover Ops screen, when your agent is currently in counter-intelligence protecting your city, it should show you how much intrigue the protected city has.  Currently, you have to physically jump to your city to look at its intrigue if it's under counter-intelligence.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2015
												Only played it during a free weekend, but I absolutely LOVE this game. I'm a big fan of the Civ franchise, and I've been playing since Civ 3. That said, I still suck majorly at the game, I play it extremely casually (but for long periods of time nonetheless). Civ 5 is an awesome game, definitely worthy of the franchise. One of the very few things I very much dislike about the Civilization games is how you are bound to going forward in time. You can chose to start from a later age but you can't chose to stay in one age longer, except if you play marathon or epic (which I usually do) but you're still unable to achieve pretty much anything in, for instance, the archaic age, even though, playing as Babylon, I should be able to have a history-worthy empire at that time (But it's impossible) which makes civ really unrealistic - as if you can't have a big empire with lots of cities 1500 BC. Another thing that bothers me about the original game is how you're always bound to the empires of this world, and always one ruler who somehow lives for 7000 years... It would be cool if you could just make your own culture and empire, not really bound by any of the empires in the actual world so you could more realistically rewrite history. I heard many people complaining that this game is "just like an expansion of Civ 5". I compeltely disagree, the game is different. I played Civ 3 and its gameplay is still similar to Civ 5. It's just a weird conclusion, this game is different and it feels different to me. What I really like about it is how there are these factions that represent more developed alliances that relate to those of the present world, and that you're not really connected to history at all so many of the problems I had with the Civ games, that I mentioned above, fall away. Nevertheless, the game isn't perfect. As I played it, it seemed rather unfinished - just slightly. There could've been a lot more features and fun things in the game, more expanding on how the other nations react to you and one another, especially concerning how to deal with alien life (I really liked how they did the thing with symbiosis with alien life though) and there should be more ways to win the game, and more immersion in the world (this does count for most civ games, though. Lacks immersion. Civ 3 had this cool thing with your palace expanding if your people get happier or something. I don't know why they ever got rid of that. That's the kind of stuff that really catches my eye and gets me immersed.)Other than all that, I'm just a big fan of sci-fi. I love history, but history is written and rewriting it is awkward (americans in mesopotamia with the pyramids and the porcelain tower??) unless you would take away all the pre-determined things (like set culture, wonders. As I said, it would be awesome if we could design our own culture. Sort of like how "Gods and Kings" adressed religion, but very much expanded upon). Sci-Fi, like High Fantasy, however, is completely free of that. This setting, the whole emotional opening cinematic, the whole idea... It just blows my mind. This setting and theme comes very close to my ideal of the future of mankind. I said ♥♥♥♥ yes many times while starting off the game.A bummer: After playing this game for 6 hours straight I was nearing the end of the game. It was a pretty big letdown. I was very close to finishing the satelity thingy for the alien buddies victory, but someone else was ahead of me. ( a freakin NPC, I know I suck.) and the ending was very anti climatic. I loaded an earlier save later on and did it again, this time with me winning but I was still underwhelmed. The original Civ games had underwhelming endings too, I must say, but this just felt like much of the 6 hours weren't  well spent. Again, this does count for Civ 5 too, but not to such extend.Alright, so let me wrap this up. I am a crappy Civ player that only plays against NPC's and sometimes a friend of mine. I am a casual player and this was my impression of the game. I'd give it a 7/10.You don't have to take my word for it though.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												Taking place after the events of Civlization V: The Wrath of Gandhi, Civilization: Beyond Earth follows the lives of colonists fleeing the ruin of Gandhi's Earth in search of a new home somewhere in the void of space. Upon planetfall, the colonists may decide to associate themselves with the native species, focus on technological advancements not previously possible in order to return to Earth to defeat Gandhi, or follow a much darker path... Devoting themselves to the memory of Gandhi and his empire in the hopes of one day bringing him to this new planet.Little do the colonists know that their so-called "Progenitor" predecessors on their new homes were actually early attempts from Gandhi to conquer other planets...

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
												I've played this game a great deal, and I have to say, it just doesn't live up to snuff. It's not as good as Civilization 5: Brave New World on the strategy front, nor is it challenging or exciting. Why is it bad?- Affinity system makes beakers the *only* important resource; rush tech 100% of the time, and you will win 100% of the time- The A.I. doesn't seem to have any programming. They often just idle the entire game, while occasionally deploying a poorly organized army at you once, and then begging for your forgiveness while rewarding you with tons of favors and resources.-  The aliens don't scale; they're a challenge for 40 turns, and then they are just fodder for the rest of the game. For something to be an integral part of the game, it needs to serve some sort of purpose beyond "Wefuxurexplorers" for a few turns- The jumps between tech levels are too drastic; a tech 1 unit, fully leveled and with virtue support, has almost no chance of contending with a tech 2 unit; the auto-upgrade immediately happening further rewards players for fast teching, instead of making them strategically utilize their resources on a per-unit basis.- Diplomacy is a complete and utter joke. Literally the worst iteration in the franchise history, I would say.- Randomly appearing trade outposts always take up the best land spots; you have to decide whether you want their bonus, or their location for tiles... and they always spawn in between the best locations, strategically.The game has a long way to go. The only positive I can say about it is that, it's a Civ game, and they do always get better with time/expansion packs/DLC. Wait until a few patches drop and and the game is fine-tuned. In it's current state, it feels like a fleshed out, early-access game that is still months away from being a complete game

number of helpful: 8 of 14 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
												This game is fantastic, difficult and challenging with a fairly open ended way to go about everything. Long gone is the linear tech tree which has been replaced by the tech web, giving you choice in the direction you build and focus your empire. But with this comes the downside of spending too much time going with whatever looks neat, and having no progression towards your ultimate victory.I can honestly see guides popping up on how to rush the right tech to the fastest victory. Anyway, Gameplay is familiar to those who have played Civ5. The atmospheric layer adds wicked little temporay bonuses to your empire, from solar collects to orbital lasers. Making it neat to play with.Diplomacy hasn't changed much, its solid with all the bells and whistles and a new Favor system. Ask for tech/trade whatever and offer favors that can be used and redeemed and it seems the AI has a harder time saying no too.Spying is actually fun now, from defending your territory, stealing tech, money, research and units. Subversion and everything in between.Speaking of units, the units in this game benefit from their own version of a tech tree. meshed with your affinity(which is chosen through tech and choices you make in the game) tech evolves into hyper futuristic stuff with wicked bonuses. gone is manually upgrading, just keep that research flowing.Barbarians have evolved into aliens and this adds a whole new dynamic, attack and wipe them out, risks bigger badder alien Xenos coming after you. or tame them, study them, and gain their abilities or outright use them.I could go on and on about this so ill focus on my own gripe at the moment.Minus a few bugs(seems the ai likes to remind you constantly of things you did ONCE) because of how the tech web is designed, it feels like the game is much shorter then other Civs, then again, I started playing at 10pm release night all the way till 5am...so maybe not so much xDI reccomend this game fully.and to anyone who says its a reskinned Civ 5.Don't fix what isn't broken

number of helpful: 8 of 14 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 24, 2014
												This game is fantastic, difficult and challenging with a fairly open ended way to go about everything. Long gone is the linear tech tree which has been replaced by the tech web, giving you choice in the direction you build and focus your empire. But with this comes the downside of spending too much time going with whatever looks neat, and having no progression towards your ultimate victory.I can honestly see guides popping up on how to rush the right tech to the fastest victory. Anyway, Gameplay is familiar to those who have played Civ5. The atmospheric layer adds wicked little temporay bonuses to your empire, from solar collects to orbital lasers. Making it neat to play with.Diplomacy hasn't changed much, its solid with all the bells and whistles and a new Favor system. Ask for tech/trade whatever and offer favors that can be used and redeemed and it seems the AI has a harder time saying no too.Spying is actually fun now, from defending your territory, stealing tech, money, research and units. Subversion and everything in between.Speaking of units, the units in this game benefit from their own version of a tech tree. meshed with your affinity(which is chosen through tech and choices you make in the game) tech evolves into hyper futuristic stuff with wicked bonuses. gone is manually upgrading, just keep that research flowing.Barbarians have evolved into aliens and this adds a whole new dynamic, attack and wipe them out, risks bigger badder alien Xenos coming after you. or tame them, study them, and gain their abilities or outright use them.I could go on and on about this so ill focus on my own gripe at the moment.Minus a few bugs(seems the ai likes to remind you constantly of things you did ONCE) because of how the tech web is designed, it feels like the game is much shorter then other Civs, then again, I started playing at 10pm release night all the way till 5am...so maybe not so much xDI reccomend this game fully.and to anyone who says its a reskinned Civ 5.Don't fix what isn't broken

number of helpful: 8 of 14 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 19, 2015
												= A late bloomer but great game =159 hrs and still discovering\conquering new worlds and challenges.When this game launched it was Civ ME. The bugs were crippling and multiplayer was just plain broken. It was sad because the vision, story, and atmosphere were great. The quest, techweb, and affinity mechanics create a "Choose Your Own Adventure" system which allows you to truly adapt to your starting terrain and opponents. The soundtrack is epic. The achievements and units were designed by scifi fans for scifi fans.After a few major patches this game is running faster than Civ5. It's stable and immersive. Multiplayer is 95% there but 100% fun. On the harder levels the AI is pretty creative and challenging. The "happiness-health leak" is fixed - it matters now but it's properly measured. Your people don't rebel just because Polynesia banned truffles. You can finish the invasion but may need to slow down.= I gave it a second chance and I'm very glad that I did =I'm looking forward to the Rising Tide addition.- Having to stop Hutama from completing the Mind Flower in 10 turns from the other side of the world without airports..- Bumping into an Multi-Kraken breeding den while moving Hail Mary reinforcements across the water..- Dune sand worms ripping apart your first two cities - walk without rhythm...- Allies beaming armies of Cloverfield titans into enemy farms to fight alongside your Astro-Roman legion mechs...- Asia attacking you before your first settler.. defending in NASA spacesuits.. the bugs eat your new tank.- Your ally AI gets mad that you built a wonder he wanted and turns on your forces the night before D-Day - 42/42 "So Say We All"

content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												Taking place after the events of Civlization V: The Wrath of Gandhi, Civilization: Beyond Earth follows the lives of colonists fleeing the ruin of Gandhi's Earth in search of a new home somewhere in the void of space. Upon planetfall, the colonists may decide to associate themselves with the native species, focus on technological advancements not previously possible in order to return to Earth to defeat Gandhi, or follow a much darker path... Devoting themselves to the memory of Gandhi and his empire in the hopes of one day bringing him to this new planet.Little do the colonists know that their so-called "Progenitor" predecessors on their new homes were actually early attempts from Gandhi to conquer other planets...

content:
Posted: November 10, 2014
												When this was announced, I was really excited, as SMAC is one of my all time favourite games. But I remained cautious because Firaxis have this unfortunate habit of releasing a mediocre game (Civ 5) and then releasing great expansions (Brave New World) to actually make it the game it's supposed to be. It's exactly the same with this game, but it does have good points.Good: -Still extremely adddictive -Atmosphere of the alien world is well done, though the terrain gets repetitive soon-Tech web is fun for a whileBad: -Feels like a half-baked mod-Illusion of choice is EVERYWHERE... in the tech web, in the virtues, in the quests, etc. There's usually one path which is most useful. For a game built around choice, this is a huge negative-Faction leaders have no personality-No luxury resources makes settling new cities far less entertaining, and removes a big aspect of each civilization's role in the world- All the factions feel the same because they ARE the same apart from their one unique ability, which is only really felt in early game. 50-100 turns into each game, all Civs are exactly the same, with different colours.-Very very little replayability-Bored already, and I've just played 11 hours. To put that into context, I played Civ5 + expansions for over 300 hours (online and offline) and I still want to go back to that.Bottom Line: NOT WORTH BUYING AT $50, or even $30. I got it cheap here in retail for the equivalent of $20 and I still feel a bit ripped off. Just play Brave New World.

number of helpful: 9 of 16 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 20, 2015
												A lot of people in their reviews say that you shouldn't buy this game or wait until the first DLC (Which is October 9th, so excited for that!), mainly because "It's a reskin of Civ 5". But in reality, it isn't in it's own little ways.First are the aliens. They are kinda like barbarians except depending on how much you destroy their nests and a certain pace, they could be peaceful to all out death destroyers. Second, is the colonization of the planet. You start out with an area to select your first city. Which, depending on the tiles it gives you, could give you an edge against other players early on. All of the other players settle 1 player per turn and the game shows where the player's capital is, which again is cool (Everything in the game, I thought was cool.) Third, is the unit upgrades. The game provides a tech tree type deal with each military unit. Once a higher tier is available, it notifies you and you upgrade all, I mean ALL of your units in one, swift click, even if they aren't in your territory.I'm not going to state EVERYTHING there is to the game. But 12 hours into playtime on the game and still enjoying it is pretty good.  Besides, I'll let you guys figure everything else out by yourself so I don't spoil the game. It is nicer that way.10/10 I would play again.

number of helpful: 10 of 18 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												Civilization: Beyond Earth. Cool title and a nice game. People often complain about the lack of units compared to say Civ 5 where you had 10-ish units with a dozen or so different models though the ages. I like the "lack" of units if you can call it that. (The basic marine has 8 models depending on perk choise and affinity level.)That said I feel there could be more variety when it comes to the alien life forms in the game. To switch things around from one game to another much like the terrain does.Combat is solid though the AI tends to be a tad crap at it. Diplomacy leaves a lot to be desired I'm sad to say.The tech web is a wonderfull idea but could use some more paint so you can easily identify what you get. (Several such mods availible in the workshop.)The one thing that annoys me is the trade convoy system. Instead of having persistent routes and a menu to manage and change these routes a treade route is permanent until the time limit for it expires after 25 turns and you have to make assign new route.That's the basic rundown of the game. I highly recommend it even with its few flaws and minimalistic GUI. I'm having loads of fun every game. ^_^
