number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth, is a continuation of the time period beyond normal Civilization Continuity. Taking place after a great disaster has occurred upon Earth mankind has moved into the stars to ensure its survival. The game begins with you selecting a sponsor and various long term and onetime bonus allowing you to craft your own play style from turn one. However, the selecting a sponsor is also points out what is one of Civ: Beyond Earth greatest weakness, variety.Upon landing  upon a world which art style and feel are most certainly harken back to Alpha Centria, with the old harsh red tones of old scraped away.  The game plays very much like a civilization game, resources strategic or otherwise play out to help your young colony grow into a prosperous future nation. Over time other sponsors send your future allies or enemies to seed their own future nation.As turns, research, random events, and quest continue on throughout the game, your actions and choices will help determine the natural course of your societies growth.  If you inclination is to exterminate the natural species on the planet you will move more toward purity, if you take actions more against your fellow man you will acquire supremacy easier, and if you want to live with the native species and co-exist, you will morph into harmony. As your become more inclined to a path your cities and units will change to reflect your play style.Civilization game Civ: Beyond Earth is a good game, but it lacks several things which make it a great game, and to be fair it is important to point those things out. If you are looking for a large amount of variation in gameplay, in its current state Beyond Earth Cannot deliver, the starting factions are too few, which makes replay factor with other factions very limited. The greatest problem, however, is in the affinity system. While is it a wonderful system for what it does, at the end of the game it also creates a game where you have three main styles of play to go down. While there are many gameplay methods to change up the way you play, it would have been enjoyable to see other affinities to help support those styles. Long term I am hoping more affinities are such as one to support stronger economic/diplomacy models.Over all Civ: Beyond Earth is game which I would give a positive review for, it will hopefully follow the Civilization V model and continue to grow over time into a stronger game. The game in and of itself has a great deal to offer.  As a long time Civilization player, personally I feel a few key things were missing which make this game a truly phenomenal game, but I would still suggest you purchase it if you love the series.

But my impression overall is positive.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												Well♥♥♥♥♥♥ Never thought I would write a negative review on a Civ game. So I played it for around 10 hours and shooting myself seemed like a better option than starting another round. Just for a sidenote , I am a complete idiot at writing reviews. Alright let's start it off - TLDR at the end for you lazy procrastinarosTech Web - what is this? Bug it if I know. At first it seems like a really cool way to introduce new mechanics to research to make the gameplay fresh but after a while you notice a couple of things. Why am I researching any of this? What do I have to research anyway? Why can't I research what I want rather than focus on a single thing and religiously sticking to it or getting mowed down by A.I. players?Buildings/wonders/research - at the tech web, you have absolutely no idea what you're doing. There isn't a single moment like there is in Civ V where you're just like : "WOAH I CAN BUILD THAT IF I RESEARCH THIS AND DO THAT? OMG YES * throws scientists* " . Buildings and wonders have almost no effect on the visual side of your city , since most wonders are just big boxes and cubes made out of whatever material. It just seems so bland and cluttered and the long research just turns the game into "Next Turn Simulator".Aliens/units - so in this game you can upgrade your units by achieving points in either Harmony , Purity or Supremacy and I have to say that the visual design ( of the player units ) is really cool and it genuienly feels like a reward , especially when your squad of merciless robots takes down a batallion of petty humans. Har har har.HOWEVER the aliens are soooooooooooo bland and most of them feel like rip offs from Mass Effect or  190124 diffirent sci - fi bugs ( seriously? Siege Worms? call BioWare , Thresher Maws are going to have a little talk ). None of them have any soul or variation and they're either annoying because they wreck your entire♥♥♥♥♥♥up when you're about to attack someone else entirely or they can be dealt with by blowing your nose too loudly. There's no balance or middle ground.Gameplay - it's the same old thing. 4X blah blah , but this time we have ORBITAL UNITS. YAY. Or not. The orbital layer barely effects the game at all , and you can ignore it the entire time you're playing. Also THERE ARE NO WEAPONS OF MASS DESTRUCTION. WHAT? WE SHOULD HAVE NUKES - LAZER KAPOW EDITION BY THIS POINT. TLDR - Don't buy. Go back to Civ V.

content:
Posted: February 26
												Civilization Beyond Earth has a lot in common with Civilization V in its gameplay, and some might say that it would just be a clone / DLC of Civilization V and nothing more. I strongly disagree, as this game plays entirely different than any Civilization; the technology tree cannot be remotely compared and involves a strategy of appropriately choosing the correct technologies to acquire the needed amount of points in your desired affinity, these choices also profoundly modifying your development to the point where, you guessed it, you start playing differently than Civilization V (because the number 1 mistake is to play it like you would play Civ V, and not only will you not fair well, but you will also obviously have that feeling of deja-vu).Speaking of affinities, this is where most of my appeal in the game comes from; it genuinely dives into possible future paths for humanity, especially on the themes of transhumanism, extropianism or simply traditional humanism.What else, soundtracks are not as great as in Civ V but I am a personal fan of some sound effects, espcially the ones for the quests.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												Beyond Earth is good. Perhaps not the best Civ game (at the time of writing this, it's only had a few updates and no post-launch DLC, so there's still time) but certainly far from terrible. The shift to alien planets and post-space cultures is really interesting, and adds some new dimensions to the gameplay. The tech tree has changed considerably as have other core mechanics, whilst still retaining the same structure as previous Civ games.It's not problem free, though. The UI is intensely confusing to start with and feels more like it was designed for its style rather than its functionality. Units and buildings feel less interesting than Civ V, and overall your progression over a period of time is less than in other Civ games. You don't have eras, instead the only real sense of progression comes through increasing your affinities. Leaders have a much smaller set of vocal responses too, and you can hear the same phrase only a few times before getting fed up.But on the whole it is a good game. It's perhaps looking a little weak compared to its siblings, but it is important to remember that Beyond Earth is still in its infancy, with at least one expansion to come. I do, however, think it's worth getting for its aesthetic and its world-building. Firaxis are really trying to make it come alive.

There is a gap you have to overcome in the beginning where it is hard to care about any nation or any leaders because they don't have a background you already know, so there is no frame of reference, no one to be excited to play.  Each leader grows on you though.  Maybe if they introduced each leader with a cutscene so show which part of earth they came from and their unknown history, which I understand is in the Civopedia. Posted: July 18, 2015
												I'm a huge fan of Civilization V and been playing since Civ 3 and Alpha Centauri.  What this game lacks is 2 things in my view.  Unique characters per faction and any real depth.  I understand that I can't expect the Samurais or Panzer tanks to show up and some would argue that you do get unique units via your choices of idealogy.  It just would have been nice to see a unique unit / buiilding/ terrain enhancement per civ just to make it intriguing to play another faction. The other thing is the real bland interactions between the factions.  Diplomacy is a non factor in this game in my view.  Anyway this game takes 2 steps back from Civ V and was so boring, I'm not even going to buy the DLC packs even if they do remedey these issues.   I mean, after trying to play two games with different factions I was so bored that I went back to play Civilization V.  Really suggest to skip this title in the series.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
												I've played this game a lot. A lot. Dozens of games. All sorts of high difficulties. Tons of mods. I'm active in several communities that piece apart issues with the game and try to improve on them, so I know a thing or two about the game's shortcomings.Does it have them? Absolutely. But most of them are behind hours and hours of understanding core game mechanics to know what is and what is not unbalanced. Listen, if you're genuinely interested in Civilization in Space, you'll enjoy this game. If you expect it to be everything Alpha Centauri was and more -- you'll probably be disappointed. If you don't actually like sci-fi and space, you'll probably be disappointed. The game is a gem for those who can appreciate it though. There's very little wrong with the game and the devs are constantly working to remedy that. I look forward to seeing how the game changes with the upcoming DLC Rising Tide.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2016
												This is the single most disappointing game I've ever purchased. Years ago I was a huge fan of alpha centuri and it's adaptation of Civ's mechanics into a science fiction setting, it was genuinely progressive and capitalized on it's setting. You could raise and lower sea levels, mind control cities and drop units into battle from space. Naturally I was incredibly excited to see these ideas revisited with a modern budget and tools.However this is at best a bland re-skin of the Civ games, lacking innovation and left me feeling flat. It's not without merits, the tech web was a great idea and I hope to see it return. I can't recommend the game either buy one of the standard civ games which feel more cohesively designed or if you want the science fiction angle search out a copy of Alpha Centuri in my eyes it's still the superior game.

												I really like this version of Civ. It's really different and while it isn't QUITE as feature rich as Civ VI I really like the sci-fi feel and the completely different victories. If you like sci-fi and wish Civ had a sci-fi themed game, this is literally it.*SIDE NOTE* - I got Starships because you can use it with this game and after hating my initial playthrough I replayed it recently after winning a game in Beyond Earth and using it as the starting point makes it like a continuation of the same story and it has much more battle oriented system which was actually a great change of pace and made me really like it. content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
												THis is by far the disappointing Civ game I have played and I have played them all (most heavily - 2, SMAC, 4 & 5). The biggest problems with the game relate to the AI and late game troop movement (1 unit per tile breaks down given the scale of the map and the number of units used in the late game. The AI doesn't understand hw to achieve victory as it doesn't place enough importance on affinities. As maxing an affinity is the key to victory the AI struggles even on the harder difficulties. On top of this the world building is poor, characters are non-existent, no cut scenes of any kind (for constructing building, units or wonders), generally forgettable wonders (both their fluff and crunch) and a extremely poor interface for organising trade routes (the single most important thing after affinities).This game might be ok in MP, but I don't play civ games like that as I don't have the time. If you enjoy Civ for the single player I would recommend Civ 4, SMAC or Endless LEgend over this. It really is poorly put together.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 27, 2014
												EDIT: Removed a line, restructured a few sentences.This was a learning experience, but not a pleasant one.People have gone so far as to call this a reskin, Civ V in space with nothing substantial added and many key elements removed. They're closer to the truth than I would like to admit.When the game was initially shown off, it looked like Civilization V running a beautiful, polished mod. When the first screens were posted, they showed off a game that was essentially the same as the game before it, down to the damage summation screen. This unspoken (but obvious) similarity continued to shine through with each new revelation.So, really, the question is 'why am I so disappointed playing a game that is exactly what it looked like it was going to be?' The fault in this case may live as much with those of us who had this suspicion and bought anyway as with the developer who knew we'd do just that, but however you place the blame there were choices made in the development of this game that simply must be addressed.Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth shows a clear and unmistakable LACK OF EFFORT. Not only are many systems simply cut-and-pasted over from Civilization V, but even much of the diplomatic and interfacial dialogue is word-for-word the same. Any of the additional personality you would hope for to compensate for a lack of leaders to play is not only missing, it's actually reduced from what Civ V offers. But really, that's not the part I feel is most damaging. No, that's a combination of THE PRICE and, still worse, THE INEVITABILITY OF PAID DLC that will address the obvious oversights made at launch. It feels almost as if this game was stripped of features and released in this state with the intent of giving fans something they would have to keep supporting through DLC to get the experience they thought they had already paid for.I do not recommend this game in this state or at this price, I let my adoration for the former title and the company behind this cloud the evidence offered during the game's development. Patching alone is not going to be enough to fix this game's shallow presentation, and unless the developers commit to MEANINGFULLY improving the experience of this game through a free expansion, I doubt those of us who are currently unsatisfied will feel anything other than exploited by a company we trusted to give us more than they did.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												CIV 5 dumbed down even further. This is what happens when the lead developers favorite civ game is the casual-friendly Civ: Revolutions. I'm not kidding. That's the lead developers favorite and inspiration for this game...and it shows.All the design choices come from Civ: Revolutions, limited amount of cities, limited amount of units (1 of each basic type), minimal player feedback, minimal complex decision making, minimal everything.  I fully expect them to port this game to the Ipad within 6 months since you can tell it was designed with that idea in mind.In addition to being an even more simplistic version of civ than civ 5, which was already pushing its luck with longtime fans. This game also feels unfinished. If you spy on a faction and get caught, nothing happens. They don't confront you or tell you to stop. I stole energy, research, and techs from the same faction over the same game. Got caught repeatedly and they never said a word. Did your city just build something, good luck knowing what it was since the game doesn't tell you. Because why bother tracking how a city is progressing since a casual might have to pay attention over just mashing buttons? Build a wonder? Get a pop-up even MORE minimalist than Civ 5's art box pop-ups. All of your futuristic buildings, no explanations of what they do or any story telling elements like in Alpha Centauri, because casuals can't be bothered to read flavor text I guess. The aliens are very passive, as is the AI overall. Got declared war on once in my first game and am steamrolling it on my first playthrough on hard difficulty.The bottom line is they've managed to dumb civ down to the point were it feels like i'm playing an ipad casual-oriented "Strategy" game on my PC, and that sucks, especially coming from firaxis. Avoid this turd. Get endless legend for a similar experience with more imagination. Time to go play CK2 again...

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												This is not the game to replace Alpha Centauri, which part of me knew before playing. Still, I hoped that maybe this would be a good enough game that I'd get lost playing for hours and hours and hours. A game that I'd download special patches just so it'll continue to work on the new operating systems like I do with Alpha Centauri. Is it? Well, to be honest, I do like it better than the Civilization games. Maybe it's just the setting, because the main mechanics are the same. It's fun to feel like you're exploring a alien world and trying to discover its secrets while staying alive. That aside... it's a game I'll play for a few weeks than move on. Maybe, when I'm craving a turn base stradegy came I'll come back to it.The nation leaders don't particularly have strong personalities. Interactions with them are annoying. I wasn't a fan of having to have an agreement before I could do some trades. Or how favors really didn't add up to much. Or how you lost all your favors with a faction if they decided to go to war. I also don't like how I couldn't talk a leader down from condemning or going to war with me with diplomacy. I just have to sit there and say "oh. Okay". Non-stackable units is the most obnixious feature ever. I don't care if it's to make things realistic. I don't like it.The aliens... are dispointing? They're really strong at first and can easily cause issues by killing your colonists, workers, or units you're exploring with. Typically they just sit around, shift around between squares, or linger on your terriority so your workers can't do anything  with that spot. Their behavior doesn't change over time, like it did subtly in Alpha Centauri. They just continue the same boring behavior.The tech web isn't bad, but what's annoying is it doesn't scroll. You're like "I want to look at the ones over here on the right!" and you move your mouse that way. Instead of moving, it just sits there. You have to click on the mini  box to change your view. That's just lazy programming. Can't customize units. My biggest issue with Civ games vs. Alpha Centauri was the removal of all the little things like that.If you enjoy Civ games and like the idea of an alien world, this can be a fun game. If you were wanting something more than just another Civ game, you'll be disappointed.This is just another game to pass time with. You probably won't bother playing it at all in a couple of years once a new civ game comes out.

content:
Posted: August 18, 2015
												Being a clone of Civilization V is not necessarily a bad thing - Civ V was a lot of fun after all. But Civilization: Beyond Earth is not at all adventurous in trying to offer anything on top of what was already made for Civ V. This is like a glorified mod, with the new features being quite insignificant compared with the overwhelming sameness of the core gameplay. It's still Civilization, and Civiliation has that addictive quality that keeps you coming back, so on that alone it can be recommended. But unless you really like the idea of playing Civ V on an alien world, there's nothing you'll get out of this game that you wouldn't get from just playing Civ V instead.

												As a lover of all things Civ this game is a glorified sci fi mod and if you've played it for ten minutes you've seen pretty much everything the game has to offer. It's not even CIV V.... IN SPACEEEE!!!!!!!! because they've cut more then they've retextured. Unit's have two options for promotion for example. Heal, or +10% strength. That's it... ever. number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2015
												Difference between CIV 5 and this. This has a very new technology tree (since now we are in space) which I think was a little harder to adapt to but it was aight. The way units are upgraded are different than it was previously.Instead of finding a new technology then paying gold to upgrade existing units you need to accumulate one of your affinities which you can acquire from researching technologies (purity, supremacy, the other one) and you select upgrades for soldiers when you accumulate enough and all your soldiers get upgraded automatically.About a third of resources that existed in CIV 5 still exist here, but there are also a few new ones like geothermal.I feel like the map is about the same as that of CIV 5 just with weird textures to try to make it feel space like, so that's a downside I kind of expected more.Overall its worth a try but I dunno I think CIV 5 and the old system is better. It's a change though.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 4, 2015
												If you are a fan of Sid Meier's games, you will enjoy Beyond Earth.  The spirit of Alpha Centauri is channeled into a Civ V feel, but there are enough differences to distinguish this from Civ V.  If you enjoy turn-based strategy games and want to colonize an alien world inhabited by alien flora and fauna, this is a good game for you.  However, I think additional expansions will be necessary to realize the full potential of this game.  The webwork tech progression provides for a variety of strategies, but unit type and progression are more restricted than Civ V.  This makes sense if one understands the influence of Alpha Centauri, but Beyond Earth lacks the unit customization its predecessor enjoyed.  Although because each faction 'evolves' as you advance, some unit customization occurs, but Beyond Earth compensates with interesting city developments which offer orbital capabilities, for example.  Sound interesting?  I recommend it.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												Disclaimer: My very large 388 hours was mainly me leaving my PC running after getting bored and wandering off to read books or whatever. I've actually "played" the game for a fraction of that time.I have always loved the Civ's, which is why it's very difficult to vote this one down.With a £25 price tag on top of the base game, it's difficult to justify this purely because of it's complete lack of replayability.The good:New factions. This is mainly just because it's something different to try out. I used to play a lot of the SMAC and alternative history faction mods so this was right up my alley.New biomes. The unique world quests were a nice touch, and the biome-specific alien behaviours were exciting to sink my teeth in to. It really changes how you play each game and that lends to replayability.The bad:The diplomacy system, even with the recent patch, was a sad failure at correcting the initial system. It's better, but it didn't quite "get there". Yes, there more buttons to press, more things to do... but it's still just as irrelevant as the old system was. Simply put: you work to please your neighboring AI, raising respect and fear... and they declare war anyway? Might aswell go full military build from turn 1.The dev's have done difficulty... wrong. In my view, handicaps != difficulty level. Difficulty level, for civ should equate to smarter, more agressive, less compromising AI. The AI shouldn't simply have "better stuff" than you. Yes, people have said that they've beaten this game on top difficulty. No, they didn't say it was fun. Just look at SC2's AI for a good example. The AI there executes unit build orders and issues battlefield commands to ultra tight timing and precision, but crucially, never actually cheats. It's more fun and rewarding, win or lose, to compete on a level playing field against a better opponent. It's never fun to beat an opponent with inbuilt advantages over you - all this shows is that the game is too easy to exploit/AI is dumb.No diplomatic victory conditions. Remember Alpha Centauri, with the UN victory? Bribing players for votes? If you wanted to win diplomatically, you had to play a really cleaver game of plate-balancing to keep all the AI's on your side, while not upsetting any of their rivals too much, and it was really fun. In Rising Tide, there is little reward for keeping the AI happy, since it's far far easier (and safer) to build up a strong military and just crush them.The ugly:Hybrid affinities. They just aren't very useful. Sure, they look cool, but strategicially they don't seem to have any personality of their own despite what the dev's claim. I think that the hybrid affinities should instead have been "more" affinities, with more strategic resources to support them.Ocean cities. It's fun at first, but after the initial buzz you begin to realise that sea cities are just... strategically weak, and boring, all at once. It's too hard to expand your territory to get at the resources you need, and there are no defensive terrain features to exploit (mountains, etc...). My game with the NSA was me in the middle of the sea all by myself (save the occasional AI unit wandering by) with almost zero interaction with the other AI's who were all land based. Forever alone.Conclusion:It appears that the dev's do not place any value in good AI for this game, and I feel that this was a grave mistake. With a bit of personality - faction agendas, personal feuds, political backstabbing, secret alliances, taboo strategies (where are the atrocities?) - the game could be a vibrant breeding ground for creative play, and I would be coming back to it again and again. Sadly however, it's effectively a selection of small, shiny-looking and well marketed mods created for a quick cash-in on the fans for little return.4/10. Probably won't village again.

												I find this game to be a great addition to the Sid Meier's collection of Strategic Turn-Based Games. However, my expectations for this game were a bit higher and I hoped that we would experience a game that took the level of colonization and expansion to a more multi-dimensional level, where the game would be started on a planet but eventually grow to create a system of planets and colonies all economically dependent on the player. Overall it has been a very rewarding game and a great way to spend my Friday nights.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 6, 2015
												It's a good game that deserves better than the rating it has. Too many people are complaining that its just a mod of Civ 5, or that its not as good as Civ 5. In truth, it is very similar to Civ 5, but in my book, that's a good thing. Civ 5 was a great game. What's different than Civ 5? The few most interesting things:1. Game setup is different. You have several choices as to what to bring to the new world, meaning that even two games with the same faction can be played differently.2. The aliens are significantly different from barbarians. They are always there, but not always hostile, and can often be lived with peacefully. Plus, there are giant alien super-units that are very hard to kill.3. Spying is enabled in the base game.4. There's alien gunk called Miasma in a lot of the world that can injure your troops. Similar to what was in Alpha Centauri.5. Affinities. These are almost like religions in other civ games, except that they are not mutually exclusive. You can level up all three affinities simultaneously if you want. Affinities offer unique units and victory conditions.6. There are only a few unit types, but they are upgraded by research into affinities. This actually makes the game easier to manage in my opinion. I like it.7. There are quests, which are kind of like optional mini-objectives that give you a reward if you complete them. It makes the game more interesting by giving you goals to work towards.So the question remains, is this as good as Civ 5? In all honesty, probably not. But that doesn't mean it isn't great in its own right. I have played through 6 or 7 games now, and I am still enjoying it. If you liked Civ 5, and want a new setting, then I definitely recommend you give this one a shot. I give it two thumbs up.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												Extremely dissappointed with this game, a great idea was completey ruined. I'm glad I got it while on sale...not worth the price at all. This level (or lack therof) of quality and innovation of this game is unacceptable for this day and age, and for carrying on a series this far. Firaxis was plain lazy. I find none of the bad elements of Civ are ever remedied in the next sequel.   I have played it twice through and have no desire to play again.Why?  Because:-Just like other civs, game becomes slow, boring grinding turn passing after a certain time, re-confirming a bunch of trade routes every few turns (unless you are doing a global conquest)-Technologies are new but a completely unintuative in their organization and have no real sense of direction, other than to pick the ones needed to fullfil the type of victory aiming for.-AI is idiotic, and as unrealistically backstabbing as usual-Diplomacy has nothing new at all compared to CIV 5, just different leaders and voices (leader 'catch phrases' are lame too) .. 'favours' are new, but almost useless, there is almost no point to communicating with the other nations.-Far less resources to trade compared to other civs-"Happiness" from civ5 has been replaced with "Health" and decreases for the exact same reasons (number of cities, number of specialists, population) which doesn't really make sense and is annoying to try to constantly keep above zero for most of the game.-Landscape is new and pretty is some ways, but I find it overly busy colour wise.- End of game is BORING - STOP making uncreative end-game sequences with absolutely no substance - a screen and a voice saying you won with a small blurb. No score, cinematic, nothing. No one likes an anti-climactic game ending.-"Quests" (which aren't quests by definition, just a 2 option decision) add little to the game. -Units are fairly dull, no weapons of mass destruction like nukes in other Civ games-miasma is annoying-games are relatively short and small maps compared to other civsPositives-espionage is a little more interesting-option to kill or adopt local alien creatures in different, as is the path and objectives to reach your victory goal-satellites and space layer good idea but not developed enough-pre-game bonus choices a good addition

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 15, 2015
												I played this game for the Free Weekend, least to say it was a so-so experience.I like the angle of the game delving into the future, and while the civpedia can be a little bland to look at, the information within is quite interesting.Drawing more upon the word bland. It is admittedly artistic wise for non-in game features very bland indeed, everything is painted with a shade of grey. Same for the long-term gameplay, the first hour is very gripping of this game as you grapple with the mechanics and marvel at the strange aliens and eat up all the information the game throws at you.Ok, so i make some solid progress in my first game, even though i played on super easy difficulty for begginers, it was a learning experience drawing upon my CIV 5 knowledge (minimum needed to play this game well) I start up a fresh new game on a different map and it just 'feels' the same, even on ramped up difficulty it feels the same.Unless im totally missing something, the main jumps on difficulty settings do not matter as it merely changes few factors such as how soon Civ's arrive (in game context you are first to land, and the earlier you get there, the more time you have to set up by game rules) and how sassy and rude franko-iberia (the 'cultural civ') is to you.To stop myself dragging too far on, a summary.- User interface is unpolished and unclear - Unable to clearly see the orbital view unless it is pointed out to me or trade routes from UI, same for saying i have no idea where my trade routes go or what slots are open unless i activate it on the map modes which are drum roll please... "hidden in the map with a small cursor"- Civ's are not as imaginative as thier names, have broad abilities to each that you forget about in game unless you look them up or actively seek to use them.- Too many bottleneck technologies such as ecology (for removing misama fart gas), and some parts of the tech tree are messy in terms of progress- Very passive AI for both aliens and other civs if you don't raise a gun at all they leave you alone (my first attempt was actually harmony alignment - (Learn more about it in the game) and i didn't need to kill a single alien, plus i harboured a nest so that they'd go away elsewhere and attack other people whilst i ate all the xenomass resources - win - win)- Quests are too frequent and powerful with effects that literally buff everything in sight making the game too easy.Unfortunately it feels more like a very well polished mod for CIV 5, rather than a civ game of its own, and unless i am simply too MLG with my strategies to play the game as intended, other than for one or two incidents ill never feel the true wrath of the godlike siegeworm as it takes away everything precious from me.Still, i would recommend this game since they are hosting a new expansion soon which will hopefully add more meat onto the bones and make it less convouluted. For the meantime the free weekend is still up so grab it while you can and see for yourself.

content:
Posted: February 26
												Civilization Beyond Earth has a lot in common with Civilization V in its gameplay, and some might say that it would just be a clone / DLC of Civilization V and nothing more. I strongly disagree, as this game plays entirely different than any Civilization; the technology tree cannot be remotely compared and involves a strategy of appropriately choosing the correct technologies to acquire the needed amount of points in your desired affinity, these choices also profoundly modifying your development to the point where, you guessed it, you start playing differently than Civilization V (because the number 1 mistake is to play it like you would play Civ V, and not only will you not fair well, but you will also obviously have that feeling of deja-vu).Speaking of affinities, this is where most of my appeal in the game comes from; it genuinely dives into possible future paths for humanity, especially on the themes of transhumanism, extropianism or simply traditional humanism.What else, soundtracks are not as great as in Civ V but I am a personal fan of some sound effects, espcially the ones for the quests.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 25, 2016
												With the "Rising Tide" expansion, this is an improvement over Civ V.  The ultimate test, yes it does have that "one more turn feeling"1. The Science Fiction setting, with the ability to start on several various types of alien worlds, from the earth like "Lush" to the very un-earth like "fungal." Each offering different types of challenges and curiosities to explore. 2. The affinity system. You improve your civilizations military not just by unlocking new technologies, but by upgrading your platforms along the lines of your affinity. This gives your units a completely different look and feel, plus different bonuses and abilitites as they develop from other players who develop a different affinity. Whereas in Civ V, every civ had very generic units, with a unique thrown in here and there. Also the use of certain technologies requires a baseline affinity level, and diplomatic relations are affected. 3. The alien fauna. Adds to the feel of exploring an alien world. They are unpredictable, but you can either attempt to tame, coexist, and ultimately use them to your advantage, or attempt to wipe them out. 4. Terraform the planet to make it into a new Earth, OR change humanity to live in harmony with the world. 5. Strategic resources matter more. Strange in Civ 5 how oil is important for early modern units, but suddenly all you need is aluminium?  6. The orbital layer. Neat. Includes fun toys such as orbital laser beams to turn the tide in war, and even global teleporters.  The game could use some improvements in the following areas:1. The AI, of course. I did find the game challenging and fun at the "Soyuz" level, with alien fauna cranked up to "frenzied," where the AI would finally credibly threaten you, and aliens would make life difficult for all. Very easy before that. The AI should aggresively pursue an affinity and be more willing to attack the player with sufficient units to do serious damage. AI does not seem to aggresively pursue a victory however. 2. Would like to see the orbital layer fleshed out more. Sattelites have more options to defend themselves from strikes, and sattelites to kill other sattlelites. Maybe add a space crusier that flies through the orbital layer, bombards and carries fighters toward the end game. Maybe space fighters too instead of just ground support or air to air attack air units. 3. Would like to see more "super weapons." Nukes are missing. Controlling the orbital layer to prevent nukes would be key here. Fortifications and something like the "citadel" in civ V would be nice. Maybe let players build rail guns on the map to bombard at range.  4. Would also like to see players be able to damage cities and population with air strikes, assaults, and bombardment to reflect the brutality of war.  It takes too long to raze larger cities. You should also be able to damage tile improvements at range with artillery or air power.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												I had been looking forward to this game since it's anouncement, I preordered the game as soon as it was available... and now I wish I hadn't, if I could I would get a refund.   Other reviews list it as mediocre, all I can say is that they are the lucky ones, the ones who are even able to play the game!Quality Control appears to have either been out to lunch or non-existant, we're not talking about trades that don't make sense or crashes to desktop that happen when x,z.y are aligned but things such as:Being unable to set your resolution, the game only offering you a handfull of resolutions because it reads the wrong information from the video card, not even offering 1080p (1920x1080) Being unable to even launch the game? Intro Movie Check!, Loading Screen? Oh oh, though I'm not affected by this one a large number of people on the forums are.Being unable even to start again!, Pick your factions, pick your world, soon as the map appears? Crashes, 100% of the time.Try the demo to see if it even works for you though there is no guarantee that the full game would, would advise anyone to not even concider buying until we can be assured it will actually work.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												If you like turn based games, you are going to like Civ: Beyond Earth. It has the best and most fun elements of Age of Empires and Risk and that in a neat looking futuristic theme. There are a lot of diferent and complex, yet coherent mechanics which are explained very well in the early game. For instance, you have the questing system, which explains you how you should play the game but at the same moment it is an important mechanic that you'll keep on using as the game progresses. You can play against the AI with advanced diplomatic options (at first I thought that I was playing against real humans, so there's that :P), but it is even more fun when playing against your friends.I dare you, play a hundred turns and try to not get addicted. I bet you can't :D

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												Managed 24hrs in the free weekend, some of my thoughts on the limited time I had with vanilla Beyond Earth:The AI is pretty awful . I performed a coup d'etat mission with one of my spies (after another AI spent about 15 turns bombing the capital but not bothering to take over it), the AI leader wasn't even mad I took the capital, no denouncing or declaring war, in fact further on in the game the leader was friendly towards me. They didn't even attempt taking back their own capital.The content is fairly lacking and the leaders are incredibly generic. I understand the reasoning for not wanting 'Gandhi in space', but at least have some backstory. I really couldn't tell you the difference between any of the leaders aside from their physical appearance. This is a large problem for me because one of the things I loved about Civ V was the personality of the leaders. In Beyond Earth, they are all the same, and they are dull.The orbital layer is a welcome new addition to the franchise, unfortunately I found most of the units either boring or useless to me. The only one I really used was the ability to create new strategic resources on unworked tiles.The Affinities is an interesting idea with Purity, Harmony and Supremacy. I'm not sure however that I liked they were tied to the Tech Web. I maybe would have liked to pre-select an Affinity or use them like Virtues and amass and spend Affinity points during the game.  I probably need to spend more time in the game to have a solid impression on that.Some of the units, especially Harmony's, are really good. Unfortunately the upgrade system is very uninspired and boring with only 2 options available.I think a certain youtuber said it best when he said that the game was, "Bound by it's theme", I think that perfectly sums up vanilla Beyond Earth. I love the theme, but their is just a stark lack of content. I think the inevitable future expansions will fix a large amount of these problems, but vanilla Beyond Earth isn't worth buying, and therefore I cannot recommend it for now.

												Honestly, I prefer Civ V. While BE included a few new elements, they removed about as much as they added and most of the things added seemed trivial or down-right bad. I feel that the things  that were added just didn't make up for the things that were lost. Here is a list of things that were added and taken away:Added:-Tech web instead of a line, useful-Senerios where you can choose new benefits for things, not very useful but not horrible-Factions with special benefits, didn't like-Cool alien things instead of barbarians-A storyline of sorts for victories (just a diary entry or something)Removed:-Religon and tourism-Dumbed down city-states-Lots fewer civs and maps to choose from- Less difficulties to play on-No great peopleAlso, I liked the journey through history sort of thing from Civ 5 better. The graphics are great and gameplay was okay but when it comes down to it,  Civ 5 is much better.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
												I have played through several times now. I've got mixed feelings.Nice is automatic upgrades of units rather than having to spend money to upgrade them(which meant I often had very antique units in my Civ games guarding cities). Nice is the sci-fi elements (no more General Ghandi to worry about). Nice are some of the units, although it takes too long in game to get really sci-fi'ish units unless you're playing harmony. Mostly, tanks, troops, jets. Overall, I found the game a bit tedious. Too many turns seem to go by with nothing really happening. This is a risk with turn based 4x games, but so far this seems particularly grindy.Aliens are underdone, more an annoyance and easily eliminated as a factor early in the game. They get to be mobile scenery very quickly once you get purity level 1 and the fence with only the Manticores being a bother. Explorers quickly come to ignore aliens and this lets you move and build your colonies in alien infested areas as you can stack the two. They aren't even "real" aliens, they are more like alien wildlife. The Siege Worms are currently the most underwhelming part. Something is bugged with the bugs' aggressiveness. That said, given the number that seem able to spawn early in the game when there's still a lot of fog of war, under aggressive is probably better than overaggresive Not stacking units seemed ok given ranged units are more common. But, every map I've place has LOTS of blocking terrain (mountains and canyons). Late game, canyons become less an issue as floaters and large walkers become available.  However, before they are available, choke points become more of a factor. There is no mountain crossing unit I've found yet and aircraft seem to frequently have too little range to reach enemy cities. There is a teleporter sattellite but that leads to the next problem:Orbital units can be expected to not last 1 turn once your cold wars go hot. they will IMMEDIATELY be shot down by the enemy. I have yet to see an option that allows them to survive the first anti-orbital strike. Orbital lasers, teleporters, etc, are best put out of range of cities, which is a strategy and sometimes gets you around the terrain problems. However, orbital units cannot overlap coverage, making it difficult to place more than one at a time. They also have limited duration before they deorbit, making maintenance of your orbital network a manual process. It makes a new feature an also-ran. You have to use them, but the best orbitals are solar collectors(virtually mandatory to keep your energy levels high in the mid game and even into the late game) and  miasma removers(early on before workers get the option or you get far enough on the harmony track to ignore it).  The "offensive" orbitals end up being either defensive or single use bombs. That would be ok, but you can't even build an orbital in a city if you have one "on the launch pad". Also, there seems to be no list I can find that lists WHERE unlaunched orbitals are waiting, which can be annoying if you don't write it down or forget.The "you win" or "you lose" screens are just horrible. A bit of text and a back ground image. It doesn't even scroll and I have yet to find a game summary screen of any sort. Just "you win".  The "contact" victory text and "you lose" in particular are horrid.  I lost one game simply because I forgot to pay attention to the AI's progress on victory, but the text telling me I lost told me nothing, so I don't even know what conditions it won on or which AI player won. Ultimately, this is a spiritual successor to Alpha Centari, but there are a lot of issues that bog it down. I'm giving it a "not recommended" because there's no "mixed feelings" selection. While I'm not the kind that demands every game have a huge story, the lack of  background info and meaningful end game text is very disappointing.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												As many others have already mentioned, Beyond Earth basically just feels and looks like a Civilization V mod. That by itself might not have been such a big deal if Beyond Earth was as fleshed out as its predecessor.As of this review it has not been 2 weeks since the game was released and we have not even seen a patch to fix high priority issues with the game (for instance the fact that anyone with a 120hz or higher monitor cannot select 1080p or higher resolutions, I use a 1440p 144hz screen and the only way I can get the game to allow me to use anything higher than 720p or so is to run it in windowed mode, which is hardly acceptable).I persevered and played through an entire match and frankly I never really felt as engaged as I do with Civilization V matches. That one match was enough for me to learn the following about the game:Beyond Earth has virtually no personality at all.The leaders have phrases literally copy-pasted from Civilization V.There's even less reason to interact with the AI than there is in Civilization V trade-wise.The Aliens are only really threatening during the early-game before you pick up any points in an affinity.The Tech Web is downright painful to look at, and it's difficult to tell where wonders are in the web. There is at least one mod I know of that improves this but since mods also disable achievements..Tooltips are missing in certain areas - for instance nowhere does it mention that buildings that give health work much like the ones in Civ V (where a building that gives 5 happiness will only give 2 happiness in a city with 2 population).If Beyond Earth didn't feel like a cheap Civilization V mod I might have been able to forgive most of this, but there's no excuse for the game to be missing so many details when the codebase is so similar. I'm just glad I didn't buy Beyond Earth on Steam where it would have cost me $90 AUD (Though for the $50 it did cost me I'm still very disappointed).That's another thing. A while ago this game was a lot cheaper on Steam for Australian customers, and then out of nowhere 2K raised the price to its current $90 without so much as an explanation. I had to hunt down a copy on an external site just to get a reasonable price.All in all, given all the issues with the game, the bare-bones nature of the game compared to Civilization V, the current price and the lack of any fixes or any real communication from Firaxis or 2K in 2 weeks, I'd STRONGLY advise anyone that was considering buying Civilization: Beyond Earth to wait until either the next major Steam sale or until the first expansion is released. It seems that Firaxis chose to ignore the lessons they should have learned from Civilization V's launch.I do not normally bother to give games negative reviews (or reviews at all, for that matter), so this should impress on you just how disappointed I am with Civilization: Beyond Earth in its current state.

Not till I pick it up for a dollar on Steam Sale.  If then.  And only if it is spectacular.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2016
												This game is beautiful, and it has an atmosphere that I've never really felt before. It really does feel like a Civilization game set on some planet out in the cosmos. The artwork is gorgeous, the aliens are a fun change from barbarians, and the gameplay really does feel like a struggle to survive a new environment.However, everything great about this game is balanced out by everything wrong with this game. It just feels like the game engine and system are very poorly optimized. Frame rates vary wildly, and textures don't cache leading to texture loading errors. The game crashes often, some quests are bugged, dialogue boxes are bugged, and you never get the sense of security to enjoy the game.Every time I play this, I have a wonderful time that is marred by the constant worry of game crashes, bugged out missions, or game freeze inducing dialogue boxes.Despite the fact these bugs are well reported, no major bug fixing patch has been made, instead the focus was on creating new DLC. Any time a company focuses on DLC instead of fixing the product for their existing customers gets an automatic downvote from me.This morning the game crashed so hard it led to a BSOD, needless to say I'll be uninstalling this game until it's fixed.

content:
Posted: November 15, 2015
												At first glance I loved this expansion but sadly, it is still not even close to Civ V. It's missing key components that break the game for any strategy but a war based empire.1. Warscore broken: You can pound a nation into the dirt for several turns, but without a land unit near their city to threaten taking it, they will never surrender. This means naval nations built on trade are rendered useless. Wars will start you can never finish.2. Diplomacy: While there are some neat improvements since the original, the new system lacks key components.... such as defensive alliances. Ally with a small power and they will use your power to declare war on a big guy. Not a broken issue, makes sense, but the lack of options for pacts and agreements make the diplomacy system not even half what earlier Civ games were.Do NOT recommend this game. Wait till they come out with more expansions to fix the broken issues, then wait till it's on sale in a gold bundle so you aren't ripped off for each individual release.Sorry Sid Meiers, you've lost a fan.EDIT: SInce the expansion, massive improvements to diplomacy. Not sure if I like what is done, but definately less broken. Warscore still an issue...

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												Extremely dissappointed with this game, a great idea was completey ruined. I'm glad I got it while on sale...not worth the price at all. This level (or lack therof) of quality and innovation of this game is unacceptable for this day and age, and for carrying on a series this far. Firaxis was plain lazy. I find none of the bad elements of Civ are ever remedied in the next sequel.   I have played it twice through and have no desire to play again.Why?  Because:-Just like other civs, game becomes slow, boring grinding turn passing after a certain time, re-confirming a bunch of trade routes every few turns (unless you are doing a global conquest)-Technologies are new but a completely unintuative in their organization and have no real sense of direction, other than to pick the ones needed to fullfil the type of victory aiming for.-AI is idiotic, and as unrealistically backstabbing as usual-Diplomacy has nothing new at all compared to CIV 5, just different leaders and voices (leader 'catch phrases' are lame too) .. 'favours' are new, but almost useless, there is almost no point to communicating with the other nations.-Far less resources to trade compared to other civs-"Happiness" from civ5 has been replaced with "Health" and decreases for the exact same reasons (number of cities, number of specialists, population) which doesn't really make sense and is annoying to try to constantly keep above zero for most of the game.-Landscape is new and pretty is some ways, but I find it overly busy colour wise.- End of game is BORING - STOP making uncreative end-game sequences with absolutely no substance - a screen and a voice saying you won with a small blurb. No score, cinematic, nothing. No one likes an anti-climactic game ending.-"Quests" (which aren't quests by definition, just a 2 option decision) add little to the game. -Units are fairly dull, no weapons of mass destruction like nukes in other Civ games-miasma is annoying-games are relatively short and small maps compared to other civsPositives-espionage is a little more interesting-option to kill or adopt local alien creatures in different, as is the path and objectives to reach your victory goal-satellites and space layer good idea but not developed enough-pre-game bonus choices a good addition
